HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rise in Slow Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose again and interest rates dipped further in sluggish trading yesterday. Prices were pushed higher by rumors late in the session that a weekly report on initial unemployment claims would rise to a record high.
The weekly claims numbers, which are released on Thursdays by the Labor Department, are considered a good indicator of employment trends. 
 The rumors were about the only highlight in an otherwise lackluster session.
 
'Holding Together Quite Well'
 "Things might seem dull, but considering the move we have had over the last week or so the market is holding together quite well," one government bond trader said.
Another trader said: "The market is vulnerable to bad news, particularly if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf. But if we don't get that sort of news, we will probably keep going."
The rally in the Government securities market and the sharp drop in interest rates proved beneficial to New York City, which yesterday sold a record $1.17 billion worth of taxable and tax-exempt securities.
Investment bankers involved in the deal said the securities, which carried a maximum tax-exempt yield of 8.55 percent on bonds maturing from 2011 to 2017, were well received by institutional and retail investors.
"The issue got a lot of support," said Kenneth J. McAlley, a senior vice president at the United States Trust Company. "The city has to be encouraged."
A major reason the auction was well received was that the risk associated with New York City issues has meant that yields on those securities are about a full percentage point higher than on other comparably rated securities. Although the higher yield attracts investors, it also translates into higher costs for the city.
 
Long Bond Gains 6/32
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the late rumors on the unemployment claims helped to push the price of the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 to 107 26/32 late yesterday, up 6/32, to yield 8.05 percent, compared with 8.06 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 1/8 in late trading, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.80 percent. And the price of the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes rose by 2/32, to 100 10/32, to yield 7.19 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell slightly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.77 percent, down 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell 5 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 6.65 percent. Rates on one-year bills fell by a similar amount, to a late-offered rate of 6.57 percent.
Although many market participants remain optimistic that bond yields can fall further, some money managers are now saying that the bulk of the move may be over.
"We think we are nearing the low end of the range for long-term bond yields," said Marshall B. Front, an executive vice president at Stein, Roe & Farnham, a Chicago-based firm with close to $10 billion in fixed-income investments. "Bond yields could fall another 25 basis points or so, but that is about it."
Mr. Front is much more optimistic about short-term rates and is advising clients to buy intermediate-term issues rather than bonds now.
"If clients have significant cash positions, I would advise them to move into the three-year-to-five-year area," he said. "With the economy doing poorly and the Fed responding to that weakness, I would not be surprised to see another full percentage point drop in short rates over the next six months."
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 to 1/4 point.
New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market cooled yesterday after a torrid few days. Despite the huge increase in new supply, prices in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds rose by about 1/8 point, dealers reported.

HEADLINE: Hard Times? Not for These Stores

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12

 BODY:
They conduct a no-frills business in cavernous warehouses on the outskirts of towns, shun advertising and limit access to those with memberships. But by offering a wide variety of goods at wholesale prices, membership warehouse clubs have quietly and firmly positioned themselves as a rare bright spot in the nation's dim retailing environment.
Moreover, in an economy certain to encourage even more bargain hunting by consumers and businesses alike, the huge stores that carry everything from mayonnaise to mattresses are expected to outperform mainstream retailers by a wide margin in the next several years. 
 Even analysts who are pessimistic generally about retailers' fortunes use words like "mindboggling" and "barn burner" to describe the $22 billion industry's sales growth prospects.
"I can't think of another retail format that has the possibility of a 20 to 25 percent growth rate for the next four to five years," said Sarah Stack, an analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles.
With names like the Price Club and Sam's Club, the warehouses act primarily as wholesalers, selling food, office supplies and other necessities to businesses at prices typically 8 percent above cost from the manufacturer. Business owners can also buy goods for their private use. In addition many individuals can buy annual memberships at $25 to $30. Membership is most often extended to those who are health-care and government workers or in other employee groups with stable incomes.
It seems odd that any store selling basic goods would limit the number of people who can shop, even in such a broad way. But industry executives say that to maintain their wholesale selling approach they try to insure that 60 to 65 percent of their customers are business owners.
And by limiting consumer memberships the clubs have created a successful balance of businesses that buy frequently and in large quantities and a steady stream of individuals who are likely to visit often. Membership also makes customers feel they are getting a good deal not available to everyone.
On weekends, people jam the aisles prowling for huge jars of peanut butter, 12-packs of English muffins, telephone answering machines, tires and dictionaries.
"The business customers are very important for us," said James D. Sinegal, president of the Costco Wholesale Corporation, based in Kirkland, Wash. "That's why we're as restrictive as we are. We don't want to drive those customers away."
Competition started heating up in the mid-1980's and now four companies account for about 85 percent of industry sales. The companies and their estimated 1990 sales are: Wal-Mart, which operates Sam's ($6.5 billion); the Price Company, which operates the Price Club, ($5.6 billion); Costco, which operates the Costco Wholesale Club ($4.3 billion), and the K Mart Corporation, which operates the Pace Membership Warehouse ($2.6 billion).
There are about 400 warehouses in the United States and Canada, according to Salomon Brothers, and expansion of the stores should continue at a rate of 10 percent to 15 percent annually through 1995.
 
Imitators Moving In
 Success is inspiring imitators who have set up smaller specialty warehouse-type companies that focus on specific categories. Some, for example, are offering wholesale prices on office supplies or auto parts.
Jack D. Seibald, an analyst with Salomon Brothers in New York, estimates that the warehouse club industry, which had sales of $17.8 billion last year, will grow 24 percent this year, to $22.1 billion. Within five years, Mr. Seibald estimates, the industry could top $50 billion in sales.
Profits, which are derived from both product sales and the $25 to $30 annual membership fees charged to businesses and individuals, should also climb as the industry, which is only 14 years old, grows.
Daniel D. Barry, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the growing attraction of the membership club concept was simple to understand. "It's a wholesale business serving the business person with prices that are cheaper than anywhere else, particularly cheaper than distributors charge," he said.
The analysts said their expectations for the clubs remained high even if the nation fell into any but the worst recession. About 60 to 65 percent of club members are small-business owners who, regardless of economic conditions, must stock their vending machines with candy and cigarettes, buy paper for fax machines and replace old cash registers.
"In an economic slowdown some small businesses, which in the past opted to have products delivered to their door, may decide to pick up the same products at a lower price at a membership warehouse," Bo Cheadle, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, wrote in a report on the industry.
The industry received a strong vote of confidence in November when Sam's agreed to acquire the Wholesale Club Inc., a smaller competitor based in Indianapolis, for $178 million. Sam's was already the largest chain in the industry, with 147 stores in 28 states.
On the same day, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, parent of the A.& P. supermarket chain, said it would enter the business by buying control of Warehouse Club Inc. of Chicago.
Among the smaller companies is Waban Inc. of Natick, Mass., which runs BJ's Wholesale Club, with estimated 1990 sales of $1.2 billion. But analysts expect several companies to be squeezed out or to merge with one of the big four, which have the strongest financing and can expand faster.
 
'Enormous Potential'
 Mr. Seibald of Salomon Brothers said the two deals were indicative of the "enormous potential" in the warehouse format.
But Robert Price, the chairman of the San Diego-based Price Club, whose father, Sol, invented the concept in 1976, is less sanguine.
"We supply to hotels and offices and restaurants, and to the extent there is any kind of slowdown in the economy that will ripple back," to his company, he said.
In some areas, like Los Angeles and Maple Shade, N.J., near Philadelphia, several warehouse companies already compete. But in many areas of the country there is room for growth. All the large chains have plans to build new warehouses, which often become hits from opening day. When Sam's built a warehouse in Fargo, N.D., recently, it immediately sold close to 5,000 business memberships.
 
Efficiency Stressed
 The membership clubs' success depends a great deal on efficiency, because of their slim markups of 8 to 10 percent, compared with 40 percent at many discount stores and 65 percent and more at higher-priced department stores. The warehouses must cut costs wherever possible.
That is why the stores are placed in industrial sites, where real estate is cheaper, and why they seldom pay for advertising, relying instead on word-of-mouth to find members.
The hangar-sized buildings typically consist of 100,000 to 130,000 square feet, compared with 70,000 square feet for the average K Mart. The floors are concrete and sales help is practically nonexistent. Merchandise remains on the pallets on which it arrived from manufacturers.
 
5-Gallon Jars of Mayonnaise
 To keep the warehouses running efficiently and to promote quick sellouts, operators typically stock only about 3,500 products, compared with more than 25,000 in the typical supermarket. That means only one or a few brands of each product are carried, usually in one large size, like five-gallon jars of mayonnaise and packages of five dozen eggs. The bigger sizes are a better deal for those who need or can use them, like restaurant operators.
But even minding the shop closely yields slim profits. In fact, at BJ's Wholesale Club the average 8 percent markup is too thin to make a profit, said T. J. Matheny, vice president of marketing. The company earns its money on the $25 membership fees.
The same is true at Wal-Mart's Sam's units. Stores like Sam's can sign up 5,000 to 10,000 businesses and 25,000 individual consumers as members, said Brenda Lockhart, a Sam's spokeswoman. At an average $25 yearly membership fee, that adds up to $750,000 to $1 million in annual profits per warehouse.
The Price Club, which earned $125.4 million on sales of $5.4 billion in the fiscal year 1990, and usually posts a pretax margin of 3.5 to 4 percent, is generally given credit for being the operator with the highest profit margins.
Analysts point to Costco, which earned $49.2 million on sales of $4.1 billion in 1990, as the fastest-growing chain and the one doing the most creative merchandising. Costco is given credit for introducing fresh fish, fruit and vegetables.
Now other chains even have special offers like cars for sale at fleet prices. and one recently had a grand piano prominently displayed -- and for sale.

HEADLINE: TREASURY HELPING NEW ENGLAND BANK WITH BIG DEPOSITS

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has been quietly shoring up the troubled Bank of New England, placing more than $1 billion of public money in the Boston bank after billions were withdrawn by depositors who were worried about the institution's rising losses from bad loans.
The Treasury Department routinely deposits in commercial banks Federal funds from personal and corporate taxes as well as operating cash. Hundreds of financial institutions act as Federal depositories through these "tax and loan accounts," which the Treasury says are "blindly" placed. 
 But the Bank of New England case appears to be the first instance in which the Comptroller of the Currency, the arm of the Treasury that regulates most large banks, has approved using funds in these accounts to help a bank improve its cash position.
 
Critics Talk of Risk
 The case has raised questions among legislators and financial experts about the safety of the procedures of the Government for investing public money and about its role in aiding troubled financial institutions.
These critics say the action is risky. Because the Federal money is uninsured, the Government could be exposed to losses if the bank failed. A senior Treasury official said all loans to depositories were safe because they were protected by adequate collateral, which could be liquidated in the event of a failure. But some experts have questioned the Treasury's methods for valuing collateral. The methods are subject to little outside oversight and are less conservative than those used by the private credit markets and by a number of state treasuries.
"Treasury should behave as prudently as any other investor, and if it takes on increased risk by investing in a problem bank, then its investment should be more openly disclosed and debated," said James Barth, a professor of finance at Auburn University and one author of a forthcoming House Banking Committee study of the Federal bank insurance fund.
 
Lender of Last Resort
 Mr. Barth is among those who wonder whether the Treasury Department is superseding the Federal Reserve's traditional role as the lender of last resort to banks.
Also at issue is whether Treasury funds should be used to prop up a troubled bank. R. Dan Brumbaugh, another author of the Congressional study, said the Treasury arrangement with Bank of New England was inappropriate and "no different in kind than what Federal savings and loan regulators did to feed the failures in the 1980's."
Mr. Brumbaugh says that by putting money in problem banks, the Government may be giving uninsured depositors time to remove their money, raising the eventual cost to the Government if the banks fail, as happened in the savings bailout.
The Treasury's activities take on increased significance because of strains in the banking system and the shaky condition of the bank insurance fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The fund, which insures bank accounts up to $100,000, is at the lowest level in its 56-year history, and, some experts say, it could become insolvent if there is a deep recession or if a few large institutions collapse.
 
Troubled Real Estate Loans
 The Bank of New England, whose parent company was the 30th-largest banking company in the nation in March, is perhaps the nation's most troubled large bank. Its bad loans, especially from commercial real estate, were the main reason the bank's parent company, which has $13 billion in assets, lost more than $1 billion in 1989. Its stock, which early in 1989 was trading around $20, closed today at $1 a share, unchanged for the day, on the New York Stock Exchange.
On Feb. 26 of this year the Bank of New England reached an agreement with the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency to reformulate a plan for keeping the bank liquid.
Arthur H. Meehan Jr., the executive vice president and treasurer of the bank, said in an interview that the liquidity plan included use of the Treasury tax and loan account, though selling some of the bank's loans was a more important source of financing.
Over the last year the Treasury has more than tripled the amount of money it has placed in the Bank of New England. The bank's most recent quarterly report lists $975 million in Treasury deposits, up from $296 million at the comparable time in 1989, documents show.
In mid-April of this year, bank officials and regulators say, the Treasury deposited $1.8 billion in the bank. Though the Treasury drew down its deposits during the next two months, they grew again to almost $1 billion by the end of September.
The plan to use Treasury accounts was part of a strategy "to maintain a sound liquidity position for the bank," said Dean DeBuck, a spokesman for the Comptroller's office.
At the time it reached an agreement with Federal regulators in late February, the bank had been borrowing from the Federal Reserve for more than 30 days. The Federal Reserve charges a premium interest rate to banks that borrow for more than 30 days. Since 1974, when the Fed's extended borrowing program was revised, no large bank that has borrowed from the Fed for more than 30 days has survived without Federal assistance, usually a subsidy from the F.D.I.C.
 
Posting Collateral
 Treasury officials say they are blind to where tax and loan accounts wind up. Any bank, no matter how weak or strong, can get these funds by posting the appropriate collateral at a Federal Reserve bank.
Some states have much stricter rules. Connecticut, for example, can invest public funds only in a bank that has a minimum capital ratio of 3 percent, or $3 in stockholders' money for every $100 in assets.
The Bank of New England currently has a 1.11 percent ratio, even though regulators, as part of their February agreement with the bank, required it to reach 3 percent by the end of May. A spokesman for the Comptroller said the office had not enforced its agreement because the bank was making progress in talks with its bondholders about raising capital.
Another concern among some experts is that Treasury regulations allow collateral like Treasury securities, municipal bonds and commercial loans to be valued based on their historical book value, or face value, with some discounts required for lower-grade collateral and some discretion for further discounts.
In the private sector, by contrast, "the most common basis for valuing collateral is marking to market with a discount based on the volatility and liquidity of the underlying collateral," said Robert J. Grossman, managing director of Fitch Investors Service, a credit rating service.
 
A Question of Value
 For example, in the private sector a $10 million real estate loan might be valued at $7 million if the property is hard to sell. But for a $1,000 deposit, the Treasury would accept as collateral a Treasury bond issued for $1,000, even though changes in general interest rates might have reduced the bond's current market value to less than $1,000.
 
An Official's Explanation
 Dan L. Sanford, a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston who administers the Treasury tax and loan accounts, said the "system has recognized that market value would be better" than the discount system used by the Fed, but it cannot change because its "book entry system is designed around Treasury's requirements to use par value."
A senior Treasury official defended the department's accounting method, saying it is the same as the one used by the Federal Reserve, but does not accept lower grades of collateral like real estate notes or consumer debts that the Federal Reserve accepts. If regulators saw a deterioration in the bank, they could require it to put up more collateral against Treasury funds, the official said.
Other troubled institutions have held tax and loan accounts from the Treasury, including, two years ago, the banks of the First Republic Bank Corporation of Texas, which were failing at the time.
It is unclear, however, whether Federal regulators have previously approved plans by banks other than the Bank of New England to use Treasury funds for liquidity.
 
Reducing Other Borrowing
 The infusions from Treasury enabled the Bank of New England to dramatically reduce its borrowings from the Federal Reserve. In early April, before the Treasury's deposit of $1.8 billion, the bank still owed the Federal Reserve $2.05 billion, according to bank filings.
By April 18, after the infusion of deposits into the Bank of New England's Treasury tax account, borrowings at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston dropped to $14 million, according to a Fed release.
By June 14 the Bank of New England had ended its borrowings from the Federal Reserve and the balance in its tax and loan account was below $100 million, Mr. Meehan said.
The bank's balance sheet for June 30 shows the Treasury's investment in the bank was $832 million. The balance had presumably increased because of tax payments due by June 15 that the Treasury disburses among its depositories.
"Substituting tax deposits for extended credit at the Fed gives the impression that banks are not as bad as they seem, " said James Grant, a financial expert and publisher of Grant's Interest Rate Observer.
Most New England banks secure the money in their tax accounts by delivering high-quality securities, like Treasury bills, to the Federal Reserve Bank in Boston, Mr. Sanford said. But the Bank of New England and a few other banks have placed commercial loans as collateral. Many of the bank's loans are in New England, where the economy has been troubled for some time.
Mr. Meehan said these commercial loans involve the bank's better customers and the Federal Reserve values them at 30 percent below their book value.
Federal Reserve and Treasury officials said there was enough additional collateral to protect the Treasury's account at the Bank of New England. They declined, however, to say exactly how much collateral secures the Treasury's investment.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DECISION;
BUSH, LIFTING 15-YEAR-OLD BAN, APPROVES LOANS FOR KREMLIN TO HELP EASE FOOD SHORTAGES

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
President Bush moved today to help the Soviet Union meet anticipated winter shortages by approving up to $1 billion in Federal loans to allow Moscow to buy food and other agricultural goods.
Lifting a 15-year-old ban on such credits, Mr. Bush also said he would propose that the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund give Moscow a "special association" that would provide assistance and advice in transforming the Soviet command economy into a market-driven system. [Transcript of Mr. Bush's remarks, page A22.] 
 Mr. Bush's action was considered by experts to be a first step toward the full membership in those institutions, which has long been denied to Moscow.
 
In White House Rose Garden
 The move will increase American farm exports, but is unlikely in the short term to lead to a big surge in two-way trade between the two countries, which will amount to about $3.6 billion worth of goods this year -- little more than what the United States exchanges with Haiti. [Page A22.]
Appearing in the White House Rose Garden with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on an unusually mild December afternoon, Mr. Bush announced that he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would meet in Moscow on Feb. 11-13 for their next get-together He said he hoped to sign a treaty limiting long-range strategic nuclear weapons during that meeting.
 
Summit After Iraq Deadline
 The summit meeting is to take place about a month after the Jan. 15 date by which Iraqi troops are supposed to leave Kuwait or face the possibility of military action. This raised the question of whether Mr. Bush would authorize an attack on Iraq in the period before the summit meeting or whether he would prefer to discuss the situation further with Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow.
In addition to the agricultural loans, which came in the form of a six-month waiver of the law barring export credits to Moscow until it permits free emigration, Mr. Bush announced that the Federal government would provide financial and organizational assistance to private organizations willing to supply emergency medical and pharmaceutical supplies to the Soviet Union.
Although the Administration believes that the food shortages in the Soviet Union are in large measure a distribution problem, not the result of crop failures, the United States hopes that emergency shipments will provide a short-term solution while patterns of distribution are corrected for the long term.
Mr. Bush's actions came in response to a request from the Soviet Government for financial assistance in acquiring agricultural and medical products. American officials said the Soviet Union was expected to use the agricultural loans primarily to buy grain.
Although Moscow has gold and diamonds to sell, it prefers to do so in small amounts to avoid driving down prices for those commodities, Administration officials said. Because of its chaotic transportation situation, the Soviet Union would also have difficulty delivering enough oil to foreign markets to raise emergency cash.
 
Praises Emigration Changes
 In explaining his actions, Mr. Bush said he wanted to "respond both to the short-term needs of the Soviet Union and to contribute to fundamental economic reform." He said he wanted to recognize the "excellent" progress Moscow has made in permitting emigration. This year, some 150,000 Soviet Jews have moved to Israel and 50,000 to the United States..
But it was also clear that Mr. Bush was hoping to bolster the Government of Mr. Gorbachev, which could be imperiled by severe winter shortages of food and medical supplies.
"The Soviet Union is facing tough times, difficult times," Mr. Bush said. "But I believe that this is a good reason to act now, in order to help the Soviet Union stay the course of democratization and to undertake market reforms."
Mr. Shevardnadze suggested that beyond seeing the floundering Soviet food system through the winter, the Soviet leadership saw Mr. Bush's actions today as a more sweeping boost to Mr. Gorbachev's political and economic policies.
"The fact is that there is certain instability in the Soviet Union and we are worried about that," he said. Mr. Shevardnadze added, "It would be a terrible thing if we were unable to assure the stability of the Soviet Union. It would be a terrible thing for Europe and for the world."
 
Some Restrictions Stay
 Mr. Bush's actions today, which won wide and immediate praise from many lawmakers, American Jewish groups and human rights advocates, did not entirely lift all the trading restrictions that have been in place since 1951, when normal trade relations with the Soviet Union were first curbed in the aftermath of Soviet backing for North Korea's invasion of South Korea.
But Mr. Bush used his power o grant a temporary waiver, until next June, of parts of the 1974 Jackson-Vanik law, which sought to restrict the resumption of normal trade until the Soviet Union permitted free emigration.
Specifically, he lifted the law's ban on loans issued under the auspices of the Commodities Credit Corporation, an arm of the Department of Agriculture, and authorized between $500 million and $1 billion in Federally guaranteed loans. Administration officials said money would be made available within 45 days after the Soviet Union asked for it.
The record on foreign countries' repayment of such loans, which are made with taxpayer dollars, is mixed.
But Mr. Bush did not move to lift the more sweeping and long-term restrictions on trade with Moscow that are now in effect.
 
Waiting for Policy Codification
 The President said he would continue to withhold from Congressional consideration the trade agreement that he and Mr. Gorbachev signed here last June -- and the favorable trade terms, known as most-favored nation status, that are associated with it -- until the Soviet Union enacts a new law that codifies its new emigration policies.
Mr. Shevardnadze said such a law would be passed "in the nearest future." But Soviet officials have been offering such assurances for more than a year and American officials said today that the draft emigration law has recently been amended in a way that could add significant restrictions.
Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze vehemently denied that the trade concessions were intended as a "payback" for Soviet cooperation in the Persian Gulf crisis.
His pique evident in his voice, Mr. Shevardnadze said: "There was no crisis in the Persian Gulf when our two Presidents met at Malta, and then there were other talks and discussions between them. And I am also referring to our ministerial meetings in Wyoming and at Irkutsk, where we spoke about cooperation and partnership."
 
'A Very New Phase'
 "All the other things, such as the Persian Gulf crisis and our cooperation on the Security Council resolutions, those were after those important events," he said.
Mr. Shevardnadze said Mr. Bush's announcements today "show that we are indeed in a very new phase of our relations."
In addition to opening the door for the Soviet Union to American and other Wesern financial markets, Mr. Bush's actions today tied his Government even more closely to that of Mr. Gorbachev at a time when the Soviet leadership is facing mounting political challenges.
A senior Administration official acknowledged that there was a risk that giving Mr. Gorbachev a major financial and political boost at this time could be seen in the Soviet Union as meddling in the country's delicate political balance.
But the official said the United States hoped to avoid that by stressing the importance of continuing Soviet economic reforms, as Mr. Bush did in his statement today. "There is no question that this is a delicate situation and that is why it has taken so long for us to come to the decision to announce these steps today," the official said.

HEADLINE: Hollywood Harmony: Labor Pact Till 1995

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12

 BODY:
In an action hailed as a major step toward improved labor relations in Hollywood, movie and television producers and writers today announced they had reached an agreement to extend through mid-1995 their existing contract, achieved only after a long, bitter and costly strike in 1988.
The extension of that contract, which was scheduled to expire on May 1, 1992, would prevent the 9,000 members of the Writers Guild of America from going on strike any time during the next four and a half years. In return, the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, representing some 200 production companies and film studios, has guaranteed a 4.5 percent annual increase in minimum fees paid for scripts and most television reruns. 
 "This is a very happy occasion that I never thought I would see in my lifetime," said George Kirgo, president of the Writers Guild of America West. "It means that for at least five years there will be peace for all of us."
Privately, representatives of both producers and writers said they were eager to avoid a repetition of the five-month strike of 1988. That labor action caused production delays or cancellations at film studios, led to a dramatic drop in ratings for television networks, resulted in layoffs for thousands of production employees and left many writers with significantly reduced incomes.
 
A Contract Adjustment Panel
 At a news conference here this morning, both sides said the key to the agreement was the creation of a new Contract Adjustment Committee. That group, which includes representatives of both producers and writers, will be empowered to negotiate changes in the existing contract, which then, like today's agreement, must be approved by the guild membership.
"There will be no ability of the guild to strike over these terms, and there will be no ability of the companies to lock out the writers," said Brian Walton, the chief negotiator for the writers' union. "Instead, both sides will have an incentive, we hope and believe, to work together for mutual advantage."
In theory, today's agreement could provide a model for similar agreements between producers and representatives of other Hollywood employees like directors and craft and technical workers. But J. Nicholas Counter, president of the producers alliance, cautioned that such progress "depends on the personality, structure and politics of each union."
By agreeing to extend the 1988 contract until 1995, the two groups have possibly defused tension over a number of issues that promised to be contentious in coming years. Among them are the determination of writer credits and increased payments of writer royalties or residuals for programs broadcast on cable television outlets.
 
Bright Prospects for All
 The movie business will take in more than $4.6 billion at the box office this year, a figure exceeded only in 1988, and industry analysts predict just as strong a performance over the next few years, along with burgeoning video and foreign revenues. In view of those bright prospects, neither side appears eager to put its share of an expanding pie in jeopardy.
In particular, the original 1992 expiration date of the current contract is potentially awkward, both sides have said privately. Later that year, the 12 nations of the European Economic Community, including such film and television production powerhouses as Britain, France and Italy, are scheduled to become a single market, and a strike in the United States, one production executive acknowledged, "could paralyze us and put us at a competitive disadvantage just as our business is becoming more global."
This morning, Mr. Walton said: "Both sides need to make this work. The need for change is obvious." He cited "new technologies, new ownerships of companies, the rise of cable, and increased international competition" as factors demanding a "nonconfrontational approach" between producers and writers.
Both groups must also contend with internal policy differences that could limit their effectiveness and maneuverability during a labor dispute. During the 1988 strike, an active dissident faction emerged in the Writers Guild, and in 1985 a strike effort collapsed after two weeks, in part because of a lack of unity, union members said.
For their part, producers too must confront potentially crippling divisions, most notably between television networks, which found themselves without sufficient programming in 1988, and studios. The networks, prohibited by law from having a full ownership stake in programs they broadcast, would also like to expand into production; if their campaign to change those rules succeeds, they would have even less reason to want to join forces with other producers they wish to supplant.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
And That's Why They Play All 82 Games

BYLINE: By SAM GOLDAPER

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, after one month of the National Basketball Association season, playing out the remainder of the schedule appeared to be just a formality for all the teams except Detroit and Portland.
The Pistons, in the midst of a 10-game winning streak, had a 13-3 record and the Trail Blazers, after winning their first 11 games, were 12-1. It seemed more practical just to let the Pistons and the Trail Blazers resume last season's championship series. 
 But things have changed, and maybe that's why the league has an 82-game regular-season schedule.
While the Trail Blazers have extended their record to 19-1, the Pistons have not only lost five of their last six games, but they have also scored 100 points in a game only once during that stretch. That came in their lone victory, against the lowly Sacramento Kings.
The Pistons' turnaround began with a road loss in which they scored only 83 points against the Washington Bullets, one of the N.B.A.'s least successful teams. The losing streak reached four straight with road losses to the Los Angeles Lakers, the Utah Jazz and the Golden State Warriors. After the victory in Sacramento, the Pistons, hoping to resume their dominant ways, returned to the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich., where they had won 77 of 90 games. Not only did they fail to score 100 points again, they also lost, 95-86, to the San Antonio Spurs. They have shot 45 percent from the field in the last six games.
Looking back to a year ago, the Pistons got off to a 13-10 start before winning 25 of their next 26 games, en route to their second straight championship.
That may be the reason why Chuck Daly, usually a worried coach, still sounds optimistic.
"We're kind of stuck in the mud right now," Daly said yesterday by telephone from Michigan. "We're in a mild recession, but I'm like the President of the United States: I'm not ready to admit we're in a basketball recession. I know this team. It's too good a team and I have to believe we're going to snap out of it. Like every team, it may need a little refining, some tuneup here and there or some small changes. We'll keep looking at it."
It doesn't get any easier. Starting tomorrow night, the Pistons' next three games are against the Boston Celtics, the Milwaukee Bucks and the Chicago Bulls, three of the Eastern Conference's top teams.
 
Thanks a Lot
 Talk about gratitude. After Jack McCloskey, the Pistons' general manager, presented David Greenwood with his championship ring in a pregame ceremony, Greenwood went out and played like a champion for the San Antonio Spurs. The 6-foot-9-inch forward, used sparingly by the Pistons last season, signed a one-year contract with a one-year option with the Spurs as an unrestricted free agent. Not only did he score 12 points and grab 5 rebounds against his former team, but he also donated $10,000 to Methodist Children's Hospital in Detroit, proceeds from the sale of T-shirts during last June's championship series. . . . With their 2-1 Texas trip, the Celtics, whose 16-4 mark is the second best in the league, increased their record over the Houston Rockets, the Spurs and the Dallas Mavericks to 65-11 since Larry Bird came to Boston for the 1979-80 season. . . . Since December 1962, the Celtics own a 17-1 record against the Pistons at the Boston Garden.
 
That's Entertainment
 The Denver Nuggets, who brought their record to 5-15 by beating the Washington Bullets on Tuesday night, are the only team in the N.B.A. that has scored at least 100 points and given up at least 100 in every game. The Nuggets are averaging 128.9 points and giving up 138.1. The sidelight to the Washington game was the battle for league scoring honors: Bernard King of the Bullets had 34 points and Orlando Woolridge, the league leader, had 33. . . . Michael Adams, the catalyst of the Nuggets' run-and-gun attack, has attempted 87 3-point baskets in the 11 games he has played, almost 8 a game. He has made 23. . . . Look for many changes in the days ahead. Any player still on a roster after Dec. 27 must be paid for the entire season. . . . The trade that brought Jeff Malone from the Bullets to the Utah Jazz is beginning to make a notable difference, as Coach Jerry Sloan had hoped. Tuesday night's 135-117 victory over the Golden State Warriors, the Jazz's fifth straight victory and their 10th in 11 games, was a Malone show. Jeff Malone, hitting from the outside, had 43 points, while Karl Malone, Mr. Inside, scored 35. Feeding them was John Stockton, who had 21 assists, 2 fewer than in his last game against the Los Angeles Clippers.
 
Ominous Assignment
 The last three coaches to take their teams to the McDonald's Open -- Jimmy Rodgers of the Celtics, Doug Moe of the Nuggets and Stu Jackson of the Knicks -- were let go after winning the N.B.A.'s overseas showcase tournament.
The league will announce soon that the Lakers will be its representative in the next open, which will be held in October in Paris. Is Mike Dunleavy looking for a new job yet?

HEADLINE: Formation of an Opposition Party Announced at a Rally in Albania

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Amid scenes of jubiliation, the formation of the first opposition party in Communist-ruled Albania was announced today at a huge rally in Tirana, the capital.
Called the Democratic Party, the new group has already applied at the Ministry of Justice to establish its legal status, one of its founding members, Gramoz Pashko, who is a prominent university economics professor, said in a telephone interview from Tirana. That ministry was recreated last summer after having been abolished 23 years earlier.
On Tuesday, after three days of anti-Government demonstrations by university students, the Communist Party central committee endorsed in an emergency session "the creation of independent political organizations."
 
No Multiparty Tradition
 Albania has been ruled uncontested by the Communist Party since 1946, and until Tuesday the party leadership had consistently declared that it would never permit opposition parties.
The small Balkan country of 3.3 million has no traditions of political parties or parliamentary government. During World War II opposing groups of nationalists, royalists and fascists tried to gain political footing, but were swept aside by the Communists.
Six weeks ago, Mr. Pashko, who is 35 years old, began describing himself to foreign visitors as "a dissident." He was at the time still a member of the Communist Party, as was his friend, Ismail Kadare, a prominent writer, who defected to France in October.
Joining the economist in announcing the founding of the Democratic Party at today's rally in the university's "Student City" were Azem Hajdari, 28, a philosophy student who played a leading role in organizing the student revolt, and Dr. Sali Berisha, 45, a Tirana cardiologist.
 
'Democracy! Democracy!'
 Mr. Pashko said about 80,000 people attended the rally - "workers, of course students, artists, lawyers, all kinds of people." Others at the scene estimated higher numbers. Tirana has a population of 300,000. The crowd chanted "Democracy! Democracy!" The economist said that although some students had been injured in clashes with special police forces on Sunday and Monday there had been no fatalities.
As yet the Democratic Party founders have chosen no leaders, Mr. Pashko said, and they have only begun to sketch out a party platform, which he said would include advocating a multiparty system, protection of human rights, a free market economy and good neighborly relations.
In a departure, however, Azem Hajdari, the student leader, said the Democratic Party would "work for the peaceful democratic union between Albania and Kosovo," the neighboring Yugoslav province of Serbia whose inhabitants are 90 percent ethnic Albanians. This call from Tirana could lead to friction with the Belgrade authorities.
Both Mr. Hajdfari and Mr. Pashko paid respects to Ramiz Alia, the Communist President and party chief, for introducing a reform program that paves the way for multiparty system. National elections are set for Feb. 10.
'

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 344 words

HEADLINE: Cavazos and Bush: A Shared Failure

 BODY:
The resignation of Lauro Cavazos as Secretary of Education comes as no great surprise. Virtually invisible during his two-year tenure, he has offered few initiatives and showed little flair for the arena. But his ineffectiveness says less about him than about his boss. How serious has President Bush really been about education?
Public education is in deep trouble. American students are leaving schools without adequate skills, threatening economic security and the social fabric. True, education is largely a state and local responsibility; but the Federal Government plays an important role, particularly in insuring equal education opportunity. It can also be an effective catalyst. 
 Mr. Bush pledged to be the "education President." Faced with huge budget deficits, however, he has offered more symbols than dollars. Fifteen months ago, when he summoned the nation's governors to an education "summit conference," he offered mainly bromides. And Mr. Cavazos was hardly in evidence.
The governors have since outlined a half-dozen laudable goals for the year 2000, including a high school graduation rate of at least 90 percent and prekindergarten programs for all children. The Administration took one big step, proposing an increase in Head Start financing. Congress went even further, passing legislation that could allow every eligible child to participate by 1994.
But there's so much more to be done. Schools need radical restructuring and a renewed commitment to equal opportunity for all students, including the poor. That will require not only money but also an aggressive effort to help school districts redesign their curriculums. Mr. Cavazos, however, has been a Johnny One-Note, fixated by the notion that giving parents more freedom to choose schools will solve many of the nation's education ills.
The official White House line is that Mr. Cavazos was dumped to make way for a more forceful Secretary who would help Mr. Bush buttress his claim to be the "education President." But isn't that also the President's job?


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Foreign Graduate Students Know Hardship

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The high percentage of foreign students in United States graduate schools (front page, Nov. 29) warrants questioning of the choices that American society and American students are willing to make to keep this country's industrial and technological edge. In contrast, the sacrifices that many foreign students make for a graduate education are beyond the experience of most Americans. 
 The foreign students who receive financial aid in return for labor performed do not pose a threat to American students. Your example of $20,000 a year in financial aid provided by the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at New York University, a private institution, is at the extremely high end of the scale. More typical is the state university that offers graduate assistantships of $7,000 to $8,000 a year. It is in these institutions where most foreign graduate students are found, many living in conditions of hardship and poverty.
In a recent visit to New Jersey Institute of Technology (where, as you report, 734 of 887 full-time graduate students are from Asia), I found that the lives of many Chinese students are not much better than their counterparts in mainland China. The students with research assistantships are managing to scrape by on $600 a month, but must spend so much time doing research for professors on whose good will they depend that they end up having to study until all hours of the morning to make the grades to stay in the program.
Students without assistantships are likely to have low-paying jobs working long hours, like a young Chinese woman I met, a Ph.D. candidate in engineering who works as an assistant cook to pay her way through school.
The objections of Americans to foreign faculty members and students are ill founded. To be fair, there is an exception to the hostility and xenophobia in American graduate business schools. Institutions like the Stern School of Business at New York University, where I am a part-time M.B.A. student, are building their reputations on having international business programs, foreign faculty members and foreign students.
With the future of American business inextricably linked to foreign economies and markets, students value learning different perspectives from professors and fellow students who have accents, whether they are Greek, Chinese, German or Indian.
If we do not retain these bright foreign scholars and scientists in the United States, and if we do not mend an education system turning out mediocre native talent from elementary school up, one day we will turn to foreign countries for their superior technology.
 
SUK-TAN CHIN
Brooklyn, Dec. 3, 1990

HEADLINE: Cuba Pioneering in Energy Conservation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In Cuba, Swapping Bulls for Tractors?" (Op-Ed, Nov. 19) by Roger Fontaine and William Ratliff argues that it is not too farfetched to assume that the key to easing the transition to a post-Fidel Castro regime is joint United States-Soviet support "for a democratic, free-market Cuba." 
 To someone who has spent some time in both the Soviet Union and Cuba in the last three months, this seems to be the height of wishful thinking. While it is true that past foreign aid to Cuba and all other third world countries is highly unpopular in the Soviet Union, as reflected in the pages of Komsomolskaya Pravda and other journals of the glasnost era, there was no countervailing Cuban anger at the Russians or President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the Soviet elimination of Cuba's oil subsidy. Rather, there were kind remarks concerning the past generosity of their former benefactors.
The Soviet underwriting of Cuban economic development permitted the Cubans to waste energy in many areas. The campaign to save energy has forced the planners to substitute animal power and bicycles for the gas guzzlers still operating as a result of the efforts of clever Cuban mechanics. Rather than "returning Cuba to its preindustrial past, a literal dark age," the ingenious Cuban decision makers are planning a society that will appeal to environmentalists and may be the wave of our own future in the 21st century if the global warmers are right.
The Cuban problems today and for the next several years are better handled through planning a la wartime economies than with the "democratic free market" solution now being experimented with in Eastern Europe. Rationing is more acceptable in Cuba than elsewhere because it has been institutionalized during the last 30 years. Only the number of products subject to rationing varies over time, and they will undoubtedly be increased over the next several years as Cuba adjusts to less reliance on Eastern European socialist countries and more friendly economic relations with other Latin American countries.
The Russians have made it clear that they are more interested in their own problems than in telling erstwhile members of the Soviet bloc how to handle their economies. If any of these countries comes up with solutions, Mr. Gorbachev is certainly ready to consider similar measures, but he apparently is not going to insist that these countries adopt any particular solution. Thus, it is likely that the Poles will revert to the interwar Poland of Marshal Josef Pilsudski, that the Czechoslovaks and Bulgarians will finally settle for social democracy, and the Cubans will continue their Latin version of "actually existing socialism."
 
LYNN TURGEON
Hempstead, L.I., Nov. 29, 1990
 
The writer is an emeritus professor of economics at Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: Don't Count Overtime For Pension Purposes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Recession -- It Took Time, But New York Yields to Laws of Gravity" (The Week in Review, Dec. 2): It is time New York City government ended costly and unjustified municipal excesses. 
 One persistent, glaring example is the policy and practice of permitting overtime pay to be calculated along with annual salary for pension purposes. This is particularly true for uniformed forces (police, fire, sanitation) whose employees often retire with annual pensions far in excess of annual salaries.
The effect of this overgenerous policy is to cost the taxpayers and the city millions of dollars in unnecessary, unjustified pension costs.
I suggest that Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council simply exempt overtime pay from calculation for pension purposes. The city should follow the example of New York State and the private sector, which do not permit the calculation of overtime pay for pension purposes on behalf of their employees.
In so doing, the city government would spare New York City taxpayers this imprudent and excessive cost. With the city in fiscal crisis, it is time to end this largess simply by the stroke of a pen.
 
ANTHONY M. PAPA
Brooklyn, Dec. 3, 1990
 
The writer is an assistant commissioner, New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

HEADLINE: Tough Choices For Connecticut As Boom Ends

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Perhaps Connecticut's political leaders thought that the boom years of the 1980's would last indefinitely. Certainly they based their budgets on that hope. And now that the boom is over, a budget deficit is emerging so large that this wealthy state is being forced toward a historic overhaul of its tax system and much less generous public spending.
Many states are struggling with budget deficits, but Connecticut's is so far the most overwhelming. The main reason is that the state's principal tax -- an 8 percent sales tax that is among the highest in the nation -- generated huge revenues when times were good. But when recession struck New England last year and people curbed their spending, the sales tax faltered almost overnight. And what was once a small budget deficit mushroomed. 
 "A confluence of things is coming together that is making the budget situation in Connecticut as nightmarish today as it was wonderful in the 1980's," said William A. McEachern, a University of Connecticut economist.
 
A Taboo Is Considered
 Suddenly the Governor-elect, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., is scrambling to reduce a deficit that is already nearly $500 million for this fiscal year and is projected to be $1.5 billion for the year that starts next July 1, if current spending is maintained. The $1.5 billion represents nearly 20 percent of the projected budget outlay of $7.9 billion -- a higher percentage than any other state has acknowledged, according to the National Association of State Budget Offices.
Because public support has not materialized for a cutback in major public spending programs, Mr. Weicker is being pushed to consider an income tax on wages. His predecessors, Ella T. Grasso and William A. O'Neill Jr., had sworn for nearly 20 years that they would never enact such a tax.
They relied instead on the sales tax for 40 percent of the state government's revenues, and on a corporate income tax -- the highest in the nation -- for 13 percent more. But the recession took the steam out of profits and consumer spending, and state budget outlays, as a result, have continued to rise sharply while revenues, for the first time, have shrunk.
"When you get shrinking sales and corporate tax revenues, as we've gotten recently, then the deficit numbers can go up very quickly," said Anthony V. Milano, Budget Director for Governor O'Neill, who leaves office in January. Connecticut has gone from a budget surplus in 1988 to today's deficits.
In all but nine other states, an income tax cushions the tax revenue swings that come when corporate profits and consumer spending fluctuate sharply. But unlike Connecticut, most of the nine other states without an income tax either have substitute revenue sources, like a tax on oil or gambling, or they rely on a sales tax but have not yet experienced the severe recession that has struck the Northeast.
"The general impression is that Connecticut is in the greatest trouble, but its difficulties may be a precursor of what's ahead for other states," said Marcia Howard, research director at the National Association of State Budget Offices.
 
Engines of Growth Slow to a Crawl
 The reversal in fortunes is taking place in a state that is home to some of the nation's wealthiest suburbs, like Greenwich, Darien and New Canaan, and some of America's poorest cities, among them Bridgeport, New Haven and the capital itself, Hartford. Much of the increased state spending in the 1980's was to pay for welfare, low-income housing, Medicaid and other services for the poor in the cities.
The 1980's boom that generated the tax revenue for this public spending showed up in Connecticut as a burst of construction and real-estate deals that brought new office towers, apartments, shopping malls and corporate headquarters to suburbs and cities, often altering skylines that had been dominated by huge, empty red-brick factories from an earlier industrial era. The state's big military and insurance industries also prospered.
But the big engines of growth were in construction, retailing, real estate and the tens of thousands of new jobs to staff the corporate offices that moved to Connecticut. Employment climbed to more than 1.6 million, and in the fall of 1988, the unemployment rate was only 2.7 percent, the nation's lowest.
"For a long time, cities like Hartford and New Haven had the lowest building vacancy rate in the nation," said Edward Deak, an econonomist at Fairfield University. "People said, 'Let's put up another building and we'll make a killing.' It was the same in housing."
Then real estate and new construction collapsed, vacancy rates shot up, and this was accompanied by a sharp downturn in banking and insurance. The military contractors still do well, increasing the value of their contracts over the last two years. But they, too, have laid off workers.
So have thousands of small manufacturers -- shops that employ fewer than 250 people -- among them metal-working operations, machine shops, manufacturers of electronics parts and others who have survived Connecticut's decline as a manufacturing state. Manufacturing employment is down 12 percent in five years and keeps falling, eliminating many higher-paying jobs.
The unemployment rate has climbed above 5 percent and total personal income, the highest in the nation on a per capita basis at $23,440, is rising this year by less than 3 percent -- after having risen through the 1980's at two or three times that pace annually.
"Rapid economic growth is a wonderful thing as long as it lasts; it's a nirvana," said Nicholas Perna, chief economist at Connecticut National Bank. "What it did was allow us to crank up public spending as if the rate of growth were endless."
 
A Reluctance To Trim Spending
 Despite flagging tax receipts, many states besides Connecticut have been reluctant to cut spending for such things as education, highways, new prisons, low-income housing, welfare and pay increases for state employees.
Complicating their problems, the states picked up new burdens as Federal subsidies were phased out. After adjusting for inflation, Mr. Milano's office estimates that Connecticut spends $300 million a year in outlays that once came from Washington.
The upshot has been rising deficits across the country, but Connecticut's biggest neighbors, New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts, still have deficits -- actual and projected -- that are less than 10 percent of budget outlays. Only North Carolina and Michigan are approaching Connecticut's level.
The big rise in spending here in the 1980's was partly to address what the General Assembly and Governor O'Neill judged to be crises. For instance, after the Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike in Greenwich collapsed in 1983, killing three people, the state undertook a $7 billion, 10-year upgrade of its highway system.
Because public schools were having trouble attracting and holding good teachers, the General Assembly in 1986 mandated higher salaries, financed mostly by the state. Now the average pay for a Connecticut teacher is $28,000 a year, the highest in the nation.
Pay increases not only for teachers, but for most of Connecticut's nearly 183,000 public employees, are ranging from 7 percent to 9 percent this year. To help pay those increases, state aid to municipalities has risen to nearly $1.4 billion from $783 million in 1985. The big pay increases are a result, in part, of binding arbitration awards.
Aside from the higher pay, rising Medicaid costs now account for 15 percent of Connecticut's total outlays. Nearly half of the $6.5 billion current budget goes for Medicaid, for the subsidies to Connecticut's 169 municipalities, and to pay more than $600 million in interest on state bonds that finance capital spending and, now, the deficit.
"These are the radical increases of the 1980's, especially the aid to the towns," said William J. Cibes Jr. (pronounced SEA-bess), a political science professor at Connecticut College whom Mr. Weicker recently named as his budget director. "Most of the town aid is for schools and to subsidize municipal budgets so local property taxes can be held down."
 
Deficit Fuels Income Tax Debate
 The O'Neill administration acknowledged the huge deficit a week after Mr. Weicker's election, and now that the numbers are out, a debate has begun over whether the state should adopt an income tax on wages. During a similar budget crisis in 1971, the General Assembly adopted such a tax at 4 A.M. one July morning, and Gov. Thomas J. Meskill signed the bill. The public outcry was so great that six weeks later the legislature repealed the tax.
The trauma left its mark on Mr. Meskill's successors, Mrs. Grasso and Mr. O'Neill. Both pledged not to propose an income tax, though during their terms they pushed up other taxes periodically, so that today the state sales tax, at 8 percent, the corporate tax at 13.8 percent and a maximum 14 percent tax on unearned income -- from dividends, interest and capital gains -- are higher than in any other state.
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who ran for governor as an independent, and Mr. Cibes, his budget director and a former Democratic representative in the General Assembly, have announced that they will try first to reduce spending. But Mr. Cibes argues that even with spending cuts, new tax revenue will be needed.
Mr. Weicker has not taken the pledge against a personal income tax. He declined to be interviewed for this article, but his press secretary, Avice A. Mehan, said, "He wants very much to keep his options open."
Until his appointment as Mr. Weicker's budget director, Mr. Cibes had advocated an income tax on wages. Right now, of the $82 billion in total personal income of Connecticut's 3.2 million people, only $15.8 billion is subject to taxes, as nonwage earnings.
"No one likes an income tax, but you have to look at the alternatives," said Ralph J. Caruso, director of the Legislature's Office of Fiscal Analysis. "If the alternatives are higher existing taxes or substantial reductions in services, then you have to see. I haven't seen a broad constituency that says we should substantially reduce services."
 
Property Tax Rise: Unpopular Option
 The other potential source of substantial new tax revenue would be an increase in the property taxes levied by municipalities. That alternative has helped convince some executives that an income tax is a lesser evil. "If you stood up in a room of businessmen and said that you favored an income tax, you would no longer be thrown out of the room," said Paul S. Goulekas, an assistant vice president at Aetna, the insurance giant headquartered here.
Opposition to property-tax increases has shown up in more than a dozen communities that in recent months have voted down municipal budgets requiring higher property taxes to offset cutbacks in state funding. Below the state level, the municipal property tax is the only major source of tax revenue in a state that does not collect highway tolls or other user fees.
Although property taxes raise a total of $3.9 billion a year in Connecticut, some experts argue that property owners are undertaxed. They note that the state's effective property tax rate -- the amount of tax actually paid as a percent of a property's market value -- is 1.46 percent, ranking Connecticut 12th in the nation, behind New Jersey (first) and New York (fifth).
The O'Neill administration "was committed to keeping property taxes as low as possible," Mr. Milano said. Mr. Weicker and Mr. Cibes have not made a similar commitment.
 
Until a Rebound, One-Time Remedies
 As the deficit developed over the last year, Governor O'Neill and the legislature resorted to patchwork remedies to keep it under control until the economy rebounded. "One-timers," their solutions were called, and they involved practices common in other states.
The administration, for example, drew down every penny of the $315 million in two surplus funds. Some $25 million in corporate taxes to be collected next July and August will be assigned to pay this year's bills. And $250 million in pension fund contributions were postponed until next year.
"We thought last December that we would have a $500 million deficit problem and the one-timers were considered sufficient to solve it," Mr. Cibes said. They hardly made a dent.
What's more, the spending in the 1991-1992 fiscal year is projected to rise by $1.4 billion from this year's levels, mostly because of the postponed pension fund payments, along with $615 million in higher Medicaid payments and aid to the towns and cities.
All this is a far cry from the mid-1980's, when annual surpluses prompted tax reductions.
"I voted to do this," Mr. Cibes said. "It appeared that with surpluses running at $300 million a year, people would say they were over-taxed. Now a lot of people would say that we made a mistake."

HEADLINE: Cavazos Quits as Education Chief Amid Pressure From White House

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Lauro F. Cavazos resigned under pressure as Secretary of Education today, even as his department and the Administration were plunged into a storm over a decision to bar Federal aid to colleges that offer scholarships designated solely for minority students.
Mr. Cavazos's resignation followed a White House meeting on Tuesday in which John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, told the Secretary that President Bush wanted him to leave the Cabinet by the end of the month, a White House aide said. Mr. Cavazos, 63 years old and the nation's first Hispanic Cabinet member, said he would leave by the end of this week. 
 The departure was announced today at a Cabinet meeting that Mr. Cavazos did not attend. He issued a terse resignation letter that omitted the customary thanks to the President for the honor of serving in the Cabinet.
Senior White House officials seemed as surprised as anyone else to hear of the new scholarship policy, disclosed Tuesday by an assistant education secretary, and were careful to note that Mr. Bush had not put his stamp of approval on it.
But they insisted that there was no connection between the policy and the forced resignation.
Some people close to Mr. Cavazos said he was upset by the scholarship policy and by the combative new posture of the Administration on affirmative action programs.
White House officials said Mr. Cavazos was being forced out because a more forceful presence was needed at the helm of the Education Department. They said that as the 1992 elections approached, they needed to buttress Mr. Bush's assertion that he was the "Education President."
Mr. Cavazos, who was president of Texas Tech University for eight years before he became President Ronald Reagan's Education Secretary in 1988, has long been considered by Mr. Bush's advisers to be a weak link in the Bush Cabinet. The President's domestic policy adviser, Roger Porter, has been the Administration's point man on education.
White House officials began looking for a successor, and said possible candidates included Thomas Kean, the former Governor of New Jersey who has been a leader in education reform efforts in the past six years, and Lamar Alexander, the former Tennessee Governor.
The statement that "race-exclusive" scholarships were discriminatory and therefore illegal was made by Michael L. Williams, the head of the civil rights office in the Education Department. Mr. Williams said today that he had not acted under instructions from the White House but had talked with lower level White House staff members who were friends and acquaintances.
 
Policy Change Surprises Bush
 Senior White House officials said the statement was being reviewed.
"The President was not aware of the strategy prior to its undertaking," John Herrick, a White House spokesman, said tonight. "Now that we are aware of it, the White House is reviewing it."
White House officials said they were looking into the decision to see if it was legal, if it was "easily reversible" and if it should be reversed.
Mr. Williams's announcement had a scalding effect in education and civil rights circles. Critics raised questions about its timing, following Mr. Bush's veto of a major civil rights bill and the bellicose comments of William J. Bennett, the former Education Department chief and Mr. Bush's new choice to head the Republican National Committee, that he was ready to challenge Democrats on the issue of racial quotas and affirmative action.
 
Accusations of 'Race Baiting'
 The American Council on Education, which represents over 1,600 higher education institutions, issued a statement advising its colleges and universities "to continue their current practices" on minority scholarships.
"It would represent a giant step backward in efforts to improve educational opportunities for the nation's minority students," said Robert H. Atwell, the President of the American Council on Education.
Ralph Neas, the executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, charged that "the Bush Administration seems determined to compile a worse civil rights record than the Reagan Administration."
Janell Byrd, the assistant counsel with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, declared the scholarship decision was "race baiting -- there is no other word for it."
 
Tapping White Resentment
 Critics of the scholarship policy said that as the nation entered a recession there was more of a tendency to look for a political scapegoat and lash out at programs designed to redress grievances against minorities.
Christopher Edley Jr., a law professor at Harvard University who was an adviser to Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 Presidential election, said the shift "comes at a time when many whites feel as though they have been made to sacrifice to create opportunities for others."
"They think they've paid enough, and the Bush people are aware of that feeling out there," he said.
Many Republicans are convinced that an anti-quota position has great appeal to large numbers of white voters, particularly economically pressed working class Americans who feel resentful about what they perceive as advantages for minorities.
 
A Dangerous Path
 Republican party strategists insisted today that they did not expect a general backlash from people who might consider the Administration action heavy handed. Any backlash that did develop, they said, would be largely concentrated among blacks and liberal whites, who do not support Mr. Bush in large percentages anyway.
Two political dangers face Mr. Bush, strategists from both parties say. The first is that he will undermine his efforts to reach out to minority voters. But more importantly, from an electoral point of view, there is a risk of antagonizing moderate, suburban Republicans for whom any hint of veiled racism is distasteful.
Robert Teeter, a top Bush strategist, said that the Administration's actions should not be seen as an ominous pattern by civil rights groups.
"Anybody who thinks George Bush is turning his back on civil rights is 100 percent wrong," he said.
 
Leaving Office by 5 P.M.
 Mr. Cavazos's resignation came before an investigation into his wife's role at the department, conducted by the Education Department's inspector general's office, was made public.
Peggy Ann Cavazos, a former nurse and the mother of their 10 children, came to the office daily with her husband and kept an office next to his for a period. She also sat in on meetings, edited speeches and policy papers and traveled with him.
Mr. Bush's advisers had worried that Mr. Cavazos, who liked to leave the office by 4:45 P.M., was turning into a political liability and undermining Mr. Bush's attempt to claim education as a strong suit.
Mr. Porter, the domestic policy adviser, had already sluiced away much of Mr. Cavazos's power, moving Charles Kolb, a deputy to Mr. Cavazos, onto his White House staff.
Mr. Cavazos is the third high-ranking Bush official to resign recently. Elizabeth H, Dole, the Labor Secretary and the only woman in the Bush Cabinet, resigned in October. Mr. Bennett also resigned last month as Mr. Bush's drug policy director but then accepted the post as the next chairman of the Republican National Committee.
In his letter of resignation, Mr. Cavazos said he was especially proud of his contributions "promoting the executive order on excellence in education for Hispanic Americans and raising awareness of the growing diversity of America's student population."
White House officials seemed taken aback by Mr. Cavazos's wounded attitude.
The officials said that possible replacements besides Mr. Kean and Mr. Alexander, included Lynn Martin and Patricia Saiki, the defeated Republican Senate candidates in Illinois and Hawaii, would also be thrown into the mix. David Kearns, a business executive, has also been mentioned as a prospect who would infuse education with the principles of the marketplace.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lauro F. Cavazos, who resigned as Education Secretary. (The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

HEADLINE: MIXED-INCOME HOUSING IN NEW JERSEY;
Big Hoboken Project Back on Track

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J.

 BODY:
Four years after it was announced and then ran into a number of problems, an ambitious plan to construct more than 400 apartments here for families of varying incomes is back on track. But instead of building a single project on one site, as orginally conceived, the sponsor will deliver the housing in two developments on three parcels.
In January, 115 of the apartments will be ready for occupancy in Observer Park. The 12-story tower is rising on the corner of Bloomfield Street and Observer Highway in the southern half of this mile-square port city on the Hudson River, opposite Manhattan. It will be followed by Hudson Square North, a 12-story, 150-unit building under construction on Third Street, between Hudson and River Streets. Twenty percent of the units in both buildings will be set aside for low-income households, with Hoboken families getting preference. 
 The third project, called Hudson Square South and in the planning stage, will also contain 150 units. All three are being built by the Applied Companies, a local developer. The architect is Becher & Wolczynzki of East Hanover, N.J.
The projects are welcomed by Hoboken, where housing development, rapid until a few years ago, has slowed considerably. "They provide much-needed affordable housing and show that the city continues to hold appeal as a residential market," said Peggy E. Thomas, director of the Community Development Agency.
Ms. Thomas was referring to the rejection by voters this summer of the 3.2-million-square-foot project planned by the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for 32 acres of Hoboken's crumbling waterfront. It would have included offices, stores, a park and apartments.
The housing developments will also bring revenue to the financially pressed city. Ms. Thomas said that when they were completed, the first two projects -- financed through state, Federal, county and private funds -- would generate taxes of $676,502 a year.
Delivering the units, however, proved to be a formidable task. In 1986, Applied contracted with the city to transform a rundown site, made up of three major parcels along Observer Highway, into a mixed-income housing project. It was to contain 450 residences in five mid-rise and high-rise buildings, as well as a park.
But homeowners in the neighborhood opposed the project, saying its height and density would destroy the character of the area. They sued the city, contending that its redevelopment plan was arbitrary and capricious. Ultimately the lawsuit, which was redirected to the scaled-down Observer Prk project, was decided in favor of the developer.
A further problem was the finding of mercury and lead on the tract, rendering it too costly to develop, and the project was shelved. Only the site of the current Observer Park project was salvaged, said Joseph Barry, president of Applied, noting that it has been cleared of contaminants. He said the cleanup had cost $350,000.
In addition, the company's joint- venture partner at the time -- Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus -- pulled out of the project. Nonetheless, Mr. Barry said he had renegotiated with the Hoboken City Council to redevelop for housing the current Observer Park site as well as two vacant parcels on River Street.
Mr. Barry said he did so because he felt there was a strong need for such housing and that if priced correctly, the units could be easily rented. Applied paid the city $6.1 million for the three sites, which Mr. Barry described as prime because they are near PATH, train and bus depots.
New Jersey is still saddled with a large stock of new and existing for-sale housing. But the rental market is brisk because an increasing number of people, concerned about the nation's uncertain economy, are choosing to rent rather than buy.
"Right now, there is a stronger rental than selling market in Hoboken," said Alice Galmann, a partner in Singleton/Galmann Real Estate, a local realty company. Monthly rents in Hoboken range from $800 to $1,000 for one-bedroom apartments and from slightly more than $1,000 to $1,300 for two-bedroom apartments, with some as high as $1,800, she said.
Market-rate apartments at Observer Park will rent for $850 to $995 a month for a 625-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment, and for $1,400 to $1,600 a month for a 1,100-square-foot, three-bedroom unit. Mr. Barry said all but six units had been rented, most of them to people commuting to Manhattan.
At Hudson Square North, where the one- to three-bedroom units will be larger, rents are expected to be slightly higher. Mr. Barry said completion of that project is set for next October. The apartments reserved for families with low incomes in both buildings will rent for $220 to $320 a month.
Mr. Barry said the third project might be a luxury rental. But that decision, he added, hinges on the market and the availability of sewers. At present there is a state-imposed moratorium on sewer hookups until Hoboken expands its treatment plant. The two buildings under construction are exempt because they contain affordable units.
