HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
German Utility Agrees To Buy Vista Chemical

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Germany's largest electric utility, RWE A.G., agreed yesterday to pay $55 a share, or a total of $590 million, for the Vista Chemical Company in the latest takeover of an American chemical company by a foreign industrial giant.
Vista's shares more than doubled on the New York Stock Exchange, rising $28.75, to close at $53.75. Its volume of 2.1 million shares traded was the second highest of the day. 
 The agreement "was consummated on an entirely friendly basis," Vista's chairman and president, John D. Burns, said in a statement.
The German company's RWE-DEA A.G. division said it planned to start a tender offer for the Houston-based Vista by next Wednesday. RWE-DEA said the tender is expected to be completed by early 1991 and the merger wrapped up on July 1. It said the tender would be conditioned on receipt of at least two-thirds of Vista's shares.
RWE-DEA said that Vista could end the merger agreement if it received a better offer but that if Vista found another buyer, it would pay RWE-DEA $29 million.
RWE-DEA's bid was undoubtedly strengthened by the depressed state of the dollar, with the United States currency dropping this week to an all-time low of 1.4630 German marks.
The deal follows other acquisitions of United States chemical makers by foreign companies. In the late 1980's, Hoechst A.G. of Germany bought the New York-based Celanese Corporation for almost $3 billion in a deal that created the world's biggest chemical maker.
Germany's BASF A.G. also bought the Inmont Corporation, the nation's largest maker of printing and packaging inks, from the United Technologies Corporation in a $1 billion deal. Among other acquisitions, Imperial Chemical Industries of Britain bought Glidden's coating and resin business for about $600 million and last year, Elf Aquitaine, the French oil and chemical giant, bought the Pennwalt Corporation for $1.1 billion.
Vista is a leading producer of specialty chemicals used in cosmetics, automobile interior trim, printing inks, vinyl pipe and sidings.
Industry analysts say that an investment in Vista is a bet on the prices of polyvinyl chloride, a versatile plastic used mostly in the building and construction market. They estimate that a one-cent-a-pound change in the price of polyvinyl chloride has a 45-cent-a-share impact on Vista's bottom line.
The slowing United States economy, which is hurting the construction industry, is expected to dampen demand for polyvinyl chloride prices in the next couple of years.

HEADLINE: CONCORD JOURNAL;
On Hustings, Not a Hopeful in Sight

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 7

 BODY:
Sitting in her lace-curtained parlor, Mary Lou ise Hancock opened one of three "Presidential Primary" photo albums and smiled wistfully at her snapshots of Albert, Jesse, Michael and Gary.
"I haven't heard a word from anyone this year, not even Albert," said Ms. Hancock, a 70-year-old Democrat. Senator Al Gore used to be a regular visitor to Concord, along with Jesse Jackson, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Gary Hart. "I guess I'll just have to wait and see who sends a Christmas card." 
 In years past, New Hampshire has been besieged by hopefuls eager to make early inroads in the nation's first primary. But this year things are different.
No campaign office space has been reserved on Concord's Main Street. No post office boxes or telephone numbers ending in 1992 have been set aside. Ned Helms, chairman of the State Democratic Party, cannot find a speaker for the party's major fund-raising event in February. And Ms. Hancock, whose parlor meetings have become a rite of passage for Democratic contenders, has yet to hear a peep.
Across the political aisle, things are quiet too. "I haven't heard a thing, and I don't think anyone else has either," said Thomas Rath, an influential Republican.
The Presidential campaign, overshadowed by the Persian Gulf crisis and the recent midterm elections, is getting a late start here as well as other early stops on the trail. That may come as a relief to some, but in New Hampshire eyes are looking south for signs of 1992.
Much of the interest has to do with egotism and entertainment. Since 1952, when the state initiated direct voting for candidates in its Presidential primary, every President from Dwight D. Eisenhower to George Bush has begun the march to Washington with a winter victory in New Hampshire.
So voters in this largely Republican state expect to be courted. In the past, lesser-known candidates would have already begun that ritual.
Having lost his party's nomination in 1968, Senator George S. McGovern began visiting New Hampshire a year later. By June 1970, he had already hired a campaign staff and was busy shaking hands. (He finished second to Senator Edmund S. Muskie in the 1972 primary, but his surprising showing helped propel him to the Democratic nomination.)
Another early starter was Jimmy Carter, who arrived here more than two years before the 1976 primary. "I can remember seeing him on the Statehouse steps and thinking, 'What does he think he's doing?' " said Robert Ambrose, Deputy Secretary of State. In 1986 former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona informally began his Democratic Presidential campaign by climbing Mount Washington, the highest mountain in the Northeast.
"We love it," Mr. Rath said. "So I say: 'Come on up. We have bean suppers, Jell-O molds and chicken dinners galore.' "
But this year, local officials note that the primary will mean more than just a flood of attention. Despite its normally stable economy, New Hampshire has been hit by recession, like the rest of New England, and it could use some money.
The state now leads the nation in the rate of delinquent consumer loans (6.12 percent). In Concord, the unemployment rate has more than doubled since 1988 and now stands at 5.5 percent.
At the Eagle Court Restaurant, where David H. Souter often had lunch before he moved on to the Supreme Court, business has dropped by 25 percent since last year. Two waitresses, three waiters and a bartender have been laid off.
Patronage by candidates, their entourages and swarms of reporters and broadcast crews means a flood of revenue for the Eagle Court and other businesses. "These Presidential elections can be kind of a pain, but they are definitely good for business," said James Makris, who owns the restaurant with his brother, Gregory. "We would welcome any kind of help at this point."
A real estate broker, Claudia Boys of the Corrigan Company, said: "The activity is short-term, and not always easy on the space. But we will welcome the new tenants."
James Smith, Concord's City Manager, agreed. "Given the current economy," he said, "we'd look forward to seeing anyone."

HEADLINE: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
D.M.B.&B. Plans to Create An Agency Network in Asia

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
D'ARCY MASIUS BENTON & BOWLES is expected to announce today the creation of a broad network of agencies in Asia.
D.M.B.&B.'s move comes as an increasing number of international agencies are scrambling to establish strong networks in Asia. Many industry executives believe that parts of Asia are fast becoming among the leading areas for advertising growth and will rival Europe within the next few years. 
 "Southeast Asia has been relatively untapped compared to the United States and Europe," said John Ferries, the president of D.M.B.&B./ International. "But we're aggressively expanding there because of the area's remarkable growth in terms of a middle-class consumer market and the rapidly growing availabilty of television and other media."
Several international agencies, including McCann-Erickson, Ogilvy & Mather, J. Walter Thompson and Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, have a fairly strong presence in the region.
Carl Spielvogel, the chairman and chief executive of B.S.B., which has one of the largest agency networks in Asia, said the strongest emerging consumer markets were in Thailand, Korea, Malaysia and Taiwan. This year, B.S.B.'s Asia operatons have added about $150 million in billings. In 1989, the agency's Asian network had billings of about $750 million, or 27 percent of its billings outside the United States.
Many agencies are expanding their networks in Asia. Burt Manning, the chairman and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson, said the agency was quickly adding staff there. "Singapore is our hottest office," he said.
Mr. Manning said a primary reason for rising growth was that governments in the region were encouraging American companies to make investments in local economies.
And as clients increase their business in Asia, it is only logical that agencies would also push into the region as well. Mr. Ferries said many of D.M.B.&B.'s leading clients, like Procter & Gamble, were concentrating more heavily on business in Asia. "Our clients are making massive commitments of money and manpower in the region and so it's only natural that we would, too," he said.
In addition, Mr. Spielvogel said companies based in Asia were seeking American agencies to help them expand into other regions. "We're helping a lot of our clients there prepare to enter into the European marketplace," he said.
In expanding its Asian network, D.M.B.&B. has acquired substantial equity positions in agencies in Thailand, the Philippines and Malaysia, and has formed joint-venture partnerships in India and Pakistan.
The agency is also negotiating to set up offices in China and Taiwan. Mr. Ferries said the agency had decided to open an office in China because some of its clients were quietly beginning to do business there again.
D.M.B.&B. already has offices in Hong Kong, Singapore, Indonesia, South Korea and Japan. The agency has billings of about $100 million from is Asia operations.
At its offices in Singapore and Thailand, D.M.B.&B. has entered into an equity partnership with Tokyu Agency International, which is its partner in Japan. This is one of the few deals in which Japanese and American agencies have become equity partners in an agency outside their countries.
As advertising growth in the United States continues to slow, international agencies are increasingly looking for opportunities elsewhere. Mr. Ferries predicted that South America would be the next region for growth in the coming years. "We're seeing a lot of stability in terms of the governments and economies in South America," he said. "It will be the next frontier, but the boom is probably a few years off."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Hurt by Recession Fears, Silver Closes Just Over $4

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The price of silver traded below $4 an ounce yesterday, hitting its lowest level in 14 years as fears mounted that a recession would deeply cut industrial demand for the metal.
The metal recovered somewhat to close above $4, but still finished lower for the day. 
 "The problem with silver is that it's being hurt by changing expectations that the U.S. recession will be deeper and longer than what had been expected only two months ago," said Jeffrey Nichols of American Precious Metals Advisors, Florida-based investment consultants.
In trading yesterday, spot silver on the New York Commodity Exchange fell 5.6 cents, to $3.97 an ounce, the low for the day and its lowest point since Feb. 10, 1976, when silver closed at $3.93 an ounce. The contract regained some of that loss, however, to close off 2 cents at $4.006.
In other precious metals trading, gold for December delivery on the Comex rose $1.60, to $374.30 an ounce, in typically slow year-end dealings.
Analysts said silver was a metal with a double personality, being both a precious metal and an industrial metal, and the concern was that the recession would mean less silver demanded by industry.
"Silver inventories on the Comex are bulging, and they're just coming out of a record high in October of 265 million ounces," said Don Tierney of Fortune Commodities, traders on the Comex. Yesterday, Comex silver stocks stood at 259 million ounces.
Worldwide production of 530 million ounces of silver this year is also overshooting an estimated industrial demand of 486 million ounces, analysts said.
Silver's chronic oversupply was highlighted in a recent research study that said world stocks were equal to 2.35 years worth of industrial consumption.
But the big drag on prices right now is the prospect of a bad economic recession, the analysts said.
Silver's major uses, for photography and solder, stand to suffer from a recession. The photographic industry consumes about 45 percent of all silver mined in the world. Mexico and Peru, both heavily indebted nations, are major producers.
Analysts said silver had also lost its appeal as an investment asset.
"There's a large overhang of silver held by disgruntled investors who bought in the 1970's and 1980's and they're tired of holding the silver," one analyst said.
"Whenever prices go up a little, there are some investors who are keen to sell, afraid that it may be their last chance to make a profit," he added. "Others will sell in a declining market because they fear that silver will go down even further."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SCENE;
Controlling Oil's 2 Great Threats

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AT the reunion in Vienna this week of the 13 members of OPEC, with the Iraqi and Kuwaiti representatives sitting grimly next to each other as the alphabet dictated, agreement was reached to restore OPEC's pre-invasion production limit of 22.5 million barrels a day and to reaffirm the target price of about $21 a barrel once the Persian Gulf crisis is over. And while the meeting was going on, the price of oil fell to $25.35 a barrel, the lowest since Aug. 3, the day after the invasion began. Though it rose yesterday, to $26.42, that is still nearly $15 below the Oct. 10 peak of $41.15.
Does the market know something the rest of us do not -- that there will be no war? No one can be sure. Administration spokesmen stress the importance of destroying the power of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to dominate the oil market and destabilize the American and world economies. As President Bush put the case two weeks after the invasion: "Our jobs, our way of life, our own freedom and the freedom of friendly countries around the world would all suffer if control of the world's great oil reserves fell into the hands of Saddam Hussein."
Oil evidently remains a powerful cause of war, as it has been throughout modern history. "The fierce and sometimes violent quest for oil -- and for the riches and power it conveys -- will surely continue so long as oil holds a central place," says Daniel Yergin in his new book, "The Prize."
And Nicholas Georgescu-Roegen, Distinguished Professor of Economics Emeritus at Vanderbilt University, who was raised in Romania, writes: "I happened to live through three wars, all in my backyard." The basic cause of "every one of those wars," he says, "stemmed from the fact that at those times Romania had immense oil reserves which none of the belligerent powers wanted to letfall into the hands of its adversary."
The aggressions of Iraq against Iran, then Kuwait and its threat to Saudi Arabia, and the blocking action of other nations are just the latest episodes in what Professor Georgescu-Roegen calls "the indissoluble binding of grand politics with mineral resources."
But another problem has emerged to complicate the politics and economics of oil -- the threat to the environment and human life. This week's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna focused, for the first time, on plans under way in Western Europe for curbing the use of oil to help reduce pollution by 1992. Calling the issue "a serious challenge," a Saudi official said OPEC would direct its economists to study the environmental concerns of Western Europe and the effect they might have on the consumption of crude oil and refined products.
OPEC is naive to think the environmental "challenge" will come only from Western Europe. Eastern Europe, after decades of Communism, is even more polluted. Indeed, the threat of pollution from hydrocarbons is global, affecting rich and poor countries alike -- not excepting OPEC members.
Solutions to both poisonous mixtures -- oil andthe environment, and oil, money and power -- will depend on two key factors: new technology to reduce dependence on oil, and conservation. And there is no quick fix for either one.
Professor Georgescu-Roegen says that during the entire life of the human species, there have been only two viable technologies. The first he calls Prometheus I, based on the mastery of fire, the legendary gift of the Greek god Prometheus. Its fuel was wood.
But as consumption accelerated and the forests began to disappear in the latter part of the 17th century, there was a "crisis of wood," in his words. This crisis was solved by two mortals, Thomas Savery and Thomas Newcomen, who invented the heat engine; this was Prometheus II, based chiefly on coal, then oil.
"The problem now," says Professor Georgescu-Roegen, "is whether and when a Prometheus III will come to get us out of the present muddle." No one knows for sure. Meanwhile, the best strategy is to gain as much lead time as possible, and the way to do that is through conservation -- "a conservation compatible with an acceptable survival of all humanity, without ignoring the needed development of those nations that are now in economic and social distress."
Conservation, whether used to lessen dependency on oil from a highly troubled and explosive region or to combat the threat to the environment, cannot be the job of one nation or a few but must be the job of virtually all nations working together.
Yet a nation seeking to protect its own economy and security can still benefit greatly from conservation on its own. A dramatic example is Japan, completely dependent on imported oil, which after the oil shocks of the 1970's drastically cut its use of energy while maintaining the highest rate of economic growth in the world. Japan's per capita energy consumption is now just two-fifths that of the United States.
A combination of high energy taxes on consumers and strong financial incentives to industry to develop and use energy-efficient equipment made the difference.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fell 0.1% Last Month

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the Commerce Department said today, as consumers pinched spending at the start of the key Christmas selling season.
Much of the weakness was in automobiles, where consumers have been cautious about making large purchases. But even without the weak automobile sector, November sales rose an anemic two-tenths of 1 percent. 
 The monthly decline was the first drop since May, when sales also fell one-tenth of 1 percent, and it was notable because the holiday shopping season usually takes off in the last weeks of November.
"While the market was expecting a weaker number, this report is hardly good news," said Charles Lieberman, an economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
Economists, surveying the weak economy, had expected a six-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales, which cover goods and services ranging from furniture to autos to restaurant meals. But they found little solace in the fact that sales turned down only slightly after a revised two-tenths of 1 percent rise in October.
 
Shoppers Remain Cautious
 Several analysts say the report suggests that shoppers will continue to be cautious and that the holiday season will be grim for retailers.
The nation's auto makers reported a 22 percent jump in vehicle sales in early December, helped by rebates and deliveries to rental fleets. But the rise was deceptively large because sales a year ago were very weak. One automotive analyst said demand for cars and light trucks remained "very depressed." [Page D6.]
In the wake of the retail sales report, Mr. Lieberman said he expected the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates again after its policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee meets on Monday.
General merchandise store sales, which usually get a strong lift from Christmas shoppers, fell four-tenths of 1 percent from the October level.
The overall decline last month left retail sales at a seasonally adjusted $151.6 billion.
Auto dealer sales fell by 1.3 percent in November after a 1.4 percent increase in October. Large car makers, including the General Motors Corporation, have announced sharp production cutbacks because of falling sales.
Gasoline dealer sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month after rises of 2.6 percent in October and 5.6 percent in September, showing that the gasoline price rises are moderating.
 
Durable Goods Sales Drop 1.4%
 Sales of durable goods, items meant to last three or more years, fell 1.4 percent in November after increasing six-tenths of 1 percent in October. Sales of nondurable goods, such as food and disposable items, gained five-tenths of 1 percent in November after a flat October.
Sluggish spending by consumers, who buy about two-thirds of all the goods and services produced in the economy, was hardly a surprise. Worries have been rising steadily about unemployment and the possibility of war in the Middle East.
The Labor Department said last Friday that 267,000 jobs were lost in November and 178,000 were lost in October, removing most doubts that the economy was in recession.
A recession is usually defined as six months of shrinking economic output, a condition the United States has not experienced since 1981-82.
 
Clothing Sales Rise
 In other sectors, clothing store sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November after a three-tenths of 1 percent fall in October.
Food store sales gained five-tenths of 1 percent after a one-tenth of 1 percent decrease in October, while drugstore sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month after rising five-tenths of 1 percent in October.
Furniture store sales increased three-tenths of 1 percent in November after a five-tenths of 1 percent drop in October.

HEADLINE: Builders May Be Forced to Pay for Low-Cost Housing

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

 BODY:
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that municipalities may charge fees to developers to pay for affordable housing programs mandated by the state.
Seventy-five towns in New Jersey have adopted ordinances requiring such fees to help pay for housing programs satisfying the state court's series of Mount Laurel rulings, which require all municipalities to provide housing opportunities for low- and moderate-income families. 
 But lower courts blocked the fees, agreeing with developers who had argued that they were unauthorized taxes on a selectgroup of individuals.
The New Jersey court and courts in other states including California, Florida, Illinois and Wisconsin had previously upheld laws requiring builders to pay the cost of improvements to roads, sewers and water systems required by their commercial or housing developments.
But to protect developers from unreasonable charges, those rulings required a direct link between the project and the needed improvements.
In the opinion written by Justice Alan B. Handler, the New Jersey court said yesterday that it was not necessary to apply such a rigid test when considering the validity ofthe fees.
"It is fair and reasonable to impose such fee requirements on private developers when they possess, enjoy and consume land, which constitutes the primary resource for housing," the court said.
Programs have been initiated in Boston, San Francisco and elsewhere to require commercial developers to contribute to an affordable housing trust fund or build some affordable housing units themselves.
New Jersey is still the only state where communities have a constitutional obligation to provide affordable housing, because of the Mount Laurel decisions, building industry experts said. The decisions took the name of Mount Laurel, the first town whose exclusionary zoning was struck down by the court.
The lawyer for the developers, Henry A. Hill, called the opinion "a shock and a disappointment."
He said it could expose the state's building industry to more than $3 billion in fees in the future to help build or rehabilitate the 160,000 affordable housing units that the state has estimated will be needed in the next six years.
"The ruling lays out an elaborate means of opening the pocketbook of the building industry to finance the court's Mount Laurel opinions," he said.
While they lost their constitutional challenge to the imposition of the fees, the developers will be able to recover the money that they have already paid. The court overturned the ordinances already adopted because no standards for their enactment had been established by the Council on Affordable Housing, which was created by the 1985 Fair Housing Act to insure that each municipality meets its affordable housing obligation.
Mr. Hill said the developers should recover about $30 million already collected by the towns. But in light of the future impact of the ruling, he added, "It looks like we won the battle but lost the war."
He said if the Council on Affordable Housing does not set up a model fee ordinance "with some sensitivity to the economic conditions in the industry, the consequences could be devastating."
 
'Intervening Step'
 Mr. Hill; Thomas V. O'Neil, spokesman for the New Jersey chapter of the National Association of Industrial and Office Parks, and Patrick J. O'Keefe, the executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association, say towns will not be able to reclaim the money they return after they adopt new ordinances. "There is an intervening step," Mr. O'Keefe said, referring to the adoption of regulations by the housing council. "After this hiatus the towns can adopt ordinances that will only affect future projects."
The fees that will now have to be returned were collected by the towns in different ways. Some made the fee -- based on the size of the project or its overall cost -- a condition of receiving approval for a commercial or housing development that did not include some low-priced units. Others gave housing builders a choice of including affordable units in their proposed developments or making a payment to the trust fund. Still others simply imposed a mandatory fee on all developments of a certain size.
The towns put the money into local affordable housing trust funds for the purpose of rehabilitating existing housing for sale to low-income families, building new affordable housing, subsidizing efforts by nonprofit groups to provide housing or paying nearby towns to accept responsibility for some of their allotted number of low-income housing units.
 
Voluntary Agreements
 The suits filed by developers against the Townships of Cherry Hill, Chester, Holmdel, Middletown and South Brunswick forced the funds everywhere to be held in escrow.
A spokeswoman for the Council on Affordable Housing, Sidna Mitchell, said the council in the past had given towns permission to enter into voluntary agreements with builders to produce revenue for low-income housing. Developers who wanted to build more units per acre than allowed under zoning ordinances were given a choice -- sell some of the extra units at reduced prices or pay a fee for the increased building density.
She said lawyers for the council would have to examine yesterday's ruling closely to see if affected the validity of such negotiated agreements.
In yesterday's opinion, the court rejected arguments by developers that the ordinances establishing the fees had violated constitutional standards covering the taking of property, due process and equal protection. But it did not discuss the question of whether ordinances that exacted fees without giving developers something in return were valid, since the ordinances were all struck down. Mr. O'Neil said that if future ordinances did not allow builders some benefit in return for paying an affordable housing fee there probably would be further litigation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Slight Gains, Mainly on Technical Factors

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar firmed slightly against major foreign currencies yesterday in sleepy pre-holiday trading that largely took its cue from technical factors.
The thinly traded currency market seemed unmotivated by external influences that brisker sessions typically take into consideration. 
 Traders said there was no market reaction to a Government report of retail sales falling one-tenth of 1 percent in November, the first decline in six months. While news of economic troubles generally drive down the dollar's value against foreign currencies, traders said the continuing prospect for war in the Persian Gulf kept them cautiously bullish.
 
Stronger Against the Yen
 War news has particularly strengthened the dollar against the Japanese yen because Japan's economy is so dependent on imported oil.
"You have two situations going against each other: Someone could make a warlike statement, and that will pop the dollar up," said Thomas J. Palladino, a trader at Osterreichische Landerbank.
"People are a little afraid of taking a position one way or another," he added.
Likewise, traders said the market was not affected by the Bundesbank's regular meeting yesterday, which left German interest rates unchanged.
 
Rumors Brushed Aside
 The market also brushed aside rumors, later proved untrue, that the planned meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had been canceled.
The dollar gained against the yen in New York, closing at 132.17 yen, up from 131.45 late Wednesday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 131.30 yen, from 131.88 at Wednesday's close, and later in London, it rose to 132.25 yen.
The dollar also gained against the British pound in New York, with the pound weakening to $1.9450, from late Wednesday's $1.9502. In London, the pound rose to $1.9440, from $1.9435 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's prices, included: 1.4790 German marks, up from 1.4756; 1.2660 Swiss francs, up from 1.2610; 5.0255 French francs, up from 5.0120; 1,115.25 Italian lire, up from 1,112.00, and 1.1607 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1606.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Note and Bond Prices Down

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stronger-than-expected reports on the economy and a rise in oil prices acted as catalysts for a sell-off yesterday in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds and a jump in interest rates.
Despite the small rise in interest rates, an auction of $26 billion worth of new one-year Treasury bills produced the lowest rate on those securities in more than two years. 
 Retail sales figures for November were weak, showing that sales dipped one-tenth of a percentage point, but they were not as weak as many analysts had forecast. And auto sales for the first 10 days of December, at an annualized 6.5 million units, were much stronger than anticipated. Although that was still below the annual rate for the year so far, it was much higher than for the last 10 days of November, when auto makers sold 5.3 million units at an annual rate.
In addition, news reports that appeared throughout the day made it appear that the tenuous peace process in the Persian Gulf was in jeopardy. Those reports in turn helped to push up oil prices.
"The economic numbers allowed people to shift the focus back to the Middle East, where we still have problems," said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities. "Combine that with a little bit of profit-taking and we were ripe for some sort of sell-off."
William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, said "the market is coming into the end of December in a very overbought situation. That heightens the desire to take profits now, because activity is likely to thin out in the next week or so."Run-Up in Oil Prices
The run-up in oil prices and the economic numbers helped to push down bond prices. And a move by the Federal Reserve Board to drain reserves from the banking system, a step analysts said was another clear signal the central bank has not yet lowered its target on the overnight Federal funds rate from 7.25 percent, helped to depress short-term notes and bills.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 107 2/32, down half a point, or $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.11 percent. Late Wednesday the benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.05 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 22/ 32, down 10/32, to yield 7.95 percent. And the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 6/32, down 3/32, to yield 7.26 percent.
At an auction of one-year Treasury bills, the securities were sold at an average discount rate of 6.58 percent, down sharply from the average 6.81 percent rate on one-year bills sold at the last auction on Nov. 15. It is the lowest rate on a one-year bill since the auction of April 6, 1988.
In the secondary market for Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 6.82 percent, up five basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 6.68 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a late rate of 6.59 percent, up six basis points.
 
Investment-Grade Bond Market
 A number of issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market yesterday, including a $500 million offering of securities backed by credit card receipts from a financing vehicle created by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
The 8.55 percent securities, which have an average life of 3.5 years, were priced at $99.737, to yield 8.680 percent, 1.19 percentage points over the blended, or interpolated, rate of the 7 3/4 percent three-year Treasury notes and the 8 1/2 percent four-year Treasury notes.
The securities, backed by an 11 percent letter of credit from the Union Bank of Switzerland, are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Chase Securities Inc. acted as lead manager for the underwriting.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, strong demand for certain segments of a $1.1 billion offering of taxable and tax-exempt New York City securities forced underwriters to lower yields on some bonds. The maximum yield on taxable bonds, which stood at 8.55 percent on a preliminary basis on Wednesday, was lowered to 8.50 percent for 30-year bonds.
The issue was not yet freed up to trade, municipal market participants said.
In the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to down 1/8 of a point.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues rose by about 1/8 of a point, traders said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell sharply during the week ended Dec. 3.
The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DECISION: SUSTAINING THE SOVIETS;
Russians Divided on Whether Donations Of Food Will Help or Hurt in the Long Run

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In the northern Russian village of Shulepovo the other day, a tractor driver named Andrei Kuzmin downed a jolt of vodka and emphatically announced his opinion of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appeals for emergency aid from the West.
 "You tell America, don't give those Communists a kopeck!" roared Mr. Kuzmin, certain that his poor rural settlement will not see a morsel of the gifts. "They're bandits!" 
 Mr. Gorbachev's low-key solicitation of assistance to help his country through a lean winter has found remarkable sympathy abroad, reaching an improbable peak today in a promise of food shipments from India.
 
Helping or Hurting Reform?
 But this rush of generosity has caused considerable division here at the receiving end, among economists and politicians, foreign diplomats and ordinary citizens like Mr. Kuzmin.
 Supporters say deliveries of food and medicine, even if the amounts are largely symbolic, will ease hardship for some residents and by calming panic will help fortify Mr. Gorbachev for the continuation of his reforms.
Skeptics say that at best the relief will provide fleeting comfort to a few of the poor, and that at worst the West may find itself killing Soviet reform with kindness.
By most accounts the flow of foreign aid is more political than humanitarian, a gesture of support from Western governments and publics for the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize and for his promises of democracy and free markets.
 
Wheat Coming From India
 India's Ambassador to Moscow today announced gifts to the Soviets of food and medicines, plus a million-ton wheat sale on favorable terms, to add to the food, credit agreements and other aid pledged by governments and organizations around the world.
But the relief effort that has been mounted would not come close to remedying a real famine, if one materialized. Lev A. Voronin, who heads a central Government commission on aid distribution, said the 1,700 tons of total foreign food deliveries so far sound impressive until they are put in context: Moscow residents alone consume 4,200 tons of meat every day.
For Mr. Gorbachev, the ability to deliver Western food aid is a chance to justify his diplomatic globetrotting, which some of his constituents have come to see as a distraction from their own hurts. It is also an answer to critics who complain he has traded away Soviet military might for little return.
Tonight, Tass hailed President Bush's decision Wednesday to authorize up to $1 billion in farm credits to Moscow as a particular triumph for Mr. Gorbachev's foreign policy, saying, "Its political and economic significance must not be underestimated."
"Politically, it is important that Washington's 16-year taboo on credits to the Soviet Union is practically annulled and also that the United States has arrived at the conclusion that the renewal processes in Soviet society are now irreversible," the official press agency said.
The American credit, though modest, is a political plum for the Kremlin because Mr. Bush had earlier vowed that no such assistance would be given until the Soviet Union enacts a law on free emigration.
That law has languished for a year in Parliament, resisted by government agencies that fear a mass exodus of capital and expertise once emigration limits are lifted.
 
Little Public Good Will
 So far there is no evidence the aid shipments have won Mr. Gorbachev the good will of his own public.
On the contrary, many Soviets see the television reports of charity food arriving in Moscow as the latest indictment of a system -- and specifically Mr. Gorbachev's five years of economic experiments -- that let food supplies decline.
The flow of Western aid carries several risks for Mr. Gorbachev, as well as for the donors.
One is that if a significant amount of the aid is diverted into the black market, it will deepen the morass of disenchantment and cynicism, undermining the leader it was intended to help.
Recalling the experience of the Armenian earthquake two years ago, when Western clothing and food relief were seen being sold flagrantly in Moscow bazaars, both Western donors and the Soviets themselves have stressed the need for meticulous monitoring.
 Even if these efforts are largely successful, however, it seems certain that aid will reach only a small portion of the hardship cases in this vast country. And when it runs out, their bitterness could return redoubled.
A second danger, some critics say, is that aid may provide an excuse to postpone needed economic change.
In a forthcoming book called "The Anti-Communist Manifesto: Whom to Help in Russia," six Soviet scholars urge the West to withhold any aid to the Soviet Union that might prop up the existing industrial and farm monopolies and thus postpone the development of truly private enterprise.
"Even grain sales to the U.S.S.R. contribute to the preservation of this parasitic system," wrote Larisa Piyasheva, an independent market economist.
A senior Western diplomat today countered that credits like those offered by Mr. Bush would give Moscow temporary flexibility in its foreign purchases, but would have to be paid back within three years.
"If they don't make the hard choices, it's not going to be because of aid," the diplomat add. "There is not that much aid."
 
Political Exploitation Feared
 A third hazard is that aid could become a weapon in the country's internal political wars.
Insurgents who have won control of local governments in Moscow and other cities worry that Western largesse will become the personal patronage of Mr. Gorbachev, the Communist Party or the K.G.B., which is proudly flaunting its new role of policing food distribution.
Western embassies say they cannot bypass the central Government, with which they have diplomatic relations. But they have urged that assistance be channeled through popularly elected officials rather than the party or the K.G.B.
"If the central Government says it wants to use its police to make sure Western aid doesn't get stolen, it's kind of hard to object to that," a diplomat said. "If the K.G.B. is taking control of transport and delivery, that would be a little harder to deal with."
One group of hard-liners, a political alliance called the Centrist Bloc, tried this week to use the aid against Mr. Gorbachev, condemning the Soviet leader for "presenting the Soviet Union as a beggar country."
 
Willing to Swallow Pride
 Most consumers, however, are by now willing to swallow their pride and accept foreign help.
"The real humiliation of our country comes from the people who, over the years, reduced things to such a state that what we produce is either destroyed or rots in the fields," the Government daily Izvestia said tonight.
One diplomat said the greatest risk of all in the current frenzy over Soviet food supplies is the danger that Western sympathy will be spent by the time it is needed.
"If this spiral of deterioration continues, by next winter the wolf may really be at the door," he said. "One hopes that if that is the case, they haven't cried 'wolf' too often."

HEADLINE: Honda's New Wagon: A U.S. Auto, Almost

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARYSVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company introduced a station wagon today that represents another step in the Japanese company's drive to become the first foreign company to create a self-sufficient United States auto maker.
The Accord station wagon is the first Honda to be designed and assembled completely in this country, although some components are imported from Japan. It was designed at the company's studios in Torrance, Calif., and is being built at Honda's plant in this city 35 miles northwest of Columbus. "For years we were supporting projects that started in Japan," said Ben Knight, assistant project leader for the station wagon. 
 By the end of this decade, Honda hopes to bring out a car that is not only entirely native-born but that also is not a version of another Honda, as the station wagon is to the Accord sedan. Honda says its goal is to respond more quickly and accurately to the desires of United States buyers.
Honda's new station wagon, which went into production Nov. 20 and has begun arriving at dealers, is one of a breed that has largely been replaced by mini-vans. The company thinks it will be strong competition for station-wagon versions of the Ford Taurus, Mercury Sable, Toyota Camry and Volvo.
In a more philosophical vein, the Accord wagon poses a challenge for American politicians, auto executives and scholars who argue that the Japanese auto industry is advancing at the expense of the domestic industry and thereby weakening United States economic competitiveness.
Because it relies on American assemblers, engineers, designers and parts suppliers, and because it will be exported to Europe and Japan, the new vehicle can be viewed as an asset to the American economy and a way to reduce the nation's trade deficit.
What is more, building the car entirely in the United States has required Honda to teach its United States employees, most of whom are Americans, sophisticated engineering and manufacturing skills that in the past were not needed at Japanese plants in the United States, which ported many parts and merely assembled them. (Nissan and Toyota are moving in the same direction.)
Among the skills: building robotic assembly machines and designing a tool and die system to build the eight large metal panels that differentiate the station wagon from the sedan.
"Our dies can stamp out a piece of metal in four motions of the press, as opposed to six or seven motions by the presses of many other auto makers," explained James Macaluso, 32 years old, who has worked for Honda for nine years. The highly efficient tool-and-die technology comes from Honda's Japanese operations but it must be learned and carried out by Americans.
 
Public Relations Move?
 Some scholars argue that improving workers' skills helps make the United States more competitive. But many see Honda's efforts as little more than a public relations exercise. They argue that Honda exaggerates the portion of the car's components -- about 70 percent -- that come from the United States in order to blunt criticism of its success against the Big Three car makers. For the last two years, the Accord has been the best-selling car in the United States.
Officials from the United Automobile Workers union criticized Honda for trying to create the impression that the company was becoming more American.
"Honda's self-proclaimed Americanization is a myth," said Sheldon Friedman, director of research for the union. "What counts, particularly when it comes to creating jobs, is domestic manufacturing content. By that measure, Honda still falls far short of the Big Three."
Doing the engineering work necessary to transform the Accord sedan into a station wagon is "not a big deal, although it's a good place to start" for Honda's American engineers, said David E. Cole, director of the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation.
"The real test of whether Honda is moving more of its core engineering here would be if the company allows its U.S. operations to do a powertrain," he said, referring to the engine and transmission, which are still designed in Japan.
 
Lack of Engineers
 Honda's decision to do the engineering work on the Accord wagon in the United States stems partly from the difficulty Japanese auto makers have had attracting skilled engineers at home, Mr. Cole said.
"The Japanese auto companies have long been concerned that the industry was not as attractive to the brightest engineers as it once was," he said. "This is, in fact, coming to pass. They are running out of people in Japan."
Station wagons have fallen from a peak of 12.6 percent of all cars registered in the United States in 1973 to 4.3 percent in 1990. Just under 500,000 were sold last year, while mini-van sales last year climbed to 735,000.
While mini-vans have become the station wagons, and even the family sedans, of the 1980's, "that doesn't mean that compact vans are going to kill off the market for station wagons," said Christopher Cedergren, an analyst for J. D. Power & Associates, a marketing research company in Westlake Village, Calif.
In fact, Mr. Cedergren expects a mild resurgence in sales of station wagons. "There is a group that still wants something that looks like a car, and doesn't like the look or the handling of the mini-vans," he said.
 
More Sales Expected
 Indeed, J. D. Power projects that sales of station wagons will begin to climb again, reaching 770,000 by 1995, partly helped by Honda's new entry. Honda expects to sell 30,000 to 35,000 station wagons annually in the United States and to export about 10,000 annually to Europe and Japan.
The price of the Accord wagon will range from $17,300 to $19,800. The Environmental Protection Agency's fuel-efficiency rating for the manual-transmission version is 22 miles a gallon in city driving and 27 in highway driving. The rating for the automatic-transmission model is 20 miles a gallon in the city and 26 on the highway.
Ford executives said they were confident that their Taurus wagon would hold its own. "Honda may take some market share," said Joel Pitcoff, a market analyst for Ford. "But it's only a four-cylinder engine, which I think would limit them." (Ford's Taurus wagon usually carries a six-cylinder engine.)
Mr. Cedergren expects Honda's real challenger to be Toyota's new Camry wagon, which is coming out next fall and is built in Japan.

GRAPHIC: Photo: American workers at the Honda Motor plant in Marysville, Ohio, were taught new skills to make the Accord station wagon, which is the first Honda to be designed and built exclusively in this country. (Kevin Fitzsimons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Parting at Waterford Wedgwood

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In a separation that could either save a four-year marriage or set the stage for dissolution, Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C., the troubled Irish maker of fine tableware, announced today that its crystal and ceramic operations would operate independently from now on.
"Waterford Wedgwood will be very much a holding company now, instead of an operational company," said Robert Davies, its chief financial officer. Mr. Davies, who is heading the reorganization, has also been named acting chief executive of the Wedgwood operations. 
 The company's new structure represents a 180-degree turn away from the strategy that brought the two brands under one roof in 1986, when Waterford Crystal paid more than $360 million for Wedgwood. Then, the idea was to integrate the two operations to streamline production and to use the products' overlapping customer base to strengthen the brands' marketing position.
 
'Better Mix of Markets'
 Analysts say they do not think the new structure necessarily means the merger is unraveling. "I suppose it creates that possibility, though clearly the Waterford side on its own wouldn't be viable," said John Hogan, research director at Riada & Company, an Irish brokerage house. "Somebody might want to buy it and take it private, to take the long view. But I don't see that as the immediate intention."
Instead, analysts say the move is probably in part a way to motivate Wedgwood executives, whose good results have been consistently overshadowed by losses at Waterford.
"Clearly, Wedgwood has proved to be the more robust company," Mr. Hogan said. "Partly I think it's because it has a better mix of markets. Waterford's crystal is heavily dependent on one market, the United States, and on the dollar. So it's producing in Ireland and selling in dollars and only getting half the Irish pounds back. Over the past five years, the exchange rate has halved for the dollar."
Mr. Hogan says the restructuring may also be an attempt to give the crystal business the flexibility it needs to come up with new products, or to cut back on production, as the United States slides into recession.
"This might give them a better, faster reporting structure," he said. "Whoever is in charge of the crystal operation will have a straight line of control from production and distribution to marketing and sales."
The market seemed cautiously optimistic about today's announcement. The company's stock, which is trading at about 37 cents a share, was up slightly.
In a letter sent to shareholders, Howard E. Kilroy, Waterford Wedgwood's chairman, said the internal restructuring "will enable each management, led by its existing executive team, to concentrate on its own brands and pursue the global strategies necessary for their development."
Waterford Wedgwood's chief executive, Paddy Bryne, resigned after saying he supported the reorganization.
 
A Heavy Debt Burden
 The merged company seemed to have problems from the outset. Waterford took on heavy debt to finance the acquisition and has been hobbled by it ever since.
In April 1989, the balance sheet worsened when auditors discovered that the crystal unit's 1988 earnings had been overstated by some $21 million. The division promptly went into the red, overshadowinng the record operating earnings of Wedgwood.
Last year also brought a softening of demand in the company's two biggest markets, the United States and Britain. Waterford Wedgwood sells 70 percent of its crystal in the United States and 44 percent of its china in Britain. Both markets were already showing signs of economic strain; orders from the United States dropped even further because of the consolidation crisis among department stores.
Waterford Wedgwood wound up with a 1989 loss before taxes and interest of $1.7 million on sales of $542 million.
By March 1990, debt stood at $233.7 million, and a rescue plan was mounted by two investor groups, which paid $158.9 million for a 29.9 percent in the company. But the investors -- led by Morgan Stanley & Company and Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, the Irish-born businessman who is also the chairman of the H. J. Heinz Company -- were unable to save the company from another problem that arose the following month: a strike by the 2,100 employees at the Waterford Crystal Works.
The 14-week work stoppage compounded the problem of softening export demand.
Mr. Hogan of Riada & Company estimates that the company's 1990 sales will reach $372.6 million, with a pretax loss of $32.4 million. "I think we got quite a lot out of the merger," he said. "But now we're looking at an economic time of being lean, focused and very accountable."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspaper Executives Report on a Difficult Year

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
"Let's not mince words; 1990 has been a simply dreadful year," said Richard D. Simmons, president of The Washington Post Company, as he began his address yesterday to a group of communications industry analysts and reporters in New York.
Representatives of Dow Jones & Company, The New York Times Company and Afflilated Publications Inc. were similarly grim when their turns came to speak yesterday at the Paine Webber Media Forum. The forum is an annual review of the past year's business and a projection of the year to come by many of the nation's largest public communications companies. 
 Indeed, with advertising sales in a nationwide slump, the weeklong forum has consisted mostly of explaining drops in earnings expected for 1990 and projected for 1991. But in every case, the year's poor results were accompanied by expressions of confidence that the basic businesses remained strong and would rebound when the economic climate changed.
While most newspaper-oriented public communications companies have diversified into other businesses like broadcasting, cable and information services, the advertising-sensitive portions of the business remain the largest for most of them.
 
'Straightforward' Approach
 With an audience that includes many of the people who recommend buying, selling or holding media stocks at some of the nation's largest brokerage houses, presenting unhappy tidings in the most positive fashion was a high priority.
Most of the executives making presentations chose a "very straightforward" approach, said J. Kendrick Noble Jr., who is a specialist at evaluating media stocks at Paine Webber and who is the moderator of the forum. He said such frankness suggested to the analyst community that the executives understood their problems and were in command of them.
Mr. Simmons of The Washington Post Company went so far as to apologize to analysts for being too optimistic a year ago. And he presented a detailed account of how the paper's advertising "fell off a cliff" in July, especially help wanted and real estate classified advertising. He blamed cutbacks in the military consulting industry, which is a big Washington employer, and a general recession.
He estimated that the Post Company's earnings for 1990 would decline 8 percent and said that he had an "unusually pessimistic view" of the overall economy, bolstered only by confidence that the Washington economy would be among the first to improve. "But I don't think we've yet hit bottom," he added.
 
Decline at Dow Jones
 Peter R. Kann, the president of Dow Jones, began his company's presentation with an extended explanation of the company's long-term strategy of expansion as a global business news and information company. Next year, Mr. Kann will replace the company's longtime chairman, Warren Phillips, who is retiring, and he said he wished to reassure the analysts that the company's essential vision had not changed.
But eventually, like the other executives making presentations, Mr. Kann had to deliver the bad news: a 30 percent decline in Dow Jones earnings from continuing operations for 1990 compared with 1989.
He said the drop had been prompted by a continuing decline in advertising in The Wall Street Journal and lower sales in the United States operations of the company's electronic financial data company, Telerate.
As for 1991, he said that the company would have to "learn to live on more reduced means" and that controllable expenses would be flat.
Walter E. Mattson, president of The New York Times Company, said 1990 had been "the most difficult year" for the company since the mid-1970's, when the city went through a fiscal crisis during a national recession.
 
Lower Earnings Predicted
 Mr. Mattson said that the company's earnings per share for 1990 would be 80 to 90 cents, compared with 87 cents in 1989.
In both years, there were significant special charges, such as start-up costs associated with a new printing plant in Edison, N.J. Mr. Mattson said that on an operating basis, earnings for 1990 would be off by 8.5 percent to 14.5 percent.
Mr. Mattson predicted "somewhat lower earnings over all" for 1991, mostly because of an 8 percent lineage loss expected for The New York Times, which he said would be offset somewhat by higher ad rates and aggressive circulation pricing.
William O. Taylor, chief executive officer of Affiliated Publications, which owns The Boston Globe, said that The Globe had been hard hit by the particularly severe economic slump in New England.
Operating income for the company in 1990 would be off by about 26 percent, Mr. Taylor said, and The Globe's advertising volume for 1991 was expected to decline further, although rate increases were expected to keep revenues flat.

HEADLINE: 4 Towns on L.I. Say They'll Sue To Keep Dumps

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 13

 BODY:
Four towns on Long Island's East End said today that they would sue the State Department of Environmental Conservation to block a law requiring them to close their landfills.
The law, enacted in 1983 because of concern about the effect of landfills on the Island's underground water supply, gave the towns seven years to close their landfills. The deadline is Tuesday. But the four towns said they do not know what they would do with their trash. 
 "We can't afford to pay another $3 million a year to truck our garbage somewhere else," said Tony Bullock, Supervisor of East Hampton. He said he would like to keep his landfill open for several more years, as the town of 18,000 people eventually recycles or composts 81 percent of its trash.
"Shutting the landfills now would bring enormous environmental and economic consequences which would be far more injurious to the people of Long Island than keeping the dumps open for another year or two," Mr. Bullock said. If the landfills were closed now, he said, it would cost the four towns about $10 million in 1991 to truck their garbage elsewhere.
The suit, which is to be filed in State Supreme Court on Friday by East Hampton, Southold and Riverhead, seeks to have the law thrown out on the grounds that it is unconstitutional and inappropriate. Shelter Island said it plans to join the suit, which also seeks a temporary injunction to prevent the state from enforcing the law until the case can be heard.
The East End towns, on the farthest end of the Island from New York City, have been squabbling with state environmental officials for months over garbage-disposal plans.
This fall, Thomas C. Jorling, the agency Commissioner, proposed a complex series of garbage swaps in which one town would send its trash to another town's landfill, for instance, in return for taking that town's leaves for composting. The towns balked, and Mr. Bullock said today that state officials had presented nothing but "farcical proposals that ignored the geographic and logistical realities."
But the Commissioner said that the East End towns had petulantly and arrogantly blocked every state effort to come up with workable plan.
The Commissioner said the state would force the recalcitrant towns to comply by taking them to court.

HEADLINE: U.S. Vehicle Sales Up; Rebates Are a Factor

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Sales of American-made vehicles picked up in early December, prodded by record rebates and deliveries to rental fleets. But wary buyers kept retail demand soft.
Over all, domestic vehicle sales increased 22 percent in the first 10 days of December, a deceptively large rise because sales for the period last year were very weak. 
 The 10 domestic manufacturers sold 136,754 cars, an increase of 27.5 percent. Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of 6.5 million, compared with an annual rate of 5.6 million in the period last year. For the last 60 days, cars sold at an annual rate of 6.6 million. So far this year, cars have been selling at an annual rate of 6.9 million.
Sales of light trucks, which account for about a third of overall vehicle sales, rose 14 percent, to 83,766 pickups, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles.
Scott Merlis, an automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley, said demand for cars and light trucks remained "very depressed." Mr. Merlis attributed the sales gains to rebates averaging $1,050 a vehicle, which he said was a record for the last three months of the year.
"That means volume without profit, no matter how you slice it," he said.
"The real problem is that a lot of polls are saying a majority of American consumers think war is likely," Mr. Merlis added. "So I can understand why showroom traffic may be slow."
Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers' Association, cautioned against "reading too much into these numbers."
"Sales tend to be volatile this time of year due to the relatively low level of sales," Mr. Webb said, adding that the latest reports of sales volume and showroom traffic from dealers were "rather pessimistic."
"That leads me to believe that fleets are propping up the sales figures again," he said. "True demand remains weak."
Japanese auto makers with factories in the United States posted a slight decline in their share of the domestic market for cars. The share fell to 9 percent in early December from 10 percent a year earlier.
The General Motors Corporation sold 65,527 cars in early December, a gain of 27.9 percent over last year's poor sales. G.M.'s small, high-mileage Geo Metro commuter car continued to sell well, partly on the strength of a large fleet order. Several G.M. models popular with fleet buyers also posted large sales gains, including Chevrolet's Lumina and full-sized Caprice, and the Pontiac Sunbird.
G.M. sold 33,872 light trucks, a gain of 11.6 percent.
 
 Ford Car Sales Up 32.3%
 The Ford Motor Company sold 41,264 cars in early December, a gain of 32.3 percent. Analysts said Ford benfited from a large delivery of its Lincoln Town Car model to daily rental companies during the period. Ford's light truck sales rose 32.6 percent, to 33,850 units.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales rose 25.4 percent, to 17,932 cars in early December. But sales of Chrysler's light trucks, including mini-vans and Jeeps, fell 13.2 percent, to 14,314 vehicles.
The Honda Motor Company sold 3,821 domestically produced cars in early December, a decline of 31.6 percent. A Honda spokesman said the company's car sales fell while others rose because Honda did not sell its cars to fleets.
The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 4,628 cars made in the United States, a gain of 47.4 percent. Toyota also reported that it sold 9,045 imported cars and 2,414 imported light trucks during the first 10 days of December.
The reporting of import sales by Toyota was the first time a major importer has followed the United States industry practice of providing sales information on a 10-day basis.
Until now foreign auto makers have reported their sales of imports to the United States only at the end of each month. However, those companies with plants in the United States already provide domestic sales results every 10 days.
Toyota's decision to follow the domestic industry practice comes in the wake of Chrysler's announcement last week that it would stop reporting its domestic sales every 10 days.
A Chrysler spokesman said the company was evaluating the move by Toyota, but declined to comment on whether it might alter its decision to stop reporting sales every 10 days.
An official for Honda said the company had no intention of reporting its import sales every 10 days.

HEADLINE: Despite Auto Fuel Economy, Environment Could Worsen

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Improvements in automobile gasoline mileage that would help the global environment would be more than wiped out by the rising number of automobiles on the road, said a study made public yesterday.
The study by the World Resources Institute, a leading private organization concerned with the environment, said the number of motor vehicles is rising by 4.6 percent a year, about two and a half times as fast as the human population. By the year 2010, the number could reach 1.1 billion, more than double the current level, as the number of vehicles is rising by about two for each one thousand people every year, the study said. 
 In addition, the study said, "There is troubling evidence that worldwide, new cars are becoming less efficient" in their use of fuel.
 
A Plateau in Fuel Efficiency
 A pollution analyst at the Ford Motor Company, Michael J. Scharz, said the estimate on the number of cars was "not out of the realm of possibility." But he said most of the rise would have to be in the undeveloped world, where economic progress might not sustain such progress.
An effort to lift fuel economy standards died in Congress at the end of the last session, but backers plan to try again. Cars sold in this country this year are about 4 percent less fuel efficient, on average, than those sold in 1988. The average fuel efficiency of cars on the road is still rising slowly, because the 1990-model cars are more efficient than old cars being scrapped, but a plateau in auto fuel economy is in sight in this country, the report said.
The solution, it said, includes cars with very high gas mileage, as well as electric cars that do not burn fossil fuels, mass transit and reduction of other gas emissions that contribute to the greenhouse effect, including chlorofluorocarbons, from car air conditioners.
Vehicles produce a growing fraction of the carbon dioxide that scientists fear will produce substantial climate changes in the next century. According to the study, "Driving Forces: Motor Vehicle Trends and their Implications for Global Warming, Energy Strategies, and Transportation Planning," vehicles accounted for 12 percent of carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion in 1971; in 1985, it was 14 percent.
Last month 18 European nations agreed to keep their carbon dioxide emissions at 1990 levels to reduce climate change, and they invited all other industrialized nations to do the same. But most of the growth is likely to come outside Europe and North America; Africa and Asia, excluding Japan, which make up nearly three quarters of the world's population, have only 12 percent of its motor vehicles, according to the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association of the United States,
But Mr. Schwarz, of Ford, said that the report "doesn't address the social and economic implications of concluding that you have to stop, or drastically reduce, carbon dioxide from transportation sources."
Stabilizing carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere would require far more than just holding fossil fuel use constant, the experts say. It would require cutting emissions by 50 percent or more.

HEADLINE: Half a Decision on Health Care for the Poor

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The State Senate today passed a bill to extend a fund that covers poor and uninsured hospital patients in New Jersey, as concern rose that inaction in the Assembly might force the state's hospital system into financial crisis on Jan. 1.
At issue is a debt-ridden trust fund that reimburses hospitals when they care for some of the million people in New Jersey who lack insurance. With the fund scheduled to expire at the end of the month, Gov. Jim Florio and the Democrat-controlled Legislature must choose between three unattractive alternatives: continuing a system whose cost is slowly winding out of control, enacting a new tax or permitting many hospitals to fall into crisis. 
 The Senate voted 34 to 2 to extend the fund, the Uncompensated Care Trust Fund, for 90 days. But Democrats in the Assembly said there was strong sentiment among their members to let the trust fund lapse to confront the public with the consequences of not raising taxes.
 
'An Ever Worsening Cycle'
 "My feeling is that when you deal with a problem, you need to come up with a real solution," said Joseph V. Doria Jr., the Speaker of the Assembly. "Putting things off for 90 days is not a real solution. You are just feeding into an ever worsening cycle."
 The Assembly's last scheduled session to act on the issue is Monday.
Under the current system, when patients cannot pay for hospital care, the cost is covered by the state's Uncompensated CareTrust Fund. The fund is supported by a surcharge on the hospital bills of those who can pay, a charge that has recently grown to 19 percent. The surcharge is driving up health-insurance costs and is actually pushing people and employers who pay for health insurance to drop their coverage.
As more people go uninsured, the surcharge continues to rise. Health experts agree that unless something is done to change the system, it is bound to spiral out of control. The trust fund, which is now more than $1 billion dollars in debt, would levy a 23 percent tax if extended to next year.
In October, a commission appointed by Governor Florio offered far-reaching proposals to control medical costs and replace the fund with a $450 million tax on employers. The tax would shift the cost of care for the uninsured and indigent from the pool of people using hospitals to a $144 tax on companies for each of their employees.
But with New Jersey's anti-tax fervor, legislators and the Governor's office agreed that anything resembling a new tax was unfeasible. Democratic leaders in the two houses now appear divided over whether a three-month extension is the best alternative.
"Is the right choice throwing the system into chaos?" said Senator Richard J. Codey, a Democrat of West Orange, the sponsor of the bill passed by the Senate today. "A new tax is just not going to happen. Forget it. The Senate has done the right thing and the smart thing. Now it is up to the Assembly."
Under the law, if the trust fund lapses, hospitals would still be required to care for the indigent. But they would then have to charge other patients to cover the cost.
 
Possible Crisis in Urban Hospitals
 A result would be a sudden jump in charges at some urban hospitals that provide care to large numbers of patients who cannot pay, said Charles A. Mowll, vice president of the New Jersey Hospital Association. University Hospital in Newark, for example, would be forced to add a surtax of as much as 50 percent, Mr. Mowll said.
Over time, some hospitals would become far more expensive than others and paying patients would flee to less expensive institutions. Some urban hospitals might eventually treat nearly all indigent patients, Mr. Mowll said, without having paying patients to cover the costs.
Some urban hospitals might have to cut back on services, other health experts said. Poor patients with drug problems, AIDS and other severe problems would be sent to smaller suburban hospitals that were not prepared to cope with them.
It is unclear, government health officials said, how quickly or severely such problems would arise. But all agreed that if the fund was not extended, the public within weeks would see a problem that until now appeared abstract and removed from all but health-care specialists.
 
Forcing the Issue
 Governor Florio has refused to take a position on the issue, leaving it instead to the Legislature to adopt the recommendations of his commission or find an alternative. But some Democratic Assembly members have argued behind closed doors that forcing a hospital crisis would bring public pressure for a solution, possibly even support for a new tax.
The Republican minority leader, Garabed L. Haytaian, however, dismissed such a move as cynical and warned that the public would hold the Democrats responsible for a hospital crisis.
"If they want to fabricate a problem by not dealing with it by the end of the year, it is going to be very interesting," Mr. Haytaian said. There is not enough confidence in government as it is. Remember, the Democrats are in charge."
When asked for his position, however, Mr. Haytaian said he would endorse neither a new tax nor an extension of the trust fund until he had conferred with other Republican Assembly members.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DECISION;
U.S. FARMERS COOL TO SOVIET AID DEAL

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 13

 BODY:
President Bush's decision to temporarily lift a ban on lending to the Soviet Union and provide $1 billion in agricultural loans received a less-than-enthusiastic response in the farm community today.
Representatives of farm groups said the President's action, which was intended to help the Soviet Union meet anticipated winter food shortages, was encouraging to the farmers who will benefit from the purchases but over all it was too late, was far less than farmers had hoped and would have no significant impact on farm income. 
 "It's been a long time coming, and it's good that it's finally here," said Terry Francl, an economist at the American Farm Bureau, the largest farm organization with 3.9 million members. "The other side of the issue is that there have been a lot of countries that have already extended credit to the Soviets, and there is no question that we have lost sales to these competitors."
 
Not 'Euphoric'
 Barry Jenkins, a spokesman for the National Wheat Growers Association, said, "This is something we have worked with the Congress and the President on for some time, but it would be way too strong to say we are euphoric."
The farmers' biggest concern was the amount of money involved. The $1 billion is less than 1 percent of the United States farm economy's annual revenues of $150 billion.
The amount is significantly less than many farmers and traders in the commodities markets had expected. There had been rumors that new loans or loan guarantees to the Soviets would total $1.5 billion to $2 billion.
The commodities markets, which had closed by the time of the announcement on Wednesday, reflected the letdown yesterday. At the Chicago Board of Trade, prices on all three of the major grain futures contracts -- corn, wheat, and soybeans -- closed lower. The contract to deliver soybeans in January closed at $5.88 a bushel, down 8.75 cents. The March 1991 corn contact finished at $2.35 a bushel, down 4 cents. The March 1991 wheat contract settled at $2.65, off 2 cents.
 
No Additional Sales
 If the reaction was, on balance, negative, one reason is that the $1 billion will allow the Soviets to fulfill purchase commitments they had already agreed to under grain accords reached in the 1980's. Thus, it will produce no incremental sales for American farmers.
On the other hand, a worldwide glut of wheat is depressing prices for farmers in this country. Other governments have tried to help their own farmers by subsidizing purchases, and the loan guarantees will make United States farmers more competitive.
But important questions remain unanswered. For instance, it was unclear today how long it would take to disburse the full $1 billion.
Another unresolved issue is the level of interest rates that the Soviets will pay. Lower rates would give them more money to buy commodities.
Finally, it is unclear exactly what foods will be bought by the Soviets. It could include corn, wheat and soybeans, as well as frozen meats like chicken parts.
