HEADLINE: NCR Board Said to Reject A.T.& T.'s $90-a-Share Offer

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The board of the NCR Corporation rejected the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $90-a-share cash bid for the company in a board meeting yesterday, people involved in the situation said.
The decision by the directors, which is expected to be announced today, sets the stage for a possible proxy battle with A.T.& T. over control of NCR's board of directors. Control of the board is necessary to remove NCR's "poison pill," which would make the bid prohibitively expensive. 
 People involved in the situation said that the rejection appeared to amount to little more than a so-called "just say no" defense, in which the target company simply refuses to accept the offered price from a bidder instead of seeking another merger partner or initiating a recapitalization that would result in a higher price for its shareholders.
A spokeswoman for NCR declined to comment. A spokesman for A.T.& T. said the company had not heard any news about the board meeting.
NCR has said it has been approached by third parties interested in the company, but it has stressed that it wants to remain independent. NCR's chairman, Charles E. Exley Jr., has also said that he intends to avoid a recapitalization that would saddle the company with debt.
 
Proxy Fight Indicated
 Mr. Exley, who was not available for an interview yesterday, has also said he will resign if A.T.&T. prevails.
A highly regarded computer executive, Mr. Exley directed NCR's dramatic retooling of the product line, and has said that the company faces a promising future on its own.
A.T.& T. has indicated that it will begin a proxy fight against NCR's 12-member board of directors if its takeover offer continues to be spurned by NCR. "It is still an option for us," Walter Murphy, an A.T.& T. spokesman, said yesterday. "We will decide at the appropriate time whether to exercise that option or not."
NCR is also preparing for a proxy fight and is working with the proxy solicitor Georgeson & Company. Mr. Exley is planning to meet with large institutional shareholders, who control more than 60 percent of NCR stock, to try to persuade them not to tender their shares to A.T.& T.
News of the board's rejection of the A.T.& T. offer came after the market was closed. A.T.& T. stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $31; NCR also gained 62.5 cents to close at $90.125.
 
Management an Issue
 Wall Street professionals are increasingly puzzled by NCR's lack of a solid defense and Mr. Exley's repeated statements that the company just wants to be left alone. But the move may well be a tactical effort to force A.T.& T., which has said it is determined to acquire NCR, to increase its bidding price.
Such a tactic could force the two companies into a negotiated merger. NCR has said that it will consider a deal if A.T.& T. pays $125 a share. The telecommunications company has refused to offer that amount. Analysts said that the deal made economic sense for A.T.& T. up to about $110 a share.

HEADLINE: Losses Widen at S.& L.'s

BYLINE: AP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Despite the Government's crash program to close failed savings and loans, losses at the surviving solvent institutions more than doubled in the third quarter, compared with the previous quarter, regulators said today.
Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said the decline was a result of the slumping real estate market. 
 Savings institutions lost $631 million in the third quarter, compared with a revised $302 million in the second quarter and $373 million in the first quarter. The second-quarter loss had originally been reported as $196 million.
 
Real Estate Is Crucial
 Mr. Ryan said housing construction was at an eight-year low and commercial vacancy rates were rising. "As long as the real estate slump continues, the thrift industry will have a tough time improving performance," he said.
The losses occurred at marginal institutions and at those that regulators say are virtually certain to fail. The institutions that are expected to fail are concentrated in five states: California has 23; Florida, 23; Texas, 19; New Jersey, 17, and Illinois, 15.
The deterioration among solvent institutions occurred even though the Government has been closing the worst institutions. At the end of September, there were 2,389 privately run savings and loans, 208 fewer than at the startof the year.
"The guys that were healthy are not as healthy, but that's not surprising since the economy isn't as healthy and the housing market is in the dumper," said Martin Regalia, an economist with the National Council of Savings Institutions.
He predicted that the losses to be reported for the current quarter and the first quarter of 1991 would also be "fairly disheartening," and he called on the Government to close insolvent institutions as soon as possible.
"It's quite clear that keeping defunct institutions in the market worsens the environment for solvent institutions," he said.
Earlier this week Mr. Ryan told a House Banking Committee task force that starting next month his office would increase the pace of closings to seven or eight a week, from two or three a week now.
His agency divides the industry into four groups: 1,130 profitable and well-capitalized institutions, which as a group earned $508 million in the quarter; 685 that meet or are expected to meet minimum standards, which earned $138 million; 356 marginal institutions with poor earnings, which lost $230 million, and 218 that are considered all but certain to fail, which lost $1.05 billion.
Results were not disclosed for 206 institutions that were open but under the control of the Resolution Trust Corporation at the end of September.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: TEXAS, USA (79%); FLORIDA, USA (79%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: RULES MAY TIGHTEN ON CABLE TV RATES

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission proposed new rules today that would give communities more power to limit the prices for local cable television service.
Under the existing F.C.C. rules, only about 3 percent of the nation's more than 9,500 cable television systems have their rates regulated. 
 Cable television rates have doubled and tripled in many cities since Congress deregulated the industry in 1984. The F.C.C. proposal, which could be enacted as early as the spring, reflects a widespread conviction among Federal officials that cable companies in many cities enjoy virtual monopolies and have raised their rates too freely.
 
Tighter Definition of Competition
 The commission's proposal follows a recent deadlock in Congress on legislation that would have restrained cable companies' ability to set prices.
The new F.C.C. rule would tighten the legal definition of "effective competition" for local cable systems. That definition largely determines whether a municipality has the right to regulate local cable rates.
Under the F.C.C.'s present definition, local cable rates are not regulated as long as there are at least three over-the-air, or broadcast, television stations in the area. In effect, that has meant that very few cable systems could face any kind of regulation.
Under the proposed rule, the commission would define "effective competition" in three new ways.
Competition would exist in an area if television viewers there can receive at least six broadcast stations and if less than half the households subscribe to the cable system.
Effective competition would also exist if new technologies that rival cable, like satellite television or microwave broadcasting, are available to at least half the households in an area and are used by at least 10 percent of the households.
As a practical matter, F.C.C. officials said, most of the nation's cable systems would not be considered to face competition under either of these criteria. Yet cable companies in largest metropolitan areas, where there is a greater number of television stations and cable systems, would generally be more likely to meet one of the requirements for effective competition and thus would not have their rates regulated.
F.C.C. officials said cable systems in Los Angeles, Chicago and the Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla., area might meet the first standard for effective competition. And William F. Squadron, the Commissioner of Telecommunications and Energy in New York City, said some cable systems in the city might come under this standard as well.
 
'Good Actor' Standard
 But a cable company could escape local price control, even if it fails to meet the effective competition standard, by providing evidence that it is a "good actor." Although details of this definition have not yet been determined, a "good actor" would be a cable company that provides basic services at prices that are comparable to those offered in cities where there is effective competition.
Some consumer groups and local officials criticized the "good actor" provision as a loophole in the proposed F.C.C. rule. But it was not enough to satisfy representatives of the cable industry, who attacked the commission's proposal.
"This proposal raises the prospect of the Government inhibiting the future development of cable programming by crimping its economic lifeblood," James P. Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association, said in a statement.
Mr. Mooney warned that Government regulators would be likely to emphasize simple price controls.
 
Warning of a Loophole
 Local officials praised the F.C.C. for deciding to jettison its old standard, but said the "good actor" provision could effectively gut the rest of the proposal. "The 'good actor' clause could be a loophole that eats up the entire rule," said Nicholas Miller, a Washington lawyer who represents St. Louis, Laredo, Tex., and other cities on cable issues.
"It's unfortunate that the F.C.C. has not adopted what is really the most sensible standard, which is either that there is another cable operator in the market or another multichannel system provider," Mr. Squadron, the New York City official, said.
David C. Olson, director of Portland, Ore.'s office of cable communications, said he was cautiously optimistic about the F.C.C. proposal. "We appreciate the commission's recognition that the current standard is meaningless," he said. "Having said that, we've got to see the specific language of this proposal."
F.C.C. officials said the proposal offered a way to exert control over cable companies without becoming embroiled in trying to determine what constitutes reasonable pricing. The hope is that cable companies will behave as if they faced competition, simply to escape the prospect of having local officials decide everything from their rates of return to their cost structures.
But F.C.C. officials acknowledged today that they did not know how many cable systems would be able to meet the "good actor" standard.
Congress came close to passing legislation that would have imposed modest new regulations and encouraged competition. But the measure collapsed at the last minute because of opposition from the Bush Administration.
In today's action, the F.C.C.'s chairman, Alfred C. Sikes, made it clear that he wanted to create what amounts to a substitute for head-to-head competition.
"We are attempting to develop rules that deal as sensitively as possible with the marketplace and give the public some assurance of fairness," he said.
Many details must still be resolved, however. The most difficult will be deciding on the benchmark prices for a "competitive tier" of basic cable service, because cable systems package their services in many different ways. Under the Federal cable law passed in 1984, "basic service" is any cable service that includes the re-transmission of broadcast television stations.

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DECISION;
U.S. AND PARTNERS IN ACCORD ON AID TO SOVIET ECONOMY

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The international community today swung behind President Bush's plan to help revamp the Soviet economy, but the United States continued to insist that Moscow make profound changes before it gets any money from international lending institutions.
The plan calls for a Special Association status for the Soviet Union in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, but stops short of giving Moscow the full membership it needs to draw on the institutions' financial resources. 
 The two Washington-based organizations would become deeply involved in the transformation of the world's second largest economy from a command to a market based one. A senior American trade offical said the situation "could evolve toward full membership."
 
Compromise by Brady
 The proposal, drawn up by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and discussed with his counterparts from the leading industrialized nations before the President announced it on Wednesday, is a compromise resulting from talks at the economic summit meeting in Houston in July.
President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany had pressed for immediate membership, and flows of money from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to Moscow. President Bush had argued that the money might be wasted if it were disbursed before the Soviets reforms were much further along.
President Bush was also sensitive to criticism from conservative Republicans who are doubtful about the prospects for change in the Soviet Union and have been hostile to the idea of international assistance to Moscow.
 
Broad Range of Advice
 Under the compromise, the two institutions would coordinate outside technical and financial assistance and provide broad advice on matters like financial and exchange-rate policies and ways to make fundamental changes in the transportation and energy sectors.
The agencies would also establish a permanent presence in Moscow, with the fund conducting annual reviews of the Soviet economy as it does now for its 154 member countries.
The senior American Treasury official who spoke on the condition of anonymity called the plan "a calibrated way forward" to integrating the Soviet economy with the world economy.
The official added: "It reflects the unique circumstances we find today, a Soviet Union that clearly is struggling to move down the path of political and economic reform, a country that has a vast economic potential, but at this time has vast economic problems, and a country that is interested in re-engaging in the broader world economy. We want to help them find a pragmatic way forward in that re-engagement."
 
Support by Foreign Officials
 Despite the differing views that were expressed in Houston, most foreign officials said they could support this new approach.
"Every move to bring the Soviet Union closer to these international banking organizations, accelerating the process of integrating the Soviets into the world's free-market economy, is very welcome," said Hans-Henning Horstmann, spokesman at the German Embassy.
Lionel Majeste-Larrouy, press counselor at the French Embassy, said that while his Government had not formally responded, "We are very much in favor of that and will express our satisfaction."
A Japanese Embassy press counselor, Hideaki Ueda, said his Government supported the initiative, but noted that it was uncertain to what extent the Soviet authorities would provide bank and fund technical teams with the information they need.
 
Other Points of Friction
 There could be other points of friction as the two institutions play a greater management role in Moscow. In the past many member governments have objected to recommendations for economic austerity, especially from the fund, arguing that such advice ignores political realities.
The fund, for example, traditionally recommends cuts in consumer and other subsidies. In some countries, for example, in Egypt in the late 1970's and in the Dominican Republic in the mid-1980's, those cuts have led to angry street marches and other demonstrations.
But Soviet officials regard the move positively. Anatoly F. Dobrynin, a consultant to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Soviet Ambassador to Washington in much of the postwar era, told a luncheon here that his Government was "in favor of the closest possible cooperation" with the two organizations. But he added: "How it will be done is not quite clear."
 
'Half Mystery, Half Reality'
 He noted that to most of his countrymen, the bank and the fund "are still rather half mystery, half reality."
The International Monetary Fund helps countries deal with short-term imbalances in their foreign accounts. The World Bank makes longer-term loans to strengthen sectors of an economy by building dams, fertilizer plants, irrigation works, ports, highways and other such projects.
American and international officials said that they expected the plan to be considered early in the new year by the boards of the two organizations and that it might be in operation by the time the two organizations hold their April meetings in Washington.
The proposal was made just a week before the bank and the fund, along with the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Develoment, are to submit a report to leaders of industrialized countries on ways the institutions can help the Soviet Union.
 
To Assess Soviet Economy
 The officials at the Houston meeting requested the report in the hope of ending the conflict over Soviet membership in the bank and the fund. The initiative by President Bush and Mr. Brady will now somewhat upstages that report, which is being prepared chiefly by the fund.
The report is expected to provide a comprehensive and timely assessment of the Soviet economy, and according to the American Treasury official, "we think it will provide a firm base for the Soviets to consider their own reform efforts and for us to consider the best ways to support those reform efforts."
American officials say they believe the international aid should help President Gorbachev politically and send signals to the private sectors to become more engaged in the Soviet economy.
 
Repatriation of Capital
 A bilateral trade agreement that has already been concluded and investment and tax agreements that are now being negotiated are expected to reassure the private sector, convincing it to "re-engage," the American Treasury official said.
The agreements would provide assurances to the business community on matters like repatriation of capital and rules on expropriatiion.
In an interview with Fortune Magazine published today, Mr. Gorbachev urged American businesses to make big investments in his country.
"I think the potential is tremendous for both of us," he said. "Our economies are so enormous that they need each other. They need to cooperate."

HEADLINE: In Korea Talks, Still a Gulf of Distrust

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Three months ago, North and South Korea began a series of high-level talks, cautious but hopeful about airing their differences politely and reducing tensions that have kept them in a state of hostility since the Korean War ended in 1953.
 But as the third round of discussions adjourn today, the gulf of suspicion between Seoul and Pyongyang seemed as wide as ever, perhaps even wider, with each nation accusing the other of using the talks for subversion instead of understanding. 
 The Prime Ministers of North and South Korea did agree to try again at another meeting in Pyongyang in late February. But spokesmen for both seem to be saying the talks would continue primarily because there have been such high hopes and neither side wants to be blamed for ending them.
The North Korean spokesman, Ahn Byung Soo, said, "We don't even know in which direction this discussion is heading," adding that the latest session was "a step backward." Yet when asked if it was time to give up, he replied, "We must never do anything to break up these talks."
The South Korean spokesman, Lim Dong Won, countered by lamenting the two sides' failure to overcome their "deep barrier of mistrust," and he accused the Communists of "slander and vilification against the South."
 
Next Talks in February
 The North Korean delegation is to return to Pyongyang on Friday. As they prepared to leave, the common theme of both sides was that the talks proved that they were still deeply suspicious of each other's intentions, frozen in the thinking of the cold war and using the negotiating table as a forum to score old propaganda points.
Doubts were also raised about the next round of talks, scheduled for Feb. 25 to 28, because that is around the time for the annual joint military exercises between the United States and South Korea.
The exercises this year are certain to be curtailed because of the Persian Gulf situation and American budgetary constraints. But many experts think that North Korea could use the exercises as an excuse to cancel or postpone the talks while blaming the South.
Ostensibly the main focus of the stalemate was the two sides' failure to agree to a "declaration of nonagression." They narrowed their differences on the form of a possible document but not the substance and broke up accusing each other of insincerity.
The difference stemmed from North Korea's insistence on an immediate signing of such a declaration while South Korea seeks first to undertake "confidence-building measures" like economic exchanges, cultural and family visits and small-scale sharing of military information.
 
Aggressive Behavior Cited
 The difference between the two approaches may seem minor but actually they underscore the nature of the two sides' lingering fears about each other's intentions.
South Korean officials say, for instance, that North Korea had never changed its attitude or behavior in the last decade, when it carried out bombings and assassinations against the South and maintained large tunnels under the demilitarized zone for a potential invasion.
These officials add that if Seoul agrees to a seemingly innocuous declaration of nonagression, North Korea will use it as a propaganda tool to undermine the Seoul Government's legitimacy and demand expulsion of American troops from Korea.
Such a campaign, they fear, might be effective among left-leaning South Korean dissidents with whom Pyongyang has long made common cause.
South Korean diplomats thus now say they think North Korea will stay with the talks because it wants to score points during the coming political season in what Pyongyang has long called its "united front" with radicals seeking to overthrow the Seoul Government.
North Korea made its own phobias more clear this week as well, with officials from Pyongyang declaring that they viewed South Korea's desire for cultural and economic exchanges and family reunions not as harmless gestures, but as a ploy to undermine their own Communist system.
While outsiders may view the example of East and West Germany uniting as an inspiration, North Korea appears to have taken umbrage, warning that it will not be "eaten up" by its economically formidable capitalist neighbor.
A tone of near xenophobia crept into North Korea's statements, as officials denounced President Roh Tae Woo for currying favor with China, the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe -- one-time allies of Pyongyang -- in a bid to undermine what it proudly regards as a credo of self-reliance.
It was, in any case, obvious that a special role was being played in these talks by four nations that are major regional powers -- the United States, the Soviet Union, China and Japan.
These countries make it clear that they are increasingly impatient with the insistence by North and South Korea on maintaining northeast Asia as the world's last relic of cold war confrontation. Each is prodding the two countries to be reasonable in the talks.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Poll Finds Americans Divided On Sanctions or Force in Gulf

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Americans are almost evenly divided over whether the United States should take military action or give sanctions more time if Iraq does not withdraw from Kuwait by the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations Security Council, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.
Americans are skeptical of anything described simply as a compromise with President Saddam Hussein, according to the Times/CBS News survey, but there are indications from other surveys that Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, followed by concessions to Iraq on Kuwaiti oil or territory, would be favorably greeted by Americans. 
 A total of 1,044 adults were questioned for the poll by telephone from Sunday through Tuesday, just as Iraq released the Americans and others who had been held hostage since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
The poll, and several other recent surveys of American public opinion on the gulf confrontation, suggest that the decision of perhaps one of five Americans on whether to support a war would be heavily influenced by the specific circumstances at the moment of conflict.
Frank Newport, editor in chief of the Gallup Report, said the wording of survey questions could produce a swing of as much as 20 percentage points in support for war, from the low 40's to the mid-60's.
A bare majority in other polls say they would support war when they are offered no alternative policy, but support for war decreases when the option of maintaining economic sanctions is included.
Support for war increases when the role of the United Nations is emphasized, Mr. Newport said.
"Bush will face a divided public if in fact we go to war," said Mr. Newport, "There is by no means a consensus. It depends on the circumstances and to some degree of the spin put on the situation."
About 40 percent of the country seems ready to support war under most circumstances, and about a third are against it under most circumstances, several recent polls show.
 
Feelings of Crucial Group
 Peter Hart, a Democratic poll taker, said there was a crucial group in the middle. About one in five Americans, he said, express support for military action but prefer that the Bush Adminstration find a peaceful alternative that could include concessions on oil and territory after an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.
"It's not the rush to war," said Mr. Hart. "We can do other things." The group willing to support war but preferring negotiation tends to be younger, and made up more of Republicans and political independents, Mr. Hart said.
Blacks, Democrats and women, particularly young women, are the most opposed to war under any circumstances.
Based on statistical sampling theory, the Times/CBS News survey's findings should generally be within three percentage points, plus or minus, of what the poll takers would have found if they had tried to survey all Americans.
 
Strong Antipathy to Hussein
 An emerging poltical problem for President Bush in the gulf confrontation may well be his overwhelming success in convincing Americans that Saddam Hussein himself is at the core of the problem.
While the country is divided over whether to go to war, 8 out of 10 Americans agree with the suggestion that the crisis in the Persian Gulf will continue until President Hussein, whom President Bush has compared to Hitler, is removed from power -- an end not likely to be achieved short of war.
This finding harkens back to Walter Lippmann's observation in 1955 that American public opinion on war and peace is often out of sync with what he called "objective developments."
Americans are slow to rouse against a foreign threat, he said, and "to overcome this inertia the enemy had to be portrayed as evil incarnate."
But then opinion swings too far, he continued, looking back toward the world wars, and "as a result of this impasssioned nonsense, public opinion became so envenomed that the people would not countenance a workable peace."
American reaction to potential developments in the Persian Gulf seems heavily influenced by how those developments are portrayed.
 
Varied Questions on Issue
 The Times/CBS News Poll asked whether the United States should negotiate a compromise with Saddam Hussein or "stick to its original demand that Iraq leave Kuwait entirely." Asked this way, 6 out of 10 said the United States should stick to its original demand.
But the Gallup Organization, in a poll last week for Newsweek, put the question differently.
"Suppose Iraq withdraws from Kuwait, the former government is restored and later the Arab countries work out an agreement to meet some of Iraq's demands for territory," the question asked. Nearly 7 out of 10 said that would be a success for United States policy.
 
Poll With Similar Pattern
 A similiar pattern emerged on the question of whether the United States should go to war to drive Iraq out of Kuwait after the Jan. 15 deadline.
A poll for NBC News and The Wall Street Journal, conducted virtually at the same time as the latest Times/CBS News Poll, found 54 percent in favor when asked simply if the United States should go to war against Iraq if Iraq did not withdraw its troops from Kuwait by the deadline. Thirty-four percent were opposed to war.
But the Times/CBS News Poll asked the question differently, adding the option of waiting longer to see if the trade embargo and other economic sanctions worked. Offered that choice, 45 percent said the United States should start military actions and 48 percent said it should wait to see if sanctions worked.
 
Larger Swing Reported
 The Gallup Organization, in its poll for Newsweek, recorded an even larger swing. About 56 percent said United States forces should engage in combat if Iraq refused to leave Kuwait and restore its former government.
But two questions later on the same poll they were asked if President Bush should begin military action soon after the Jan. 15 deadline or wait longer to see if economic and diplomatic sanctions were effective.
Forty-one percent said begin military actions and 53 percent said wait longer, a swing of about one in six Americans away from military action when nonviolent pressure was offered as an option.
With the budget debacle and the midterm election behind him, President Bush's overall standing improved. Some 61 percent said they approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling his job, up from 55 percent in November and 52 percent in October.
Mr. Bush's standing improved in several more specific areas as well.
Approval of his handling of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait increased to 57 percent, from 50 percent in November. Half of the public said they thought Mr. Bush had explained the situation in the Middle East well enough, up from 41 percent who said so in November.
There was somewhat greater optimism that war could be avoidided.
Forty-four percent said they believed the situation would be resolved without fighting, up from 36 percent in November, just after the President dispatched thousands of additional troops to the gulf.
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 9 to 11 with 1,044 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education. In theory, in 19 of 20 cases the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus nine percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Move Against Minority Aid Is Debated

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
A sense of disbelief and in some cases defiance gripped colleges and major education associations throughout the nation yesterday, after it was learned earlier this week that the Department of Education was considering scholarships granted only to minority student to be illegal.
In Washington, where many of the larger education organizations are, the morning was busy as meetings were called and agendas hastily amended to discuss what many are calling an assault on efforts to include more minority students in higher education. But in other quarters the Education Department's reversal on minority scholarships was applauded. 
 "It's a tough issue that needs to be discussed openly and frankly," said Steven M. Cahn, provost and professor of philosophy at The Graduate School of The City University of New York. "If anyone has a quick answer, they are oversimplifying it."
The policy change, disclosed by an Assistant Secretary at the Education Department, came as a surprise to top White House officials, who took it under review. Presidential aides said today that a White House staff meeting was marked by strong debate on whether to accept the regulation.
Six influential education organizations representing 3,000 public and private colleges and universities met yesterday and struggled to measure the implications that banning scholarships for minority students might have on their institutions.
 
'Great Deal of Confusion'
 "Right now there is a great deal of confusion," said Allan Ostar, president of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities, who attended that meeting. "We need a legal clarification, and we've got to provide some guidance to our institutions."
Like scores of education experts contacted yesterday, Mr. Ostar said he did not know how many minority scholarships or students could potentially be affected by the decision. A spokesman for a respected Eastern university who asked not to be identified said hundreds of programs at his college alone might have to be reviewed.
Mr. Ostar said his group, which meets twice a month, was discussing writing a letter of concern to President Bush on the matter. He said it was also considering asking Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to intervene.
In the meantime, a former Assistant Secretary of Education, David Tatel, was preparing a white paper on behalf of the organizations, analyzing the Education Department's new position on minority college aid, Mr. Ostar said.
"We are telling our members to keep their powder dry and don't panic," he said.
 
Many Colleges Use Need Only
 At many institutions, including most of the Ivy League universities, scholarship assistance to undergraduates is based solely on financial need.
At some colleges and universities, such aid is supplemented by outside fellowships or grants, a great many of them worth $1,000 or less. And a few, like DePaul University in Chicago, have a tuition grant program based on financial need but available only to minority students.
The announcement of a new intention to apply Federal anti-discrimination laws to minority scholarships arose after the Department of Education learned that organizers of the Fiesta Bowl, a Jan. 1 college football game to be played in Tempe, Ariz., were offering a $100,000 scholarship fund for minority students to the two universities that participate in the bowl.
Michael L. Williams, Assistant Secretary of Education for Civil Rights, said in an interview on Tuesday that to give "race-exclusive" scholarships or ones based on ethnic origin was illegal because it would be discriminatory. He said institutions that issue such scholarships could lose their Federal financing.
 
Surprise and Strong Reactions
 Word of Mr. Williams's position caused strong reactions in academia and in Washington. On Wednesday, Lauro F. Cavazos resigned as Secretary of Education, apparently under pressure from President Bush's advisers, and perhaps in part because Mr. Cavazos had voiced doubts about Mr. Williams's position.
"This caught everyone by surprise," said Timothy Christensen, associate director for research and marketing for the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators. "There were no leaks or no advance warning that this was going to come out."
One result, he said, was that administrators across the country have been calling their lawyers for help and wondering what would become of decades of efforts with programs to help more minority students attend college.
At the University of Miami, which has 50 black scholarship students but no members of other minority groups on minority scholarships, the provost, Louis Glaser, said: "The law is the law. We will abide by it. But institutionally and personally we have always believed in giving help to minorities."
Tuition is $13,000 a year, and 60 percent of the college's 8,500 undergraduates receive some form of financial aid.
"As a private institution, our tuition is very high," Dr. Glaser said. "It will mean fewer minority students will attend the university, and minorities are already grossly underrepresented in the professional world."
He said the university would probably challenge the Department of Education's policy. Meanwhile, the university's scholarship obligations to minority students would be honored, he indicated.
"It would be unconscionable to cast out students to whom we have promised four years of support," Dr. Glaser said.
At the University of Pennsylvania, Ralph R. Smith, a professor of law, said: "It's obscene to use civil rights laws to support the exclusion of minority students from higher education."
"I see this as a continuation of the Bush Administration's policy of appeasement to the far right ideologues," Professor Smith said.
He accused the Administration of attempting to manipulate white Americans' fears as they see an economic downturn and a deterioration of their standard of living. People are being offered a "simplistic explanation that minority scholarships, welfare and quotas are to blame," he said. "It's not true."
Officials at many other universities expressed concern.
"For years colleges and universities have been making a concerted effort to increase the ranks of minority students and to make sure that they are funded at a level that will allow them to succeed academically," said John Schoultz, director of financial aid for DePaul. "All of a sudden the Government says you can't do that. It seems really contradictory."
Florida Atlantic University, a college in Boca Raton, Fla., with predominantly white students, has nine scholarships open only to blacks, Americans Indians or Hispanic students, officials said. Some were created to satisfy a 1978 Federal consent decree ordering the school to desegregate its student body. Such use of scholarships would still be permitted under Mr. Williams's new policy, he said Wednesday.
 
Minority Scholarships Praised
 But the university's president, Anthony J. Catanese, said he planned to continue using them even when the university has increased the number of minority students to the point where the Federal order ceases to require the scholarships. He added that the university intended to continue the scholarships despite the new policy "because it is the right thing to do."
"These scholarships have worked," said Dr. Catanese, noting that minority students now account for about 10 percent of the institution's 13,000 students. "Without them we never would have been able to attract minority students to our campus."
The scholarships were the subject of a complaint filed by the Washington Legal Foundation with the Education Department. The complaint challenged Florida Atlantic's minority scholarships as "reverse discrimination."

HEADLINE: Sounds Around Town

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS

 BODY:
Chamber Improvisations
Arcado, Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street, Manhattan, (212) 219-3055. One of the best small ensembles to come out of the late 1980's, Arcado works like a chamber group, but includes intense improvisations. The members -- Mark Dresser on bass, Mark Feldman on violin, Hank Roberts on cello -- swoop in and out of written sections that call to mind European classical composing as well as all sorts of other sources. The improvisations are American, and the group has a spectacular blend. The show tomorrow night starts at 9; tickets are $10.
 
A Gospel Bargain
 "Gospel, Africa and the Blues," S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, Manhattan, (212) 243-4940. A triple bill built for a recession: for $15, a listener gets the deep gospel fervor of Clarence Fountain and the Five Blind Boys, the blues-based secular eclecticism of the Holmes Brothers, and the soft folk of the Ugandan singer Samite. Mr. Fountain is a certified house rocker; the Holmes Brothers toss be-bop lines played on pedal steel guitar into the gospel harmonies and blues and soul songs, and Samite uses acoustic instruments to create a gentle mood. The show on Sunday night starts at 8.
 
Virtuoso With Quirks
Dorothy Donegan, Fortune Garden Pavilion, 209 East 49th Street in Manhattan, (212) 753-0101. Dorothy Donegan is one of jazz's great eccentrics, a musician fearless when it comes to improvising with tunes; she'll play a European classical run in the middle of a Duke Ellington piece, or throw in some boogie-woogie to mix things up. She's also a virtuoso, so her eclecticism is neither glib nor a mask. She's one of jazz's great undiscovered minds, and when she turns to glare at the audience, she's a terrific comedian as well. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 8, 9:30 and 11; Sunday's shows are at 7, 8:30 and 10 P.M. THere is no cover charge; the minimum charge is $2o for the first two sets and $15 for the third set.

HEADLINE: Full-Size Sedan Shown by Ford

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The Ford Motro Company today displayed its 1992 Ford Crown Victoria sedan, part of a new line of full-size cars.
Ford expects annual sales of 100,000 Crown Victorias, which have eight-cylinder engines, rear-wheel drive and seating for six.
"The Crown Victoria is the first major redesign of Ford's full-size, four-door family sedan since 1979," said Thomas Wagner, general manager of Ford division.
No price has been announced for the redesigned car. The 1991 model has a base price of about $18,000.
Full-size cars are among the most highly profitable vehicles sold in North America. Last month, Ford displayed the Crown Victoria's sister car, the Mercury Grand Marquis. Both are scheduled to begin production in Canada next month and will go on sales this spring.
Mr. Wagner said the fuel economy and performance of the new Crown Victoria have been improved by a 4.6-liter V-8 engine. The car has driver-and optional passenger-side airbags and antilock brakes.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF: LAST U.S. FLIGHT OF HOSTAGES, ENVOY ABOARD, GETS TO WEST;
Signal From Saudis

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 13

 BODY:
In an effort to signal that it will accept nothing short of total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia has informed Algeria that a visit by its President, Chadli Benjedid, will serve no useful purpose unless President Saddam Hussein accepts the principle of total and unconditional withdrawal.
"He has not exactly been disinvited," an Arab official said. "He has simply been told that a visit to Riyadh would be useless and would encourage false hopes of a compromise if Iraq is not prepared to comply with the will of the international community and its resolution." 
 Mr. Benjedid was in Teheran tonight after visiting Amman and Baghdad in an effort to find a peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis before the Jan. 15 deadline authorizing United Nations member states to use force to secure Iraq's withdrawal. The Algerian leader is also scheduled to visit Oman.
Arab mediation has been viewed by Arab diplomats in the region and by some American officials in Washington as the best hope of avoiding a military confrontation. President Bush announced on Nov. 30 that he was inviting the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, to Washington for direct talks and was prepared to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to Baghdad. But the two governments continue to bicker over the timing of the meetings.
In a speech on Sunday, King Hussein of Jordan praised the Bush Administration for what he called the end of the "embargo on dialogue."
But there appears to be widespread discontent among Saudi, Egyptian and Syrian officials and other Arab members of the anti-Iraq coalition, which does not include Jordan, about Mr. Bush's failure to discuss his initiative before making it public.
The official, who asked not to be identified, said that the prospect of direct dialogue might have inadvertently increased the chance of war by leading Saddam Hussein to think that by "hanging tough and talking and talking, he can come out of this with a face-saver."
"I'm persuaded that Saddam believes that the alliance is going to back down," the official said, "that Saddam Hussein and King Hussein have misread the signals."
But this miscalculation could be dangerous, the official warned. "If he believes that the alliance against him will back down," he said of Mr. Hussein. "He won't give an inch."
 
 Hussein Says He Wants Peace
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 13 (AP) -- President Saddam Hussein said today that his country wanted peace but that it would gladly wage war rather than permit foreign domination of Arab oil or land.
"We want peace, endeavor to achieve it, and work to reach a point where no one of us brandishes his sword against the other," Mr. Hussein said in remarks carried by the official Iraqi press agency. "But if the enemies want to push affairs to a military duel, then by God's help we would win and would walk over their corpses and tread on their heads."
The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Mr. Hussein told his Cabinet that Iraq's enemies did not want it to remain an economic, military or political power because they believe it is a danger they should not permit in the region.

HEADLINE: Remember the Refuseniks?

 BODY:
Another foreign fantasy has erupted into fact. Two fantasies, actually, and their realization warrants reflection. In 1974, a handful of brave Soviet Jews haunted foreign embassies in Moscow hoping for exit visas. Refuseniks, they were called; the Brezhnev Government wouldn't let them out. 
 Who could have dreamed that one day, Soviet Jews by the thousands would be pouring into tents in Israel? And who would have imagined that the United States and the Soviet Union, after their harsh confrontation over the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, would stand allied against a common adversary in the Middle East?
Yet there stood President Bush Wednesday announcing his waiver of the Jackson-Vanik amendment restricting aid to the Soviet Union -- just as the flood of Soviet emigres to Israel is transforming Soviet-Israeli relations. The pace of change in the post-cold-war world is accelerating.
The 1974 amendment sponsored by Senator Henry Jackson of Washington and Representative Charles Vanik of Ohio, both Democrats, barred favorable trade treatment for Communist countries unless they made it easier for dissidents to leave. Jackson-Vanik eventually became the very symbol of a cold war turning colder.
By waiving Jackson-Vanik, Mr. Bush has now cleared the way for $1 billion in credits to Moscow to supply its people with food. The aid will demonstrate American concern to the Soviet people, beset by shortages. That can only advance a long-lasting thaw in U.S.-Soviet relations.
Israeli-Soviet relations are breaking through the permafrost, too. Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, publicly backs food aid for the Soviet people, and the Jewish Agency is sending 25 tons of fruit, vegetables and powdered milk.
Jackson-Vanik was never more than an irritant, and hardly a spur to emigration. The flow of Soviet emigres rose and fell with the ups and downs in U.S.-Soviet relations. In 1972, with the signing of SALT I, 32,000 Soviet Jews were allowed out. In 1974, when Jackson-Vanik was voted, departures fell to 21,000, then to 13,000 in 1975.
With the 1978 wheat deal, the outflow jumped to 29,000, and with the 1979 strategic arms treaty, to 51,000. Then came the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and an American wheat embargo; the number dropped again, to 21,000.
With the renewed arms race of the Reagan Administration, it plummeted to less than 1,000. But after the 1986 Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting in Reykjavik the number rose again, to 8,000 in 1988, 71,000 in 1989 and an astounding 150,000 or more this year.
Unlike the refuseniks of 1974, many of today's Soviet emigres are Jewish in name only and regard Israel as a refuge from the reeling Soviet economy and rising ethnic tension. And many more are likely to leave; the Soviet Government has proposed a law easing emigration generally.
Repeal of Jackson-Vanik need not await its enactment. Indeed, that law now has European neighbors worried about a rush to the exits by Soviet citizens. Western aid, if it spurs Moscow's economic reforms, could make the Soviet Union more habitable for all its people, including Soviet Jews. Now, in 1990, that seems a possible dream.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
BOC Group Names New Chief Executive

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The BOC Group, an international producer of industrial gas and health-care products, said yesterday that it had named Patrick Rich to be chief executive, succeeding Richard V. Giordano.
Mr. Rich, 59 years old, is currently deputy chairman of the company, whose world headquarters is in Windlesham, England. Its United States operations are based in Murray Hill, N.J. 
 He will succeed Mr. Giordano on Jan. 1 as chief executive. The company said that Mr. Giordano, 58, would continue as chairman for a year before retiring, and that Mr. Rich would then succeed him in that post, too.
In 1978, Mr. Giordano was chief executive of Airco, an industrial gas company in the United States in which BOC had a 35 percent stake. When BOC, formerly the British Oxygen Company, sought all of the company, Mr. Giordano resisted, but BOC won. Rather than losing his job, Mr. Giordano was kept on and made managing director of BOC in 1979. He was named chairman in 1984.
In October, a survey by Charterhouse, a British merchant banking company, ranked him seventh in earnings, with an annual salary of $1.7 million, among Americans running British companies.
In yesterday's announcement, Mr. Giordano did not state why he wished to retire, except to say he had hoped to do so at the end of last year and had stayed on for business reasons.
Mr. Rich, who is based in England, has a cosmopolitan background. Born in Strasbourg, France, he has degrees in political science, European studies and law from Strasbourg University. He was also a Fulbright scholar, studying economics at Harvard. In addition to French and English, he is fluent in German, Spanish, Italian and Portuguese.
After service in Algeria with a French paratroop brigade, he took a job in Canada at Alcan Aluminum Ltd. as a project analyst and after 18 months in Montreal was transferred to Guinea to run an Alcan project.
His next stop was London, and in 1965 he was transferred to South America and then Spain. Back in Canada in 1976, he joined the Alcan board and continued his move upward at the company, taking six months out in 1982 to become an executive in residence at the Harvard Business School.
Mr. Rich left Alcan in 1986 to head Societe Generale de Surveillance Holding S.A., a Geneva-based service company. In 1983, he was named a director of the BOC Group, and he joined BOC full time in April this year as deputy chairman.

HEADLINE: Frank Bourgin, 80, Belatedly Honored Historian

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Frank P. Bourgin, a former Federal official whose received his doctoral degree in 1988, 44 years after it had been denied, died Wednesday at Chevy Chase House, a retirement home in Washington. He was 80 years old.
Mr. Bourgin died of pancreatic cancer, his brother, Simon, of Washington, said. 
 In 1944 Mr. Bourgin's academic career at the University of Chicago was interrupted when his doctoral dissertation was rejected by a faculty committee. The dissertation rebutted the idea that President Franklin D. Roosevelt's social reform programs were a departure from the intentions of the founding fathers. Mr. Bourgin argued that the framers of the Constitution were committed to government intervention for development, a view that other historians have since come to share.
Abandoning his academic career in political science, Mr. Bourgin became wartime historian for the Army quartermaster office in Chicago, and operated a chain of clothing stores in northern Minnesota. In 1963 he joined the Office of Emergency Management, based in Battle Creek, Mich. From 1970 until his retirement in 1983 Mr. Bourgin was program officer in the Washington office, responsible for preparing emergency plans.
 
High Praise From Schlesinger
 In 1985, with the approach of the Constitution's Bicentennial, he brought his thesis to the attention of Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the historian. Mr. Schlesinger assured him that he was "a true pioneer in the reconstruction of the early economic policy of the republic," and asked the University of Chicago to reconsider his case.
"Even after 45 years," Mr. Schlesinger wrote, his thesis makes "a fresh contribution to the political and economic history of the early republic."
In June 1988, the University of Chicago granted Mr. Bourgin, then 77 years old. his Ph.D. His thesis was published, to warm reviews, as "The Great Challenge: The Myth of Laissez Faire in the Early Years of the Republic" (1989; George Braziller).
Besides his brother, he is survived by two daughters, Marilyn Israel of Minneapolis, and Claudia Sandonato of Southfield, Mich.; and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Jonathan Daniels, 26, Is Killed in Avalanche

 BODY:
Jonathan B. Daniels, a former Wall Street investment banker and a mountain-climbing enthusiast, died on Sunday in an avalanche in the Tatra Mountains on the border between Poland and Czechoslovakia. He was 26 years old and lived in Boston.
Mr. Daniels had been in Warsaw since late November with the Task Force for Company Assistance, a partnership of North American and Polish interests seeking to help Polish industry convert to private ownership in a market economy. Last weekend he was with three other Americans on a climbing trip when the avalanche struck, his family said. His companions were apparently unhurt.
He was born in Boston and graduated in 1986 with highest honors from Dartmouth, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He worked for the Wall Street firms of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Bear Stearns before leaving on a round-the-world mountain-climbing trip 14 months ago. He spent the last year in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Daniels is survived by his father, Belden, and his mother, Pamela, of Boston, and a brother, Andrew, of Watertown, Mass.

HEADLINE: Inflation Fears Depress U.S. Debt Issues

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Renewed inflation fears depressed prices of long-term Treasury debt issues yesterday and ended a week of generally declining interest rates.
Fears that the uptick in inflation would inhibit further moves by the Federal Reserve to ease credit eroded prices of Treasury bills, which are as sensitive to Fed policy moves as bonds are to inflation trends. 
 Treasury bond prices began falling at the opening after Washington reported unexpectedly sharp rises of five-tenths of 1 percent in both the overall and core components of the Producer Price Index for November.
 
Large Declines Cited
 Dealers said the selling would have been even greater except for the large declines in industrial production and the use of factory capacity that the Government also reported. The 1.7 percent drop in industrial output last month was he largest since the decline of 2 percent in December 1982, a time of deep recession.
"Also depressing bond prices was some carry-over profit taking that began Thursday," said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. "What limited the selling, aside from the industrial output and capacity figures, was the realization that much of the jump in November wholesale prices was caused by one-time factors, such as the rises in cars and tobacco product prices."
Mr. Ricchiuto noted that tobacco companies moved up their planned price rises rather than have them coincide with the Federal and other tobacco taxes that are scheduled to go into effect after Jan. 1.
In any case, late trading found the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, being offered at 106 9/32, down 25/32 on the day, after declining as much as a full point, or $10 per $1,000 of face value, early in the session. The long bond's yield climbed to 8.18 percent, from 8.11 percent on Thursday and compared with 8.17 percent a week ago.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8.5's of November 2000, declined by 13/32, at 103 8/32, for a yield of 8.01 percent, unchanged from a week ago. By comparison, the yield on Japan's competitive 10-year long bonds fell to 7.14 percent, from 7.21 percent a week ago, while the yield on the 10-year German long bonds dropped to 8.62 percent from 8.77 percent.
At the short end of the Treasury debt market, the discount rate on 90-day bills rose two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.86 percent; the six-month bills rose by six basis points, to 6.77 percent, and the one-year bills rose four basis points, to 6.65 percent.
Meanwhile, the Fed, which touched off a strong rally in fixed-income debt issues the preceding Friday by easing credit, did not intervene in the money market yesterday. Dealers said the Fed was apparently satisfied that Federal funds traded at 7.25 percent for most of the day before moving up to 7 5/16 percent at the close. The 7.25 percent rate is now perceived to be the Fed's current target for what is considered the bedrock cost of credit: the rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans.
A feature of the corporate debt market was the pricing of an issue of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, through GMAC Grantor Trust 1990-A, of $1.057 billion in pass-through certificates backed by receivables on cars and light trucks. An underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation priced the 8.75 percent certificates, which have an average life of 1.78 years, at 99.59375, to yield 8.443 percent. The issue is rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Sales Abound, but Retailing Lags

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
With the holiday shopping season limping along much more slowly than retailers had hoped, and their hopes fading for a last-minute turnaround, many stores have been forced into the very tactics they swore they would avoid: slashing their prices and advertising sale after sale.
But even that usually reliable recipe does not seem to be working very well. So, with a little more than a week left to Christmas, frustrated merchants across the country have already used up most of their limited bag of tricks to increase buying. 
 "Business is not so hot," said James F. Nordstrom, a co-chairman of Nordstrom Inc. who is known for his plain-spoken candor. "We keep asking ourselves why and have no answers. Our stores seem full of people. They like what they see. But the sales results are less than we hoped."
 
 Big Move by Sears
 Still, Mr. Nordstrom said he saw no reason to change strategy at the Seattle-based fashion chain, which is holding fewer sales than most of its counterparts. He said he plans only to continue to "make our merchandise seem as attractive as we can."
Executives from stores of all stripes have similar laments. As a result, store executives and industry analysts say they doubt whether the final days, including the crucial Dec. 21-23 weekend, will be strong enough to pull the season up over last year.
A big confirmation of how bad sales are came last week when Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, shocked the industry by announcing that it was moving its "after Christmas sale" to before Christmas.
Not all major chains followed Sears, but some did. Store executives and industry analysts say the results have been disappointing.
"The price cutting is stimulating traffic into the sores but the sales results are less than retailers had hoped they would be," said Richard E. Pyle, managing director of Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood, a Minneapolis stock brokerage. "Even the promotions aren't opening the customers' pocketbooks as much as they did last year."
Some retail marketers say they are not surprised, and say that many merchants lack the creativity needed to overcome the slump.
"Constant price cutting is the typical fear strategy," said Wendy Liebmann, a New York retail marketing consultant. "Too many retail executives, knowing that they were heading into a difficult season, adopted a defensive strategy by limiting their stocks and hoping to move them with markdowns, instead of taking creative steps."
 
 Sales Explosion Seen
 A wide spectrum of retailers, from mass merchandisers like Sears to major clothing retailers like J. C. Penney, to higher-priced fashion chains like Nordstrom report that their sales so far this season are running either slightly behind or about the same as last year. And when retail executives say "flat" sales, they are really acknowledging that revenues will be behind last year when adjusted for inflation.
Generally, pessimism appears to be growing, a significant development in an industry known for its almost relentess optimism and often rosy sales forecasts even in very slow economic conditions.
As pervasive as price cutting already is, retailers and analysts say they expect an explosion of sales this coming weekend and the final pre-Christmas weekend.
Retailers have kept their holiday inventories much tighter than in recent years, hoping this time to avoid a barrage of sales. But slow business is causing those stocks to mount, creating another reason to slash prices.
There are exceptions. A few stores that appeal primarily to affluent and fashion-oriented women, like Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's, say business is improving. On the other hand, stores that sell expensive men's clothing, like Paul Stuart and Louis of Boston, report that sales are only equal to last year's, reflecting a deep recession in men's clothing directly related to economic concerns.
 
 Some Latitude in Cuts
 Still, even having to resort to more price cuts than they had hoped might not be a fatal blow to profits, some retail executives said.
One reason is that the markdowns are more often on a narrower range of goods than advertisements make it appear.
And even cutting prices on bread-and-butter items can be done with some latitude. For example, an item may cost a retailer $50 from the supplier. If he sells it for $100, he can easily take off as much as 35 percent from the original selling price and still make a profit. For most stores, it is only when additional markdowns reach 40 percent and more that the profit falls to a critical level.
For all this, stores are trying to maintain full price on goods like top-name sportswear and furnishings, underwear, linens, hosiery, housewares and furniture. Thus the mixture of sale and regular-price merchandise still yields enough of a markup to keep a store's earnings relatively high.
Chief competitors of Sears, like Montgomery Ward, the K Mart Corporation and the J. C. Penney Company said that they did not plan to follow suit at this time, but would monitor the effects of the Sears action.
"Of course, we can't sit still when a big competitor does something like that, but we have already added some categories of merchandise to our price promotions such as apparel and home furnishings," said Ann Raives, Ward's vice president for corporate planning.
At Sears, Matt Howard, senior vice president for marketing of the Merchandising Group, said that the holiday season was running "slightly below our expectations but we are optimistic that the final weekend, with three full shopping days, will make a major difference."
 
 Penney's Sees Decline
 Even though Sears switched to what it calls "everyday low pricing" a few years ago, it is not considered a discount chain like K Mart. Sears's change in policy implied it would need to hold few sales, but analysts said this concept had created some confusion among consumers. Sears officials insist that they plan to continue sales as circumstances warrant.
At J. C. Penney, with headquarters in Dallas, Robert Gill, the vice chairman, said that business was slow. Even with a hoped-for gain in sales of 3 to 5 percent in December, he said, Penney's expected a profit decline in the final quarter.
A spokeswoman for K Mart, based in Troy, Mich., said business was "in line with last year," and that merchandise inventories were in "better shape," a positive factor. "Comparatively," she said, "there's little pressure on us to take a lot of markdowns."
One discount men's wear chain, NBO Stores, says it may have hit on a sales promotion that is working.
"We have a shot at getting at least 10 percent sales jump over last year," said Eugene Kosack, the president and chief executive, "We had originally expected the season to produce a slight decline." He said the key for NBO was a "buy one, get one free" sale. First it was buy one shirt or tie and get one free. Now, Mr. Kosack said, shoppers are responding well to "buy a sports shirt and take home a sweater free."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shoppers yesterday at Macy's Herald Square in Manhattan. Because of poor sales, retailers and analysts are expecting an explosion of sales this weekend and the final pre-Christmas weekend. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed, Gold Rises And Silver Drops Below $4

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday against foreign currencies amid new doubts over whether diplomatic talks between the United States and Iraq would succeed.
Gold was higher, closing up by $2.40 a troy ounce, to $376.70, on the Commodity Exchange.
But silver prices sank below $4 an ounce on the lack of decisive Persian Gulf moves and a large selloff by institutional investors. Over the last few days, silver has traded at the lowest price levels in 16 years. 
 The dollar strengthened as traders anticipated Middle East tough talk from President Bush at a news conference, but the currency eased in value when the Bush comments showed he was not yet ready to scrap the diplomacy option. Mr. Bush scolded President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for failing to agree on a date for the diplomatic trip to Baghdad by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
"The dollar came off a little bit after over-anticipating," said Francoise Soares-Kemp, manager of the corporate advisory desk at Credit Suisse in New York. "Bush was tough, but he didn't declare war in the next 24 hours."
Over all, the dollar gained against the yen, which has generally weakened on Mideast war fears because Japan's economy is so dependent on imported oil. The dollar closed at 132.85 yen in New York, up from late Thursday's 132.17. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.57 yen, to a closing 131.87 yen and, later in London, it was quoted at 132.85 yen.
Jitters in Eastern Europe, particularly unrest in Albania, helped the dollar against European currencies.
The dollar moved slightly higher against the German mark, closing at 1.4825 marks compared with late Thursday's 1.4790. But the dollar also strengthened against the British pound in New York, with sterling weakening to $1.9370 from late Thursday's $1.9450.
Brokers said the dollar also got support from the rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for November, when an increase of only one-tenth was expected. The poor performance suggested the Federal Reserve might have less room to lower interest rates, traders said. Higher interest rates generally make a currency more attractive.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's prices, included: 1.2735 Swiss francs, up from 1.2660; 5.0405 French francs, up from 5.0255; 1,119.75 Italian lire, up from 1,115.25, and 1.1583 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1607.
Gold rose in New York, closing up by $2.40 a troy ounce, to $376.70, on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $375.75, up $2.40 from late Thursday.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Endorses Trump's Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump got approval yesterday from New Jersey regulators for a deal to rescue the Taj Mahal casino, and people close to the Trump Organization said he might surprise the bondholders of another of his Atlantic City casinos, Trump's Castle, by making an $18.4 million payment due today.
The Trump Organization is believed to be sitting on millions in cash from earnings of its various properties. The interest and principal payments of many of these operations were suspended or reduced as part of a bank loan package that rescued the financier last summer. 
 If the $18.4 million payment is made, it will be a departure from the recent rounds of crisis deal-making that have entangled the developer much of the year. The first round of crisis talks began in the spring, when Mr. Trump informed his bankers that he could not make a $43 million interest payment on the Castle bonds. This time, Mr. Trump has until Monday to make the Castle payment because the due date falls on a weekend. If he fails to make the payment on Monday, he will have a 10-day grace period before the Castle can be forced to seek bankruptcy protection.
Last evening the New Jersey Casino Control Commission approved a slightly modified version of the plan agreed to last month by Mr. Trump and holders of $675 million of high-yield, "junk bonds" he sold to finance the completion of his extravagant Taj Mahal casino on Atlantic City's Boardwalk. Among the changes in the plan, Mr. Trump will now have an additional year for the bonds to mature instead of the additional two years granted initially.
Last month, Mr. Trump, who could not make a $47.3 million payment on his Taj Mahal bonds, narrowly escaped having that casino forced into bankruptcy by making a deal with bondholders. As part of the deal, he had to give up 50 percent of his equity and could eventually lose control if the casino fails to meet certain earnings projections. In exchange, bondholders reduced the interest rate on the bonds, extended their maturity, and agreed to return 30 percent of the equity they got in the deal if the casino manages to pay the original 14 percent interest rate over the next decade.
Among the other changes brought about by the commission, Mr. Trump will lose the ability to get back 30 percent of the equity in the Taj if for any reason his bankers foreclose on the property. In that event, the interest rate on the bonds would revert to the original 14 percent, the bondholders would automatically get control of the company and they would be given the right to terminate Mr. Trump's management contract.
On Monday about $16 million in interest payments is also due on about $250 million of high-yield bonds sold to finance the Trump Plaza casino in Atlantic City. Trump Plaza bondholders largely expect that $16 million payment to be made and unlike the Castle bondholders they have not set up a creditors' committee or retained legal and financial counsel.
People familiar with the Castle bondholders' committee said the bondholders had had almost no substantive negotiations with Trump Organization executives and the rudimentary financial reviews that are common in these situations have not yet been completed. Calls to representatives of several Castle bondholders were not returned.

HEADLINE: Drink-Box Makers Fighting Back

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Faced with one statewide ban and the prospect of others, the companies that make the increasingly popular containers known as drink boxes are moving to counter criticism that the containers cannot easily be recycled.
The airtight boxes, which can preserve liquids for as long as six to nine months without refrigeration and have become a staple for products like Gatorade, Mott's apple juice and Hawaiian Punch, are made of layers of paper, plastic and aluminum. Environmentalists favor packages made of a single material, like aluminum, glass or plastic, over multilayer containers because there are no dissimilar materials to be separated before recycling. And with aluminum and glass, the material can be made again into containers, whereas the recycled drink boxes are put to more limited uses, like plastic lumber.
 
Wrapping Product in Flag
 But in newspaper advertisements, and in pilot recycling programs in Rhode Island and California, the industry producing the boxes, known as aseptic packages, has tried to make the case that they are environmentally benign. The industry has even wrapped its product in the flag, noting that American troops in Saudi Arabia are drinking their milk from such boxes. 
 The aseptic-packaging industry's actions are only the latest example of an industry trying to defend its market niche by associating itself with recycling. Makers of the plastic foam used to package electronic instruments and McDonald's hamburgers have also set up recycling centers to enhance the environmental image of the material. (Even so, McDonald's recently decided to switch from foam back to paper packaging.) And big consumer-products companies like Procter & Gamble and Lever Brothers are emphasizing the use of recycled plastic in packaging like detergent containers.
Tetra Pak Inc., the largest producer of the boxes, and Combibloc Inc., the other major producer, have been running full-page newspaper advertisements extolling the benefits and environmental compatibility of the packages. One recent one was headlined: "Drink boxes are as easy to recycle as this page." But environmental advocates say that unlike newspapers multimaterial boxes are too complex to be recycled economically without industry subsidies.
The aseptic-box producers' claims are not escaping government scrutiny. Last week, New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Mark Green, filed a complaint against the two major manufacturers, charging that their ads constituted deceptive trade practices. "These companies are unfairly capitalizing on pro-environment consumer sentiment to create the false impression that their products are benign," Mr. Green said in a statement.
 
 Report by Officials
 The claims may also draw the attention of a group of state attorneys general who have been cracking down on misleading environmental claims. The group, which includes New York's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, and nine others, recently issued a report concluding that "environmental claims relating to disposability should not be made unless the advertised disposal option is currently available to consumers in the area in which the product is sold."
Although almost anything can be recycled in theory, environmentally conscious specialists on solid waste say that unless a recycling program was economical, it would probably collapse once subsidies from producers were withdrawn.
The aseptic-packaging industry is sponsoring a variety of pilot recycling projects, said Edward A. Klein, president of the Aseptic Packaging Council and vice president of Tetra Pak. School children in North Kingstown, R.I., are depositing the multilayer boxes into containers that also collect plastic waste. From there packages are shipped to a plant operated by National Waste Technologies in Ronkonkoma, L.I., where they are combined with other plastics and made into artificial wood.
Warren C. Tyler, the president of Combibloc, acknowledged that the Rhode Island program involved a subsidy, but said the Contra Costa program was self-sustaining because of the value of the paper pulp recovered from the boxes and milk cartons. "Those materials are worth $120 a ton when they have been shredded and baled," he said. "And as pulp it sells for $400 a ton."
He characterized the Rhode Island program as "an early demonstration" and said, "We do not see it as a model for the future."
Mr. Klein said the industry expected that the recycling would be economical after an initial period of subsidy. "We hope to demonstrate within six months to a year that the recycling can be conducted on a self-sustaining basis," he said. "We will not abandon this program."
But the aseptic packagers "have drawn a very big conclusion about recycling from a very small demonstration project," said Allen Hershkowitz, a scientist at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "It is very marginal in a commercial sense."
Erica Guttman, an official of Rhode Island's Solid Waste Management Corporation, said the collection effort was mounted this autumn after legislation was proposed to ban aseptic packaging in that state. Earlier this year, Maine adopted such a ban. Environmental advocates said attempts would be made to enact similar bans in other states in 1991.

1. Polyethylene and graphic design: Protective, water-resistent coat keeps package dry and structurally sound. Printing identifies and advertises the contents.
 
2. Paper: Provides stiffness, strength and shape to box.
 
3. Polyethylene: Bonds the paper and aluminum foil.
 
4. Aluminum foil: Forms a barrier against light and oxygen, preventing spoilage and taste change.
 
5. Polyethylene: Primarily bonds aluminum foil to innermost layer.
 
6. Polyethylene: Keeps product from spoiling and leaking, prevents contamination. (Source: Aseptic Packaging Council
