HEADLINE: Albany Plan Focuses on Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 14

 BODY:
While differing in many specifics from the plan outlined by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last month, the sweeping deficit-closing measure approved by the State Legislature early today achieves the same broad objectives he laid out.
It focuses mainly on the spending side of New York's budget, not on new taxes or borrowing, to bridge what is a $1 billion chasm between the state's projected revenues and its expenditures this year. In fact, the Legislature adopted by far the largest package of midyear spending cuts in the state's history, and many fiscal monitors praised the Governor and lawmakers today for showing such discipline. 
 The plan also avoids many of the one-shot, cash-generating budget manipulations that have raised credit analysts' eyebrows in the past, although it did contain one controversial provision: State employees will be required to defer a week's pay now, in return for an extra week's pay at their prevailing salary when they retire.
But despite lawmakers' general belt-tightening, the measure enacted shortly after 4 A.M. today may be only a prelude to an even more painful period of budget cutting in Albany. One lawmaker described it as a warm-up drill for the coming fiscal year's budget, which some officials say may have a deficit of up to $3 billion.
 
'Next Year Will Be Wide Open'
 And many of those who will feel the impact of today's cuts most severely -- school districts, hospitals, local governments and some private social-service organizations -- could well endure worse cuts next year, officials said today. That is especially true for New York City, which is mired in its own budget problems and lost $70 million in school money in today's package.
"This is just the first in a series of difficult decisions," said Carl Carlucci, the secretary of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee. "Next year will be wide open. When the economy was expanding in New York, there was an expansion of services. But when you're in a contracting economy, you have got to look at a contraction in the range of services you deliver."
Among the more striking changes from the Governor's proposed package is the deferred-pay plan, which the Legislature adopted instead of Mr. Cuomo's proposal to place all state employees on mandatory unpaid one-week furloughs. Today, the Governor defended the revised plan, often described as a lag payroll, by noting that it saved the same amount of money, about $150 million, would not roll a cash deficit into the next fiscal year and "even provides greater productivity than furloughs would."
The Legislature also came up with an alternative formula for distributing cuts in aid to the state's hospitals and nursing homes.
 
Hospital Plan Changed
 Under the Governor's proposal, Medicaid rates would have been reduced in such a way that hospitals would have gotten lower payments not only from the state government, but from the Federal and local governments and private insurers as well. The new plan leaves the Medicaid rates unchanged but imposes a flat assessment on hospital revenues that produces roughly the same savings, $125 million, projected in the Mr. Cuomo's plan.
While the Governor's plan envisioned cuts of about $80 million in state aid to public universities, the Legislature authorized a $300-a-year tuition increase that would help offset much of the effect of the reductions. Annual tuition at the State University of New York has been $1,350 since 1983, and at the City University of New York, $1,250.
The Governor, who last year vetoed authorization for a $200 annual increase, said this afternoon that he had consistently fought against any increases but that "today's difficult circumstances require a relaxation of that constraint."
The plan also includes some -- but not all -- of the fiscal-relief measures for local governments sought by the Governor, which he said would help to offset the state aid cuts they are asked to sustain.
 
No More Rabbits From Hat
 For instance, regulations that require New York City teachers to participate in an extensive mentoring program were lifted. City Board of Education officials said the change could save them as much as $10 million in the current fiscal year.
While congratulating themselves on showing the fortitude to approve such heavy cuts, top lawmakers already seemed to be focusing on next year's budget deliberations, which will begin in early February with Gov. Cuomo's proposal of a budget for the 1991-92 fiscal year.
"I think this process has shown two things," Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, said in an interview. "It shows that we can make very difficult decisions in a relatively short period of time. And I think it shows a growing reality that in dealing with the budgets we can't keep pulling rabbits out of a hat. We have to cut."
Mr. Miller said that instead of relying on across-the-board cuts next year, the Legislature was likely to eliminate certain programs, although he declined to identify specific targets. For example, rather than "watering down" five different programs with cuts of 20 percent, he explained, it might make more sense to get rid of one program altogether.
The plan adopted today was generally endorsed by fiscal monitors who had criticized past state budgets. "This program is much much better than previous midyear corrections," said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a private monitoring group.
The president of the Business Council of New York State, Daniel B. Walsh, said the Legislature came up with "real, significant spending cuts" compared to those of earlier years.

HEADLINE: Moody's Cuts Debt Ratings Of Five Leading Insurers

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Services said yesterday that it had downgraded its ratings of the financial strength of five leading insurance companies.
Moody's said that the downgrading reflected concern over the near-term rise in problem assets in the insurers' mortgage portfolios and that the move had come after a three-month review. The rating agency said the move reflected the rising pressures on earnings and capital that the companies would face as a result of losses and delinquencies on mortgages. 
 The five are Mutual Life Insurance of New York, Mutual Benefit Life Insurance, Home Life Insurance, Equitable Life Assurance and Equitable Variable Life Insurance.
 
Drop in Profitability
 "What we expect is that the level of mortgages that are not performing as originally expected will go up for the rest of this year and into next year," said Weston Hicks, a Moody's vice president. "From a credit point of view it means that the profitability of these companies will go down and the margin of protection for policyholders -- retained earnings and surplus -- will also lessen."
Mr. Hicks added that the changes were still relatively modest and noted that the ratings still leave the companies within the categories of strong, investment-grade institutions. The Moody's report noted that the ultimate effect of growing nonperforming mortgage loans on each insurance company would depend on how deep and protracted the current real estate recession turns out to be, each company's cash position, financial flexibility and earnings outlook, and regulatory pressures.
Moody's noted that because typical life insurance commercial mortgage commitments were made on established, income-producing properties, insurers have weathered previous real estate downturns largely unscathed. However, Moody's argued that the present downturn would be more severe than in the past and it expected greater insurer losses.
Moody's also said the ratings of other big life insurers with large mortgage portfolios were also confirmed by the study. The Aetna Life and Casualty Company's financial strength rating was confirmed, but Moody's lowered Aetna's senior debt rating because of similiar concerns over its mortgage portfolio.

HEADLINE: Impromptu Air Trips? Possible, but Not Easy

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Last-minute vacation flights during the Christmas-New Year holiday, especially to Florida and the Caribbean, are at a premium. They can be found, even a rare few at bargain prices, but travelers will have to look hard and be flexible.
Most discount fares are long gone, although some might become available just before a planned departure date. And fares in general continue to cover wide ranges, with such a variety of prices charged on most popular routes that even sophisticated travelers may be thoroughly confused.
 
Be Wary of Airline Promotions
 The lowest fares are generally nonrefundable, must be bought in advance and limit departures to the middle of the week. But even so, because a majority of the holiday flights will be heavily booked, the airlines are setting aside just a handful of inexpensive seats from their remaining inventory. 
 Don't be confused by new promotions that some airlines are offering. Delta Air Lines, American Airlines, Northwest Airlines and United Airlines are offering members of their frequent-flier clubs a free ticket for making as few as two round-trip flights between today and March 15. But the free tickets will be only for travel starting in the middle of next year.
The problems that last-minute travelers are likely to face in the next three weeks come at a time of unusual turmoil for the airline industry. Overall airline fares have risen by at least 15 percent since fuel prices rose abruptly after Iraq invaded Kuwait last summer, one of the biggest increases in history over such a short period.
In addition, less than two weeks ago Continental Airlines, the nation's fifth-largest air carrier, filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws, succumbing to the double pressure of higher fuel costs and a weakening economy.
 
Few Seats, Fewer Bargains
 "Travel for the holidays, -- it's very rough," said Phil Davidoff, the owner of Belair Travel, an agency in Bowie, Md., and president of the American Society of Travel Agents. "If you want to go outbound from Dec. 21 to Dec. 24 and want to return on Jan. 1 or Jan. 2, you're going to pay top dollar."
Lorna Greene, a travel agent at Reliable Travel in Cedarhurst, L.I., put it this way: "Never mind any kind of bargains. How about a seat? People are saying to their travel agents, 'Just find me something.' "
So the first advice for anyone looking for airline seats to a popular warm-weather vacation spot in the next few weeks is: Be willing to make changes. Be prepared to fly on a different day, at a different hour and probably on a different airline than you had sought.
"It's a trial-and-error kind of thing," said Julia Nystrand, director of electronic services for the Official Airline Guide, which compiles information on airline fares and schedules.
John Unger, president of the Travel Network, a travel agency in Tampa, Fla., said: "Tell your travel agent that you are flexible on either side of the trip. Ask the agent to take a look at the availabilities and give the agent time to do the research."
If you get a reservation, though, expect to pay one of the highest fares. For example, round-trip coach fares from New York to Orlando, Fla., or Fort Lauderdale, Fla., currently range from $198 to $664.
"If you look at the fine print, you see that airlines say 'prices from,' " said Marilyn B. Cicero, president of Colpitts Travel Center, a travel agency in Lexington, Mass. "People call expecting the discounted fares and they just won't find it. It takes a lot of explaining on our part."
Nevertheless, some travelers find bargains. Mary O'Neill, a spokeswoman for American, suggested that travelers who are willing to book flights on their own "call reservation agents and ask them to search for the lowest possible price."
"They have short cuts to find the discount fares and the flights that they are available on," she said.
A tougher approach was recommended by Christopher J. Witkowski, director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, an organization founded by Ralph Nader. "Consumers who call an airline in response to an advertisement, particularly when the ad appears that day, should be insistent on getting either the reservation agent or his supervisor to honor the advertised fare," he said.
"If the low fare is sold out and the consumer cannot afford the higher fare, that should be made clear to the agent or supevisor," Mr. Witkowski said. "You might just land a lower fare in the last few days."
That, however, means travelers have to be able and willing to wait and content to spend the holidays where they are if nothing works out.
Another way to get to a holiday destination, possibly at a discounted price when flights are otherwise fully booked, is to take a package tour. Travel agencies often offer packages combining air fare, hotel and possibly other vacation expenses, and tour wholesalers sometimes sell these packages directly to the public.
Joel Cutler, president of the Vacation Outlet at Filene's Basement in Boston, said his agency is now selling one-week packages from Boston to Cancun, Mexico, starting Dec. 21, that are "hundreds of dollars" less than they would be if the various elements were bought separately. One package consisting of air fare and seven nights at an "inexpensive" hotel costs $429, based on double occupancy, while another at a "moderate" hotel costs $529.

HEADLINE: Patents;
New Air Bag Called Cheaper and Safer

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Stern & Stern Industries, a small company in New York City that makes products using specialized woven fabrics, obtained a patent this week for an automobile air bag that it said was cheaper and safer than the bags now in use.
Because air bags need to inflate in about one-tenth of a second, they employ propellant gases that essentially explode when they are activated by electrical voltage and produce a brief burst of enormous heat. Current bags handle that strain because they are made of fabrics that have plastic coatings, but the inventors of the new bag contend that these coatings are bulky, expensive to apply and pose ventilation problems. The new bag is made of uncoated fabrics consisting of tightly woven polyester or nylon. 
 Peter B. Thornton, the company's president and one of the inventors, said the chief advantage of the new bag was its ability to deflate at just the right speed. Air bags need to begin deflating almost immediately after a crash, so people do not feel as if they are hitting a brick wall. Because plastic coatings do not let any air escape, he said, current bags are made with small round holes to allow for deflation. The problem, Mr. Thornton said, is that both air and propellant gases spew out of those holes at jet speeds and can actually burn the person being protected.
The new fabric is woven extremely tightly, and then subjected to heat and pressure that makes it become almost, but not quite, impermeable. As a result, Mr. Thornton said, the bag inflates as efficiently as current ones and deflates more efficiently.
Mr. Thornton said the General Motors Corporation and several air bag manufacturers had tested the bags and were interested in them.
Mr. Thornton, Stanley Cone and George Booz received patent 4,977,016.

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Kindly Toward Arithmetic

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
Several engineers write that I am unfair to their profession. This follows my recent observation that afflictions like those proliferating and ridiculously complicated new telephone systems come about because "engineers refuse to leave well enough alone."
 Prof. Jerry Nathanson of Union County College in New Jersey, for instance, believes I have "a narrow-minded and pernicious anti-technology attitude." Worse, he thinks, I contribute to the decline in the number of Americans studying engineering. 
 This is alarming, because one of my few convictions about American education is that far too many people are frittering away college educations by studying history, literature and psychology when they should be studying engineering, mathematics and science.
 Living in a society where technological know-how is vital to people who want the good jobs, we graduate ever higher percentages of people ignorant of science, impotent in mathematics and incompetent at any technology more complex than changing a light bulb.
Everybody knows this, everybody says something must be done about it, and nothing seems to result. The problem doesn't excite the educational world as it did 30 years ago when the Soviets threatened to beat us in the race to the moon.
This isn't because American educators lack passion. To the contrary, they happen just now to be enjoying one of their periodic, exhilarating frenzies of self-examination, but if you're curious why the United States has trouble keeping pace with Japanese and European industry, the educational issues being debated may seem theologically abstruse. For instance:
 Which novelists should students be reading and which should be expelled from the curriculum? Whose version of history should be laid down as gospel and whose renounced as heresy?
 Yes, these are issues worth fretting about. They go to the sociological nature of education, dealing as they do with the question of whether some social blocs are empowered by educational systems, and others disempowered. (What is it about sociology that instantly bogs us down in fens of jargon?)
 The routes to empowerment, however, do not all run through the departments of literature and history. Ability to deliver the goods in a difficult job can also empower people, sometimes faster than substituting Du Bois for Milton can.
 So if Professor Nathanson is right about me discouraging people out there from studying engineering, or science, or math, I apologize. All I say to such people is, What's wrong with you anyhow? Are you so wishy-washy you can be turned away from a crack at a good life by a newspaper columnist?
 On Professor Nathanson's other point, I remain sassy. Complaining about engineering's refusal to leave well enough alone is neither "narrow-minded" nor perniciously "anti-technology."
 Its refusal to leave well enough alone may, in fact, be one thing that repels young people from engineering careers. "Why," they may ask, "should I spend my life making everybody else's life more complicated than it already is?"
 The curse of technology is its habit of trying to improve what it already does almost perfectly. The result: What was once simple becomes complicated. The improvement of a new phone system, for instance, typically makes it more complicated to use the phone than it was before improvement occurred.
 The benefits resulting from the complication -- financial advantage perhaps to large corporations, including telephone companies -- are hidden from those who have to learn all over again how to use the phone. The engineer's aim, Professor Nathanson, should be to create the hidden benefits without punishing the user.
 Engineering's low priority on simplicity leads to many modern nightmares: trying to program a VCR, for example. This can hardly be done without a degree in electronics. Even if you come close, you can't cope with those little power-company glitches that turn off the machine's idiot electric clock, thus wrecking the entire program.
 I know VCR's are all Japanese, but what a triumph for America if Professor Nathanson & Colleagues could design one that all humanity could work by just pushing a few buttons. Like the old telephone.

HEADLINE: Tribal Colleges Prepare Indians for Future

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Robert H. White's "Indians -- New Harvest" (Op-Ed, Nov. 22), on successful entrepreneurialism on American Indian reservations was welcome Thanksgiving reading. Economic revitalization and self-determination among native Americans is being fueled by the 27 tribally controlled colleges throughout the Midwest and West, most on reservations.
Hardly known outside of native America, these colleges began two decades ago with Navajo Community College and have been outstanding successes. Courses in math, science, sociology, business administration and English are offered alongside classes in native American history, literature and languages.
Many of the colleges also prepare students to join local industries. For example, Northwest Community College, serving the Lummi Indians of Washington, offers a certificate program in commercial fishing. Other colleges offer programs in ranching, agriculture and mining.
A student who attends a tribal college for even one year is 40 times more likely to succeed at a non-Indian institution than a student who enters one directly. More than 30 percent of tribal college graduates further their education, more than 80 percent are employed.
The 27 tribal colleges present a fresh outlook on the future of native Americans.
 
BARBARA BRATONE
Director, American Indian College Fund
New York, Dec. 3, 1990

HEADLINE: Misguided 'Orphan Trains' Idea Rolls On;
Farms for the Homeless

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Moving the Furniture Around," Anna Quindlen's Dec. 2 column about the homeless, prompts a suggestion: that cities or counties place the homeless on large farms, as was the custom many years ago. Almost every county had a "poor farm," like the one we had in Dodge County, Wisconsin, when I was a boy in the early part of the century. It was an economical and healthy way of providing for the destitute.
They had to work at repairing and painting buildings and equipment, making ice cream and butter, baking, sewing, canning vegetables and fruit, washing and serving at meals. The cost would be small, compared with housing the homeless in hotels; the counties could pay part of salaries (placed in savings accounts), which could help the occupants become self-sustaining.
The public would gladly support such a rehabilitation method, compared with a costly system that only creates perpetual care for the homeless.
 
HAROLD LINDEMANN
Eatontown, N.J., Dec. 4, 1990

HEADLINE: Access of the Poor to Quality Higher Education Is Imperiled

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Since 1847, The City College of New York has served a great American ideal. It has given the children of poor, largely immigrant families the chance to obtain a first-rate college education. In the process, it has educated some of our nation's most notable citizens -- people such as Jonas Salk, A. Philip Randolph, Upton Sinclair, Bernard Malamud and Felix Frankfurter.
Over the years, the college has played a large role within a growing City University, and the college's student population has changed. Today's students more frequently come from African, Asian and Latino cultures than from European backgrounds. But the college and university have maintained the primary mission of a quality education for those who can't otherwise afford it.
This year, however, the college and university have suffered damaging budget cuts at the hands of the state government. At City College, we will be forced to reduce course offerings, increase class sizes, lose journal subscriptions and cut back on already insufficient secretarial services. Moreover, we will be unable to hire young faculty members to replace those retiring. As a result, the college will lose some of its vitality, and be unable to bring in more women scholars and those of diverse cultural backgrounds. Equally serious problems confront the university as a whole. The proposed tuition increase would restore only a small fraction of the budget cuts, while creating new roadblocks for many students.
So far, the budget cuts have been made very quietly. There has been almost no vocal opposition. Indeed, the cuts have hardly made the news. Perhaps many people assume that, given all the other economic problems in our state, these cuts are of minor significance. But a critical issue is at stake: the access of the poor to a quality higher education. I hope those who care about this issue will begin to ask about the cuts and fight against them.
 
WILLIAM CRAIN
Professor and Chairman, Psychology Department, The City College
New York, Dec. 13, 1990

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
G.O.P. Plagued With Democratic Problems

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
When William J. Bennett backed out of his agreement to become chairman of the Republican National Committee he was walking away from one of the biggest headaches in American politics right now.
The Republican Party is rife with problems that have long been associated with the Democrats: ideological schisms, personal bickering, pique parading as principle and individual agendas undermining party unity.
There is rising concern among Republicans around the country that at a time when the White House should be pulling the party together, the President is distracted by a range of foreign crises and his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, is more concerned with settling grudges with other powerful Republicans.
The absence of Lee Atwater, the party chief who is suffering from an inoperable brain tumor, has become glaringly apparent, many Republicans now say. Mr. Sununu has tried to consolidate the jobs of chief of staff and chief political adviser. This would be difficult for even the most light-footed of operatives. But politically minded Republicans say it has created nothing but grief under Mr. Sununu, who walks across political minefields with all the grace of a raging elephant.
Friends insist Mr. Bennett was telling the truth when he announced he could not succed Mr. Atwater because his concerns about conflict of interest would keep him from making as much money as he needed. But they also said that he had long discussions with associates about the seriousness of the party's internal divisions, and that this did nothing to encourage him to overcome the financial obstacles.
Indeed, officials in Mr. Sununu's office say they offered to more than double the chairman's salary, to $300,000, to entice Mr. Bennett. But that was said to be less than half of what he could make from speaking fees. So he walked away sending a letter of explanation to the President and holding a news conference in the White House driveway that only added to the sense that the Republican camp is in disarray.
"I would not characterize it as chaos," said Eddie Mahe, who helped run the Republican National Committee when Mr. Bush was its chairman. "But it surely could be characterized as confusion. There is no shining beacon on any hill that all forces are moving toward. It's just a mumbo jumbo of forces on a plain."
Some of the current problem goes to the very core of the party. Two of the bonding agents of the Republican coalition, opposition to communism and opposition to taxes, have been weakened, one as a result of world events and the other as a result of White House handling of the budget negotiations.
On top of these philosophical problems, and in several cases because of them, Washington is being treated to a series of Republican feuds of a sort remarkable even by Washington's standards of pigue, backbiting and infighting.
Some news from the battlefield:
*Two of the party's best known conservatives, Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development who was a Presidential candidate in 1988, and Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the minority whip who hopes to be the next Republican leader of the House, openly rebelled against Mr. Bush's decision to raise taxes to get a budget deal with Democrats and are still battling the White House over domestic policy.
*Conservatives of various stripes are talking about a challenge to Mr. Bush for the 1992 Presidential nomination. Pete duPont, the former Delaware Governor and another candidate for the Republican nomination in 1988, is setting up a political committee that some conservatives hope will serve as a vehicle for another Presidential campaign. Aides to Mr. duPont say these are pipe dreams of frustrated conservatives.
*Mr. Sununu is barely on speaking terms with Mr. Gingrich and, in a seperate feud, has blocked the President from signing fund-raising letters on behalf of the House Republican Campaign Committee so long as Edward J. Rollins, one of the Republican Party's most outspoken political strategists, is in charge. Mr. Rollins's offense was to suggest during the midterm campaigns that Republican candidates should separate themselves from Mr. Bush's flip-flops on taxes.
The grumbling on the right has become so loud that one Republican entrepreneur has even carved out a successful market by selling buttons with the message, "Dan Quayle now."
So far, most of this is of fascination to a few thousand political insiders. But Republican operatives fear that the confusion is beginning to plant doubts in the public mind about the competence of the President. That would be nothing more than an irritant if the economy, that great mover of public opinion, were headed up. But it is the last thing Mr. Bush needs as the economy heads down, dragging the President's political standing with it.
 
An Old Argument in New Light
 Mr. Bush took a list of potential party chairmen to Camp David this weekend. But some Republicans say that what may be more important is who he names to run his re-election campaign. That is the person who will probably emerge as chief political adviser and will provide the counterweight to Mr. Sununu that has been missing since Mr. Atwater became ill.
Some of what is going on is a battle for control of the domestic policy agenda. "We are in the middle of an argument which a lot of us thought ended in 1989," Mr. Gingrich said. "There really is a fundemental difference between the managerial/accommodationist approach to the welfare state and the reform/replacement approach."
Ideological conservatives like Mr. Gingrich would like the White House to champion a program of low taxes, curtailed bureaucracy, freer markets and the use of Federal funds to increase individual choices in areas like education.
A White House conservative, Jim Pinkerton, called this program "the new paradigm" for a post-New Deal conservative agenda. That led to an inside battle when the budget director, Richard G. Darman, seemed to make fun of the idea in a recent speech. Mr. Gingrich, a proponent of Mr. Pinkerton's thesis, said Mr. Darman should be dismissed if he did not embrace the effort to forge a new conservative agenda.
Mr. Darman and Mr. Gingrich have held about 12 hours of meetings since their blow-up, Mr. Gingrich's staff reports. The mood between the two men is said to be better now, and Mr. Gingrich's camp at least credits Mr. Darman with showing enough respect for the new paradigmists to debate their ideas.
But the big test, the conservatives say, will be what Mr. Bush says in his budget and State of the Union Message about domestic policy. Mr. Sununu tried to address some of that in a speech this week, saying that whether it was called the new paradigm or something else the cornerstone of Mr. Bush's domestic policy was the encouragement of capitalism and the expansion of free markets.

HEADLINE: Police Plan Would Help Some Safer Areas More

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
New York City's police expansion plan, created after last summer's heavily reported rash of criminal violence, would send proportionately fewer officers to some of the city's highest-crime precincts than to some of the safest, a computer study shows.
An analysis of the plan by The New York Times found a number of disparities between levels of violent crime and the percentage of additional officers that would be assigned to precincts and borough commands. 
 A top police aide presented with the findings said that violent crime was only one of many criteria used in developing the proposal, which is meant to shift the department's emphasis toward community patrols.
 
All Would Gain
 The plan's prospects withered early yesterday when the State Legislature recessed without acting on it. Worsening fiscal news is likely to make its passage more difficult in 1991 when the Legislature reconvenes. The city's hopes were smothered by a combination of political factors, along with a suspicion on the part of Republican Senators from Queens and Staten Island that it would slight their districts. [Page 30.]
But the analysis shows that the safest borough, Staten Island, would fare best under the plan, and found no overall pattern of significant differences between the four other boroughs.
At issue is not whether any command would suffer losses -- all 75 precincts and borough offices would be augmented under the plan -- but which would gain most and least.
One Staten Island precinct, the 123d, which already enjoys the city's best police coverage for violent crime -- about 85 officers for every 100 reported violent crimes -- would move to an even higher ratio, the Times study found.
At the same time, the Brooklyn North command, with some of the city's highest-crime precincts, would wind up with the lowest percentage increase of officers. Five northern Brooklyn precincts that now have less than six police officers for every 100 reported violent crimes would find their officer-to-violent-crime ratio improving by only two or three.
In descending order, the largest increases would go to Staten Island, the Manhattan North police command, Brooklyn South, Manhattan South, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn North.
The question of how the Police Department deploys its resources has long been a thorny one, carrying sweeping social, political and economic consequences. With a finite staff, adding patrols in one community has meant subtracting them from another, although the possibility of a record expansion now poses a different question -- how to divide a bigger pie.
Police officials say that measuring coverage in terms of violent crime alone does not fairly reflect the scope of the plan, which seeks to address community concerns from burglaries and auto theft to highway dangers, prostitution, panhandling, peddling and other "quality of life" problems.
"This is an attempt to significantly increase the uniform patrol presence throughout the city, not just the quote 'high crime' areas," said First Deputy Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, the department's top aide to Commissioner Lee P. Brown. Mr. Kelly led the group of department officials that drew up the plan in weeks of frenzied analysis and round-the-clock meetings.
Mr. Kelly said that Commissioner Brown's concept of community policing involves "a lot more than focusing in on crime, or even violent crime."
"It is recapturing the streets," he said. "It is having community patrol officers marshaling community support. It's job stabilization, keeping business in the city. It's not just, 'Oh, let's respond to the robbery.' "
He said the deployments were drawn up through traditional deployment formulas, not favoritism, and that politicians or community leaders had not been consulted in advance.
 
'Not Etched in Stone'
 Still, he said, "This is a plan and if the assumptions are wrong, you change it. This is not etched in stone."
Hubert Williams, a former police chief of Newark and president of the Police Foundation, a Washington-based nonprofit research group, said that while an analysis of manning by violent crime was useful and could be revealing, deployment had to be based on broader considerations.
"If you put your manpower only on violent crime, you'd end up putting your resources exclusively into the minority communities," he said, after being told of the findings. For equal protection under the law, he said, a more balanced use of forces is needed.
The finding that the police expansion plan does not funnel extra officers proportionately into precincts highest in violent crime is striking if only because the plan was so often described by Mayor David N. Dinkins and police officials as a response to the summer's wave of shocking crimes.
Victims included sleeping children killed by stray bullets, a child slain over a moped, a Bronx prosecutor cut down in a drive-by shooting, a Utah tourist fatally stabbed while trying to defend his mother from robbers in the subway and an advertising executive shot to death in a phone booth.
When Mayor Dinkins arranged last August to have a first contingent of 1,058 extra officers added to the ranks, a mayoral spokesman, Lee Jones, said the largest group would go to the highest-crime precincts. Later comments by the Mayor presented the expansion plan as an attack on street violence.
Mayor Dinkins's original $1.8 billion, four-year plan, including court, educational and youth programs totaling $644 million a year, was to have been financed by a property-tax increase, a payroll tax and a lottery surcharge.
In the face of opposition from suburban legislators and City Council members, Mayor Dinkins and the Council last week proposed the slightly scaled-down package. The revised plan, to put 9,744 more officers on the streets, at a cost of $450 million a year, would be financed by a property-tax increase, extension of the city income-tax surcharge and a new city lottery game -- all of which need legislative approval.
But the Senators, including John Marchi of Staten Island, said that they thought that high-crime areas would drain officers from their districts, and demanded that precinct-by-precinct deployments be written into law.
A report by the chairman of the State Senate Standing Committee on Cities, Senator Frank Padavan, last year faulted the department for "serious gaps in manning" but suggested few remedies beyond closer attention to problems in each community. Senator Padavan, from Queens Village, was one of those blocking the plan this week.
Police staffing is determined by a patrol allocation plan with four parts: a radio motor patrol staffing model developed in 1973 by the Rand Corporation to calculate the number of cars needed to handle emergency calls; a sustained operational conditions component that takes into account fixed staffing requirements like diplomatic missions, sports arenas, stations and airports; a public safety factor that rates precincts by their crime statistics, and a local police judgment factor, an assessment of crime problems by field commanders.
 
A Record Force
 "We've been around here a long time and know the busier precincts," said Deputy Commissioner Kelly, a 27-year department veteran.
The initial anti-crime plan, unveiled by Mayor Dinkins and Commissioner Brown on Oct. 2, called for hiring 4,106 additional city police, transit police and housing police officers, above 3,825 additional officers already budgeted, to create a record total force of 38,994 by 1992, compared with 27,024 today.
With some consolidation and the hiring of 3,584 additional civilians to take over former police functions, the department expected to expand its daily patrol strength by 54 percent, from 6,640 to 10,227 officers.
Under the compromise plan, 683 fewer officers would be deployed, generally 6 to 10 fewer per precinct.
The Times used a computer to rank the increases in officers in the new plan by precinct and borough command. The analysis found that the number of officers would grow by almost 40 percent and civilians by 30 percent.
Every precinct was allocated three extra civilians, a reflection of the limited functions that non-uniformed personnel can assume, Deputy Commissioner Kelly said.
The allocation of uniformed staff varied widely among precincts. Topping the list was the 122d Precinct in Staten Island down for a 79 percent increase in officers. The 122d would grow from 144 to 258 officers.
The plan envisioned an expanded role for the seven borough task forces, one each in Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island and two each in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The units were to be used as pools to fill gaps in the precincts with each command.
The Staten Island task force drew the largest expansion, 350 percent, from 20 to 90 officers. The Bronx task force followed with a 134 percent increase, from 99 to 232 officers.
From statistics reported annually by the department, The Times then calculated the average level of four violent crimes -- homicide, rape, robbery and felonious assault -- in each precinct for 1988 and 1989 and compared them to the numbers of officers currently assigned and proposed.
Citywide, there were currently just over nine officers for every 100 violent crimes reported. The plan would lift the figure to 14 officers.
But precincts varied widely in their ratios of violent crimes to the number of officers now and proposed.
After Staten Island's 123d Precinct, with its present ratio of 85 officers for every 100 violent crimes, scheduled to go up to 131, came Manhattan's Central Park Precinct, with nearly 42 officers for each 100 violent crimes, scheduled to rise to about 56. The officer-to-crime ratio of the 111th Precinct in eastern Queens, 32, is scheduled to rise to 48; another Staten Island precinct, the 122d, would see its ratio of 30 officers go up to 54.
At the bottom of the list were a band of precincts in northern Brooklyn, the 73d, 75th, 77th, 79th and 83d, which each now have less than six officers for every 100 violent crimes reported. Under the plan their ratios would go up only to between seven and nine.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Declines 1.7% In Latest Indicator of Recession

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
In a report that hinted of a recession more severe than has been widely assumed, Government figures released today showed the output of the nation's industries tumbled 1.7 percent in November the third straight monthly decline and the biggest in nearly eight years.
Figures also came out today showing that the prices of goods at the final stage of processing climbed five-tenths of 1 percent last month. The rise was more than had been expected, but still represented a slowdown in inflation after three straight months of huge increases driven by oil. 
 But prices at the intermediate stage of production, like flour used to make bread, edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent, and the price of crude goods, like wheat, plunged a record 6.2 percent.
 
A Picture of a Slump
 Those figures and the production numbers together portrayed a slumping economy that would probably keep inflation suppressed in coming months, many analysts said.
The drop in industrial production, which was also worse than generally expected, "is an indication of serious recession in the manufacturing sector," said Alan C. Lerner, an economist at the Bankers Trust Company. "It's in terrible shape" across the whole spectrum of industries, he added.
Michael P. Daly, an economist for the Cigna Corporation, a large insurance company, estimated after seeing today's numbers that the gross national product would drop in the current quarter at a rate of 4 percent. The G.N.P. includes industrial output along with services and production from sources other than factories, mines and utilities.
In the credit markets, prices of debt securities retreated today and interest rates rose, which some analysts attributed to the fact that the increase in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods exceeded expectations. Others suggested, however, that more important factors were skittishness about the Persian Gulf crisis and profit taking after a big run-up in the bond market.
 Those who cited the price data generally contended that with the index rising by amounts higher than would normally be associated with recession, the Federal Reserve would be less likely to decide to take further steps to relax monetary policy at its strategy meeting early next week.
Mr. Lerner and others, however, called inflation statistics a "lagging" indicator and contended that the Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee would conclude that prices were under control and would allow a new round of interest-rate cuts to try to bolster the economy. Many analysts expect further cuts in the banking system's overnight lending rate and probably a cut in the discount rate, which is set by the six members of the Federal Reserve Board.
The discount rate is what the Federal Reserve charges financial institutions for loans, and it has been at 7 percent for almost two years. A reduction in the discount rate would be the strongest signal yet, many analysts say, that the central bank is convinced the economy needs the stimulus of lower rates.
 
Industrial Production
 Today's industrial output figures, and related data on capacity utilization that accompanied them, were almost uniformly bleak. The only significant mitigating factor, some analysts said, was that a huge 3.6 percent drop in production by the nation's utilities was largely a result of unseasonably warm weather.
Manufacturing fell 1.7 percent, the same as the overall index, with durable goods down 2.5 percent and nondurables down six-tenths of 1 percent. Mining fell one-tenth of 1 percent, the report showed.
A 20 percent drop in motor-vehicle assembly, combined with a sharp reduction in related parts and materials, represented more than half the overall 1.7 percent November drop in total industrial output.
The report also showed that consumer goods fell 2 percent, business equipment fell 1.9 percent and construction supplies fell 1.7 percent.
The output figures for both September and October were also revised downward today. . Output for September, initially estimated as having risen two-tenths of 1 percent, was revised to a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent. October's decline was put at nine-tenths of 1 percent, rather than eight-tenths.
The overall November drop was the biggest since a 2 percent slide in December 1982 at the end of the most recent recession.
At 107.5 percent of its 1987 average, output last month was six-tenths of 1 percent below its level of November 1989.
Capacity utilitization fell 1.5 percentage points, to 80.9 percent, last month, its lowest level since May 1987. The utilization rate for manufacturing fell to 80 percent from 81.6 percent, the lowest level since January 1987.
 
Producer Prices
 Among some analysts the rise in the November Producer Price Index was dismissed as an aberration even though the index rose the same amount -- five-tenths of 1 percent -- with or without the energy and food components, which often show wide swings.
"I don't think the number can continue at that rate," said Mr. Daly, the Cigna economist.
Other analysts who contend that prices will not keep rising noted that although the price of passenger cars rose modestly last month that trend seemed unlikely to be maintained in the face of slumping sales. They also said that while prices of tobacco products soared 3.7 percent, that was probably a one-time jump in anticipation of late-year buying by those hoping to beat the tax increases that take effect on Jan. 1. The Federal tax is going up 4 cents a pack, to 20 cents.
 
Food Costs Rise
 The rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods last month followed three straight increases exceeding 1 percent. Food, not energy, was the major factor last month, with an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent that reflected higher prices for fresh and dried vegetables, fish, pork, beef, veal and confectionery and bakery products. The biggest declines were in dairy products, processed fruits and vegetables, eggs, shortening and cooking oils.
Finished energy goods rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, with declines for gasoline and home heating oil of 2.6 percent and 7.3 percent, respectively. Analysts said that during the month there had been a lessening of the "war premium" built into oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. There was, however, a 5 percent jump in the price of natural gas.
Prices rose more rapidly than in October for pharmaceuticals and tires and tubes, and prices turned up for household textile goods and floor coverings.
Among intermediate goods, domestic producers received slightly lower prices for energy after three months of rapid increases; the price of foods, feeds and construction materials turned down after sharp October increases.
 
Some Prices Are Down
 Consistent with the drop in industrial output, the price of durables used in manufacturing dropped 1 percent, after showing no change in October. Primary nonferrous metals tumbled 7.5 percent, aluminum mill shapes fell 1.7 percent and prices also fell for cold rolled steel sheet and strip. Prices dropped faster, 5.5 percent, than in October for copper and brass mill shapes, and for hardwood lumber prices were down five-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department report showed.
Nondurables used in manufacturing, however, rose an average 1 percent, after a 1.3 percent October advance. Plastic resins, chemicals, paint, paperboard, nitrogenates and synthetic rubber all rose, while prices fell for wood pulp and finished fabrics.
The record 6.2 percent plunge in the price of crude goods was paced by a 10.3 percent decline in crude energy, including a 16.1 percent drop in petroleum. Foods and feeds fell 1.7 percent, aided by lower prices for hogs and soybeans. Crude materials other than food and energy fell 2.3 percent.
With food and energy excluded, intermediate goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent, half as much as in October, while finished goods rose five-tenths of 1 percent, after no change the month before.
Finished goods now stand 7 percent higher than in November 1989.
Producer prices tend to foreshadow those at the consumer level but the correlation is relatively loose. Unlike the Consumer Price Index, which is to be reported next Tuesday for November, the producer index does not include imported goods or directly measured services.
 
Inventories
 In yet another report, this one covering October, the Commerce Department found that business inventories rose modestly, to $813.9 billion, or 2.5 percent above the level of October 1989. Stocks of durables were up 1.4 percent, while stocks of nondurables were 4.3 percent higher.
Business sales also rose, reaching $551.8 billion on a seasonally adjusted basis.
The inventory-sales ratio at the end of the month was 1.47, down from 1.48 in September and 1.51 in October 1989. The ratio means that at current sales rates, it would take 1.47 months, or about 44 days, to deplete current inventories. The ratio has gone as high as 1.74, in January 1982.

HEADLINE: Texas in Black and White

BYLINE: By Michael Oreskes; Michael Oreskes is a national political reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:

RACE AND CLASS IN TEXAS POLITICS
By Chandleravidson.
Illustrated. 344 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $24.95. 
 WITHOUT any real warning, 221 pages into his book, Chandler Davidson suddenly brings his reader face to face with the dark soul of American politics. We have already examined copious charts and endless footnotes on the subject of "Race and Class in Texas Politics" when he introduces two men he calls Bob and Al, whom he overheard arguing politics while lounging in a Houston swimming pool in 1985.
Bob is a union electrican, out of work. He is falling behind in the rent and can't make his child support payments. "That son-of-a-bitch Reagan put me out of a job," Bob mutters. Al, his friend, stiffens. "You're talking about my man."
Bob blows past the objection. He spits out statistics about 200,000 lost union jobs in Texas. "The bastard's a union buster."
Al tries to calm him with promises of better times to come. But when that fails he shifts his argument: "You've got it wrong. . . . It's the goddamn niggers, who'll work for lower wages. And it's these goddamn wetbacks. That's who's taken your job. You can't blame that on Reagan."
"Now you're talking sense," Bob finally says, after remaining silent for a long time. "Now you're talking something that I can relate to. You've put your finger on something now."
Mr. Davidson, a sociologist at Rice University who tends to write in the academic past tense, was paying attention. For all his other research, and it is considerable, nothing sums up his story -- the failure of Texas politics to move in the progressive direction he would like -- better than this moment. It is the story of a state that, he argues, has a liberal impulse stronger than most outsiders realize, but an impulse that remains frustrated by the abiding schism of race.
"Because the racial issue and the complex social questions connected with it -- poverty, crime, drugs, and abortion, among others -- had not subsided and, indeed, showed little sign of doing so," Mr. Davidson writes, "the possibility of an ascendant liberal-moderate coalition seemed remote."
The elements are here of a more important book than Mr. Davidson has actually written. The struggle over race in America has clearly entered a new and troubling phase. This problem of Texas politics -- liberal intent curbed by racial voting -- has become the problem of national politics. As Mr. Davidson correctly points out, the politics of the United States is the politics of each of the 50 states, and Texas, to stress the obvious, is one of the biggest: "In area, it ranked second in 1980; in population, third; in aggregate personal income, third."
Mr. Davidson's purpose is to revisit the findings of V. O. Key Jr., the political scientist whose post-World War II book "Southern Politics in State and Nation" was a seminal piece of American political theory and analysis. Key, a Texan, demonstrated how the issues of race and class were intertwined, and how wealthy Southerners had used race to convince the white working class that their interests as whites bound them to the upper classes more than their interests as workers separated them.
It was Key's vision that in the new South the one-party system would break down. Then, he believed, progressives would take control of the Democratic Party as the wealthy found their new home in the resurgent Republican Party. Clear ideological distinctions, blurred in the old one-party South, would be drawn; white workers would follow their class interests by remaining Democrats but abandon their racial allegiance to the white aristocracy.
V. O. Key got all but the last part right, Mr. Davidson concludes. The South in general, and Texas in particular, have a vibrant two-party system that cuts across class lines; however, more whites than Key predicted have moved to the Republican Party. Liberals are ascendant in the Democratic Party -- after Mr. Davidson's book was completed, they even managed to elect Ann Richards as Governor of Texas (although they had a good bit of help from a Republican candidate, Clayton Williams, whose only real appeal as a candidate was his willingness to put up millions of his own money for the campaign).
But Mr. Davidson's pessimism runs deeper than any one election. Unfortunately, he brings us to the heart of the matter but then, literally on his last page, leaves us there. In academic tones, he concludes: "How could the exorcism of racial issues from Texas politics be achieved when racial antagonisms were still tightly woven into the fabric of everyday life? How could one ignore race when every step forward by racial minorities was resisted by numerous whites who perceived this progress as being at their expense? How could a moratorium be declared on the subject when one of the two major political parties saw an advantage in keeping it before the public, fanning the embers of old racial hostilities? These were questions to which there were no good answers."
PERHAPS not. But there are other questions, too. Why was Bob's anger, as overheard by Mr. Davidson, so easily redirected from class to race? Shouldn't those who view themselves as progressives be trying to explain to him the value and correctness of current civil rights efforts? Can they? If not, why not? To what extent are middle-class whites protecting class or economic interests by voting with the Republican Party?
Is it even really correct to talk about "old racial hostilities"? Or has the hostility tramsmogrified into something fundamentally new? President Bush, by vetoing the Civil Rights Act of 1990 and injecting pejorative rhetoric about "quotas" into the midterm Congressional election, may well have helped Jesse Helms, a symbol of old hostilities, save his United States Senate seat in North Carolina. But painting the Democratic candidate, Dianne Feinstein, as a supporter of racial quotas was also a powerful help to Senator Pete Wilson on his way to winning the race for Governor of California, where new hostilities -- toward Asian and Hispanic immigrants -- matter more than old ones.
Millions of white Americans, and not just in Texas, join Bob and Al in their sense that racial minorities are taking unfair advantage, and that the Government is helping them do it. Confronting that view would be more productive than just bemoaning it if Texas, and the nation, hope to find the "way out" for which V. O. Key was searching 41 years ago.

HEADLINE: How We Got That Run-Down Feeling

BYLINE: By Robert Howard; Robert Howard, an associate editor at the Harvard Business Review, is the author of "Brave New Workplace."

 BODY:

THE HUMAN MOTOR
Energy, Fatigue, and the Origins of Modernity.
By Anson Rabinbach.
Illustrated. 402 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $34.95. 
 In 1904, the German physiologist Wilhelm Weichardt announced that he had discovered a vaccine against fatigue. Weichardt's experiments with the blood chemistry of fatigued rats had convinced him that exhaustion was the product of a specific toxin. In his laboratory he had created an immunizing antitoxin and injected small amounts in human subjects -- with, he claimed, remarkable results. Over the next 10 years, scientists sprayed Weichardt's vaccine in school classrooms, pumped it as a gas into laboratories and injected it into soldiers. By 1914, most physiologists had concluded that Weichardt's claims were exaggerated. But the search for so-called "nerve whips" to combat fatigue (the most promising candidates were tea, coffee and cocaine) continued.
The peculiar combination of scientific method and utopian yearning in the story of Weichardt's fatigue vaccine is the subject of Anson Rabinbach's important new book. "The Human Motor" is a history of a scientific and technological metaphor. It describes how the conceptual revolution of 19th-century physics -- specifically, the discovery of the laws of thermodynamics -- gave birth to the idea of the working body as a particular kind of machine. Mr. Rabinbach, an associate professor of history at Cooper Union in New York, tells how efforts by European scientists to harness the human motor transformed the modern understanding of work and society, and of modernity itself. It is also the story of the rise and fall of a particular scientific utopia, the vision of a society without fatigue.
Mr. Rabinbach is no great stylist. His text is at times repetitious and rambling. Still, his book is a fine example of what might be called the new cultural history of science. Tracing in great detail how one metaphor from science and technology has shaped contemporary political and social thought, "The Human Motor" is an intriguing study of "how science organizes, represents, and structures its knowledge along sometimes unconscious fault lines, often with unintended political and social consequences."
According to Mr. Rabinbach, 19th-century Europe inherited a fundamentally moral conception of work. The legacy of medieval Christianity, this view led people to understand work in terms of personal attributes or failings. The social disruptions of the Industrial Revolution -- for example, conflicts over the work disciplines of the new factory system -- were at first seen entirely in terms of this moral framework, as a battle between "industry" and "idleness."
But in midcentury, this moral discourse about work began to change under the impact of ideas from physics. In 1847, the German physicist Hermann von Helmholtz articulated the universal law of the conservation of energy. Helmholtz conceived of all the forces of nature as but the myriad forms of a single, universal energy, what he called "the groundwork of all our thoughts and acts."
The idea of a universal energy led to an equally universal concept of work. Helmholtz's term for it was "labor power." Initially a measurement of the force of machines, labor power came to be a measure of the conversion of energy into use -- whether by nature, technology or the human body. According to this theory, the body was quite literally a motor -- a machine for transforming energy into work -- no different from a waterfall or a steam engine. And the only criterion for distinguishing the work of the human motor from that of any other was "the utility and efficiency of the energy transferred." Work was shorn of social purpose, abstracted from the specific context of particular occupations, social relationships or human goals.
Helmholtz's idea of nature as a vast storehouse of energy available for productive work spoke to the optimism of 19th-century bourgeois society. The theory that human society and nature were fundamentally linked by the primacy and identity of all productive activity -- a world view that Mr. Rabinbach labels "productivism" -- encouraged the conviction that a scientific approach to work could liberate the productive potential of the human body.
Mr. Rabinbach persuasively argues that productivism decisively shaped 19th-century social thought across the ideological spectrum. In his early works of the 1840's, for example, Karl Marx had considered work an essentially human activity that defined social identity. By the early 1860's and the writing of "Capital," Marx had so thoroughly assimilated Helmholtz's idea of labor power that his view had changed completely. No longer the paradigm of human activity, work was a burden from which humanity would be emancipated through technology and what Marx called scientific social organization.
But there was another, more pessimistic strand to the new scientific understanding of work. Not long after Helmholtz set out his theory of energy conservation, Rudolf Clausius demonstrated that in practical terms the transformation of energy into work was accompanied by an inevitable dissipation of force -- an idea that led to the second law of thermodynamics, which explains the irreversibility and decline of energy in entropy. Thus, parallel to the enormous promise of productivism was the fear -- Mr. Rabinbach calls it an "anxiety of limits" -- that the demands of industrial work and of modernity itself would exhaust the body. "Fatigue became the objective nemesis of a society founded on labor power," Mr. Rabinbach writes. Work ceased to be a matter of individual moral character to become a problem of social hygiene.
The major focus of Mr. Rabinbach's book is the search by European physiologists, psychologists and physicians to create a "thermodynamics of society" that would allow European civilization to transcend the problem of fatigue and realize industrial society's productive potential. Before 1870 there were hardly any scientific studies of fatigue; by 1890 there was an extensive literature on the physiological and psychological aspects of the problem. And by 1900 laboratories devoted to the experimental science of the "human motor" were established in almost all countries on the Continent.
European work scientists strove to identify the laws of fatigue and use them for social improvement. Physiologists devised instruments to measure fatigue and studied the physiology of the human muscles and the role of nutrition in the thermodynamics of the body. Psychologists searched for the causes of mental diseases such as neurasthenia in the underlying physiological dynamics of fatigue.
Arguing that a more scientific approach to fatigue would result not only in social justice for the worker but greater productivity for society as a whole, work scientists also took an active role in the debates over work reform. They lobbied for a shorter workday and for the adoption of social insurance to compensate workers suffering industrial accidents. The result was a characteristically modern political ideology that celebrated science as the solution to social problems, in particular the endemic economic and political conflicts pitting capital against labor in industrial Europe.
But, according to Mr. Rabinbach, "the greatest weakness of the science of work lay in its most compelling assumption" -- that scientific objectivity alone could resolve the worker question. With few exceptions, European work scientists were more comfortable in the laboratory than in the factory. This proved a singular disadvantage when they were confronted with a new American import -- Frederick Winslow Taylor's system of scientific management.
Like the European work scientists, Taylor promised a neutral, "scientific" method to solve the problems of workplace conflict. But his was a movement of engineers and managers with far more direct experience of the shop floor than the physiologists and psychologists in their experimental labs. Even more important, Taylor took worker dissatisfaction as a given -- to be countered by the higher wages made possible by increased productivity, but never entirely eliminated. When Taylor's method was first introduced in Europe in the years before World War I, it was immediately embraced by industrialists, as well as by many trade unionists. The ideas of the European work scientists did eventually come to be incorporated into management practice, but only as techniques for "humanizing" scientific management, not as a full-fledged program for social reform.
Mr. Rabinbach argues that as work has come to depend less and less on physical effort, the idea of the human motor has lost its compelling power. With its disappearance, work has ceased to be a central issue in modern social thought. But here Mr. Rabinbach's relentless focus on the human-motor metaphor may lead him to miss the deeper phenomenon of which it is an expression.
Today, new technologies and new competitive realities are transforming work much as did the Industrial Revolution in the 19th century. As people cope with the unique demands of knowledge work, their worries have come to center not on physical fatigue but on psychological stress. Similarly, both researchers and managers have fastened on a new technological metaphor: not the body as a kind of motor but the mind as a kind of program or expert system. But while the terminology is different, the basic impulse remains the same. The modern tendency to seek in science and technology the antidote to our "anxiety of limits" lives on.
