HEADLINE: Birth Control Backlash

BYLINE: By Philip J. Hilts; Philip J. Hilts is a science and health reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
IN THE 30 YEARS SINCE THE CONTRACEPTIVE pill was introduced in the United States, this country has fallen farther and farther behind Europe in the birth-control choices available. Until 1980, at least nine large pharmaceutical companies were carrying on significant research into contraceptive development. Now there is only one, the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, which makes a variety of birth-control devices.
This month the F.D.A. is expected to approve what would be the first substantially new contraceptive brought out in the United States in 25 years. Known as Norplant, it is a long-term hormonal device that would be implanted under a woman's skin. Norplant was developed by a small nonprofit group concerned with population problems and issues, the New York-based Population Council. Perhaps more remarkable than the promise of Norplant as a socially useful drug is that no American pharmaceutical company seemed willing to research and develop it. The Population Council spent 24 years, on and off, raising money and doing research in its own labs, before it finally brought Norplant to the Government for approval. 
 Dr. C. Wayne Bardin, a soft-spoken Texan, is the director of the Population Council's Center for Biomedical Research. One afternoon a few months ago, he gave a visitor a preview demonstration. Dozens of soft surgical-rubber tubes, each about the size of a match, nestled in a small cardboard box he had placed on the black marble table in the center of his office. He picked out six of the tubes and arranged them on the table, as if he were spreading a deck of cards, in a nearly complete circle.
"They would go under the skin like this, in a sort of fan, on the inside of the upper arm," he said. "You can feel them under there, but you can't see them usually." The tubes are slightly porous, and once in place dispense the hormone, a type of progestin, at a low, steady rate into the body, for up to five years, after which they may be replaced by a new set.
Norplant is likely to be, with the exception of sterilization, the most effective contraceptive ever introduced. More effective than the pill, because its effectiveness is not dependent on someone remembering to take it, it should also have fewer side effects, because it delivers a low, steady dose of a single hormone. According to Bardin, it will cost about $200 to $300 for the five-year dose. The initial cost is high but much less than the cost of using the pill over the same period.
Norplant's history reflects the surprising state of contraception in the United States. It is widely known that the so-called abortion pill, RU-486, has been kept by its manufacturer, Roussel, from all countries except France for fear of the political and economic consequences, although the company is now considering England as another market. But what is perhaps less known is that RU-486 is only one of many contraceptives held off the American market for political or business reasons.

CURIOUSLY, IT WAS an unwitting coalition of longtime adversaries -- manufacturing companies and courtroom litigators; feminists, right-to-life groups and religious activists, including the Catholic Church -- who over the last two decades, working independently, created what is now described as the birth-control backlash.
Three decades after the introduction of the pill, the most popular way of preventing pregnancy among American women and men is sterilization. Among those who use some form of contraception, this most extreme and largely irreversible approach is the choice of 28 percent of the women and 12 percent of the men. The next most popular methods are the oral contraceptive, used by 31 percent, and the condom, used by 15 percent.
In the 1980's, all four American manufacturers of the intrauterine device, the most effective method of birth control after the pill, pulled their products off the market when one, the Dalkon Shield, was found to cause serious and sometimes fatal infections. Political opposition has prevented the use of injectable contraceptives, like Depo-Provera, which is commonly used in other countries.
Abortion serves as the method of birth control for 1.6 million women annually in the nation. At least half turn to abortion after their chosen method of contraception has failed.
Earlier this year, official recognition of the dire situation came in the form of a report by the National Academy of Sciences' Institute of Medicine. Millions of unwanted pregnancies, abortions and sterilizations have occurred in the nation, the report said, because the contraceptive methods available have failed to meet the need.
Dr. Luigi Mastroianni, chairman of the academy's study group and professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center, presented the report at a news conference: "While we in the United States make do with the same range of options available 30 years ago, in some European countries people can choose among contraceptive implants, injectable contraceptives, and a variety of pills, IUD's and sterilization techniques not available here."
Moreover, Mastroianni added, "many European countries are years ahead of the United States in the development of further contraceptive advances." And they are likely to remain so. "The outlook for new contraceptive development is bleak," he said.
Carl Djerassi, a Stanford University chemist who was one of the creators of the pill, agrees with Mastroianni's assessment. "The United States is the only country other than Iran in which the birth-control clock has been set backward during the past decade," he wrote in Science magazine. While some 50 nations have improved their record on birth control and population, he estimates, resolve in this country has flickered.
It is perhaps a sign of the tumbling order of things that Djerassi himself published an article recently in which he advocated a "jet age rhythm method," conjuring an image of the father of the pill turning from his child. "The present crisis in contraceptive R.&D. through the virtual withdrawal of large pharmaceutical companies," he wrote in Science, ". . . suggests we take another look at one of the least efficacious methods, natural family planning." He suggested that chemists develop litmus-type tests to predict and confirm ovulation.
Thus, as Bardin sits with Norplant fanned out on the table before him, he shows some commingled feelings. Strains of chagrin darken the pleasure of the moment. "This is not the best way to develop a contraceptive," he says. "But it appears that for now, this is the way we will have to do it. The system has broken down."
There are 10 other contraceptive products on Bardin's list, including a vaginal ring that dispenses hormones, two male implants that will suppress sperm production but keep libido up, a hormone-releasing intrauterine device, a simple doctor's-office method of male sterilization. They also may have to be brought to market by this unorthodox new route.
Developing contraceptives this way, he says, "is good only if you are opposed to contraception. This way of doing things will certainly keep contraceptives off the market. Listen, we are only a teeny, tiny operation, and we have to spend a huge amount of time fund raising. It takes us a very long time to bring a contraceptive to market." If Norplant succeeds, a small percentage of the profits will be given to the Population Council to finance further research, the rest will go to the distributor, Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories.

MANY EVENTS IN business, politics and law led to the current situation. But perhaps equally influential have been American attitudes toward sex and unwanted pregnancy.
"We are fooling ourselves if we think a technological fix is going to get us out of our dilemma of high rates of pregnancy and abortion," says Dr. Jacqueline Darroch Forrest, the chief of research for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit research and education organization. On a rainy, chilly afternoon in early summer, Forrest sat in her small Manhattan office, surrounded by stacks of journals and books. A spider plant hanging from the ceiling dropped its tentacles onto the tall stacks.
In 1986, Forrest surveyed a group of 760 young American women in low-income groups. Her survey showed that the women on average were afraid of the pill and the intrauterine device because they feared health problems. At the same time, they did not want to use barrier methods, like the condom and diaphragm, because dealing with the issue of birth control with their partners was awkward. Anyway, the women said, those methods were ineffective enough to leave them fearing pregnancy.
Their shyness about dealing with their boyfriends on the issue of birth control is striking. In America, sex is used routinely to sell products and to entertain. But people avoid talking about it when it comes to health. In "sex education" classes around the nation, AIDS is a required topic, Forrest points out, but the details of what constitutes safe sex are often not discussed. "You can tell them about all the bugs they can get and not talk about sex. You can tell them not to become pregnant but not tell them what the negotiating skills are with partners so you can use a condom."
In the mid-1980's, the Guttmacher Institute carried out a case study comparing contraceptive use and outcomes among teen-agers in five European countries and in the United States. When European parents were asked about issues of sexuality, they said their chief worry was to prevent unwanted pregnancies. "I don't think parents there are comfortable about the issues, or about their children having sex," Forrest said, "but I think they're more focussed on trying to avoid harm coming to them that way."
Parents in the United States, however, said their greatest concern was that their teen-agers were having sex. "They focused on the sex rather than the consequences," she said.
The issue was moral, with a result that for teen-agers it came to seem acceptable to have sex only without planning. "It is not so much the spontaneous sex that seems sinful to the young women, but the premeditation," Forrest said.
Ultimately, it is an attitude that affects many women of childbearing age. American men and women have one of the worst records in the industrialized world when it comes to the use of contraception. The physical cost is abortion or pregnancy, either of which is more dangerous in terms of health risks than any contraceptive method.
Forrest's studies have shown, for the first time, just how high the rate of unintended pregnancy is in the United States compared with Europe. Young women in America have double the number of unplanned pregnancies. "It was surprising that we were so different," Forrest commented. "It's not that we were having so much teen-age sex -- that was happening there too -- but here teen-agers are much less likely to use contraceptives." Among those between 15 and 19 years old, the study found, the rate of pregnancy in this country was 95.2 per 1,000 women, compared with 39 in Canada, 46 in England and Wales, 29 in Sweden and 13 in the Netherlands. A similarly high rate existed among women 20 to 24 years old.
The rate of abortions among teen-agers in the United States was also high, 43.5 per 1,000 compared with 14.2 in Canada.
"I just don't understand -- if we don't want to have 1.6 million abortions every year -- why we aren't focusing more efforts to avoid unintentional pregnancy," Forrest said.
In the 16 years she has been tracking the numbers, the carnage from unwanted pregnancy and abortion has continued largely without change. "I think there is a punishment motive there, as well," Forrest said. "Why should we invest in things for these women to do what we don't want them to do?"
She leaned over her desk, resting her cheek on her hand. "I am discouraged. In the era of 'Just say no' and AIDS, people were expecting a return to chastity. But the data say it didn't happen." Between 1982 and 1988, the rate of teen-age girls who had ever had sex rose to 53 percent from what was considered extremely high at 47 percent.
It was chilly in the office, and she pulled her turquoise jacket a little more tightly around her. "I wonder whether we as a country care about this or not?"

THE BIRTH-CONTROL PILL and its medical and political side effects were also a major factor contributing to the current situation.
The pill was relatively cheap, and it could be used without the permission or even the knowledge of men. Thus sexual acts were uncoupled from the biological momentum toward birth; reproductive choice was finally in the hands of women. But the 1960's and 70's were a time of anger. The pill became politicized. The backlash came not only from the right, as might have been expected, but from other quarters as well. It was a multiple collision of forces.
Feminists had for years worked to encourage the creation of the pill, but not long after it appeared, a new generation of women was angered by it. A few years ago, a revised version of the popular women's health manual "Our Bodies, Ourselves," written by the Boston Women's Health Book Collective, recalled the early days of the pill: "The Food and Drug Administration approved the pill for marketing in 1960 without adequate testing or study. A synthetic pill almost 100 percent effective in preventing pregnancy when taken daily, it created tremendous excitement among the medical, scientific, pharmaceutical and population-control communities. . . . The pill became a gigantic experiment: within two years about 1.2 million American women used it."
In fact, the medical side effects of the pill were always very rare, but they came as a shock. Dr. Gabriel Bialy, head of the contraceptive research program at the Federal Government's National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, says the feminist attitude was naive: "There's no such thing as a free ride. Every drug has certain side effects. People should have expected this, but they didn't."
The first pill to come on the market was far stronger than it needed to be: it "represented an overdosage," Bialy says. "The companies didn't understand the effects of the hormones, and needed a product that would be unquestionably effective. So they guessed too high. Companies did recognize the side effects within three or four years and cut back on the dose. But the next thing you know it was a male conspiracy, and the pill was bringing death to women. Generally when people pick up a cause, objectivity is not the prime requirement."
Detecting the side effects before the pill came to market would have required clinical tests on hundreds of thousands of women. But even after the side effects became apparent, doctors continued to prescribe it. Barbara Seaman, author of the 1969 book "The Doctor's Case Against the Pill," recalled for National Public Radio in a recent program that many women were unaware of the possible side effects. "Doctors were not telling them. So I just got angrier and angrier about that. I felt it was our bodies . . . what right did they have to give normal healthy women a very powerful medication to take year in and year out, that in one degree or another would kill a few of them and maim more than a few of them?"
Another writer, Jane O'Reilly, prefers to think of herself and other women as pioneers. "We could either look at ourselves as guinea pigs who were used, or we could look at ourselves as martyrs and heroes of the women's movement," she said recently on the same program. "Because, by trying it . . . we did discover what would be safer. But principally we discovered what it was like to take control of our reproductive lives."
For some, the experience with the pill was the catalyst to organization. By the time Senator Gaylord Nelson held hearings on the safety of the pill in 1970, early pamphlet editions of "Our Bodies, Ourselves" were already being published. The National Women's Health Network was formed in 1975 when Barbara Seaman and Belita Cowan wanted to establish a full-time feminist health lobby in Washington.
The fear of harm to women has remained a theme over the years. Feminists now advocate the use of diaphragms or cervical caps, with abortion as a backup, according to Judy Norsigian, co-director of the Boston Women's Health Book Collective and a board member of the National Women's Health Network. The backup may be necessary because these barrier methods are relatively ineffective.
The National Women's Health Network urges caution with methods that use hormones to stop ovulation, like the pill. In order of preference, the group lists even spermicides and natural birth control (observation of the body's cyclical fluctuations) ahead of the pill in preference. This has put them in the unfortunate position of appearing elitist, by advocating the methods most effectively used by affluent white women like themselves, but which are most unacceptable and startlingly unsuccessful among the disadvantaged. (The pregnancy rate for white women who use the diaphragm as their method of birth control ranges from 10.3 to 22.5 percent. The rate for nonwhite women is 30.3 to 57 percent.)
Another contraceptive plagued by the fear of side effects was Depo-Provera, an injectable contraceptive that used hormones similar to those in the pill. In 1974, the F.D.A. decided to approve Depo-Provera, made by Upjohn, for use as a contraceptive; it was already being used to treat cancer, and had been on the market in other countries for contraception. But the agency deferred further action after a campaign led by feminists who cited unwanted side effects. For more than two decades, the debate raged.
"Among the companies, the feeling was that if they throw out this one, they could throw out anything," says Richard A. Edgren, director of scientific affairs at Syntex Laboratories, a leading manufacturer of the pill. "It was tainted forever. This said to the companies, that after 100 million dollars of work, women can throw it out, even after the F.D.A. approved it." Finally Upjohn decided not to resubmit its application for approval.
"Upjohn said, 'We'll never do it again,' " Edgren says. "I can't believe how fast and how completely they shut down. They fired people and retrained the rest for other areas."
Then in the 1970's came the Dalkon Shield, an intrauterine device made by A. H. Robins Company. In the Gaylord Nelson hearings of 1969 and 1970, it was one product mentioned as an alternative to the pill. In fact, the Dalkon Shield turned out to be far more dangerous.
When serious infections began to be reported in large numbers, company executives hid the facts. Some 320,000 claims were filed against the company, and eventually it was ordered to pay compensatory and punitive damages. In bankruptcy proceedings a year or so later, it was ordered to set aside $2.475 billion to pay the claims.
Now, as Norplant is about to be put on the market, the worries continue. The National Women's Health Network has announced its opposition to its approval and marketing; the group suggested more research was needed.

ULTIMATELY, THE TURMOIL had its effect on the contraceptive business. For the executives who have run the contraceptive divisions of pharmaceutical companies, the matter became one of doing business in what they call "a difficult climate."
The plain-spoken and feisty Roderick L. Mackenzie, chairman of Gynopharma Inc., a small contraceptive manufacturer in New Jersey, which markets one of only two IUD's now sold in the country, complains: "The F.D.A. put major restrictions on development; organized women's groups campaigned against the pill and other methods. This is not a very encouraging atmosphere. After the baby has been thrown out with the bath water, then they say: Hey, why is everybody out of business?"
A major argument put forward by some companies and by the report of the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences, is that lawsuits against the companies were a key factor in the decline in America's work on birth control. "It is an article of faith," Mackenzie says, "that the litigious climate in the United States has created such a product-liability monster that all of the problems facing women and their contraceptive choices in the United States can be blamed on this truth."
But, he adds, taking a listener by surprise: "Everybody believes this except the senior executives of the prescription-contraceptive businesses. The reason these executives don't believe this is they know the facts. The truth of the matter is that the cost of defense, insurance premiums, settlements and court-mandated judgments has not been overwhelming. It represents a very small cost when measured as a percentage of sales over the past 5, 10 or 20 years."
Edgren, who has worked at Searle, Wyeth and Warner-Lambert as well as at Syntex, said the anger of the 1960's and 1970's was demoralizing. "During that period more and more companies began pulling out. There was litigation that people were starting to worry about, there was bad publicity." But he too is surprisingly frank, as he adds: "But mostly it looked as if the market was saturated -- there were quite a number of companies selling the pill. It looked like new products might not do well financially, so they started pulling out.
"You can keep four or five researchers busy in the area of reproduction, but you could put the same four or five in cardiovascular research and be likely to come out with a more lucrative product. After all, there are about 50 million customers of reproductive age. But there are darn near 100 percent of the whole population as it gets older who will need these other products."
After 45 minutes of explaining some details of the situation to a reporter, MacKenzie paused.
"Look," he said, "you must bear in mind that there were billion-dollar single entities out there, like Tagamet for ulcers. Immunotherapy drugs. Cardiovascular drugs. In those fields you don't have to be 100 percent effective, you can be 70 percent effective. Your side effects don't have to be zero, they can be 20 percent and still not be unacceptable. You don't have a sea of bad publicity endangering your other drugs, and your researchers can get Nobel Prizes."
Companies actually stayed in the field longer than one might have expected, he maintains. Not only dollars and cents were involved. There was some sense of social responsibility. "But over 15 years people got exhausted and got out."
A few small companies have picked up the flag from the fallen majors. Alza, a California pharmaceutical corporation, has for the past few years been selling an IUD. Peter F. Carpenter, a preppy-looking executive who is president of Alza's development branch, is one of those leading the effort to bring new birth-control devices to market.
"My sense of what's happening is that things are getting very polarized, a time when everybody but the fiercest bows out of the argument," he says. "I find it a very ominous development because in a democracy we need to find a common ground. Contraception has become politicized. We as a society do not deal well with controversy, and leave it to those on either end to fight it out.
"The prudent businessman will stay away from controversy because it exposes his entire product line to boycott," he says. "What would happen if we sacrificed earnings for three years to do something interesting? The Wall Street people would say: 'Hey that's nice. I'll get out and come back later.' It is very hard to take the long-term perspective.
"As a consequence," Carpenter says, "here we sit in the most advanced society in the world, and a woman here has fewer contraceptives than any woman in the developed world."
The decision has been taken in business -- and in government. The Federal Government has abandoned its position that slowing population growth in the world is essential. It has withdrawn funds from the International Planned Parenthood Federation and the United Nations' Fund for Population Activities. Congress has failed to reauthorize domestic family-planning legislation for four years, effectively freezing funds for the nation's clinics.
And the embodiment of the Government's concern about birth control, the contraceptive research program at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development has been budgeted at about the same level for the past 15 years, despite an inflationary spiral. An era has ended. Having created modern contraception, having convinced the world of the importance of birth control, America has abdicated leadership in the field.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Heard About the Copy Shop In Budapest?

BYLINE: BY FRED MARTIN; Fred Martin is president of the Bancroft Group, an international business consulting firm in Washington.

 BODY:
At day's end, the exhausted business travelers gather in the bars of Budapest's hotels -- the Forum, the Hyatt, the Gellert -- and trade stories. They are happy warriors, frontiersmen on the edge of an entrepreneurial wilderness, proud of their exploits and bemused by the strangeness of local ways. They love to tell war stories, show their medals from the front. One night it was the Japanese fellow who told of selling turbines to Bulgaria in exchange for eggs. For several months afterward, he couldn't get an omelet in the hotel's dining room.
Then there was the English hotelier who told of flying from Helsinki to Leningrad, standing in the aisle because there were no available seats. We wondered when Aeroflot would install straps. And there was the Kodak man who topped them all. Not long ago, on his first trip to Moscow, he was deciding what to order in a restaurant on Red Square. Looking around, he saw a nearby diner eating chicken, and said to the waiter, "I'll have what he's having." The waiter walked over, picked up the plate of food and gave it to the Kodak man. 
 Most misunderstandings are less dramatic, but there is plenty of room for confusion when Westerners and Eastern Europeans get together to discuss business. This story tells of one attempt to start a small business in downtown Budapest during a year of momentous economic and political change, and of the cultural miscues that ensued.
My firm represents large American manufacturing companies, hotel chains and retailers trying to invest in or start up operations in Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Romania. We also help individuals make investments. One of our clients, Paul Panitz, a businessman in Washington, had the idea of opening a small shop in Hungary, an idea that appealed to me as a challenge: it would mean engaging in precisely the kind of entrepreneurship that Eastern Europe needs to create free markets.
In the 11 months since this collaboration began, my company has helped large corporate clients execute significant deals in Eastern Europe, but nothing has been more difficult or frustrating than starting this shop -- and nothing could have been more instructive in demonstrating how the wheels of commerce turn in Eastern Europe.
Paul Panitz is a 43-year-old who created his own typesetting company and then sold it for a substantial sum three years ago, leaving him free to pursue other projects. Like many people, he was moved by last year's historic events in Eastern Europe and wanted to be part of them. He first approached me in February 1990, asking for advice on how to aid the cause of a free press in Eastern Europe. (Eventually, we made a loan-equity deal with a large daily newspaper over there, lending a fair amount of money in return for a potential stake in the company.) We also discussed setting up a small business in Hungary, not unlike the one Paul had started in America. The venture would throw us into the thick of Eastern European economic change; it would contribute some capital and jobs to Hungary's fledgling free market, and, properly run, it just might turn a profit someday.
I suggested a copy shop. Tight Government control of information had left Hungary with inadequate copying technology and services. There were probably fewer than 10 color photocopiers in the entire country. Here was an opportunity. Paul, who knew the typesetting business, liked the idea. We set to work.
Our first step was to seek a third partner with expertise in the copy business. We took in Dirck Holscher, 43, an old friend of Paul's and half-owner of a successful chain of copy shops in Washington. The three of us drew up a business plan, estimated our start-up capital at $200,000 and quickly agreed on rules to govern our partnership. We discussed the mix of machines and services, the volume of business necessary to turn a profit, marketing, staffing and all the other things that go into creating a new business. Isn't this impressive? I thought. The American way of doing business -- orderly, logical, responsible.

SOON AFTERWARD, ON A BUSINESS TRIP TO BUDAPEST, I VISITED a real-estate agency. I suspected that leasing space would be one of the hardest things to do in this venture, and I was right. Accompanied by a translator, I visited one of the largest agencies in town. I explained that I was looking for roughly 1,000 square feet of ground-floor space in the Fifth District, the central commercial part of town. Impossible, the agent said. There was nothing available in the Fifth District. I offered to pay a premium. The agent said she would look, and we agreed to talk again in a few weeks.
Budapest is a busy, imposing city of two million. Buildings from the 19th century still show their elaborate decoration, marred as it is by falling masonry and unpatched bullet holes dating from the battle between the advancing Russians and the retreating Germans in 1945, and also from the 1956 revolution. The Danube splits the city in two, and at night the lighted bridges and hills on the Buda side make an enchanting scene.
And yet for all its charm, Hungary is a hard place to get things done, for foreigners as well as for natives. Most Hungarians don't have telephones, and the phones that are available don't always yield a dial tone. Buying a train ticket can take several hours. Changing a plane reservation is often an ordeal, requiring a personal visit to the airline office or a branch of the state-owned travel agency. Creating a foreign-owned corporation takes six months: you need to get approvals from two different ministries and one court -- and Hungary is more advanced than any other Eastern European nation in its foreign investment laws.
Hungary is the Eastern European country that many people singled out as most likely to succeed in a free market. Well before revolution swept over Eastern Europe a year ago, Hungary had moved away from central planning and allowed a measure of free enterprise and foreign investment. The result was something called Goulash Communism. Westerners, however, often failed to note that Hungary still needed time to develop the constellation of habits that drive a capitalist economy. The country lacked accounting principles, a rational legal structure, clear-cut property laws.
Walking near my hotel one afternoon, I noticed many shops on fancy streets -- stores selling toys, fabrics, food, office equipment -- with no customers. This sight was familiar from previous trips, and I wondered how long these loss-producing establishments could continue to operate before the state, which owns most of them, pulled the plug.
I went to a Hungarian friend, a specialist in joint ventures, and asked for advice: how could we rent space in the Fifth District? She advised me to walk down the street, pick out the store we liked, then go inside and ask if we could rent it or form a joint venture with the user of the space. This struck me as a peculiar strategy -- and I did not follow it then -- but it wasn't bad advice. When a system is self-destructing, deal with its smallest parts.
Before long, the real-estate firm reported that it had found space for us. I brought Paul to Budapest, and he visited the sites. Then the confusion began. The agency informed Paul that to have the space we would first have to buy the right to use it, for around $200,000. (In Hungary, since 1949, there are essentially two different kinds of property rights: that of the owner and that of the user. The state owns most property, but often a state-owned company, cooperative or other entity holds the user rights.) We explained that we merely wished to rent a storefront, not buy one. The agency was unimpressed.
Later, our translator told us that the people at the real-estate agency had thought Paul a con man. He didn't wear a suit and tie, for one thing, and his manner was suspicious: he rejected outright the idea of buying a store or building, and he kept repeating what the partnership was after and what it was prepared to pay. All this struck the real-estate agent as a little pushy, undiplomatic, even tasteless.
The Hungarian way is to observe the formalities -- to respect one's opposite, to negotiate rather than say no, to respond politely, formally, even ornately. Hungarians are very careful to preserve the dignity of a situation. They will not telephone someone for you unless they know his full name. "Mr. X" will not do, and using the first name alone is unthinkable. They are punctilious about formal and informal usages -- not just the familiar and unfamiliar pronouns, as in French and German, but the linguistic decorum that they entail. Hungarians employ two different words just to say goodbye, depending on the formality of the occasion. They offer refreshments at every business meeting, to show respect for their guest. When a business discussion has concluded, it is common to adjourn to a large dinner with wine and toasts, even if the prospects of making a deal are obviously remote.
Something more than etiquette was at stake, however, in the charge of "con man." Moneymaking is still suspect in some quarters in Eastern Europe. Whether this suspicion predates the 1940's, and is part of an aristocratic disdain for commerce, or whether it is a cultural vestige of Communist rule is hard to tell; but a cultural bias against capitalism does exist. The pursuit of money is not widely respected; it is associated with greed, tawdriness and unfairness. As a consequence, some of the most visible new entrepreneurs in Eastern Europe have operated at the margins of acceptability -- money-changers and black marketeers. You cannot make money without cheating someone, a Romanian told me. Property is theft.
A few months later, we called up a Hungarian friend in a large state-owned company and asked if he knew of anybody with space to rent. He said he knew of another state-owned company that was having hard times and was looking for capital. Perhaps it would rent one of its many storefronts in downtown Budapest to stem the losses. This struck me as an excellent idea. Not only would such a deal help us, it would provide just what the Hungarian economy needed: an infusion of cash to revive a failing company while creating new enterprise.
Paul and I went to visit a retail shop owned by this company, and soon saw that many people were still working there. What would become of them? we asked. Our friend replied that this could be worked out. Not easily, it turned out. Later, the company director said yes, of course, we could rent the space, but the current enterprise would continue to operate from the premises. When we asked how this would work, the director proposed sharing the front door but partitioning off the interior. Odd though this may sound, many businesses operate this way in Eastern Europe because of the space shortage. We were prepared to accept such an arrangement. We left my Hungarian friend to work out the details.

THEN OUR TROUBLES escalated. The Hungarian Government began to review all the directors of state-owned companies -- some 20,000 bosses in all -- to determine whether they should keep their jobs. This review was perfectly reasonable -- some managers of companies were suspected of corruption, or just plain torpor -- and a thorough review would result in the strongest possible leaders for Hungary's leading enterprises.
Unfortunately for us, the review put a cloud over all negotiations, even negotiations as small as renting half of one little store for cash. Company directors were afraid that they would be accused of corruption, of disposing of company assets for personal gain. To ward off any hint of suspicion, in midsummer they simply stopped making deals for several weeks.
By this point, we had decided to cast a wide net. We had at least four people looking for space for us. An American manufacturer of copiers had agreed to supply our machines. Large institutions were prepared to sign on as customers. We had created an American corporation and had begun the lengthy process of creating a Hungarian company. All was ready, but we had no space.
One lead, a Hungarian construction contractor named Miklos, assured us he could find us a storefront. This sounded promising. Miklos, a hard charger, talked even faster than he drove, and whenever we saw him he seemed to have three conversations and three deals going simultanously. Surely, Miklos was our man.
But every meeting we had with Miklos tended to center on other issues. One day, he introduced us to a renowned environmentalist, and we talked about the looming environmental crisis in Hungary. At the next meeting, Miklos showed me designs for converting an ancient castle into a hotel resort and spa. (For a while, someone new would bring me a castle deal about once a week.) Then it was an import-export business that Miklos wanted to start with us.
This style of negotiating soon became familiar to us. We called it the Salami Syndrome. The experience is something like going into a delicatessen, asking for a doughnut and having the counterman offer to sell you salami. The discussion turns not on how much you will pay for the doughnut but on how much salami you will buy in order to get the doughnut.
At every meeting, we would steer the conversation back to our copy shop, and finally Miklos started to show us space. We looked at several shops in the center of the city and told him that any one of them would do. Miklos said: "Great. We'll put the jewelry store on the first level and the copy shop on the second." We said we didn't want to have a combination jewelry store-copy shop. Miklos looked disappointed and said the copy shop would never make any money, but he would help us anyway. We went with Miklos to the state-owned company that owned the storefront we liked best, and Miklos signed a letter of intent with the firm's counsel.
At last, we thought, we're getting somewhere. Soon, however, we discovered that Miklos had gone ahead and rented the entire space for his jewelry store, cutting us out. (In a year and a half of business transactions in Eastern Europe, this was the only instance I have encountered of double-dealing, which I suspect is a lower rate than occurs in the United States.)

BY NOW IT WAS Summer. The streets filled up with tourists, the weather was warm and Budapest was beautiful. Something else was changing, too: there were boarded-up storefronts, closed shops throughout the city. The new Government had begun cutting the national budget, which meant cutting subsidies to loss-producing firms, and as a consequence (or in anticipation of these cuts), companies were beginning to close down their stagnant stores. This was a painful, although necessary, step for the Hungarian economy; it was also one that opened the door to foreign investment like ours.
With renewed energy, then, in July and August we inspected dozens of storefronts in Budapest and held several negotiating sessions with the worried managers of bankrupt companies. The terms were similar in most cases: around 1,000 square feet for anywhere from $1,000 to $3,000 a month, depending on the location. We also discussed joint-venture possibilities, in which event the concern firm would throw in the space and receive a percentage of equity in return. Sometimes the company would insist on a year's rent in advance, a practice also common in retail leasing in America. (A friend negotiating in Russia was asked for 25 years' rent up front, which struck him more as a World Bank loan than a lease.)
By September, we had three or four options and were entering the final stages of negotiations. One of the properties was owned by a large export company (state-owned, of course), whose manager, Sandor, insisted on taking us out to a lavish dinner after showing us the premises. For several hours, this elderly, charming man told us how he rose through the ranks of various state enterprises, first in the provinces, then in Budapest. It had not been an easy life, reading the minds of the apparatchiks in the hierarchy, but Sandor had always landed on his feet.
We drank toast after toast of sweet Tokay wine, pledging lasting friendship and fruitful collaboration between our two enterprises for years to come. When I rose to leave, he presented me with bottles of wine and kissed me on both cheeks. I left the restaurant charged with the warmth and strength of these people, steeled for hardship by a difficult history.
But I also left feeling that Sandor had been a little too emotional. One week later, we learned that soon after the dinner he had been dismissed and pensioned off, one of the managers who had not passed muster, perhaps deemed to be the old guard, not up to the task of managing the transition to free markets. Whatever the reason, Sandor was gone, and I thought, not for the first time, that if we found this transition hard to take, the Hungarians were finding it excruciating.
With Sandor out, we turned our attention to a former beauty parlor on Engels Square, near the Danube. It is close by Rosenberg Street, named for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the American Communists executed for spying. On Oct. 3, we put our deposit down and told the owner we would rent it. Five days later, we learned that Parliament had just passed a law prohibiting many transfers of commercial property pending a review by the State Property Agency; moreover, completed transactions, going back to the fall of 1988, would be reviewed by the same agency. The intent of the new law was to prevent corruption; the effect was to stop all transactions in their tracks, including ours.
Hungarians often refer to "the little door," meaning loophole. Everyone professes to be an expert at finding it. For 40 years, skirting the rules has been the routine method of doing business. But this time, it appeared, there was to be no little door. Not only did the law make it illegal to rent space without review by the State Property Agency, but flouting it was precisely the kind of suspect behavior that would endanger a manager's job in post-Communist Hungary.
We now had the odd experience of walking the streets of Budapest past boarded-up storefronts owned by bankrupt companies that were barred from taking our eagerly offered money. Our only recourse was to propose a joint venture with an existing store and thereby get the use of its space. One fellow operating a copy shop and printing store was eager to make a deal. But when we talked it over, we learned that he also ran an export-import business that he wanted to share with us -- the Salami Syndrome -- and that, moreover, he intended to continue running his own copy shop while being a co-owner of ours. Pressed about the possible conflict of interest, he replied that there was enough business to go around.
Conflict of interest is not a fully developed concept in Eastern Europe. During one public bid in which I participated, involving an environmental facility, the management of the bid was handled by a state-owned company, at the behest of the ministry sponsoring the bid. The state-owned company had hopes, like most enterprises, of becoming a private shareholding company. This became apparent at a discussion we held with its managers concerning details of the bidding process. During the discussion, the managers said that they would like their company to play a role in the project after the bid was awarded. I asked who would decide whether they would have that chance. The managers replied, "You will decide that, if you win the bid."
I was, of course, surprised that one of the judges of the tender should also contemplate negotiating with the bidders about his own share in the award. It seemed to me an insuperable conflict of interest. But this was one of my first public tenders in Eastern Europe. I have encountered the same thing several times since. Never is the proposal made under the table; in fact, the very publicness of the proposal indicates that nothing incorrect is thought to be occurring. Rather, in a system where 95 percent of the enterprises are owned by the state, one must necessarily have a state enterprise as a partner in any substantial venture. The confusion occurs because these same state enterprises are trying to establish themselves as private enterprises by raising capital, issuing stock to shareholders and making themselves profitable. Thus, the people running the state-owned company, who still have extensive claims on public power, access and privileges by virtue of their connections to the Government, also suddenly have very personal motives for making a deal.
Hungarians are keenly aware of this problem. That is why the Parliament has frozen transactions pending a review by the State Property Agency: to prevent current managers and foreign investors from making sweetheart deals. But the line between public and private is still blurred.
Privatizing with the right mix of efficiency and justice is only one of the problems facing Hungarians today. The average family income is $200 a month; the standard of living is extremely low. Prices are rising. The assumption that everyone will be taken care of, fostered by years of socialism, will be hard to change. So will the corollary assumption: that everything belongs to everyone. On one of my early trips to Budapest, I bought a book from the Museum of Fine Arts in German because the museum store had run out of the English version. A Hungarian friend told me to take the book to any bookstore downtown and exchange it for the English version. I was skeptical that any store would exchange a used book bought elsewhere for a new one. But he was right: with no questions asked, a clerk exchanged the German for the English book. My friend explained: "They don't care. It's not their book. In a way, they do not feel entitled to withhold the book from you."

MEANWHILE, WE HAVE taken an apartment in Budapest, now occupied by Paul. We have sent more troops in to join him and have hired additional Hungarians as well. All these people are working on several projects, all of them with a dollar value that dwarfs the copy shop. But our small venture is the greater challenge.
Paradoxically, the larger the deal, the easier the negotiation. You're dealing with the very top of the power structure, where it's possible to cut through the extraordinary bureaucratic accretion, the rules designed to thwart initiative in any state-directed economy. A Communist system is perfect for approving deals from the top; what it does not encourage or comfortably tolerate is individuals who come forward with an idea of their own to start an enterprise of their own.
The Hungarian system is no longer Communist; but it's not a free market yet, either. It's in transition, and because of that it is harder to do even the big deals today than it was a year ago. But we are stubborn -- in fact, obsessed. This has become a test of wills: against us (and the Hungarians) is a chaotic, rule-bound economy in the process of being confusedly dismantled. We do not intend to give up. We are still negotiating with a state-owned enterprise to form a joint venture. Under the proposed terms, we will invest money and management expertise; our Hungarian partner will contribute its flagship store and personnel, along with substantial experience in how to do business in Hungary. If the deal goes through, all we'll have to worry about is the collapsing economy of Eastern Europe -- and whether people in Budapest have a lot of documents to copy.

HEADLINE: 'Radical' Rap: Of Pride and Prejudice

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
One lesson of the 1990 elections was that politicians would rather not talk about politics -- taking sides on issues can be too risky. Mainstream popular culture prefers to stay on the sidelines, too, since there's no use in alienating a potential fan. When pop singers get earnest, the message is likely to be about compassion and charity rather than anger, resistance or placing blame.
The only militant messages headed for the pop charts appear in rap songs: a new contingent of self-described "radical" rappers are determined to carry serious ideas onto tape decks and dance floors. Three years ago, Public Enemy was the only rap group taking a combative stance on issues; now, half a dozen bands have followed up, while established groups make at least token efforts to be "righteous." 
 While uncontroversial, slow-chanting rap showmen like M. C. Hammer have sold millions of albums, rap is still so close to street level that some rappers have decided they have nothing to lose by stating harsh, even divisive convictions. Hearing the raps of Laquan, Movement Ex or Paris, who are among the better new radical rappers, is to hear the shape of urban debates to come -- on race, education, drugs and crime. The rhetoric heard in New York street demonstrations resounds in rap songs that urge black solidarity and demand an end to compromise.
To an outsider, radical rap is thoroughly mixed, an amalgam of unassailable facts, penetrating insights, arguable interpretations, anger, demagoguery, paranoia and hard-headed resistance. Its vision of America as a racial and economic battleground is apocalyptic. But that image is simply the flip side of the typical, 6 o'clock-news image of the inner city as a lawless jungle. From the inside looking out, radical rap assigns blame for the situation to powerful outside forces and promotes self-help as the only solution. While no one can promulgate a complete political program in a five-minute song, radical rappers do their best to hammer home their ideology.
 These rappers simply assume they are speaking to young black audiences, "Brother to Brother," as a song by Laquan puts it. To reach the listeners they hope to teach -- listeners more attuned to flashy electronic media than to books -- they often set their militant messages alongside boasts about verbal, pugilistic and sexual prowess. Their music is as individual as different disk jockeys and voices make it; Brand Nubian and Poor Righteous Teachers are jaunty and playful, Paris and Movement Ex are stark and somber, Laquan uses primarily live rather than recorded backup and lets slick pop choruses buoy his songs.
But the messages are adamant and, given the contentiousness of most rap, surprisingly unanimous -- in part because most radical rappers (beginning with Public Enemy) echo the teachings of the Nation of Islam, the Black Muslim group. The rappers are believers who ground their ideas in the unshakable tenets of their own variety of fundamentalism. When rappers talk about the "original Asiatic black man" and "devils," they are alluding to Nation of Islam beliefs that the first humans were black and were crossbred by devils to produce lighter and lighter races.
Radical rappers don't spout racist, anti-white rhetoric, although they do allude to Black Muslim genetic theories. In "I Deal With Mathematics," Movement Ex raps, "You ask who's the original and I reply I am/ At 200 degrees in the shade it couldn't be a white man/ Must know and understand that their skin has no melanin." More often, the rappers denounce white racism for specific malfeasances. "You want to erase my misplaced race/ Just to make America a beautiful white place," Intellectual Hoodlum snarls. As the successful re-election campaign of Senator Jesse Helms and surprisingly high turnout in Louisiana for the ex-Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke suggest, racial tension generates a strong response.
 For radical rappers, black Americans are the victims of kidnapping (through slave trade), theft (of labor and culture), brainwashing (through education) and imminent genocide (through crack, AIDS and murder). The rappers urge re-education, discipline, unity and black self-reliance, while they are divided on how far to go in self-defense. Movement Ex declares, "In order to be free, you gots to have a shotgun." After rapping about the abuse that greeted a black march through the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to protest the fatal shooting of Yusuf Hawkins, Brand Nubian says, "I wanted to get violent but I'm a lover of black mothers/ And black mothers need sons, not children that's been killed by guns."
In some ways, rap is replaying the schisms of civil-rights activism in the 1960's. The ideas, and sometimes the recorded voices, of Malcolm X and of Black Panther Party firebrands have been revived by radical rappers; so have questions of cultural nationalism, of violence versus nonviolence, of evolution versus revolution. One difference is that the colloquy now takes place in recordings issued by major companies, which are happy to see activism turned into a profitable commodity. (Laquan raps, "Most of you want to do what I do/ State facts on wax and make a million or two," though he's not making millions yet.)
Another difference is that integration is not discussed, except to put down blacks who wear blue-tinged contact lenses or date whites. Racial separation is virtually assumed, but there's no simple "black is beautiful" equation; upwardly mobile blacks who have, as Paris puts it, "been trained/ To respect the game but you turn your/ Back on a black with the same claim" are targets for derision.
When it comes to practical matters, radical rappers agree with more established authorities. They denounce drug use and drug dealing; as the rapper Paris chants, "I'm above a thug/ Killin' off his own, tryin' to make a buck." And they urge listeners to practice safe sex: "You better wear a prophylactic/ 'Cause things are getting drastic," Brand Nubian advises. But they have little use for the authorities they see daily. For radical rappers, the police are a source of brutality and harassment, not order; in Paris's "Warning," five police officers shake down a 13-year-old -- "Up against the wall hands in the air/ Just wants to pump the fear" -- and the rapper vows vengeance if something like that happens to him.
 Up the political ladder, anger turns to disgust. Laquan's "Imprison the President" denounces Willie Horton commercials ("Frighten whites on election night"), the invasion of Panama ("Start a war, what the hell for/ Take him out he won't talk no more"), the savings-and-loan bailout ("The banks are bankrupt, the Congress corrupt") and "False prophets and demagogues/ Livin' large while the people starve."
Regarding education, radical rappers are Afrocentric. They have joined the current academic battle over what education should be in a multicultural United States. They insist that Africa, not Europe, is the original fount of culture, science and philosophy; X-Clan and Brand Nubian proudly drop the names of Egyptian places and deities. And they want to shift the cultural credit back to Africa, instilling pride in a younger black generation and revising the historical record (itself a matter of heated debate); some also want to revive African traditions and rituals, a tricky proposition in a modern industrial culture. Still, the emergence of radical rap cements rap's connection to the West African griot tradition, in which musicians carry history and commentary as well as stories.
The seminal radical rap group, still unmatched for musical innovation and verbal dexterity, is, of course, Public Enemy, which single-handedly raised the political stakes for rap. Before the rap era, performers like the Last Poets and Gil Scott-Heron had linked political poetry and music, but by the mid-1980's most rap had turned away from their example (and away from hard-hitting early rap singles like Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five's "Message" and "White Lines") in favor of elaborate boasts.
Public Enemy's first album, "Yo! Bum Rush the Show," released in 1987, carved out a new place for rap, as its best songs moved beyond individual bragging to insist that rap could speak to, and for, a community of young blacks. The self-assertion that was implicit in earlier rap became explicit in lyrics by Carlton (Chuck D.) Ridenhour's lyrics, a demand for empowerment that was backed up by the music's corrosive atonality and Mr. Ridenhour's stentorian, syncopated delivery. Whether the band was perceived as invigorating or menacing, no one who heard Public Enemy could ignore it.
 Over the course of three albums, Public Enemy has been entangled in a continuing string of controversies. Yet the band's verbal and sonic rage, and Chuck D.'s willingness to examine topics from the F.B.I.'s infiltration of the Black Panther Party to media hype to white flight from cities, brought them an audience in the millions. Meanwhile, Kris (K.R.S.-One) Parker's Boogie Down Productions sold hundreds of thousands of albums with austere, didactic raps, using stripped-down drumbeats and a touch of reggae.
Part of the audience may have bought the albums for novelty value or the thrill of self-righteousness. But Public Enemy and Boogie Down Productions also registered the sense of urgency as urban ghettos grow increasingly desperate and audiences want to know why and what to do. The bandwagon is now big enough for opportunists as well as idealists. As King Sun says, "Now everybody's wearing the red, black and green" (the colors of black liberation). Then again, King Sun's second album, "Righteous but Ruthless," marks a late conversion to righteousness; it has as many gangster (ruthless) raps as righteous ones.
 Radical rap has its thinkers and posers, and it is evolving fast. And despite the dogma and occasional wrong-headedness, it remains one of the most promising zones of popular music. It confronts problems with commitment rather than apathy or nihilism or escapism, and where most popular music promotes pleasure, radical rap urges listeners to seek knowledge before titillation (even if the specifics of that "knowledge" are sometimes dubious). Radical rappers aspire to be teachers, not gangsters. The question is whether they are building a movement, or simply a market.
 
 
ACTIVIST ALBUMS
 Here is a selection of new militant rap albums, listed in order of preference. All are available as LP's, cassettes and CD's.
"Movement Ex" (Columbia CK 46894): Hard-nosed arrangements and fast-talking, exclusively political lyrics, including a rare environmental-disaster rap and a song denouncing Santa Claus.
Paris: "The Devil Made Me Do It" (Tommy Boy 1030): Paris, who wants to revive the legacy of the Black Panther Party, has a 10-point program, a low, implacable voice and, as producer and arranger, an ear for ominous combinations of sounds. Raps like "The Hate That Hate Made," about escalating racial incidents, plunge into situations where nobody has a clear-cut moral advantage.
Laquan: "Notes of a Native Son" (Fourth and Broadway 444 029): Midtempo funk and jazz-funk, played primarily by live musicians, carry the somber rhymes of what may be the most serious 16-year-old in Los Angeles.
Poor Righteous Teachers: "Holy Intellect" (Profile 1289): Nimble, free-associative raps over riffs that change just often enough, like a more politically explicit De La Soul.
"Intelligent Hoodlum" (A&M 75021 5311): Percy Chapman, a k a Tragedy, raps about his experiences in prison and reprises slogans -- "America's a prison and we want to be released" -- as if he'd discovered them himself. Marley Marl's backing is stripped-down but propulsive.
Brand Nubian: "One for All" (Elektra 9 60946): A peculiar merger of sexual boasting, self-promotion and occasional political perspective. The lyrics carom around easygoing pop-jazz riffs, but Brand Nubian doesn't take its own advice: "Civilized man's main goal is to teach."
X-Clan: "To the East, Blackwards" (Fourth and Broadway 444 019): Incantations for the converted, full of references to Egypt, black American revolutionaries and "the crossroads," rapped in the artificial-sounding tones of radio disk jockeys.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1908 words

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
Disenchanted, and Trying to Laugh About It

BYLINE: By David Richards

 BODY:
Whatever else it's remembered for -- and that will probably not be a great deal -- "The Big Funk" by John Patrick Shanley may nonetheless take credit for momentarily elevating the bubble bath to a position of prominence in the theater.
The cinema has always appreciated the peekaboo possibilities of suds, of course, and television soap commercials are forever showing us how mountains of foam make for a happy all-American family. But the last time I saw someone luxuriating in a tub on stage was a revival of "The Women" by Clare Booth Luce. The woman in question was a catty husband-stealer, and her willingness to loll about all day in hot water was equated with her brazen lack of morals. 
 Mr. Shanley has far sweeter purposes in mind, when the curtains at the Public Theater's Anspacher Theater part to reveal a pink and rose marble tub and in it, a very recalcitrant young woman named Jill (Jeanne Tripplehorn) whose experiences with the opposite sex have tended up to this point to be highly degrading. Only a few scenes earlier, in fact, we are privy to a characteristically disastrous date -- this one with a British lout, who plops a family-size jar of Vaseline on the cafe table and then says in a tone Rasputin would have applauded, "I think you want to get a little shiny. I think you want to get a little greasy."
Thereupon, while she sits passively and he hums "It's a Long Way to Tipperary," he proceeds to smear her face and hair with petroleum jelly. She is eventually saved from this humiliation by Austin (Jake Weber) -- an unemployed actor, the self-proclaimed hero of the play and, it would appear, Mr. Shanley's mouthpiece, although I should point out that all the characters spend a large part of their time sharing their musings on life and death with the audience. Viewing himself as something of a constructive person, Austin convinces Jill to come home with him and let him clean her up. Which is more or less how she winds up in that tub -- her teeth on edge and her body steeled against who knows what perversity to come.
But no. Austin is just what he says he is -- a man who's only trying to tidy up a small corner of a messy universe every day -- and he's put on a blue suit to show his honorable intentions. "This is so much better than fighting with people in the street," he reassures Jill, as he squeezes a wet sponge over her head and lathers up her hair. "The Girl From Ipanema" is playing on the tape deck, his touch is gentle and after a while even she has begun to wiggle her toes with enjoyment. Once she's whistle-clean, Austin helps her out of the tub, dusts her down with a circus-sized powder puff, then, surveying his work, proclaims proudly, "Good as new."
As Mr. Shanley himself has staged the scene and Mr. Weber and the beauteous Ms. Tripplehorn play it, it's oddly beguiling -- a little bit of Eden reclaimed from what the playwright clearly sees as a neurotic, self-destructive world, suffering from near terminal paralysis.
Were it not for a persistent optimism-in-spite-of-it-all (Mr. Shanley is, we shouldn't forget, the author of the buoyant screenplay for "Moonstruck"), "The Big Funk" could easily be mistaken for any number of anxious plays that came to be known collectively as the theater of the absurd a few decades ago. In them, language was turned inside out and shown to be useless. Human behavior was deemed unfathomable -- which reduced people to the status of puppets or automatons. Society was degenerating into chaos, God was apparently dead, and the big void, if not the big funk, was lapping up against life's very edges.
Mr. Shanley would seem to have no argument with that. He has even adapted many of the standard practices of the absurdists, discarding traditional narrative for a topsy-turvy structure that is held together as much by free association as anything else. Among his unconventional characters are Omar, "a family man," who for a living throws knives at a one-inch black dot from 35 paces; and Fifi, Omar's wife, who announces abruptly that she is pregnant with twins which she'll be birthing tomorrow. When Omar admits, "I'm trying to like break into a new way of speaking that'll rip the television set outta my head," we may presume that he's also expressing Mr. Shanley's ambitions as well.
Well, television "The Big Funk" isn't. But it isn't particularly captivating theater, either. Mr. Shanley's sense of the ridiculous and his social conscience make for a very uneasy blend. Off-the-wall reflections exist side by side with grand pronouncements on everything from fate ("a miracle that gives you a job") to happiness ("a side issue . . . it comes to you while you do other things . . . like grace"). The two don't complement each other so much as they tug the play in opposite directions.
The dinner party that constitutes most of Act II comes close to pure surrealism. Omar's wearing Viking horns. Fifi, the dutiful hostess, is armed with a four-foot pepper grinder. Jill is facing enough salad to feed an army of rabbits. The conversation is decidedly screwy. Before the coffee has been served, Austin excuses himself, disappears off stage and then reappears soon after, naked as a jaybird. We've all had dreams like that, although, unlike Austin, we don't necessarily cap them off by delivering a long, socially relevant speech.
Austin wants us to know, however, that we're tense and sweating and living our lives as if death were imminent, when we're the very ones, not destiny, who are responsible for this big thundercloud, this big funk, overhead. And just as we've created it with our anxieties, we can dispel it, if we "relax" and "be casual." I'm not sure the speech amounts to much more than Roosevelt's "The only thing we have to fear is fear itself," retooled for the dazed 1990's. But Mr. Weber delivers the message genuinely under difficult working conditions.
Mixed signals are coming at us all evening long, however. Strangely as it sometimes behaves, "The Big Funk" is never giddy enough to defy gravity. Insightful as it wants to be, it is loath to admit to preaching, when that's precisely what it's doing. The most charming interlude is a wash. So, I'm afraid, is the rest of the play.
'Love and Anger'
In "Filthy Rich," his zesty 1979 tribute to all the grade-B detective flicks you ever saw, the Canadian playwright George F. Walker drafted a hard-boiled, ex-investigative reporter to fight the forces of corruption in The Big City. At best, the battle ended in a stalemate. Now in his comedy "Love and Anger," which is being given its American premiere by the New York Theater Workshop at the Perry Street Theater, he has put a lawyer on the job. But you can't call it a draw this time.
Either the privileged classes are becoming more entrenched or Mr. Walker's crusaders are becoming more inept. Actually, I suspect it's a matter of both. Mr. Walker is no less disenchanted with the times than Mr. Shanley is, although he relies on a more straightforward dramaturgy to depict chicanery in places high and low. His heavy is the ruthless publisher of The World Today, a big-circulation rag, who doesn't like anyone defacing his vending machines, let alone his reputation. Opposing him on wobbly pins is Peter (Petie) Maxwell, a high-octane corporate lawyer until a stroke reordered his priorities and brought him around to the side of the downtrodden.
Petie has no more principles than before, mind you. He's just decided to apply the lack of them to the goal of undermining "the entire institutional bias of our culture." Proclaiming himself a citizen of a new era, he explains with a feistiness that threatens his already shaky equilibrium, "I call this the age of getting even."
As played by Saul Rubinek, a schmoo-shaped dynamo when he isn't momentarily having one of his dizzy spells, Petie could be the fifth Marx Brother -- Pinko. He's got a pit bull's tenacity, an anarchist's madness and a tent preacher's indignation, and he's quite funny -- careering about the hole in the wall he calls an office or charging up the steps and out the door in pursuit of the evidence that will bring the publisher to his knees. (When it is pointed out that his pitiful evidence boils down to a few flagrantly doctored photos, Petie doesn't blink. "They can be improved," he snaps.)
Even funnier is Sarah (Deirdre O'Connell), a schizophrenic who has just been released from a mental institution and turns up in Petie's office, where she has little trouble fitting right in. Sarah believes deeply in the conspiracy of "beefy white guys" who surround small towns with their tractor-trailer trucks before taking them over. She tends to confuse males in evening dress with vampires and is not comfortable in the presence of pizza. Despite a tumble of red hair and a complexion that would be the envy of any Irish milkmaid, Sarah also thinks she is black. This makes her a natural ally, if an altogether unpredictable one, in Petie's assault on the citadels of power.
There is a lot of the young Sandy Dennis in Ms. O'Connell, who can inject a sudden gurgle of laughter into a lamentation or bring the tone of sweetest reason to bear on the most outlandish observation. The performance zigzags all over the lot, but hewing to some wild, emotional logic of her own, the actress never leaves you behind. In the play's best scene, she and the newspaper publisher (Arthur Hanket, adroitly walking the fine line separating sleek from oily) come to a meeting of the minds, although it's clear to us, if not immediately to him, that her mind has the general consistency of fruitcake.
Sanity is not quite so colorfully depicted by Mr. Walker. Still, you're not apt to overlook Steve Ryan, as an aspiring politican, well bred and better connected, who promises, "If I am elected, I'll keep a . . . what's that thing? . . . Open mind!" Or Kristine Nielsen, who was so vivid presiding over the switchboard in "Machinal" earlier this season and is here having an understandably rougher time maintaining order as Petie's Gal Friday. Or Tonia Rowe, who gets the whole play rolling when she enlists Petie to help spring her innocent husband from jail. ("Innocent?," he snorts. "More and more I hear that word less and less.")
Mr. Walker's characters are far and away what is most vigorous about "Love and Anger." In Act I, they sound one another out, draw up sides and face off in a stupendous cat and dog fight that threatens to demolish Petie's office and put them in traction for the next six months. From then on, though, a lot of steam goes out of the tale and the directors James C. Nicola and Christopher Grabowski don't seem to be able to do much about it.
Act II is given over to a mock trial of the newspaper baron and a second fight that can't hold a baseball bat to the first. By this time, Petie is growing short of breath and his eyes are glassing over. His tirades have turned to whimpers. All he and his unlikely cohorts have done is hold the rich and mighty temporarily at bay.
"This has got to be a place for winners," barks the publisher, with the authority of the victorious. "We've got to keep up the momentum. Let the slower people pick up the jet stream. That's our only choice. We've got to get richer. The only alternative is to get poorer."
Sound familiar? Consider "Love and Anger" a fitting addendum to the Reagan years. And know that the first half, at least, is nutty, knockabout fun.
