HEADLINE: On the Road, Sleeping for Less

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE; BETSY WADE writes the Practical Traveler column.

 BODY:
IF you can survive on the road only with the aid of a wall-mounted hair dryer and a sauna, forget budget motels. They provide two small, thin towels, two cups, some soap and toilet paper, and that is about it for amenities.
If you want a comfy dinner without having to go outdoors, or, heaven forbid, want to call room service, pass 'em by. If you require someone to carry your bags or turn on the lights, you are in the wrong place. 
 But my nights of counting hangers and sleeping in five minimum-service motels, plus earlier stays in other chains, added up to a surprise for me. The rooms were uniformly clean; the mattresses were firm and new; the big color television sets all worked on the first try. None had shag carpets or bare light bulbs although only one could be said to be decorated. In the hard-budget category, you can measure the dollar saved by the bare walls and in the inch lost in towel length. But sight unseen, I would bet on a room at a budget chain motel against an unknown place along the road, even at a higher price.
In choosing the best low-priced motel, one thing is potentially more important even than brand name, and that is newness. When you reserve, see if you can find out how old the building is or if it has been recently renovated. When chain motels in the midprice bracket get too beat up to bear their names, they are sometimes renovated and slid into a cheaper category. Newer is cheerier. Worthwhile checking, too, is whether renovations are in progress.
In the last month, I stayed one night in Motel 6, Super 8, Econo Lodge, Red Roof Inn and Budgetel. All were in the vicinity of New York or Boston, so I did not get out into really cheap territory such as rural areas. Without taxes, the prices for two in a room ranged from $31.95 to $52.88. For one in a room, the bottom and top prices, without taxes, were $25.95 and $49. Taxes ranged from 6.75 percent to 9.70 percent.
Everyone was helpful to some degree, but these motels did not indulge in the elaborate courtesies of upscale places: the smiling question, "And how long will you staying with us, Madam?" is replaced by a polite, "How many nights?" And you get to your room on your own. There is no point in fussing about the view: it's either the parking lot or the highway.
"Minimum service" means that the motel does not run a restaurant, as was the case in all the motels I stayed in. It may be nestled among fast-food establishments, but if you want to go to a real restaurant it may mean an expedition.
In the morning, all five of the motels offered some palliative for those who leave before Denny's, Valle's or the Big Boy opens. At a Comfort Inn near the airport in Albuquerque, the porch off the lobby was set up as a free electronic serve-yourself kitchen with coffee, tea, microwave oven, toaster, muffins, cereal and juice. Most budget chains provide less, coffee and perhaps a machine dispensing canned juices for a price, possibly 75 cents. Day's Inn in Portland, Me., offers a carafe of fresh coffee in the lobby.
One drawback is that the security seems only adequate in most low-price places, probably a factor of the building's age. Good technology has recently been developed for secure room keys, but it didn't exist in these five motels. A budget motel I researched earlier, a Sleep Inn -- these are all new -- had doors that opened when I put my own credit card into a slot. (The slot on my room had been programmed to accept only my card.) But the five I surveyed last month all had standard metal keys with the room number marked but no motel name, a minimum safeguard. All had peepholes in the doors, however, also a necessity. Super 8 had a device inside to prevent the insertion of a key on the outside. Budgetel had one of these as well as a dead bolt and a chain. The Red Roof Inn had the same device and a dead bolt but no chain. The Econo Lodge had a bolt and a chain on both doors, but Motel 6 had no way to secure the door other than the lock.
All had smoke detectors, and the five-year-old Budgetel had a sprinkler. All had room phones, usually with local calls free. The Super 8 said it imposed a surcharge for long-distance calls placed with credit cards; the rest allowed free use of a credit card.
Towels ranged in length from 39 inches to 47 inches. All were white with no logo.
Here are highlights of my tour de motel.
 
Motel 6
 This chain, usually identified with its folksy Tom Bodett radio commercials, provides a room at a really low price; decor and extras have been reduced to the vanishing point. The room we stayed in in Deerfield, Mass., the cheapest of the five I visited, did not even have a box of tissues. There were two plastic-foam cups to be used for everything, although the clerk, when I asked, offered two additional regular plastic cups. The towels were the smallest I encountered, and the two bars of soap the tiniest. After I used one bar, it was clear that two were provided because one would not be adequate to lather truckers of the bulk I saw in the corridor. The device to plug the tub drain was gone in the plastic tub-shower combination, but fortunately I did not want to take a bath. The room was minimally furnished: a low, small table with two chairs, two comfortable double beds, a narrow wall shelf with mirror and a TV attached to a metal arm that came out of the wall opposite the beds with cables hanging loose. Two free movies a night were available on one channel. There were curtains but no pictures and no light in the vestibule-coat rack area.
Although the motel had a nice-looking heated swimming pool surrounded by potted plants and trees in a glassed-in wing, the people I saw at breakfast in the area next to it did not appear to have come there to swim.
Room payment is required the night before. Local calls are free; long-distance must be charged.
 
Econo Lodge
 Having stayed at an Econo Lodge in Orlando, Fla., I was prepared to learn in New Brunswick, N.J., that to get phone service I had to put down a $10 deposit or leave the total open on my charge slip although I had to sign it -- pay up -- the night before. I agreed to use my phone credit card. This meant that each time I called out, I had to ask the clerk to get the operator; the clerk stayed on the line until I had told the operator that I was using a credit card. This sort of thing, like unremovable hangers, does not interfere with comfort or safety, but it sure shouts "budget."
The room was spacious, with a double bed, a round table and four chairs with upholstered seats and a dresser containing drawers with a TV on top. The bathroom had the usual plastic built-in tub with shower but there was no plug in the tub here, either.
At the Econo Lodge, which had a gloomy off-season feel to it, the glass-box check-in area had a snug cluster of vending machines. One sold toothbrushes and aspirin and such; the machine that sold me 60-cent potato chips also offered condoms. The ice dispenser had a coin slot but no notice of what coin to use. When I asked the clerk, he gave me a token, and after I inserted it, one small pailful of ice tumbled down. I doubt that he would have given me enough tokens for ice to fill my cooler.
This motel had an outdoor pool in the center of its grassy quad, quilted and locked up for the winter.
The Econo Lodge offers the Super Video Cinema system: it allows you to rent a player and tape for $6.49 at the desk. I used the quite satisfactory FM radio in the TV and read by the light of the shaded lamp and its 100-watt bulb over the bed. A Sealy Hotel Special, it was perfectly comfortable. This Econo Lodge said it provides free coffee to guests at 6 A.M., but the office was locked and no coffee had been brewed at 6:30. The eating places next door were shuttered.
 
Super 8
 At this motel, the clerk I reserved with was helpful on driving directions and said, "Thank you for choosing Super 8." But when I arrived here, and at some of the other motels, mostly after 6, the clerks on the desk were barely this side of surly.
At the Super 8 in Danbury, Conn., I stared at the sign that said no one under 21 would be registered. It reminded me to ask for the 10 percent senior citizen discount, which I got.
Everyone at this motel must enter through the lobby, which adjoins a claustrophobic vending room with a free ice dispenser and an automatic brewer that provides free coffee and water for tea, as much you like. The place bustles in the morning.
My room had no curtains, but there were narrow-slat blinds in good condition. The bed was king-size, and it had extra-length pillows. Otherwise the room was Spartan, with one drawer for clothes.
The furniture other than the bed was an upholstered recliner chair facing the TV set, affixed to the top of the clothes rack. No remote control device, but there was a switch on the wall above the bed to shut the set off. A movie and a video player on the Super Video Cinema system could be rented for $6.49.
The bathroom had the standard new plastic tub-shower combination, but in a great splurge, the curtain bore the chain's logo.
 
Red Roof Inn
 This was the only motel in the survey where the No Smoking sign was not affixed to the outside door; in the room we rented in New London, Conn., there was a sign on the table saying the room "has been cleaned to remove tobacco odor." There was no particular odor.
This chain took a middle course between providing no tissues or a dispenser with a full box: a pocket pack of tissues with a logo, to my mind a fine solution because I felt free to take it with me.
This room, which had two double beds, was brightly lighted but was still somehow cheerless. The two chairs with the round table were wooden captain's chairs without upholstery.
The room had two pictures on the wall. There were no drawers: the counter along the wall had two shelves, and even the night table had a shelf but no drawer. "Impossible to leave anything behind here," my traveling companion said. The TV set had a shut-off switch on the wall above one bed. Free movies, three a day, were offered on one channel.
Red Roof Inns also make you pay the night before, although I did not realize it at the time. The charge-card slip was bopped, but I was not required to sign it then or indeed later. I did sign a slip agreeing to pay for all my charges. This expedient did serve to make me feel less sordid than at the sign-in-advance places.
 
Budgetel Inn
 This place was definitely more cheerful and more concerned with appearances than the other four. The clerks at the motel, in Auburn, Mass., said that it was only five years old. The room had pictures on the wall and a remote control for the TV set. Someone had throught about colors of lamp bases and chair upholstery. Not surprisingly, it was among the most expensive: a room for two with two double beds cost $51.95, plus tax. Entry to all rooms in the semi-futuristic building was through the minute lobby, but the lights from an adjoining small glass-walled meeting room reduced the cramped feeling.
The room was furnished lavishly in the context: it had two double beds, a desk with a chair, an armchair, two drawers in a dresser and two hunting prints on the wall. A four-cup Mr. Coffee automatic brewer was plugged in on the sink counter, plus two plastic-foam cups and a filter bag of ground coffee. The rest was less classy: packets of powdered creamer, sugar and artifical sweetner, plus plastic stirrers. A good gimmick was the glass ashtray upside down, with a sticker on the bottom saying, "This is a nonsmoking room." Seven movies were available on the TV at a charge of $5.95 a movie. In a switch on the familiar giveaway, The motel charged 50 cents for USA Today.
We laughed about the free Continental breakfast illustrated on the cover of the Budgetel directory, with the pastry placed so near the camera that it appeared to be the size of a Frisbee. We ordered this "room delivered" convenience, and sure enough, in a plastic bag hanging on our doorknob in the morning were two vending-machine-size Sara Lee danish and two four-ounce containers of orange juice.
We prepared coffee, I rinsed out the plastic cups to serve the juice, and we drove out of Auburn modestly fortified.
 
10 BIGGEST BUDGET CHAINS
 LISTS of the 10 biggest chains in the limited-service category shift almost by the day. Franchise-holders change loyalties; chains buy up each other's properties; individual owners may drop out of a chain.
Below is a list of the 10 biggest U.S. chains, on the basis of total rooms. Average daily rates sound ludicrous compared to actual rates in high season, but they are country-wide averages.
Days Inns has perhaps 1,100 properties with a total of 127,000 rooms. Most are run under franchise. Its average daily room rate in 1989 was $40 to $45. Day's Inns, bought in 1989 by Tollman-Hundley Hotels of New York, is now working out a plan with its debt-holders after a default on $325 million last month. A directory with prices and map may be obtained by calling 800-325-2525.
Motel 6, with 560 properties almost entirely owned by the chain, is owned by the French hotel company Accor. Its average daily room rate in 1989 was $25 to $27. The name dates from 1962, when the charge was $6 a room. A directory with insert of prices may be obtained by calling 505-891-6161.
Comfort Inns is a division of Choice, formerly Quality International. Almost all 600 Comfort Inns are franchised. The 1989 average daily rate was $40 to $45. Among other brands in the Choice group is Sleep Inns, a super-economy line begun in 1988. Sleep Inns are all built new, not renamed, with prices in the $29-to-$35 range. Eight are open now. A directory of Comfort and Sleep Inns, plus Quality and Clarion motels, is available by calling 800-221-2222.
Super 8 has 775 properties, mostly franchised. The 1989 average daily rate was $32.50. The name derives from the original 1974 rate of $8.88. An unidentified group of Hong Kong investors is taking over the chain in January. A directory may be obtained by calling 800-848-8888.
Econo Lodge, now owned by Choice, has 630 motels, almost all franchised. The average 1989 daily room rate was $36. A directory of Econo Lodges and Friendship and Rodeway Inns may be obtained by calling 800-553-2666.
TraveLodge, a national chain of 470 motels, is one brand name of the British-owned Trusthouse Forte Hotels. Half of the TraveLodges are franchised and half are chain managed. The average daily rate reported for 1989 was $39. A directory for the United States and Britain may be obtained by calling 800-255-3050.
Hampton Inns, a national chain of 200 motels, reported an average daily room rate of $43 in 1989. Most Hampton Inns are franchised; headquarters is in Memphis, and the chain is strongest in the East. A directory may be obtained by calling 800-426-7866.
La Quinta Inns' 200 motels are centered in Texas, the Southeast and California. The 1989 daily room rate was $39. Most of the motels are owned by the chain. A directory with an insert for prices may be obtained by calling 800-531-5900.
Red Roof Inns has 200 motels, mostly east of Texas, all company owned. Beth Shannon, a spokeswoman, said that the average daily rate in 1989 was in the mid-$30's. The directory does not show rates, which can be learned when a phone reservation is made. The directory does include a map and an index. It may be obtained by calling 800-843-7663.
Scottish Inns is a chain of 160 motels franchised by Hospitality International, which also comprises higher-priced Red Carpet Inns and Master Host Inns. The chain is concentrated in the Southeast. Scottish Inns reported a 1989 average daily rate of $23. A directory for all three groups with index and prices is available by calling 800-251-1962.
Not in the top 10 is the Budgetel chain, which ranks about 15th with its 82 motels, mostly east of the Mississippi. The chain, which has been growing fast since 1985, owns most of its motels; 14 are franchised. The 1989 average daily rate was $35. Budgetel was included in the survey because of its "free room-delivered Continental breakfast" promotion. A directory with prices and index may be obtained by calling 800-428-3438.
There are also two new names in the hard-budget category: HoJo Inns and Holiday Inn Express. Some of these will be conversions of higher-priced motels. When I called to reserve at a Holiday Inn Express for this article, the clerk told me that renovations were in progress, so I passed. -- B. W.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1085 words

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
A Downtown Hartford Convention Center

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
SEVERAL cities are looking to convention centers as catalysts to invigorate their sagging downtown economies. While the Northeast's large-scale convention business is dominated by the 1.8 million-square-foot Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, smaller cities, hoping to scoop up trade that bypasses the Big Apple for costs or other reasons, are building their own convention centers.
 Construction is expected to be completed in Providence, Syracuse and Hartford within the next two to four years. Now in its site-selection process, the Connecticut center is scheduled to open in 1994 or '95. 
 "The first one in the ground is going to eliminate the competition," said State Senator William A. DiBella of Hartford.
 While 500,000 square feet is a maximum projected size, the Hartford center will initially have some 300,000 square feet, including 150,000 for exhibition space, 40,000 for meeting rooms and 30,000 for banquets, and parking space for 1,000 cars. The estimated cost is $150 million.
 By way of comparison, Syracuse's center is budgeted at $80 million for 208,000 square feet, including a 64,500-square-foot exhibition hall and parking for 1,000 cars. Construction, begun in October, will be finished late in 1992.
Providence will spend $120 million on a 365,000-square-foot center with 100,000 square feet of exhibition space and a 2,400-car garage. Work will begin on Jan. 15, 1991, for an opening in mid-1993.
 "The center will have a profound impact," said Warren Trafton, president of Hartford's Convention and Visitors Bureau. "It's projected to attract a quarter of a million people a year from out of state, attending 40 to 45 annual events. It will generate spending of about a half-billion dollars a year, as opposed to $50 million now spent on similar events."
 The 15-year-old Hartford Civic Center, originally intended as a convention facility, still books a limited number of small conventions into a 70,000 square-foot exhibition space. But its function over the years has refocused on sporting events and large-scale theatrical productions, leaving "a pent-up demand for convention space," said Mr. Trafton.
 After a site is selected in January the General Assembly must act on floating a $15 million bond issue for land acquisition. The architectural firms of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum in Manhattan, and Jeter Cook & Jepsom in Hartford, have been hired as co-designers of the project.
 Out of nine sites submitted by various landowners, three or four are expected to emerge for serious evaluation of size, cost, traffic congestion, proximity to transportation, entertainment and shopping, and the ability to attract a major hotel.
"The center and the hotel must open at the same time," said Frank Aieta, vice chairman of the state's 13-member Convention Center Authority. "We would not go forward without a hotel committment."
 Lack of business forced Hartford's Parkview Hilton and Summit hotels to close this year. According to Carl A. Candels, executive vice president of the Connecticut Hotel-Motel Association, based in Hartford, the Sheraton, Holiday Inn, Ramada and J.P. Morgan, with a total of 972 rooms, are doing better as a result.
"The insurance companies took more than 400 rooms and a substantial amount of meeting-room business away from the hotels when they began building their own conference centers," said Mr. Candels. "We are very concerned that when the convention center opens, it has at least 50 solid bookings for each of the first four years or the existing hotels will be badly hurt."
There are about 3,000 rooms in and around downtown Hartford. The proposed convention hotel would have 750 rooms.
"A convention center alone will not solve downtown Hartford's problems," Mr. Candels said. "Everybody is out in the suburbs. The streets close up at 6 P.M. We need more people living in the city, and we need to generate more shopping."
 Sage-Allen, a major department store, closed its flagship store downtown this year, and several individual shops are vacant. D & L's, a popular clothing chain, will close its store in the Hartford Civic Center Shops in January.
THE city administration is pushing hard for a convention site that consists of a privately owned parcel and a city-owned parcel at Trumbull and Main Streets.
"Deputy Mayor Charles Mathews made it clear that if it doesn't go on that site it will not have the support of the City Council," said Senator DiBella, who also favors that site.
 Mr. Aieta identified three sites as more viable contenders and his preferences: a 10.5-acre Columbus Boulevard site owned by Phoenix Mutual, Travelers Insurance and Gordon Interests; a six-acre site at Church and Allen Streets owned by Oakleaf Development Corporation, and a five-acre Spruce Street site owned by private investors.
"The state is offering the city of Hartford a gift," he said, in building the center there, "and the authority will not be intimidated by city officials.
 Asking prices compiled by Alphonse Marotta, State Representative from Hartford and a member of the authority, vary from $19 million for the privately owned portion of the Trumbull-Main location to more than $30 million for the Columbus Boulevard tract.
Another site, 4.25 acres at Constitution Plaza between Market Street and Columbus Boulevard, includes a small parcel where a city-owned jail and courthouse will be phased out in 1991; it is estimated to cost $37.9 million and involves acquiring and razing several buildings.
 The Trumbull-Main site, favored by Mr. Marotta, "allows for expansion onto the grounds of a public school soon to become defunct," he said, speculating that the privately owned parcel of 4.9 acres could contain the convention center and the hotel could be built on the city's 3.4 acres.
"The city is willing to provide incentives, like a land lease arrangement and phased-in property taxes over seven and a half years," he said.
 The lot is currently used for parking and it abuts the Holiday Inn, which the hotel chain bought back this month from Bass PLC, a British franchiser, for $12 million. It is just off the junction of I-84 and I-91 and Mr. Marotta suggested the inn could double in size on its own property instead of -- or in addition to -- building the convention hotel.
 John Tarantini, vice-president for Holiday Inns' eastern region in Washington, said "nothing is confirmed, but we will take a look at the size of the convention center and do a feasibility study."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Aieta of Convention Center Authority in downtown Hartford. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

INDUSTRY: NAICS541330 ENGINEERING SERVICES (51%); NAICS541310 ARCHITECTURAL SERVICES (51%); SIC8712 ARCHITECTURAL SERVICES (51%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: CONNECTICUT, USA (95%); NEW YORK, USA (93%); 

CITY: HARTFORD, CT, USA (95%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (93%); SYRACUSE, NY, USA (88%); 

COMPANY: HOK GROUP INC (51%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: ;HARTFORD (CONN)

HEADLINE: Talking: Insurance;
Getting Coverage In Co-ops

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
THE recent merry-go-round among managing agents for New York City's cooperative buildings is resulting in growing confusion over insurance. The difficulty is being compounded, board members say, by mislaid records, lack of long-term familiarity with the insurance history of each building and some glaring oversights.
 Consider the 30-unit co-op at 114 Morningside Drive on Manhattan's Upper West Side. The board thought it had successfully muddled through a parade of managing agents only to learn, said Gioa Shebar, the president, that "our directors' and officers' liability policy had lapsed and our fire insurance levels had never been adequately updated to compensate for inflation." 
 Making sure the building and individual shareholders carry the right insurance can be complicated, but a firm grip on the basic needs will help. For instance, the co-op corporation will always be responsible for insuring the structure and its common elements, such as elevators,hallways and the lobby, against a whole range of perils including fires and floods. This policy normally includes about $1 million of liability coverage.
 Shareholders will be responsible for insuring all personal belongings in their apartments as well as improvements made to the interior, carpeting, wallcoverings, applicances and fixtures. The goal is to be fully covered for replacement costs.
 For a 50-unit fire-resistant building with 100,000 square feet insured for $10 million, the annual structural premium should range from $8,000 to $15,000, depending on such variables as location and history of claims. Shareholder policies normally cost $175 to $3,000, depending on the value of contents and improvements. Board members will also need additional liability coverage against lawsuits, which can add $750 to $2,000 to the corporation's annual premiums.
 While this may seem straightforward, it is not easy because boards are being besieged by a growing number of insurance agents, each seeming to offer the best deal. Muriel Bishop, president of Muriel Bishop Insurance of Manhattan, an agency specializing in cooperatives, said co-ops -- especially newly converted buildings not served by professional management or those that have not yet forged strong alliances -- are seen by the industry as a lucrative source of new business.
 Some agents also are seeking business among mature co-ops with professional management. For example, Mackoul and Associates of Manhattan insists it can save almost any building 25 to 60 percent on premiums regardless of whether its current policies were written individually or by a managing agent who was able to offer a group discount.
 The reason, says Robert E. Mackoul, the president, is that many co-ops are still being classified as rental buildings by underwriters who are not fully conversant with the differences and who therefore are not making adjustments in premiums for what statistically is a lower-risk category.
 A board can start to make an informed decision by getting a copy of the building's policies, which may not be on the premises, since managing agents have traditionally kept their client's policies in their offices. These can provide the details that can best determine what modifications, if any, should be sought.
 It might be best to have one board member investigate the options. The board should then seek at least three bids, one of which should come through the managing agent, if the building has one.
Irwin Gumley, president of Gumley-Haft, managing agents in Manhattan with an insurance division, said bids should not be obtained until three months before the expiration of the existing policies because any bid is normally valid for only 90 days.
 Make sure, say experts, that each insurance salesperson is bidding on exactly the same coverage. The board should determine in advance exactly what it needs, said Ms. Bishop. To safeguard objectivity, she said, this should be done by someone who understands co-op insurance but is not bidding for the building's coverage.
SOME insurance specialists, such as Ronald Alford, technical director of Disaster Masters of Kew Gardens, Queens, have begun offering co-ops consulting services. One problem, he said, is that sales agents can be so persuasive that boards "buy more coverage than they really need."
 Mr. Gumley said it may not always pay to join the group put together by the building's managing agent. The policy for the physical structure, he said, is often better written individually since the group may include buildings that carry higher risk ratings, "and their claims history will affect your rates," he said.
 When evaluating bids, the board should make a list of specific perils to be excluded, said Mr. Alford, and then ask which might be included after all. "Most people don't know you can negotiate the terms," he said.
 For instance, Mr. Gumley insists it has become common to exclude water damage from wind-driven rain, underground seepage and water main breaks. But these can be included on request, he said, although the rider could cost extra.
 Further, said Mr. Gumley, the structural policy should cover the "full replacement cost" of any item, not its depreciated value at the time of the loss. Also, the building itself needs to be insured at no less than 90 percent of its true replacement cost to get full reimbursement for any structural damage.
 Most buildings also need a separate liability policy. It is rarely sufficent, experts say, to rely on the $1 million or so of liability coverage automatically included in the structural policy. Liability coverage can often be cheaper if bought within a group. But comparisons should still be made. The amount needed normally ranges from $5 million to $30 million.
 If the building is joining a group liability policy the board should find out in advance, said Mr. Gumley, if the coverage quoted is the total that can be paid out to all the buildings in the group in any given year, or if the limit is for each building.
 The co-op should also get a separate directors' and officers' liability policy since board members are unlikely to be protected under the general liability policy if they are sued individually. Further, the board must remember to ask each sales agent for details of the amount that can be saved by increasing deductible levels.
 Once bids are in the board should check the underwriters' ratings in the 1990 edition of the A. M. Best Rating Guide -- a profile of insurance companies. This is critical because some insurance companies are starting to suffer from the same financial shakiness that has been undermining banks and savings and loans.
 The board should also get long-term references on any new insurance agent before making a changeover. "At least one should be from a building that has been involved with the agent in a claim," said Brian Haviland, president of a 9-unit loft building at 34 East 30th Street, a co-op that recently revamped its coverage.
 When evaluating bids, the board should make a list of specific perils to be excluded, said Mr. Alford, and then ask which might be included after all. "Most people don't know you can negotiate the terms," he said.
 For instance, Mr. Gumley insists it has become common to exclude water damage from wind-driven rain, underground seepage and water main breaks. But these can be included on request, he said, although the rider could cost extra.

Also, the building itself needs to be insured at no less than 90 percent of its true replacement cost to get full reimbursement for any structural damage.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Liability of a Condo Board
 
Question: In the offering statement for the condominium I bought in a new building about three years ago, it was clearly stated that the building would be responsible for maintaining the exterior, including washing the outside of all windows. When I wrote to the managing agent about this I was told the board had not provided funds and windows would not be cleaned. I would like to see the condominium live up to its responsiblity to clean the windows without a suit. But would the board members be liable for failure to manage the building in accordance with the offering plan? . . . Charles Bradford, Manhattan
 
 Answer: Probably not. Stuart Saft, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said that while board members could he held liable for failure to carry out the terms of the condominium's offering plan, it would be hard to make a case that your board had acted ureasonably or in bad faith. "It would be different, " Mr. Saft said, "if, for example, the board members had used building funds just to have their own windows washed. It may be that the board decided that the best utilization of the condominium's resources did not include window washing."
Mr. Saft suggested you write to the board to find out exactly why the windows have not been washed.If you feel they are sufficiently dirty to need immediate attention, he said, you "could look for support among other owners for a special assessment to have the work done."
 
Low Water Pressure
 
Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan. Each time I shower the pressure drops to just a trickle. Is there a minimum level that must be maintained? . . . David Krakower, Manhattan
 
 Answer: Not exactly. The city's Housing Maintenance Code does not specify that water pressure be maintained at a specific level, but it does say landlords must provide an adequate amount of hot and cold water to all tenants.
"If water pressure is not sufficient to provide a tenant with water for washing and showering," said Roz Post, a spokesman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, "then the landlord is in violation of the code."
To arrange for an inspection, call the Central Complaint Bureau in the Division of Code Enforcement at 960-4800. If it is determined that your water supply is inadequate and your landlord does not correct the problem, you can file a reduction-in-services complaint with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. You might be eligible for a rent reduction. Forms are available at all borough offices. In Manhattan they are at 156 William Street, ninth floor, and at 163 West 125th Street, fifth floor.
 
Adding a Name to a Lease
 
 Question: I am 76 years old and have been living in my apartment for 22 years. After my husband died last year my nephew moved in to assist me. My lease is up for renewal and I would like to add his name to it, but my the landlord said this is not possible. Can he refuse? . . . Jadin Dowling, Manhattan
 
 Answer: Yes. Landlords of rent-regulated apartments are obligated to add to leases only the name of a prime tenant's spouse. However, your nephew might have the right to remain after your death. Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said the rules that govern rent regulated housing gives certain family members, including nephews, who live with prime tenants 62 years or older or are disabled the right to renewal leases if the prime tenant dies. However, your apartment must be your nephew's prime residence. For more information call the agency's rent administration hotline, (718) 739-6400.

HEADLINE: Can Marketers Outsmart Real-Estate Slump?

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
FROM chocolate fondue to cats to contests, Connecticut entrepreneurs are trying to find ever more creative means to entice prospective customers into spending in spite of a slumping real-estate market. Their marketing ploys include inviting cats into apartments and sweetening up prospective tenants with chocolate fondue, decorating the windows of vacant stores and going on the radio to seek prospective home buyers.
"This is the time for the fertile mind to really bloom," said Jerome Lowengard, a public-relations consultant in Hartford who has been in the field for nearly 40 years. He recently became president of the company that publishes The Business Journal, a biweekly publication serving Hartford and New Haven. 
 The tight economy provides an opportunity "for people who are supposed to be creative people to look at creative ways to do business," he said. "For years, all of us have been very complacent. Although we did it, we were doing it in a market that was receptive. Now we're doing it in a market which says, 'Challenge me.' "
 
'Most Depressed Man'
 William H. Heard, a former public-relations executive in Hartford, created his own campaign to sell his house in Glastonbury when his real-estate agent could not succeed. Mr. Heard, who was seeking to move to California, described himself in humorous newspaper advertisements and radio commercials as "the most depressed man in a depressed real-estate market." He sold the house and now works for a public-relations company in Los Angeles.
Although most house sellers do not have Mr. Heard's advertising background, he said there are lessons to be learned from his success.
"There is nothing wrong with the standard tactics that real-estate agents have always used in a good market," he said. "But in a poor market, they have to reach out for other solutions and gimmicks."
Vacant office space posed a problem for Stanley Seligson, a developer and real-estate agent in Norwalk. "Probably as much as anything else, the perception in the minds of purchasers or people who will lease space is that this is a bargain environment," he said.
He was faced with overcoming that perception in two of his developments, he said, an eight-store retail plaza that includes a branch of Loehmann's, the discount clothing chain, and a new bank building with unrented space.
When he tried to market space at Loehmann's Plaza in a converted factory building in Norwalk, "we felt the historic nature would lend something," he said. "But people would say: 'What a mess. It's an old building.' So we put a mural up, to show people what it could be."
The mural, painted by Brechin Morgan, an artist from Westport, shows prospective tenants how the plaza will eventually look. It depicts a galleria with banners, plants and a fountain.
In the case of the new Connecticut National Bank building, also in Norwalk, Mr. Seligson enlisted the help of another Westport artist, Marlene Siff, in helping decorate some unrented office space. At his invitation, Ms. Siff filled the office building with her large, colorful geometric paintings and sculpture.
"For the bank building, we were surrounded with things that weren't moving, so we decided to create our own enviornment," Mr. Seligson said. Since the building already had tall ceilings, the white walls gave the space "a gallery look," he said.
"We decided to make it a gallery and focus our attention on something that was kind of upscale, and in came Marlene Siff," he said. "We thought her work was very special, in that it had a corporate look."
Mr. Seligson also acted as host at a party sponsored by the local Chamber of Commerce, to draw additional attention to the building.
"In real estate, like everything else, people, if they're looking for quality, want to get it, if it's the best," he said. "If I just said, 'Twenty thousand feet available,' nobody would believe it, unless they came and saw it. I can't say we've signed a lease as the result of the art show or the chamber party, but I can say there's been a lot of interest."
 
Chocolate Party
 Ms. Siff said the collaboration with Mr. Seligson is paying off for her. The show gave her the opportunity to display her work and increase her corporate contacts.
"It's very difficult for artists to get their work out there," she said. "It takes a lot of time and a lot of effort and pulls you away from painting."
With more and more commercial and residential properties on the market, just attracting brokers can be difficult, said Marc L. Nevas, a developer in Westport. This fall, when he began marketing his latest office building, Old Hill, he threw a grand-opening party aimed at brokers. To entice them, he created a "chocoholics theme," he said. "We served different kinds of chocolate fondues, with tropical fruit and poundcakes for dipping."
The party featured live music and a caricaturist to sketch guests. As a result, 70 brokers showed up, Mr. Nevas said, and many stayed for two hours. "Our goal was to get as many brokers as possible and keep them there as long as possible," he said.
Such promotion takes effort and money, but "I think you don't have a choice in this market," Mr. Nevas said.
Those seeking to renting apartments also need creativity these days, said Deborah Robinson, the marketing director for the 583-unit Clemens Place Apartments in Hartford. About a year ago, she hit upon the idea of advertising apartments for cat lovers, and has not regretted it, she said.
 
'Lots of Sunny Windows'
 "Typically, apartment owners don't want to encourage lots and lots of cats," said Ms. Robinson, a cat owner herself. "But we're in a slumping market and pretty competitive one, so we decided this could give us an edge and reach a market we weren't addressing."
"Cats Now Playing At Clements Place," said her advertisement. "Some of our best residents are cats. With lots of sunny windows to bask in and lots of nooks and crannies to nap in, we're a natural for your feline companion."
Ms. Robinson said: "You can't sit back anymore. During the 1980's, developers went in, put up property and didn't market it. The places sold themselves. It's not that way anymore. Nowadays, you can't open the door and wait for the traffic to show up, because there's very, very little traffic."
Vacant stores can even provide an opportunity for those who seize it. With the closing of some retail stores in Hartford, including the Sage Allen department store, Wilson Faude, executive director of the Old State House museum, said he was unhappy with the prospect of all those dark store windows, especially at Christmas time. He could not think of anything more bleak, he said, so he offered to fill the Sage Allen windows with merchandise promoting the museum's store.
Mr. Faude got other downtown merchants to join in decorating their own windows and those in the vacant stores. That was the beginning of the Great Hartford Window Contest. About 100 merchants are participating, he said, and "I'm about to run out of windows."
For the contest, 35 clues have been placed in store windows. Each clue refers to a word, and when put together, the words make up "a great Hartford quote," he said.
Participants will be writing their guesses on slips of paper and depositing them at participating merchants. The contest ends on Jan. 1, and the winning entry will be drawn from all those with correct answers on Jan. 10. The prizes include free dinners, first-edition books and shopping sprees, said Mr. Faude.
"To make a city work, you don't have to have a big wallet," he said. "Now I've got store owners calling me and asking, 'How can we get into the window game?' .
"It's also pulling everyone together. They're not just moaning about how bad things are. We've got everyone on this. It's a kick, and the cost is basically zero."

HEADLINE: A Report on Blacks Elicits Support

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
LEADERS of Westchester's black community began to look beyond a 165-page indictment of its status in the county last week to the economic, social and political changes they say are essential to reverse a continuing decline in the position of blacks.
Some of the likely changes include strengthening and enforcing a six-year-old executive order designed to increase the level of participation of blacks in county contracts. The order, issued by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, was limited to construction contracts worth more than $100,000. Most minority-owned companies could not participate at that level. 
 Other changes that black leaders have indicated they will seek are improved coordination and planning among county departments and improved delivery of services, such as using churches and community centers, where minority families are comfortable, rather than schools and government agencies.
 
Not Depending on Government
 Efforts will also be made to encourage greater involvement by successful blacks in helping to improve the plight of others who are less successful. "We can no longer depend on the government to do everything for us," said Herman Keith, a County Legislator from Yonkers,
"Few people I know got where they are on their own, without someone extending a hand or making a phone call," he said, adding that such "networking" in the business community was practiced less among blacks, "many of whom are not aware of the condition we're in."
A report outlining that condition, a survey of Westchester's black community, was prepared by the African-American Advisory Board, formed by Mr. O'Rourke in 1987. The report, delivered earlier this month, was described by Mr. O'Rourke as revealing a "sadness and a feeling verging on hopelessness." The County Executive pledged support for the report's recommendations, which cited housing, economic development, criminal justice, drug and alcohol abuse and education as areas requiring improvement.
One of his first steps, Mr. O'Rourke said, would be "to make a pledge in 1991 to take back the streets in Westchester County." He was reminded during a question-and-answer period after the presentation of the report, however, that his proposed 1991 budget all but eliminated the War on Drugs program, an educational effort.
 
An Idea From a Historian
 The idea for a survey of the black community in Westchester began with John Harmon, a black historian, who approached two county legislators, Mr. Keith and Ernest D. Davis of Mount Vernon.
"It was his suggestion," Mr. Davis recalled, "that we form an African-American advisory board to get a cross-section of blacks that could focus intently on the problems we faced."' Mr. Davis said the Board of Legislators "did not want to deal with it and asked us to take it to Mr. O'Rourke, who took it over and appointed its members."
The appointees, a cross-section of corporate, civic and church leaders; educators, social service experts and others prominent in the black community, were selected by Mr. O'Rourke. But they did not spare the County Executive and members of his government from criticism.
In presenting the report, J. T. Childs Jr., an International Business Machines executive who is chairman of the advisory board, said there was "a total lack of awareness by county government" that blacks were participating "only in the smallest way in the abundant opportunities available in Westchester County."
The proposed 1991 budget, Mr. Childs said, "is the antithesis of the recommendations of this report." He said the contradiction could be resolved by "executive leadership" to bring about "even-handed funding, funding that does not balance financial responsibility at the expense of the poor."
Mr. Childs said blacks represented 12 percent of Westchester's population, or nearly 105,000 people, but that 80 percent of the county's homeless and 68 percent of its prison population were black. Sixty-three percent of the county's blacks completed high school and 12 percent "have some college background," the survey reported.
 
A List of Problem Areas
 "No discussion of the African-American condition in Westchester can be held without recognition that race has played a role in the outcome," Mr. Childs said. The evidence of "exclusion based on race," he said, is "evidenced by chronically high unemployment rates, poor and segregated housing patterns, high infant-mortality rates, drug and alcohol abuse, poor health and susceptibility to disease, inferior education and the disproportionate number of African-Americans in the criminal justice system."
Mr. Childs said the county lacked a clear policy to promote black business growth. The report said the county should expand and strengthen the Office of Affirmative Action, ask county agencies for plans to better use minority-owned businesses and direct programs for the black community toward serious economic development.
Housing problems for blacks, the report found, "have reached a point of crisis in some areas of the county." In 1980, one-half of the housing units in the county were rental; by 1985, one-fourth of those units had been converted to condominium or cooperative apartments. During that same time new construction declined.
These factors had a serious impact on black families, whose average earnings in 1980 were $19,726, compared with the $36,283 earned by white families. The report recommended the development of a "fair share" plan for providing affordable housing, with strong incentives for communities to meet targets set by the county, like a surcharge on local property taxes for failure to do so.
In the area of criminal justice, "recent national data indicates that 25 percent of black males are incarcerated," Mr. Childs said. In Westchester, the same percentage of black males "are involved in some element of the criminal-justice process."
 
Racial Bias Is Cited
 The report said that the group had found racial bias in all the areas studied and that this was a "key contributing factor to the increasingly high rate of African-Americans in the criminal- justice system." It called for local projects that would increase contacts between the police and blacks, more patrolmen on the beat and "satellite" police stations in schools and community centers.
Mr. Childs said 80 percent of the offenses that led to the incarceration of blacks were drug-related. In 1988, he said, blacks represented 66 percent of Westchester County drug arrests. The report called for greater drug outreach, especially among children, and better treatment programs.
The county's educational system "does not serve poor students well," Mr. Childs said. Among blacks who entered the ninth grade in 1981, 54 percent failed to graduate with their class in 1985. The report recommended creation of an Office of Early Childhood Services, innovative programs to identify and monitor dropouts as well as adult literacy programs and training for single mothers.
Mr. Childs suggested that all these areas were interrelated. "If I can't find a job or it's a low-paying job, that will influence where my housing is, and that will influence where my children go to school and that will determine who their friends are, and their habits.
"The report shows we're not dealing with a one-acre lot; it's a big farm with a lot of plowing to be done and a lot of places to plant seeds," he said.
The initial plowing will be done by the Whart Development Company of Yonkers, which conducts studies and serves as a consultant to small businesses and to municipalities involved in revitalization.
 
Implementing the Suggestions
 Ruth H. Thompson, president of Whart, which prepared the report, said, "We will be submitting a proposal to the County Executive with the kinds of things we think he can do to help implement the report's recommendations." She said he was expecting it by next summer.
Mrs. Thompson said she would also be working with government departments, "which do a fairly good job but don't coordinate well." Different departments may deal with the same people, she said, "but they're not always cognizant of what's going on with that same family."
Asked if there was a need for blacks to find ways to help themselves in the face of shrinking government budgets, Mrs. Thompson offered this example:
"When I was working with one of the county agencies, we talked about a substance-abuse prevention program that currently exists in the schools, and the concern that there were very few participants.
"There is a tendency on the part of agencies to establish programs in minority communities, but they don't work because of the facilities involved. People are much more comfortable attending a church than they are attending schools or other kinds of institutions."
The report was issued on the ninth floor of the County Office Building here, Mr. O'Rourke's office, while one floor below the Budget and Appropriations Committee of the Board of Legislators was seeking to restore some of the social services cut back or eliminated by the County Executive in his budget proposal.
Mr. Keith said it was telling that none of the seven members of the Budget Committee "had any concentrations of people of color in their legislative districts." Mr. Davis, who is black and represents Mount Vernon, a city with a heavy minority population, had been a member but was replaced this year by Audrey G. Hochberg of Scarsdale.
"I'm not questioning the sensitivity of the Budget Committee members," Mr. Keith said. "But what's missing is some knowledge of the urban centers where 80 percent of the people of color in this county live.
"We can't afford to lose the cities of Westchester's south and the people who live there just to reduce the property-tax rate increase, to keep it at a number that is satisfactory to the wealthy and more affluent of this county. I'm a property owner and I don't mind paying a couple of extra dollars if it's going to help keep a kid out of jail or help him find a job, or help a mother who needs Head Start to keep herself off welfare."
Mr. Davis said the members of the African-American Advisory Board were distinguished, "but they represented a sameness: there was too much professionalism on that board."
Mr. Davis added that "everyone was polite and nobody was angry except Walter Brooks," the president of the Ossining branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, "and he was right."
Mr. Brooks said at the report's presentation that the survey "leaves a lot to be desired in terms of the class composition of the committee; we miss the working class. When you begin to recommend satellite police stations," he said, "you know something is wrong."
Later, Mr. Brooks added: "The input to that report was all middle-class values. The report failed to deal with politics."
Mr. Childs said the report represented "all elements," including those who testified at a public hearing, and was "based on an enormous amount of discussion."

HEADLINE: Lights on Tappen Zee Celebrate 35 Years

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DeCHILLO

 BODY:
ON Dec. 15, 1955, the first automobile crossed the Tappan Zee Bridge. On Dec. 18, the first car crashed on the bridge. After 35 years, the three-mile bridge that snakes across the Tappan Zee from Tarrytown to Grandview in Rockland County carries 38 million vehicles each year, collecting more than $42 million in toll revenues and still generating a lot of controversy.
To celebrate the anniversary of the opening of the bridge, lights outlining the superstructure are to be turned on this weekend. The "necklace lighting," as it is known, is the same type that illuminates the George Washington Bridge, 15 miles downriver. 
 "It's a holiday present to the area," said Peter Tufo, chairman of the New York State Thruway Authority and the one who came up with the idea of putting the lights on the bridge. The lights were incorporated into plans for a safety-ropes system and navigational lighting already in the works.
"With the shimmering white lights on the trusswork and the red aviation beacons on top of each tower, it looks like a Christmas tree," said John Marich, the project manager for Herbert G. Martin Inc., the Yonkers electrical contractor that did the job.
Not everyone is enchanted by the lights. "People aren't going to like this," explained Robert Edwards, supervisor of the painting crew on the span. "Everywhere the roads are a mess, and these lights are just a thing of beauty."
The necklace consists of 35 mercury vapor lamps on each side of the superstructure and are part of a metal stanchion and wire rope system that allows workers to move more safely around the top of the bridge. Rockland and Orange Utilities will supply the electricity for the 70 100-watt lamps. The electric bill will run $1,500 to $2,000 a year.
 
A Prediction by Dewey
 Few people saw the enormous changes the Tappan Zee Bridge would bring to the region, but former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey sent a telegram to the opening-day ceremonies in 1955 saying, "This bridge alone is a symbolic span over which Westchester and Rockland Counties will move virtually overnight 20 years into the future."
Long gone are the ferryboats that provided the only link between Westchester and Rockland Counties south of Bear Mountain before 1955, but they didn't operate after dark, in bad weather or when the river froze.
"For better or for worse, the bridge has made the world a much smaller and faster place," said Mr. Tufo, adding that the populations and economy of Rockland and Orange Counties have grown dramatically in the last 35 years.
Yet the span at the Tappan Zee may be a victim of its own success. Rush-hour congestion on the bridge and on the approaching roads are a nightmare to drivers and local communities. "When the bridge was completed in 1955, we were a sleepy little village community," said Eileen Pilla, Mayor of the village of Tarrytown. "The bridge brought tremendous changes. Since then we've become the hub of Westchester because of our location on the river, the Thruway, the Expressway and the Parkway."
 
'Inundated With Traffic'
 While the bridge has been a positive thing for Westchester, she said, "We find ourself just inundated with traffic. If there is a slowdown or an accident on the Tappan Zee, our village becomes a total parking lot."
S. J. Schulman, president of the Westchester County Association, a business group, called the Tappan Zee Bridge congestion "a serious threat to the economic vitality of Westchester."
"When the bridge opened you could play baseball on it all day long and not be interrupted by a car," said Mr. Schulman, who was then chief planner for Westchester County. "The bridge has been integral not only to the residential opening up of Rockland County but also to the economic development of central Westchester. I call Route 287 a linear breadbasket, but it is a breadbasket supplied by a labor force that drives across the bridge from Rockland County."
The bridge was designed to carry 100,000 vehicles on six lanes on a peak day, or yearly traffic of 27 million vehicles. With the addition of a seventh lane 18 months ago, the bridge carries 38 million vehicles a year and continues to exceed the traffic capacity for which it was designed.
The Thruway Authority is currently looking at a number of short-term solutions to the problem that could be instituted when it replaces part of the deck of the bridge in 1992.
One possibility would be to eliminate all walkways on the span and expand the bridge to eight lanes, four in each direction. Another is to install a movable concrete barrier system, permitting the addition of a temporary lane in the direction with the heaviest traffic flow. The third short-range solution would be the addition of extra lanes on either side of the bridge by sinking floating new bridge supports.
Mayor Pilla wants the movable concrete barrier system installed in 1991. "We can't wait until 1992, we need it now," she said. "It will not take away the problem but it could dramatically alleviate our congestion." Petitions are circulating in Tarrytown, asking the Thruway Authority to install the movable concrete barriers as soon as possible.
"We're also asking the Thruway and the Westchester Expressway to implement high-occupancy vehicle lanes for commuters," Mrs. Pilla said. "We are very concerned in Tarrytown about the talk back in 1987 concerning a second Tappan Zee bridge proposal. We are totally against that. Accommodate the cars that are already on the road, but don't pave us over because there will be more cars to fill it up.
"Our neighbors across the river in Nyack, Suffern and Grandview are very much against a twin bridge, too. We've seen what the bridge did to us in 1955. We don't want the traffic. We've done our share."

GRAPHIC: Photo: View of the Tappan Zee Bridge; John Marich, project manager for Yonkers company that installed lights on the Tappan Zee (Photographs by Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Many, Neediest Cases Fund Is a Chance to Hope Again;
Finding Quiet Home for a Broken Heart

BYLINE: By DANIELLE M. DELINCE

 BODY:
Like many emigrants who flee their homelands in search of economic, political and religious freedom in the United States, Andres D. left the Dominican Republic 27 years ago for greater opportunities.
He settled in the Bronx, then later moved to Staten Island. For many years he worked as a welder and a janitor at an apartment building in the Bronx, providing for his wife, Eduarda, and their four children. He saw his children through high school and college: One is now an engineer, one is a minister, another is a bank manager and the fourth is an accountant for the city. Family and faith were the underpinnings of his life. 
 But in January, Eduarda died after a long illness and -- after 60 years of marriage -- Andres found himself lonely and depressed. He moved in with a daughter who lives in the Bronx with her husband and adult sons.
 
'I Did Not Know What to Do'
 The crowded house, with loud merengue, jazz and rock music constantly blaring, proved to be too unsettling for 88-year-old Andres, who had become accustomed to solitude in his former home. He stopped eating and "would not touch anything in the refrigerator," his daughter, Rosa, the bank manager, said in a recent interview.
"My dad really needed to be with people of his age," she added. "He was very attached to his memories and I did not know what to do."
Rosa sought help from her employer, who knew about a housing program for the elderly that was operated by the Community Service Society, the nonprofit agency that has been an advocate for New York City's poor since 1847. It is one of seven charities that receive contributions from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
Through its Enriched Housing Program, which has been in operation since 1979, the society provides housing and housekeeping assistance for people over 65 who -- like Andres -- are capable of living on their own.
The housing program is but one of many projects of the society, which shifted its focus in the early 1980's to address issues of homelessness, health and education as services declined and the demands for them became greater.
But "the most important element of the society's work is its academic approach to the basic problems of the poor," said Dwight Langhum, the society's director of special projects,
 
Soup Kitchens and Reading Help
 It publishes periodic reports on conditions that affect the poor and proposes solutions to government and private social service agencies. It also promotes participation in elections and in the last two years has registered some 135,000 voters.
Through its Retired Senior Volunteer Program, some 10,000 volunteers work in soup kitchens, teach adults to read, and assist in museums, libraries and schools.
The Society, which has an operating budget of $14 million, received $1.7 million from the Neediest Cases Fund's last campaign.
Five months ago, Andres became one of its thousands of beneficiaries when he was placed in a one-bedroom apartment in the Randall-Balcom housing project in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx. Designed for the elderly, the three adjoining red-brick buildings are home to several hundred men and women who find comfort in helping each other. Andres is one of 10 residents who are being assisted through the Society's housing program.
Each day about 9 A.M. a social worker, Idesia Bastos, calls to check on him. And two or three times a week a housekeeper does his shopping, making sure he has at least a three-day supply of food. She also cleans the apartment and does the laundry. Just as importantly, though, Mrs. Bastos and the housekeeper provide a bit of companionship.
 
'They Take Good Care of Me'
 "This is a cheaper and more pleasant alternative to a nursing home," Mrs. Bastos said.
Mrs. Bastos tries to make the residents' apartments as homey as possible -- she bought white lace curtains for Andres's living room and bedroom -- and she tries to make their holidays brighter. She has promised Christmas presents for Andres and his neighbors.
"They take good care of me," he said through an interpreter. He even acknowledged that he had gained a few pounds.
Andres, a shy, private man, lives in his apartment surrounded by symbols of his faith -- a blue-and-white wall-hanging in his bedroom proclaims "Mi Corazon Pertenece A Cristo" (My heart belongs to God) -- and photographs of his family, including his nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. But most of all, there are memories of his beloved Eduarda.
He brightens as he talks of their 60 years together and reverently looks at a small black-and-white photograph of them that was taken on their 25th wedding anniversary.
In his bedroom is a wooden plaque given to him and Eduarda by their children for their 50th wedding anniversary 10 years ago.
A tidy man, Andres gets up every morning about 7, makes his bed, prepares his breakfast, watches the news on television and waits for his daily calls.
At midday he goes to an adjacent building to have lunch with the other residents. As the only man in a crowd of ladies, Andres gets a lot of attention. But he does not say much because he speaks very little English and, he said, "I am embarrassed by my accent."
Andres often walks to a neighborhood grocery store for milk or bread and takes frequent walks in a nearby park.
In many ways Andres seems very content with his current life. Still, Mrs. Bastos said, she often finds him weeping silently.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Brigham Young;
Students Fight A Dress Code From the 60's

DATELINE: PROVO, Utah

 BODY:
Although shorts, sweatpants, sockless feet, long hair and beards are commonplace on most university campuses, they have been forbidden for more than 20 years at Brigham Young University, which is owned by the Mormon Church.
Now, the school's Student Advisory Council is proposing a new dress code that would eliminate restrictions some students call illogical and would establish more minimal restraints. 
 The dress and grooming standards the students are challenging were imposed during the restive 1960's as a section of the student honor code. Administrators said the rules were meant to set B.Y.U. students apart from the spirit of rebellion then sweeping other campuses.
Any change in the code would need to be approved by President Rex Lee and the university's trustees, most of whom are church leaders. In October, Mr. Lee created an Honor Code Review Committee of faculty, staff, administrators and students, to consider whether the codes should be changed.
Mr. Lee last week declined to comment on the student proposal until it is formally presented.
 
 Not Immutable
 There have been some changes in the dress code over the past two decades as students have tried to reassert more control over their conduct. Women, for example, were required to wear skirts or dresses. In 1971 they won the right to wear slacks; in 1981, jeans were approved. Today, they are still prohibited from wearing hemlines above the knee, strapless dresses or sleeveless shirts. And the code still states that the "no bra look is unacceptable at B.Y.U."
Other standing rules include the requirement that "men must wear socks with shoes" and that "approved hair length is interpreted as less than one-half inch over the ear. Hair must be above the collar in the back." Beards are prohibited, well-trimmed mustaches are allowed and men are urged to shave daily.
The proposed new code is much less specific -- 163 words in all. It states that men's hairstyles should be clean and neat; beards and mustaches, if worn, must be neatly trimmed; "grubby" clothing, like sweatpants or ripped jeans, may be worn in living areas and informal outdoor activities but may not be worn to "school activities," including athletic events.
Students are admonished, in the proposed code as in the old one, not to wear shorts or skirts above the knee, and encouraged to wear clothes "modest in fabric, fit and style."
 
 Separating the Codes

The Student Advisory Council, which includes representatives from all the colleges in the university, has also proposed separating the dress standards from the honor code.
The president of the council, Brett Blake, a senior in public relations from Ogden, said the main points of the honor code, like academic honesty and integrity, are being overshadowed by the attention paid to the dress code.
Rob Daines, a former student body president who is now a law student at Yale University, said that proposals to revise the dress code have been made year after year, and to his mind remain unlikely to succeed. He said the grooming code "drew attention to things like wearing socks and away from building a different kind of university."
Shannon Dickman, a junior in international relations from Orlando, Fla., said: "I don't think whether or not someone has to wear socks makes a difference in the attitude and atmosphere here,"
"After all," she said, "Brigham Young had a beard, didn't he?"
 
 'Wouldn't Hold My Breath'
 Kristin Smith, the chairwoman of the student committee that drafted the proposal, said she feels that changes will be made in the code eventually. But the sophomore from Batesville, Ind., majoring in political science and economics, admitted, "I wouldn't hold my breath that it will go through as it is now."
The Honor Code Review Committee will send both the student proposal and its own recommendation on to the university administrators who make up the President's Council.
R. J. Snow, the university's vice president for student life, who is chairman of the review committee, said that it is unlikely that its proposal would be as unrestrictive as that of the students. He said that beards -- even the "neatly trimmed" ones the students are proposing -- would probably not be permitted.
The Church takes great pride in the university, said Mr. Snow, and wants the emphasis on campus to remain on education.
Also, he said, the school has many visitors, and the Church wants it to be a place "where people can visit and feel good about what they see."

HEADLINE: Camera

BYLINE: By Andy Grundberg

 BODY:
What a difference a year makes. Last year, I went to the I. M. Pei-designed convention center in New York City to visit the exhibits at the Photo 89 show and found the halls darkened by an electrical failure. Such glitches drove the exhibitors nearly batty. They were mostly manufacturers of pro gear, although the big guns like Kodak and Nikon were in attendance as well.
This year's version, Photo 90, went off with nary a power surge -- especially good news for those showing the latest in computerized, electronic image making. The exhibitors were pleased and so were the more than 10,000 visitors. The annual event, which has a West Coast counterpart each spring in San Francisco, has become a mecca for photographers eager to see and hold the latest high-tech, expensive camera gear. 
 While most manufacturers introduce their latest at the every-other-year Photokina trade fair in Cologne, Germany, or at the PMA (Photographic Manufacturers Association) show held every winter in the United States, some new products emerged at the Photo show. Many were geared to really serious photographers, like new power packs for studio electronic flash set-ups. But a few reached into the thicker part of the photography market.
Ilford, a British company that owns the Swiss-developed Cibachrome process and is in turn owned by the International Paper Company, has a brand-new batch of black-and-white and color products in the pipeline. Some of the most innovative films won't be announced until February, but a few rolls were handed out for testing purposes. As soon as I've tried them, I'll supply the details.
What can be told now is that Ilford's HP5 Plus, a 400-speed, black-and-white film that has a remarkable developing latitude, is newly available in roll- and sheet-film sizes. That may not mean anything to 35-millimeter users, who have been shooting the film for a year, but the expansion of the line gives pros and serious amateurs new options at a time when black-and-white is hot stuff in advertising and editorial contexts.
Other Ilford good news included a new Cibachrome processing system, P-3X, which is both more efficient and more catholic. Processing times are cut by about a third from the old P-3 system (12 minutes versus 18), and the chemicals serve equally well for Cibachrome prints and display transparencies. Its advantages are aimed more at machine processors than at lowly processing drums, however.
Since Cibachrome prints are known to be expensive, Ilford has come up with a low-cost alternative, Ilford Color Rapid. It has a very brief, 2 1/2 minute wet time, which makes it economical for large-volume processors. Let's hope the savings get passed on to the customer!
At Agfa, the news was a high-speed black-and-white printing paper. Called Multicontrast High Speed (they took the words right out of my mouth), the enlarging paper is claimed to require half as long exposures compared to the others.
Remember Contax? That's the low-profile camera that Yashica rescued from oblivion in the 1970's and established as its luxury line, kind of like what Lexus is to Toyota. Now there's a Contax RTS III, an updated version of the classic RTS. Its most notable feature, in this day and age, is manual focusing. Since the lenses are made by Carl Zeiss in Germany, that's not necessarily a disadvantage.
Those enamored of auto focusing, however, might want to check out Minolta's special-edition Maxxum 8000i, which has a reflective white finish. Because it will stay cooler than the standard black-finish model, it would be ideal for taking pictures in, say, Saudi Arabia.
Sunpak, a leading flash maker, has a nifty new add-on ringlight called the DX-12R. Built to fit over lenses with filter sizes of from 49 to 72 millimeters, the ringlight provides ideal illumination for close-ups and a wild "halo" look for portraits. The round flash tube unit plugs into a hot-shoe mounted power source, which resembles a standard on-camera flash.
Mamiya took the occasion to uncover its new version of its venerable RB67, a roll-film camera much used by pros. The new name is the Mamiya RB67 Professional SD, but as far as I know amateurs are allowed to buy it if they can find the cash. The camera has a new lens mount that goes with a brace of new high-speed Mamiya lenses.
Finally, I spied Beseler's new version of its 8-by-10-inch enlarger, which has an improved cold-light source. Okay, so 8-by-10 enlargers aren't typical amateur fare -- especially since most of them are the size of a fork-lift truck, and just as heavy. But Beseler's svelte model, which I used last summer in its earlier, more primitive form, can actually fit in an average home darkroom. This makes me want one, if only to be able to enlarge a whole roll of 36-millimeter film with one exposure.
