HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/Dec. 9-14, 1990

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
After 15 Years, Washington Looks to Moscow's Hunger
 
The question is, will Western aid for the Soviet Union furnish a down payment on economic progress, or a drunken, delirious banquet likely to end in deeper despair? Russian citizens and American scholars wonder. President Bush last week approved $1 billion in Federal credits for the Soviet Union, lifting a 15-year ban on such aid with the goal of easing Soviet food shortages. The United States rejected European calls for full Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, saying the Soviets should receive only Special Association status pending further economic reforms. Many Soviets feel the kindest deed they can do for foreigners bringing money and supplies is to warn that their fellow Russians are cheats, profiteers and thieves. Using the K.G.B. to police food distribution is hardly reassuring. The K.G.B. officer trying to sell his high-crested hat to tourists one day is unlikely to to keep his hands off Western goodies the next.
 
Dyed-in-the-Wood Gorbachev
 
Under the skin, deep inside, is Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev really another Brezhnev? A Khrushchev? A Stalin, or Lenin, perhaps? Moscow souvenir-hunters can count up the implications of the nesting wooden dolls of Soviet leaders sold along the Arbat, the pedestrian mall. They are a 1990's version of the traditional matrushka dolls, which, in Brezhnev's and Stalin's times, invariably depicted maidens, soldiers and other politically safe subjects. The doll vendors are evidently taking advantage of Mr. Gorbachev's encouragement of free markets, hawking Gorby dolls for $20 (hundreds of rubles).

Mexico's Telephone Sale
 
For many Mexicans, a long-distance or international call means a trip to the Telmex office, an hour's wait and charges equal to a day's salary. Last week, the Mexican Government said it would sell Telefonos de Mexico for $1.76 billion to a group that has agreed to bring a donkey-and-cart system into the airline era. The sale, to Grupo Carso of Mexico, the Southwestern Bell Corporation and France Telecom is the latest sign of the country's willingness to accept American investment, according to Sidney Weintraub, a professor at the University of Texas Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs. He added that the United States is meanwhile becoming more hesitant about the free flow of goods and money across its southern border. "I find that role-reversal ironic," he said.
 
Post-Hammer Occidental
 
Maybe Armand Hammer kept going for all those years partly to frustrate the traders who always bid up Occidental Petroleum on rumors of his demise. He died on Monday at the age of 92, the day before his planned bar mitzvah. The stock jumped 1 7/8 to 22 5/8 on Tuesday. Dr. Hammer was long the Soviet Union's favorite capitalist; tour guides at the Lenin Museum in Moscow point out the small statue, a gift from Dr. Hammer, that still sits on Lenin's desk. At Occidental, Dr. Hammer ran his own command economy, purging top aides and spending company funds on an art museum to house his collection, no matter what other stockholders said. Analysts expect Dr. Hammer's patient successor, Ray R. Irani, to introduce perestroika, possibly selling the company's 51 percent interest in IBP Inc., a major meat packer, as well as coal and natural gas operations, to concentrate on chemicals and oil.
 
In Brief
 
Eastern Airlines might still be falsifying its maintenance records, according to a court document released last week. Eastern and several employees were indicted by a Federal grand jury in July on charges of falsely recording repairs.
 
The strong German mark, it would seem, buys more in the United States. The largest German utility, RWE A.G., agreed on Thursday to pay $590 million for the Vista Chemical Company. The offer, $55 a share, was more than double the previous day's closing price of $25.

 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Spreading Recession
 
The worst monthly decline in industrial production since 1982 confirmed the views of many economists that the current recession is unlikely to be mild. Output fell 1.7 percent last month, with automobile production especally weak. "Almost every sector is declining now," said Lawrence Krohn, an economist at Shearson Lehman. He expects production declines to moderate but continue for several months. Not to worry about November's five-tenths of 1 percent rise in producer prices, he added. "Anyone who looks for an acceleration of inflation given this depressed environment will be mistaken," he said.
 
New England Bailout
 
The Bush Administration placed more than $1 billion in Treasury deposits in the ailing Bank of New England this year just as worried depositors were withdrawing billions. Treasury officials denied that the bank had receieved special aid. But the Senate Banking Committee and the General Accounting Office have opened their own inquiries.
 
Retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in November -- no surprise to the store managers who are resorting to pre-Christmas sales.
 
 
COMPANIES


CBS Dumps the Cash
 
The implosion of CBS Inc. continues. It was a premier television network with record and magazine businesses besides; then, a network with a huge pile of cash; soon, just a network with lagging profits and a smaller pile of cash. CBS offered on Thursday to buy back about 44 percent of its stock for $190 a share, using about two-thirds of its $3 billion in cash. The immediate cause was the need for the heirs of William S. Paley, the company's founder, to pay estate taxes. But some analysts said the company's president, Laurence A. Tisch, could find no better use for the cash. Or maybe, some said, Larry the Liquidator wants to trim the company down so it can be acquired in one easily digested bite. Mr. Tisch was greeted as a white knight when he invested in CBS in 1986. Now, some there question his colors.
 
Equitable Passes the Hat
 
That man in front of a midtown Manhattan skyscraper ringing a bell and seeking contributions might be from the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. The needy insurance company announced last week that it plans to raise about $500 million by offering stock to the public. Like most other major life insurers, Equitable has been a mutual company, owned by its policyholders. Losses on "junk bonds" and real estate have forced the company to raise capital. Analysts expect other impoverished insurers to follow Equitable's examples.
 
Power Over Cable?
 
Communities would have more power to limit the cost of cable television service under new rules the Federal Communications Commission proposed last week. The measures could be enacted as early as the spring.
 
An Animated Separation
 
Call off the caterers. Cancel the hall. Mickey Mouse and Miss Piggie have broken off their engagement because their families just can't get along. The Walt Disney Company said on Thursday that it has abandoned its planned acquisition of Henson Associates Inc. and its Muppets. After Jim Henson, the Muppets' creator, died in May, some industry executives say, his five children became rather piggy themselves, refusing to reduce their $100 million-plus asking price. Disney maintained that buying Henson Associates without Henson was like buying Kermit the Tadpole.
 
Kerkorian Targets Chrysler
 
With the Chrysler Corporation smelling like carrion in the desert, sooner or later a vulture was bound to appear. On Friday, Kirk Kerkorian, the takeover artist who rules his own arid kingdom of Las Vegas casinos and hotels, emerged as the owner of 9.8 percent of Chrysler's shares, which cost him $277 million. The Chrysler board did its best on Friday to make the company unappetizing, offering to sell new shares at less than market value if anyone acquires more than 10 percent of its stock. Some analysts say Chrysler is so weak that, to avoid falling prey to an enemy, it needs to sell out to a wealthy, protective friend.
 
NCR Spurns A.T.&T.
 
NCR and A.T.& T. are taking their public battle to the stockholders. The NCR Corporation board unanimously rejected a $90-a-share buyout offer last week from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. NCR chairman Charles E. Exley Jr. plans to visit major institutional investors so as to urge them to keep their stock out of A.T.& T.'s hands. The telephone company, for its part, has threatened a proxy fight against the NCR board.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Consumer Driven? Not This Economy

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
In one more sign that the hard times are
a-changin', the number of new households being formed in the United States had fallen to near-Depression levels before the weaker economy became apparent, reports Richard F. Hokenson, a demographer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Fewer new households, of course, is ominous for housing and consumer-goods industries.
One reason for the drop is the declining number of marriages. Another is that more young men are living at home. "I hope this is not a permanent trend," Mr. Hokenson said of the latter, "and I know their parents hope so, as well. But even if it were to reverse -- and it actually shows signs of growing -- it's a very protracted reversal process." 
 And, packing "a real negative whammy," Mr. Hokenson said, the number of people turning 25 is dropping. "That means much slower growth in the labor force, and workers translate into consumers. To call our economy 'consumer driven' may have been accurate in the past; it is an inaccurate depiction of our future."

HEADLINE: The Art Boom: Is It Over, or Is This Just a Correction?

BYLINE: By PETER C.T. ELSWORTH

 BODY:
The biggest art boom in history may be over, but the market still has a long way to tumble to reach the levels of just two to three years ago.
The growth of the art market through the 1980's reflected a money-obsessed decade when billionaires replaced millionaires in business magazine pantheons. There seemed to be no limits. Prices went ever higher and the boom offered the once-unimaginable prospect of a $100 million painting. It nearly came to pass. 
 But then the economy slowed. The weak results from the fall auctions at Christie's and Sotheby's in New York and London indicate the once white-hot market for Impressionist, modern and contemporary art has cooled. About 20 percent of the Impressionist and modern works failed to sell in New York, and no more than 50 percent of the contemporary works moved.
Still, said Amy Page, editor of Art and Auction magazine, "People are saying we've gone back to 1988 prices, but that's still extremely high, that's not a crash."
"What has crashed in the art market is all the speculation," added Milton Esterow, publisher and editor of ARTnews magazine. "This is very healthy. All the folks who were in the market for a fast buck are out and some of them have gotten burnt."
The sales also offered a few pockets of strength. At Christie's, for example, a van Gogh drawing set a record by selling for $8.4 million, well above the estimate of $5 million to $7 million. But earlier the same evening, one of his paintings, expected to sell for $12 million to $16 million, failed to find a bid higher than $9 million.
Only last May, in the same auction room, a Japanese buyer, who was reportedly prepared to go as high as $100 million, paid a record $82.5 million for the artist's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet."
Even the contemporary market held up in places. "Summer" by Philip Guston sold for $1.1 million, a record for the artist, and de Kooning's "July" sold for $8.8 million, well above its estimate. But a number of works by some of the best-known artists to have emerged in the 1980's -- Eric Fischl and Julian Schnabel, for example -- as well as Pop icon Andy Warhol, failed to find buyers.
Despite continued firmness in a number of other art markets, Latin American among them, the current slump may continue. Christopher Burge, president of Christie's North America, sees a period of consolidation following what he called the buildup of "unsustainable" values led by Impressionist paintings. He noted auction sale results tend to dip every seven years or so.
"It's a much-needed correction," said Ms. Page. "Art is not a liquid investment. You can't turn it over every six months."
The question is how long the correction will run.
"If the economy had continued, the art market would still have corrected itself to a degree," said Paula Cooper, a dealer in SoHo. "A lot of people thought this was coming a lot earlier than it did. I think the next season will be shocking to people. They're going to have to adjust to a new market."
Sotheby's, the world's largest auction house, said last week it was planning a restructuring that will involve laying off about 6 percent of its staff worldwide.
The 1980's art boom was fueled by the flow of new money on Wall Street, the strong Japanese yen and aggressive marketing by the auction houses. In the late 1980's, prices for late-19th- and 20th-century paintings soared above other categories such as Old Masters or English silver. Art, always a speculative venture, constituted the best return on investment for some during the 80's -- provided it sold at all. (Average returns on collectibles do not generally refelect items offered at action but withdrawn if the bid is not high enough.)
The art auctions constitute a secondary market, often dominated by speculators, as opposed to the primary market of artists, galleries and collectors, where, some dealers say, prices are holding up. They add that they are happy to see fewer calculator-toting buyers.
"A person buying to speculate tends not to have an emotional involvement with art," said Mary Boone, another SoHo dealer. Even those who have ridden the 1980's boom welcome the change because art lovers never like to see works reduced to mere commodities.
"It's the people who were in it for investment only who have dropped out," said one dealer, who goes by the name Gracie Mansion. In the mid-1980's, she was at the center of a vibrant art scene which developed in New York's East Village when more than 50 storefront galleries dotted the area. Hardly any remain.
"I've been very lucky," she said, looking around her spacious new gallery in SoHo. But perhaps it wasn't just luck. Perhaps it had to do with looking beyond the dollar value of art.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
As the Banks Ebb, Will the Market Follow?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Bank stocks led the stock market up in the rally that started in October. But now, the banks are starting to fade, and it is possible they will lead the market right back down again.
The state of the banks has worried investors for many reasons. No one can recall the beginning of a recession when the financial system appeared to be in shakier condition. The banks are being damaged by falling asset prices, which continue to drop in part because the banks won't lend money to would-be buyers.
Now, the attention is shifting to Washington, where William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, again raised his estimate of the deposit insurance fund's losses for this year, to $4 billion. A few months ago, they were supposed to be half that.
Tomorrow, a hearing of the House banking committee on the state of the fund is expected to produce more glum estimates, and soon the pressure will be on to make the healthy banks pay. "An outstanding bank like J. P. Morgan would, in an economic sense, effectively face ongoing exposure to New England real estate risk if it were forced through deposit insurance premiums to pay" a share of other banks' losses, warned Eric Hemel, a bank analyst at First Boston, in removing most of his buy recommendations from bank stocks.
The bank stock rally that began on Sept. 28 was a powerful one, albeit from a depressed base. By Dec. 5, Morgan was up almost 50 percent, and the average New York bank added 25 percent. But since then, the average bank has lost 11 percent, while Morgan, still outperforming, is off just 7 percent.
The banks were particularly weak on Friday, as the Dow Jones industrial average lost 20.55 points, leaving it up 3.71 points for the week, to 2,593.81.
When the banks were moving up, one reason was the widespread perception that interest rates were headed down, as the Fed eased. But rates backed up a bit at the end of last week, as Government reports indicated that retail sales and inflation were both stronger than expected in November. That could make the Fed hesitate.
A survey of institutional investors by Richard Hoey, the chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, showed more bullishness on bonds in late November than ever before, breaking the record set a year earlier, just before rates surprised almost everyone by rising. Mr. Hoey expects a repeat, and the dip in interest-sensitive utility stocks reinforces that forecast.
The Fed also is beginning to appear isolated internationally. The outlook in both Japan and Germany seems to be for tighter monetary policy, and Germany now effectively runs Europe. Gilles Halna du Fretay, the president of HDF, a French money management firm, noted last week that while the French economy may need lower interest rates, it won't get them unless Deutsche Bundesbank reverses course.
The danger is that American interest rates will have to rise to attract foreign capital. If so, that is bad news for the banks, and for the economy.

HEADLINE: Running on Fast-Forward in Budapest

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
As an anti-Communist youth, George Varga fled Hungary in 1956 to avoid arrest by the Soviet forces that crushed his homeland's rebellion.
This year, with Communism crumbling, he returned as president of the biggest American joint venture in Eastern Europe: the General Electric Company's bold $200 million effort to revive the Tungsram Company, Hungary's largest maker of light bulbs. 
 Once one of the world's premier light-bulb producers, Tungsram slipped badly under Communism, and Mr. Varga now sees his mission in life as resurrecting the company and making it a beacon for Hungary's 2,000 other state-owned enterprises.
"It feels like a calling," he said, his brown eyes sparkling. "We want to take this country, this company, and put it in fast-forward."
To succeed, he will have to push a lot of buttons all at once -- to improve Tungsram's work ethic, to add modern bulbs to its aging product line, to slash the number of bulbs shattered on the assembly line, to install modern computers and teach people to use them.
Mr. Varga and General Electric are under a lot of pressure to make this experiment work -- it is one of the most closely watched "joint adventures," as they are sometimes called, in Eastern Europe. American companies want to see if giant G.E. can pull it off before they decide whether to take the plunge into Eastern Europe; Hungarians want to see whether America's vaunted capitalist magic can make Tungsram gleam again.
"There are a lot of people watching on both sides," said Mr. Varga, whose elegant gray suit and Milan-modern black leather furniture seem out of place among the smokestacks and industrial din of northern Budapest. G.E.'s investment in Tungsram is the most visible of more than 100 American projects in Hungary, which can boast more American investment than any other Eastern European country. Thanks to its open economy, tax breaks and liberal joint-venture laws, Hungary has also attracted General Motors, Ford, Kodak, Digital Equipment and Levi Strauss.
Turning around Tungsram will not be a cut-and-dried business-school exercise, but a protracted process requiring sacrifice, sensitivity and ingenuity. Tungsram's bloated work force picked up many bad habits under Communism, and many workers are not rushing to embrace Western ways. Its computer system was so backward that when G.E. took over last January, Tungsram tallied its profit and cash flow once every six months, not once a month as G.E. expects.
 
Bumps and Bruises
 What is more, G.E. has come on the scene as Hungary, like the rest of Eastern Europe, is struggling with a stormy situation that is growing stormier by the day: rapid inflation, disarray in the Soviet economy and bumps and bruises from moving toward the free market.
Mr. Varga, a trim, 54-year-old with straight, light brown hair, has to walk a fine line in leading Tungsram out of its difficulties. He is seeking to slash Tungsram's work force while managing somehow to improve employee attitudes. And he is trying to teach Hungarians how to take responsibility after they spent 40 years either shunning it or being shorn of it.
"The most difficult part is the human software," he said. "New ideas were discouraged, there was very little initiative and zero sense of ownership. Attitudes will be the most difficult thing to change. It's not a problem you can just throw money at." Mr. Varga's solution: making his workers feel that Hungarian ways are still appreciated even as he introduces Western ways. This means that he and other G.E. executives, often considered an arrogant, hard-charging bunch, have to be more considerate, more touchy-feely than usual.
"We have to worry about a lot of tender sores," said Mr. Varga. "Some people worry the Americans are trying to colonize. Making this company American overnight will not work."
 
A New Global Fit
 Eastern Europe was long a blank spot on the map of Western executives like G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr., who have ambitions to span the globe. When Communism's momentous collapse began last year, however, G.E. executives warmed up to the region and concluded that Tungsram would fit neatly into their global strategy.
Underlining just how much business's attitude has changed toward Eastern Europe, G.E.'s lighting executives now view Tungsram as key to their European plans. G.E., the world's No. 2 light-bulb maker behind Philips N.V. of the Netherlands, long had just 2 percent of the West European market. That made its $2.3 billion lighting business a distant sixth in that dynamic region.
"It was imperative for us to compete from a much stronger position in Europe," said John D. Opie, a G.E. senior vice president and head of its lighting business. "In order to do that, we needed a European product line, some European manufacturing capacity and an organization that understood the European market."
Tungsram fit the bill. Despite all its flaws, the company, with 7 percent of the Western European market, was a jewel by Soviet bloc standards, exporting an impressive 70 percent of its production to hard-currency countries. Indeed, Mercedes-Benz was so pleased with Tungsram's lights that even this most exacting of auto makers bought them for its cars. Tungsram also gave G.E. a strong position in the promising Eastern European market and a well-educated work force whose wages average $40 a week, one-tenth of what G.E.'s American workers earn. So in November 1989, G.E. agreed to pay $150 million to obtain 50.1 percent of the company.
Now, a year later, G.E. has decided to build on the Tungsram purchase by forming a joint light-bulb manufacturing and distribution company in Britain with Thorn EMI P.L.C. In addition, G.E. is buying Thorn's light-bulb manufacturing activities in the rest of Europe. The deal, announced last month, cost G.E. $138 million and doubles its market share in Western Europe, to 18 percent. That raises its Western European rank to No. 3.
Once G.E. took control of Tungsram, it seemed that every top manager save one knew who was the obvious choice to head the company.
"I was stunned when I got the call," said Mr. Varga, whose previous job was heading a $500 million-a-year G.E. plastics plant in the Netherlands. "The idea was in everybody's mind but mine."
For the man born Gyorgy Varga, it has been a long road back to Budapest. A star soccer player as a youth, he fled to Vienna at the age of 20 after opposing the Soviet invasion, leaving behind his parents, two brothers and two sisters. He felt blessed when he obtained a visa for the United States, and he moved to a refugee camp in New Jersey. There, a minister from Maryland offered to take young Gyorgy and 20 other refugees to Westminster, Md., promising to look after them. On the bus to Maryland, Gyorgy met Judith Szabo, also a Hungarian refugee and the woman he would marry.
Mr. Varga went to Western Maryland College, where he became an all-American soccer player, once scoring 11 goals in a game. Notwithstanding his beginner's English, he did so well in college that he won a scholarship to get a master's in economics at Stanford University. He then joined General Electric, where he has been for 28 years with stints in Spain, Mexico and Switzerland.
 
The Perfect Place
 "Sometimes I feel I spent the past 34 years learning English, going to college, moving ahead at G.E., just to prepare for this job," Mr. Varga said. "I could not wish for anything more perfect than this."
He relishes telling how the Karl Marx School of Economics in Budapest invited him to give an address some 35 years after it rejected him as a student simply because his father was a businessman, not a proletarian. (Mr. Varga's father, who owned a small furniture-making company, died in 1975. His mother still lives here.)
Nowadays, Mr. Varga often ambles over in his soccer player's walk to meet with workers in Tungsram's rundown, turn-of-the-century plant here.
"The most common question workers ask is, 'Is this company going to succeed?' " he said. " 'It's not just my job,' I tell them. 'It's going to be all right, but you're all responsible for making this happen.' "
Central to his efforts is increasing productivity at Tungsram, which had 18,000 employees when he arrived in February. G.E.'s lighting business has the same number of workers, but seven times the sales. Tungsram reported profits of $22 million last year on sales of $300 million, but G.E. reckons that under standard Western accounting methods, earnings were just $9 million.
Mr. Varga has already reduced employment to 15,000, and he is aiming for 13,000 next year. He is doing this mostly through early retirements, attrition and a hiring freeze. However, he is laying off 400 white-collar workers in an overhaul of Tungsram's administration. During the top-heavy Communist era, Tungsram had 11 layers of management in some areas. Overall, there was one white-collar worker for each 2.5 factory workers, compared with a ratio of 1-to-7 at many Western companies. One example of swollen bureaucracy: a purchase order required 24 signatures with a copy going to each person.
 
A Touchy Issue
 Mr. Varga has avoided clashes over the job cuts by working with Tungsram's union. "We acknowledge that to increase productivity, some strict, unpopular measures must be taken, such as reducing the work force," said Gyorgy Selmeczy, head of the union local. Wages are a touchy issue, however, with the union demanding across-the-board raises of about 45 percent (Hungary's inflation rate is 37 percent).
G.E. is telling employees that, although there will be fewer of them and they will work harder, those who remain will earn more. In a singularly un-Communistic move, it has instituted a merit raise system in which some workers receive no increases and others get up to 40 percent.
"It's getting people to recognize that individual performance will be rewarded, and poor performance will not," said James R. Cunheady, Tungsram's vice president for manpower development. "The good performers seem to resent the poor performers' getting the same pay."
In many ways, Tungsram is a microcosm of the region's need for change and its ambivalence toward change. Some workers are disappointed that Tungsram has not already been transformed into a 21st-century enterprise with robotized production and Western pay scales. "I haven't felt any changes yet," said Mihaly Keresztesi, a 27-year-old worker helping assemble headlights. "We thought things would have gotten better already.
But other workers protest that G.E. is pushing too hard to change their petrified work patterns. "We work a lot harder, but we don't get a lot more money for it, and we don't know what's going to happen to our jobs," said 31-year-old Gyongyi Dancs, as she hunched over a microscope. She said she now has to inspect 3,600 headlight filaments a day, up from 2,700 in the pre-G.E. days.
This mixed message is echoing throughout Eastern Europe, as some people say reforms are coming too fast and causing too much pain, while others urge far-faster reform to leave Communism's dreariness behind all the sooner.
G.E. got a different kind of mixed message from Tungsram itself.
When G.E. sent a team of manufacturing experts to Budapest, they were pleasantly surprised. Tungsram had more expertise in the chemistry of tungsten filaments than G.E. did. Tungsram also had some modern computer-controlled Japanese equipment, even though the Hungarian Government took more than 80 percent of the company's profits and nearly starved it of investment funds.
Another plus was that Tungsram was the world's lowest-cost producer of high-quality incandescent bulbs and paid far more attention to quality than did most Communist enterprises.
"Tungsram sold a lot to the West, and they learned their lessons from customers saying, 'Take it back. We're not going to accept defects,' " said Kevin Gallimore, Tungsram's new vice president for manufacturing.
 
Unpleasant Surprises
 But there have been some unpleasant surprises as well. A halogen bulb factory lost an astonishing 70 percent of potential production because of defects, breakage and machine breakdowns. G.E. engineers reduced those losses to 30 percent by, for example, adjusting glass-making temperatures, bulb thickness and pressure inside the bulbs. That compares with 20 percent losses at Western halogen bulb factories.
Another jolt: Tungsram often didn't test its bulbs until a week after they were made. This meant not only unpacking and repacking bulbs, but also often discovering that a week's worth of bulbs were defective. G.E. is installing quality-control equipment that tests the bulbs as they are made.
To modernize and expand production, G.E. plans to invest a total of $60 million this year and next. It is installing equipment to update Tungsram's product array to include compact fluorescent bulbs and high-pressure sodium bulbs for street lamps.
Although Hungary has liberal laws allowing the repatriation of profits, Mr. Varga says G.E. plans to reinvest almost all its Tungsram earnings for several more years. He expects just a few million dollars in profits this year because of restructuring costs, soaring oil prices, high inflation and a 20 percent drop in sales to recession-plagued Eastern Europe.
For the 10 Americans G.E. has sent to Hungary, the biggest surprise of all has been the difficulties caused by the language barrier. That barrier is far more burdensome than in Western Europe where the languages are more familiar to American executives and more local people speak English. G.E. executives complain that time is wasted when everything needs to be translated and that important subtleties often get lost in translation.
"We are working at the same effort level as in the U.S., yet we accomplish just 25 percent of what we do there," said Mr. Gallimore, the head of manufacturing.
For their part, some Hungarians bitterly complain that less talented Hungarians who speak English well are being promoted over more talented Hungarians with weak English.
Despite these tensions, everyone is thankful that there is a Hungarian-American at the helm. This wayward son of the Communist era has become a favorite son in the post-Communist era.
"I don't think you could do this job if you didn't speak Hungarian," Mr. Varga said. "So much of this is an attempt to marry two cultures, to make people live together, that you need someone who is equally comfortable in both languages."
 
 
SOME TRICKS OF THE HUNGARIAN TRADE

So your company is thinking of investing in Hungary? Well, don't set up shop until you have done your homework.
 Eastern Europe is not a place for quick killings, American executives in Hungary warn, although service companies like accounting firms can drum up a lot of business quickly.
"You have to be patient here," said Steven M. Bina, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hungary and co-director of Schwinn Bicycle's joint venture in Budapest. "It's a long-term investment that has the potental to pay off very handsomely 5, 10 years down the road."
Theodore S. Boone, a Budapest-based attorney with Baker & McKenzie, warns that potential investors in Hungarian companies have sometimes had problems just identifying who can sell them a stake.
Although most companies are state-owned, sometimes ministries control them, sometimes workers councils do and sometimes management boards do. "Be very sure you're negotiating with the correct party," Mr. Boone said.
What's more, he said, it would be naive to think that all an investor has to do is plop down some cash for a joint venture to succeed. "You also have to bring in management expertise and technology," he said.
Before the General Electric Company acquired a majority stake in Tungsram, Hungary's premier light-bulb producer, it worked hard to control the risks.
G.E. won guarantees from the state that it would have the same freedom to make management decisions, like layoffs, as it has in the West. Fearing that the Government might, for example, force it to pay twice as much for oil as Hungarian companies, it also won guarantees that it would not be treated worse than domestic companies.
"We're talking about investing a large sum of money in a country where no one was sure what would happen," said William Woodburn, managing director of G.E.'s European lighting operations and the company's new worldwide vice president for marketing. "We were able to mitigate a lot of the risk associated with the business operations."
But there are other risks, largely beyond control. Hungary's 37 percent inflation rate this year has hurt the competitiveness of Tungsram's exports. Sales to the old Soviet bloc have slipped after the region's economy plunged into recession for numerous reasons, including higher oil prices, the deterioration of the Soviet economy and the disintegration of Comecon, the Soviet-led trading group.
Despite these risks, Hungarians are still counting on Western investors to help turn their economy around. Andras Pinter, the Hungarian who heads Levi Strauss's jeans-making joint venture, said, "If Hungary gets some good products and good technology, its industry could really do well."

HEADLINE: All About/Dog and Cat Food;
Will the American Pet Go for Haute Cuisine?

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
When is a consumer not a consumer? When the product is pet food and the human buyer is merely the medium by which the pet obtains its grub. On that paradoxical relationship rests the brutal business of feeding the nation's 109 million cats and dogs. Americans spend some $7.5 billion annually to keep their four-pawed pets in chow, more than on any other category of packaged food.
Though profitable, the industry recently has grown only 3 percent to 4 percent annually. Consolidation has reduced the number of producers and put others in jeopardy. In 1982, seven manufacturers held 74 percent of the market; in 1989, the Big Six manufacturers held 84 percent, according to John Maxwell, a food industry analyst with Wheat/First Securities. 
 "There's no doubt this is a mature industry," said Douglas Mills, president of the diversified grocery product division at the Quaker Oats Company in Chicago. The problem for the Big Six food companies -- Ralston-Purina, Carnation, Quaker, Heinz, Mars and Alpo -- is that consumers are increasingly likely to buy either in expensive specialty pet shops or in discount houses like Wal-Mart. "The volume of pet food sales is shifting away from supermarkets," Mr. Mills said.
But an industry that monitors every twitch of consumer behavior has begun to detect its next big opening. The heightened human awareness of nutrition and fitness is changing the diets of cats and dogs.
"People are feeding their pets like they feed their children. The nutrition kick has moved over to our pets," said John McMillin, who follows the food industry for Prudential-Bache Securities. The marketing of pet food and the marketing of human food are converging as companies try to persuade pet-loving, health-conscious consumers to pay from a third more to twice as much for a can or bag of food.
In the brawling tradition of food producers, the Big Six are still slugging it out with expensive introductions of new pet-food products. Alpo, owned by Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate, rolled out its first cat food last year. But to insure profitability and margins that are typically 8 percent to 10 percent, but sometimes as high as 25 percent, the companies must also search for new turf.
Thus, the 16 percent of the market not dominated by the major producers beckons. This field was long conceded to small, so-called "premium" pet-food companies, like Hill's Pet Products and the Iams Company.
Mr. McMillin estimates that this niche is worth as much as $1 billion, with 20 percent annual growth in recent years. Even smaller, entrepreneurial outfits like Lick Your Chops, which uses organic ingredients, are attracting more customers. For the moment, the tiny tail of the industry is wagging the corporate dog.
 
Marketing Is Key
Consumers Show Scant Brand Loyalty
In pet food, the wise producer rarely sleeps. The Ralston-Purina Company, the St. Louis feed giant, has remained the industry leader for several years by regularly trotting out new products to keep its lines fresh. Perhaps because consumers sense what animal nutritionists know -- that the major brands of pet food are almost equally nutritious -- there is little brand loyalty.
That makes sales a matter of marketing, and a big company may spend millions on coupons and advertising to promote a new product. The ads generally work by giving human attributes to pets, often presenting them conversing with humans or expressing their own willful little personalities.
"We know that most pet owners talk to their pets," said John Goodchild, chairman of the Weightman Group in Philadelphia, which produces advertising for Alpo and choreographed marketing in the $70 million debut of Alpo's new cat food. "The emotional bond between owner and pet is extremely powerful. We try to evoke that or show that we understand."
Alpo says its premium cat food, introduced with the help of Garfield the cartoon cat, is the most successful new pet food in years. The company says the product has added $126 million in sales for Grand Metroplitan, which earlier this year tried to sell Alpo but could not.
The industry is skeptical of Alpo's claims. Competitors and analysts say the cat food's initial success has depended on promotions and discounts that Alpo will be unable to sustain over the long haul. "We'll see how much share Alpo has once they stop the promotions," said Mr. McMillin of Prudential-Bache.
The industry does agree that Alpo forced everyone to spend more money on marketing. "Everyone got hurt by their aggressiveness," Mr. McMillin said.
 
The Big Six
All Are Jostling For Premium Niche
 The supermarket frays are likely to continue as the Big Six muscle into premium food. In the last four years, virtually every major producer has jumped into the upper bracket. The acronym-driven Ralston-Purina has launched Pro-Plan, O.N.E. (for Optimum Nutrient Effectiveness) and, at the end of this year, a reformulation of Pro-Plan, Pro-Plan CMN (for Clinical Nutrition Management). Heinz's Nine Lives, the leading canned cat food, is now available as "Lean Entree" for the full-figured tabby. Quaker Oats is reformulating Cycle dog food for delivery early next year, to be sold in supermarket "nutrition centers," which will offer guidance on choosing Cycle products appropriate for a pet's age.
If it sounds like the new pet foods will require owners manuals, blame Hill's Pet Products, bought by the Colgate-Palmolive Company in 1975, and Iams, an independent based in Dayton, Ohio. Until recently, the two companies have had the premium territory almost to themselves.
Hill's grew more than tenfold in the 1980's, to an estimated $470 million in sales last year. The company began making dog food in 1948, then expanded by developing a network of veterinarians who used its Prescription Diet to help manage ailments like feline urological syndrome, and heart disease and obesity in both dogs and cats. In the early 1960's, Hill's began to sell the Science Diet, originally formulated for dogs involved in medical research who needed a nutritious, consistent diet. Hill's continues to sell both products through veterinarians, but has also moved Science Diet into specialty pet stores, where it often shares shelf space with Iams, its smaller rival.
Neither company admits to being worried by the unabashed copy-cat strategy of the Big Six. Some larger producers have adopted the names of the Hill's "Senior," "Performance" and "Maintenance" lines. "It discourages me that other companies don't have the ingenuity to come up with their own product names," said David Geier, vice president of marketing and communications at Hill's.
 
Specialty Boutiques
From Nut Brittle To Kitty Pasta
 Anyone passing by at a shop-til-you-drop pace would be forgiven for mistaking the Lick Your Chops pet shops on Manhattan's Upper East Side for one of the neighborhood's many human boutiques and gourmet food stores. The front of the shop is festooned for the holidays and overflowing with ceramic food bowls, leashes and toys.
In the back are the shelves of super-premium pet food -- not only Hill's and Iams, but also Chef Andriu's Chicken 'n Pasta, for cats; Haute Canine, the Natural Gourmet Dog Snack; Dandy Doggy Bowser Brittle, with rain-forest nuts, and Lick Your Chops' own "Junk Food for Cats," which looks a lot like Pepperidge Farm Goldfish crackers.
Lick Your Chops may never dislodge Ralston-Purina, but the South Norwalk, Conn., company is clearly in the pet-food avant-garde. It is an example of a small entrepreneurial company that found a niche in an industry dominated by wealthy behemoths.
Susan Goldstein, the company president, was selling the ingredients for home-cooked pet foods when, in 1979, she founded Lick Your Chops. Now she has five stores, a line of pet foods, treats and diet supplements and, she says, $4 million in annual sales. She calls her pet food "natural," with organic, pesticide-free ingredients. "It is a lot of work to feed animals consciously," she says of her New Age approach to pet cuisine.
Might consumers be less inclined to pay for organic ingredients if the United States economy continues its free fall? "We might see a drop-off on leashes or bowls, but not on food and supplements," Ms. Goldstein said. "People still want the best for their pets."
 
SORTING OUT NUTRITIONAL CLAIMS
The thought of eating a typical can of pet food may make a human blanch, but according to animal nutritionists, cats and dogs eat very well. "America's dogs and cats eat more healthily than America's children," said Dr. James Corbin, a dog-and-cat-nutrition researcher at the University of Illinois in Urbana.
Pet food typically contains meat byproducts, cereals and grain, which provide protein, minerals, fatty acids, vitamins and energy. "If an animal is eating pet food, all it needs is water to have whole nutrition," Dr. Corbin said.
The industry is heavily scrutinized by state and Federal agencies, including the Food and Drug Administration.
Pet food makers are sometimes frustrated by labelling regulations. They are not allowed to make health claims without satisfying the clinical standards of the F.D.A. But claims about being low-calorie or "light" are legal -- if they are true. And a pet food maker may not claim its food is especially tasty unless, during a complicated set of feeding trials, several animals actually choose its food.
The industry would like to expand label information, but regulators are skeptical. "Labelling is a marketing tool," said Richard Sellers, the chairman of the Association of American Feed Control Officials Pet Food Committe. "You can list everything that's in a can of food and that still won't tell the consumer anything about what the animal will actually digest." For example, an indigestible byproduct of leather like rawhide, which shows up occasionally in some very inexpensive pet foods, is considered a protein.
There is some difference between the regular and so-called premium -- more expensive -- pet foods the companies are touting: premium food is denser in calories and vitamins and may be easier to digest. "The animal may eat less food and have less stool. It's easier for an apartment dweller to take care of," said Dr. Corbin. "But the difference is really between a Cadillac or a Mercedes and other cars. The superpremiums are more refined," he said. Animal nutritionists say any food from a major producer is nutritionally adequate.
And is "natural" pet food -- made, say, from New Zealand lamb, as one small company has advertised -- healthier than supermarket or pet-shop pet food? "What is a 'natural' product? 'Natural' is a figment of the advertising industry's imagination," said Dr. Bruce Little, the executive vice president of the American Veterinary Medical Association. "Lamb from New Zealand is no better than lamb from Idaho."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Year-End Push for Keoghs

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
At the end of the year, there is always a surge in the number of people setting up Keoghs, the retirement plans for the self-employed and for those who work for them. But this year, Fidelity Investments, for one, says it is opening Keoghs at a faster rate than last year. What's fueling the growth? More owners of small businesses are getting into them, particularly since they are one of the few tax shelters left.
Given that, how should people invest their Keogh funds? Most investment advisers recommend putting a big chunk of retirement savings into stock funds, which tend to outperform fixed-rate investments over time. Because most Keoghs are long-term investments, you can afford to be aggressive. But in today's environment, it makes sense to move into the stock market slowly, to limit the impact if the market takes another nosedive. Put the Keogh cash into a money fund and then buy shares in stock funds at regular intervals. 
 What follows are some questions that investors are posing to Fidelity and answers from two retirement experts: Linda Lindbeck, a Fidelity product manager for self-employed retirement plans, and Robert M. Fields, an attorney with the New York law firm Spengler Carlson Gubar Brodsky & Frischling.
Question: How much can I contribute to a Keogh?
Ms. Lindbeck: That depends on which of three variations you choose. In a profit-sharing Keogh, you decide each year whether to contribute and how much; the maximum is 13.04 percent of your net profit, up to $30,000. With a money-purchase Keogh, you must contribute a fixed percentage of earnings each year, up to a maximum of 20 percent, or $30,000. Most people, however, use "paired plans," with features of both. You choose the percentage that you contribute annually to the money-purchase portion, usually 8 percent, and then you can contribute up to 12 percent more to the profit-sharing portion.
Q. When I set up a Keogh, can I make contributions for myself without putting away money for my employees?
Mr. Fields: No. All employees eligible for the plan are entitled to contributions. The amount depends on the plan's guidelines, but employees must benefit comparably with you or you lose the Keogh tax advantages: contributions are tax-deductible and earnings in the account build up tax-free until withdrawals begin. You can deduct contributions that you make for employees.
Q. I hold a full-time job, and I've just set up a consulting business on the side. I'm covered by a retirement plan at work. Can I use a Keogh to shelter part of my business profits?
Ms. Lindbeck: Yes. Employees who own separate businesses generally can contribute part of their business earnings to a Keogh.
Moreover, executives who serve as outside directors on corporate boards usually can fund a Keogh with part of their fees.
Q. What's the deadline for setting up a Keogh?
Ms. Lindbeck: The account must be set up by Dec. 31. Don't worry if you are short of cash -- it's prudent to put a small amount into the account, $100 say, because the maximum amount is not due until your tax return deadline, April 15, or later if you get an extension.
Q. I was recently laid off and I've just started a new business. Can I roll over the money from my previous employer's retirement plan into my new Keogh?
Mr. Fields: For most people, yes. But you cannot roll over money into the Keogh from an Individual Retirement Account to which you contributed; from a 403(b) plan, used by universities and non-profit groups; or from a 457 plan, used by municipalities and government. Keep in mind that rollovers must be completed in 60 days. When you miss the deadline, you owe tax on the money, plus a penalty if you are younger than 59 1/2. And the Internal Revenue Service almost never waives the 60-day deadline.
Q. Do I need a lawyer to set up a Keogh?
Ms. Lindbeck: Not if you choose a "prototype qualified plan," standardized plans, of the three Keogh varieties. These are sufficient for most businesses and mutual funds that sponsor Keoghs can give you the forms.
Q. How much will it cost to set up a Keogh?
Mr. Fields: Mutual funds generally don't charge to open the account. After that, expect to pay a small maintenance fee each year, about $10, but that can rise depending on how many funds you invest in and how many people are covered by the plan. Keep in mind that the annual custodial fees are "miscellaneous expenses" that can be deducted to the extent the total expenses exceed 2 percent of your adjusted gross income. To claim the deduction, you must write separate checks for the Keogh contribution and the expenses, not one to cover both.
 
THE MONEY FUND CASH POT
 Investors poured enough cash into money funds this fall to break the half-trillion-dollar mark, a record. A big chunk of that came from investors who usually keep their cash in bank certificates of deposit, but who decided to move their cash because of their worries over a deteriorating American banking system.
Another large chunk came from stock and bond fund investors, part of the continuing flight to safety that began when the stock market plunged in August and rising oil prices brought the weakness of the American economy into sharper focus.
What happens next? The trend is likely to continue, experts say.
"Cash will probably keep flowing into money funds until the question of war in the Gulf is resolved and the economy settles down," said Martha Wittbrodt, editor of IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a newsletter in Holliston, Mass.

HEADLINE: We'll Sell One Another Ice Cream Cones

 BODY:
To the Editor
You continue to cling editorially to outmoded textbook nonsense about the advantages and blessings of free trade despite a world in which countries protect and promote their own industries and people -- except the United States, that is.
Our leaders preach the gospel of free trade despite the facts that show we are well on our way to becoming a low-wage, service economy. The latest indictment of the folly of the free trade philosophy comes in "Hard Work Can't Stop Hard Times" (front page, Nov. 25). In this article, the first of three in a series titled "Scraping By," you point out that "industries pressed by low-wage competitors overseas" have trimmed work forces or closed factories, "elminating more than 850,000 jobs in manufacturing, most of which paid well." In their place, we have millions of new jobs that "generally pay less and offer fewer benefits."
We have seen our high-wage industrial base virtually wiped out by unfair trade practices, such as dumping, and by our failure to protect this base. We have also watched foreigners capture this country's electronics and textile industries. In short, we have been giving away the store.
Some 25 years ago, I. W. Abel, who was then president of the United Steelworkers of America and the industrial union department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., warned in a Washington conference on international trade that unless the United States stopped playing the role of international Santa Claus, we Americans would wind up working in a service economy in which we tried to sell one another ice cream cones or rent one another motel rooms.
 
DONALD E. SMITH
Sun City West, Ariz., Nov. 30, 1990
 
The writer retired as assistant public relations director of the United Steelworkers of America.

HEADLINE: Listen Up, Corporate America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
RJR Nabisco's Louis Gerstner Jr. offers a familiar but flawed and even tired argument that only a unified national marketplace, which new state government activism threatens, can save the competitiveness of American business ("Untangle the State Regulatory Web," Nov. 25). Even the choice of the word "web" wrongly equates public purpose with that of a spider.
Gerstner ignores two salient points. First, that several American states always have been strong regulators of business and vital policy crucibles. States always have had the option of setting higher environmental standards than the Federal Government, for example. Second, while Europe is moving toward more uniform standards and regulations, these will never exactly mirror those in the United States, Japan, Canada or anywhere else. There will continue to be wide differences in world marketplaces.
The most competitive companies thrive by being more flexible and more responsive to markets and customers. I.B.M. is only the latest company being forced to make that adjustment. As the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Commission on Industrial Productivity found in "Made in America: Regaining the Productive a study published last year, the adjustment involves shedding outdated mass-production and economies-of-scale strategies that Gerstner champions in his unified marketplace argument. Harvard's Michael Porter calls it being "fixated with static efficiency when progressiveness and innovation are far more important." M.I.T. prescribes new, long-term commitments to excellence; partnerships with workers, suppliers and customers, and responsiveness to differences in cultures, practices and habits.
The lesson for American executives is that the world owes neither your product nor your service a living. Neither does any individual American state. So move the American business mind off webs and onto delivering what the customer values. A clean environment, safe, healthy products and an ability to make an informed choice are part of the new definition of "quality product." And what state legislators hear is there for business executives, too.
 
J. DOUGLAS KOELEMAY
Washington, Nov. 30

HEADLINE: Japan Is Moving to Scale Back Military Spending

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Six weeks after Japan backed away from proposals to send its troops to the Persian Gulf, the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is putting the final touches on a five-year military program that for the first time in years will greatly slow the growth of the country's military spending.
The final plan is scheduled to be approved on Thursday by Mr. Kaifu's Cabinet. But earlier this week, under questioning in the Parliament, the Prime Minister suggested that Japan was planning to restore, in practice ifnot in policy, its self-imposed limit of spending no more than 1 percent of the country's gross national product on national defense.
 
That limit was swept away by Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone in 1987, in what was hailed at the time as a major symbolic change.
Should Japan return to its previous spending ceiling, first imposed in 1976 by Prime Minister Takeo Miki, it would appear to constitute a major setback for the United States. Throughout the 1980's American officials pressed Japan to greatly increase its military budget, its readiness, and its support for the 60,000 American troops based here. A limit on total military spending seems bound to heighten tensions with Washington over the size of that "burden-sharing," just at a time that Congress is insisting that Japan take a much larger share of the cost of basing troops in Japan.
Before Congress went out of session, it passed a nonbinding resolution that called on Japan to assume 100 percent of the yen costs of basing troops here, or risk a rapid withdrawal of American forces. Currently Japan pays about 40 percent of those costs, or roughly $3 billion, and it has indicated a willingness to raise this level to 50 percent. The Congressional vote, however, was prompted largely by frustration over Japan's unwillingness to provide more than just money for the Gulf effort.
In Parliament this week, Mr. Kaifu defended his plan to slow Japan's military buildup by pointing out that the rationale throughout the 1980's -- that Japan had to be prepared for an attack by the Soviet Union -- looks increasingly unrealistic. He said that the Government would have to reassess what kind of tanks, aircraft and warships it would need in the future.
 
Kaifu's Attitude
 But they also have major implications for Mr. Kaifu, a man of pacifist leanings who, by all reports, opposed the own party's efforts to enact a bill that would have allowed Japan to send troops to the Middle East in non-combat roles. The bill, and a new interpretation of the Japanese Constitution that was floated by Mr. Kaifu's Government to pave the way for the first overseas military mission since World War II, was withdrawn after overwhelming criticism from the public and opposition parties.
Even in the late 1980's, as Japan emerged as one of the biggest military spenders in the world, it never ventured far beyond the 1 percent line. The military budget rose fractionally above the limit for three years starting in 1987, but last year, when the economy grew faster than expected, it dropped just below. Still, the Japanese economy has surged ahead so rapidly in recent years that the budget of the Self-Defense Forces, as they are formally known, has regularly jumped 5 to 6 percent a year.
Japanese Government officials contend that there has been no change of policy, but that the days of big increases are over. "There is a general sense that there is no longer a need for that kind of increase," a senior Japanese diplomat said this week. Among the changes likely to be approved next week, for example, is a reduction of Japan's authorized ground forces from 180,000 men to about 150,000. But the old figure has been something of a fiction, because the military has not been able to attract enough recruits to reach its full strength.
The United States may find itself in a difficult position to press Japan for further buildup. At a time that the Pentagon budget itself is being cut, American diplomats say they can hardly urge Japan to take the opposite view. Nor do they want to be seen in the rest of Asia as urging Japan to rearm.

HEADLINE: 'Something Askew' In Society's Contrasts

 BODY:
The Oct. 21 issue was a puzzlement in contrasts. The front-page lead article was headlined "New Homes for Lives of Luxury Late in Life" and dealt with the growing older group of New Jersey citizens who are retiring to luxurious surroundings and the developing industry catering to them.
The Opinion page had an article with the headline "Spending a Night With the Homeless" and a subtitle, "The people at a shelter aren't so different from us."
Also on the front page was "S.& L. Crisis Hurting State's Economy." This article emphasized the difficulty that potential borrowers are having in borrowing funds in excess of 100 percent collateral.
I read this and learned that borrowers and bankers alike seemed to think such loans were not out of line since deposits were insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation for up to $100,000. No need for the bank to be careful.
What a confusing, unsettling grouping of articles. What a sad commentary on our present society. Are we really very much like, very close to the homeless? Who are those who live "lives of luxury late in life" who are so great in number as to create a whole new industry in the state?
And who are those who are borrowing from the banks in excess of 100 percent of their collateral? Is it right to make loans in excess of collateral and rely on the taxpayer to take up the risk such a loan involves?
There is enough food for thought here to last a lifetime. Who are we really most like? The luxury-living retirees? The high-flying borrowers? The homeless? Which is representative of our society? Do we have a "good" society when there are such extreme contrasts, where credit is so loosely provided?
If nothing else, one must at least recognize that such dramatically contrasting conditions and points of view cannot lead to a stable society or economy. There is something askew in New Jersey as well as the rest of our country.
Will we recognize this? Will we do something to correct it? Or will we wait for some calamity to bring us to our senses?
 
 CHARLES P. HUETHER
Clifton

HEADLINE: Japanese Bank's Charity to Aid New Yorkers

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
The Industrial Bank of Japan Trust Company, a subsidiary of the world's seventh-largest financial institution, has created a foundation in New York to assist homeowners in the city's poorer neighborhoods and to help improve the schools.
The IBJ Foundation is just the latest example of Japanese philanthropy in the United States, but it is the first foundation created by a Japanese financial institution. Until now most Japanese philanthropies were established by companies that sell consumer goods like automobiles and electronics. For example, the Toshiba AmericanFoundation, created last May and based in New York, promotes science and technology curriculums in high schools. 
 The new foundation began with $2 million in assets, and that will be increased to $10 million in the near future, said Isamu Koike, chairman of the Trust Company.
Mr. Koike said the decision to set up a foundation was not motivated by a desire to attract new clients or burnish the bank's image.
"Our presence and success have grown and we have reached a stage where we want to show our appreciation to the host community for its enormous support during our 30 years here," he said. The bank is a subsidiary of the Industrial Bank of Japan, which has 1,200 employees in the United States, in its Park Avenue headquarters and branches in six other cities.
The bank's decision to go beyond traditional support of American universities and cultural centers, and to respond more directly to the needs of schools and neighborhoods in New York, was welcomed by others involved in philanthropic efforts, who said American banks were cutting back in their support.
"The question remains whether this is just one step by an enlightened financial institution or the start of a trend by others domiciled in New York to pick up the slack," said Dr. Delwin A. Roy, president of the Hitachi Foundation, the largest of the Japanese corporate philanthropies.
The IBJ Foundation's first round of grants will provide $50,000 for Neighborhood Housing Services of New York City to develop self-help centers for low- and moderate-income residents to receive financial counseling about mortgages, insurance and home repairs.
Another $50,000 will enable the Fund for New York City Public Education to improve geography education by strengthening teacher-training and by establishing two Geography Learning Outcome Based Education Centers, called GLOBE centers. The two learning centers, for sixth and ninth graders,will be equipped with maps, charts, globes, videotapes and computer software.
A third $50,000 grant will be used by National Public Radio to expand economics and business reporting to include a more international perspective.
Japanese corporate giving in the United States has increased from $85 million in 1987 to about $200 million annually, Dr. Roy and others said.
"There is a new enlightenment among Japanese businessmen that their contribution must go beyond check-writing and include personal involvement in American communities, especially where they have business interests," said Tadashi Yamamoto, president of the Japan Center for International Exchange and a leader in encouraging Japanese philanthropy.
But he said the growth of Japanesephilanthropy was still too slow given the "conspicuous" wealth and involvement of Japanese concerns in the United States.
He said Japanese business leaders had to be educated about philanthropy, which is still an unknown field to many because many Japanese expect charitable needs to be met by government, not private, resources.
"Japanese corporations also are becoming more sophisticated and professional in their giving programs, going beyond gifts to the blue-chip universities like Harvard and Stanford or the cultural icons," he said.
Because the IBJ Foundation is endowed by the IBJ Trust Company incorporated in the United States, the bank is entitled to tax benefits for its contributions.

HEADLINE: Man Killed on Corner, Apparently by a Stray Bullet

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A 42-year-old man was killed Friday evening, apparently by a stray bullet, as he was drinking wine with a friend on a street corner in his East Harlem neighborhood, the police said.
It was unclear yesterday whether the shot was intended for someone or the gunman was shooting for thrills or practice. But if Randall Wade, of 316 East 102d Street, was an unintended victim, as the police believe, he would be the 37th person to be killed in New York City this year by stray gunfire, Police Department records show. Ten of the victims were under the age of 14. 
 Mr. Wade was shot at 7:06 P.M. in front of the Heidi grocery store at 2029 First Avenue near 104th Street. He was drinking and chatting with friends at the time, the police said. They said the shot was fired from either the East River or the Woodrow Wilson housing projects, which rise between First Avenue and the East River.
Detectives canvassed the projects for witnesses yesterday, but by late afternoon they had no suspects.
 
A Divorced Father
 Mr. Wade, who was unemployed, lived most of his life in the neighborhood, said his mother, Delores Wade of the Bronx. He has an 18-year-old daughter, Tunisia, from his marriage, which ended in divorce several years ago, Mrs. Wade said.
"He was a brilliant boy," his mother said, "but he never could get his life together. He was always reading. You never saw him without a book or newspaper in his hands."
After his marriage ended he lost his job. "He hasn't been gainfully employed since," his mother said.
Mr. Wade started drinking heavily, his mother said, and spent a lot of time socializing on the street in East Harlem. He passed the Postal Service exam but never followed through on the job application, she said. For a while he worked as a cook in a soup kitchen for the homeless in Harlem.
Two weeks ago, he was hospitalized with pneumonia after he went to visit his parents. They saw that he was pale and sick and forced him to see a doctor, his mother said. When he came out of the hospital last week, she said, he looked "more like his old self" than he had in years. He told his mother he was planning to apply for a job with the city's Parks Department.

HEADLINE: Long Lines at a Failed Bank

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 15

 BODY:
Hundreds of people lined up today in sleet and snow to claim their savings from the United Savings Bank, which has been ordered to return deposits.
The Paterson police said more than 2,000 people waited to take their turn at United's main office. Customers began camping out there at 2 A.M. 
 Federal regulators seized the bank in May, accusing it of documenting loans improperly, offering risking interest rates, making unsafe real-estate loans and paying excessively high salaries.
The Federal agency that manages ailing thrift institutions, the Resolution Trust Corporation, closed the 49-year-old savings bank without warning on Thursday night.
"I made a deposit Wednesday and nobody said anything," said Regina Ellerbee, 36 years old, of Paterson.
But a Resolution Trust spokeswoman, Andrea Plater, said no one should have been surprised.
 
Couldn't Find a Buyer
 "They knew it was a troubled institution and the Government was trying to close it," she said. "Customers knew we were trying to find a buyer."
But Ms. Plater said Resolution Trust could not sell the bank; more than 680 solicitations had failed to bring a single bid, she said.
A former president of the bank, Donald J. Moskowitz, pleaded guilty in September to defrauding the bank of about $2.5 million. In November, a former controller, Ronald Rudd, pleaded guilty to Federal bank-fraud charges.
The thrift's branches in Parsippany-Troy Hills, Succasunna and Bricktown were also returning customer deposits. Refunds will continue during the week, and on Friday the bank will mail checks to depositors who have not claimed their money, officials said.
The bank has 32,300 accounts, with total deposits of $183.4 million.
Ms. Plater said officials have so far identified 11 accounts in excess of $100,000, the maximum sum insured by the Federal Government.

HEADLINE: Northeast Housing Slowdown Spreads Into Industry Recession

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A prolonged slump in home sales that began in the New York and Boston areas soon after the stock market collapse of 1987 has expanded into a housing recession that engulfs much of the nation, according to economists and real estate executives.
As always, the strength of home sales varies in different regions and cities. One legacy of the economic boom of the 1980's, the experts say, is that those markets in which prices were propelled to the highest levels, particularly on the East and West Coasts, are now experiencing the deepest declines.
 
Volume and Prices Down
 But in a broad shift of economics and market psychology over the last six months, buyers have moved to the sidelines in almost every section of the nation. The sale of houses is down 7 percent from 1989. New construction is at its lowest level since 1982. Since July, the median price paid for houses around the country has fallen 6 percent. 
 At least for the moment, the American romance with home ownership appears to have cooled.
"The anxiety is national," said Louis H. Masotti, a professor of real estate at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management who is now a visiting faculty member at Stanford University.
"You look around the country and there are fewer and fewer spots of non-recession," he said.
Analysts attribute the downturn to a number of factors, some temporary and others deeply embedded in the economic downturn, which is having wide-ranging effects on people around the country. [Page 26.]
In addition, the housing analysts say other factors in the slump are fears of war in the Middle East, corporate job cuts, overbuilding, more stringent lending requirements by banks and savings institutions, demographic changes that have brought fewer first-time buyers into the market, and the simple fact that too few Americans can afford the prices being asked for homes, even where prices have fallen sharply.
"Buyers were lining up at the door, but that turned around in March," said Mike Cook, president of CedarMark Home Corpo-ration, a Seattle builder. Seattle had one of the nation's most robust housing markets in 1988 and 1989, with prices rising more than 20 percent a year.
Now, Seattle buyers have retreated and prices have fallen by more than 10 percent. Mr. Cook said, "We are trying to sell off excess inventory."
Smaller cities in the Midwest are proving more resistant to the downturn. But they are not immune.
 
Michigan Listings Climb
 In Ann Arbor and Ypsilanti, Mich., the number of "for sale" listings has climbed nearly 50 percent this year, to 1,749 in October. "It is typical of what is happening across the country," said Dennis R. Capozza, a professor of finance at the University of Michigan.
In Indianapolis, James and Lynn Meyers paid $162,000 for a four-bedroom colonial house in October, but made their decision only after a marathon house hunt that real estate executives say has become standard procedure around the country. They looked at more than 100 properties.
Buying a house now "is a leap of faith," Mr. Meyers said. Houses in Indianapolis are "just not moving," he said.
And in Florida, builders in Tampa, Orlando, St. Petersburg and other cities are struggling to sell a bloated inventory of new houses and condominiums intended for retirees and other migrants from northern states. The problem, they say, is that would-be buyers cannot sell their homes in New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and other states that have been mired in the real estate slump for more than two years, so they are postponing the move south.
 
Still, a Modest Slump
 "We are dealing with a ripple effect," said Douglas Buck, director of community affairs for the Florida Association of Home Builders.
Housing markets have always moved in cycles, and the current downturn appears modest when compared with the sharp slump in 1981 and 1982 when interest rates on mortgage loans soared to more than 16 percent. The National Association of Realtors, a trade group in Washington, estimated this week that 3.2 million American houses would be sold by the end of this year. While that would be down 7 percent from 1989, it still represents 60 percent more sales than in 1982, when the housing market had reached its lowest point in recent years.
And while home ownership remains beyond the reach of millions of Americans, it is getting closer. With prices coming down in some regions, interest rates falling and incomes rising slightly, studies show that houses are more affordable than at any time since 1978.
One analysis in October, by the National Association of Realtors, found that the median family income of $35,353 was 110 percent of what was necessary to qualify to buy a house at $92,800, the median price for the nation. The study also found that the median selling price of houses had sharply fallen since July, when it reached a record high of $98,300.
 
New York Market Is Tough
 Regional variations remain wide. Another study of median incomes and house prices by MortgageWright Inc., a mortgage banking company in Richmond, Va., found that the least affordable markets included the New York City area, Los Angeles and San Francisco. In New York, the study found that the median family income of $36,900 was only 68 percent of the amount needed to qualify for the median priced house of $175,000.
That contrasts sharply with many cities in the South and Midwest, where home ownership is a comparatively simple option. The MortgageWright study found that Saginaw, Mich., with a median family income of $37,200, or slightly higher than in New York, was the easiest place to buy a house. The median home price there is $49,300.
Because housing costs remain high in the Northeast and California, the slump could last longer in those areas.
"House prices have reached such rarified levels compared to incomes that they cannot be sustained," said David Shulman, a real estate analyst for Salomon Brothers, the securities firm. "It is going to take several years of income growth" to resurrect the most expensive markets, he said.
Hardest hit by the downturn this year has been Southern California, where housing demand seemed unaffected by the 1987 stock market drop, and prices soared in 1988 and 1989. Now, "for sale" signs have multiplied, and analysts in the region say sellers would be lucky to get 80 percent of what they could have a year ago.
 
California Couple Hurt
 One couple who suffered from the drop were Bruce Bigelow, a reporter at The San Diego Tribune, and Lynn O'Shaugnessy, a freelance journalist. "We were crestfallen," Mr. Bigelow said after they sold their two-bedroom bungalow in the Silverlake area of downtown Los Angeles for $225,000 this month.
Mr. Bigelow said the buyer, a Los Angeles lawyer, agreed to pay $248,000 in September, but the bank appraiser would approve financing only at a sale price of up to $220,000. So the buyer went to another bank, and its appraiser put the limit at $210,000.
Ultimately, Mr. Bigelow said, he and the buyer accepted the first appraisal, and the buyer agreed to pay $220,000 with bank financing, and another $5,000 in cash. The price was just enough to cover what Mr. Bigelow and Ms. O'Shaugnessy had paid in 1988, plus money they had spent for improvements.
"It was like being hit with hammer," Mr. Bigelow said, "watching the value of our house plummet."
 
New York Market Up Slightly
 Studies offer some evidence that the New York City area market, hit first and hardest by the current downturn, may have reached bottom in selling prices, or come close to it. An analysis by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey showed last week that average selling prices of suburban homes in the area fell sharply in 1988 and 1989, to $174,700 from $186,600.
This year, the study found prices coming back, albeit gradually. In the second quarter of 1990 it found an average price of $175,400, and during the third quarter, an average of $176,700.
Other measures of the housing market in the New York City area are less encouraging. Listings of unsold properties remain huge and many homes have been languishing on the market for more than a year.
Still, for those who can afford to, buying a home now may prove wise.
"We seem to have hit a floor of resistence," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority. "People are unwilling to lower prices any more, and somewhere there will be a trigger that will clear the market."
 
Interest Rates Falling
 One such trigger for slumping home sales around the nation could be further declines in interest rates. Fixed 30-year mortgage loans, which rose to more than 10.50 percent during the spring, have since fallen sharply and are now offered at 9.5 percent in most regions. Economists said they may go lower, perhaps to 9 percent.
But a futher reduction in rates might still not be enough to end the slump. Analysts maintain that the current housing recession is different from those in the past because interest rates, even at recent levels, have not been unusually high.
Part of the problem, they say, could be tied to the gloomy economic outlook. The Government said Friday that the output of the country's industries dropped 1.7 percent in November, the third monthly decline and the biggest in nearly eight years, hinting of a deeper recession than had been widely assumed.
"Things have been really shaky out there," said Dave Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, referring as well to the political outlook in the world. "Consumer psychology is the key now."
