HEADLINE: NASA Aura Dims as City Fights Rocket Test

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 11

 BODY:
Back in the 1960's, when the space program started testing rocket motors in a big tract of swamp near here, many people felt proud and patriotic about the loud noises and smoke plumes in their woods.
Those kinds of feelings for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are now rare. What once was a symbol of America's scientific superiority has lost prestige everywhere due to some spectacular failings, and along this stretch of the Gulf Coast the space agency is now commonly viewed with fear and distrust.
The dispute here is over a plan by the agency to test a new rocket motor for the space shuttle. Despite repeated assurances from NASA, many residents fear that the tests, each of which will release 350 tons of chemicals into the woods about 12 miles from Main Street, will pollute the environment and endanger the public.
 
'Nothing but Moonshine'
 Unlike the liquid-fuel motors that have been tested here in the past and that produce exhaust made up of water vapor, the new one uses solid fuel and produces an exhaust composed of hydrogen chloride gas, particles of aluminum compounds and other chemicals.
"When NASA first came in, there was nothing much but moonshine in Hancock County, and it was really great for us to feel like we had something to do with sending Americans to the moon," said Dr. Bert Chevis, a local physician.
"That was when the space program was like a young, top-of-the-line surgeon," he said. "Well, it's gotten to be like an old doctor that's forgetful and doing things upside down all the time."
In recent months apprehension over pollution from the rocket exhaust has suddenly produced long petitions and loud protests at public meetings.
Next week state officials are to start considering whether the John C. Stennis Space Center, named for the state's Senator from 1947 to 1989, should receive the environmental permits it needs to start construction at the testing site so that the first rockets can be fired on schedule in 1994.
 
Fight May Go to Court
 This application process is likely to become a major stumbling block for the shuttle program because angry citizens have vowed to take their fight to the courts, if necessary.
Support for the program comes primarily from the business community in the area, which has an unemployment level that is consistently above the national average, which was 5.9 percent in November. Fred Sullivan, president of Darkat Inc., a management consulting company that helps small businesses applying for NASA contracts, said, "We feel the environmental question has been answered, and as far as the economy is concerned, we dare not turn our backs on this opportunity."
But Lisa Cowand, a member of the Hancock County Board of Supervisors, said the promise of an economic contribution by the space complex had not helped the agency's position here. "The rocket might mean some new jobs in the short term," she said. "But, if they build it, no businesses are ever going to want to move down here again, and we'll end up the losers in the long term."
The space agency's plan calls for the new motors to be fired while anchored to the ground in a horizontal position. Seven such tests would be conducted in the first two years of the program and two a year after that.
The exhaust from the 1.2 million pounds of fuel in each firing would shoot from the device's nozzles at a temperature of 6,000 degrees Fahrenheit and at a speed of 5,500 miles an hour. The space agency says a ramp would deflect the exhaust upward and that air currents would carry it away before it could seriously harm any people or wildlife.
 
Concerns About Exhaust
 Opponents of the test argue that in certain kinds of weather the exhaust would remain close enough to the ground to endanger thousands of people close by and to pose risks as far away as New Orleans, 50 miles southwest of Bay St. Louis. They argue that hydrogen chloride gas in the exhaust will come down as acid rain, bringing with it particles of aluminum compounds that can increase the risk of neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease.
The space agency disputes those assertions.
Although pollution is the main point of the dispute, NASA's problems with its Hancock County neighbors reflect a broader distrust of the space agency that was brought about by the 1986 Challenger disaster and a number of subsequent mishaps, including the computer malfunctions and plumbing problems in the latest shuttle mission. Also this week a Federal advisory panel issued a report calling for drastic changes in the agency's approach to space exploration. A central recommendation of the panel is that NASA rely less on shuttles and more on unmanned rockets.
"We don't believe that NASA knows what they're doing," said Robert Esher, head of environmental research at a Mississippi State University research unit located at the Stennis Space Center.
Mr. Esher has played a leading role in arousing public opposition by providing an expert view that challenges NASA on the scientific aspects of the environmental dispute. But he has also been relentlessly attacking NASA's integrity.
"They've done all they could to keep the truth from coming out," he said at a public hearing last week on the NASA permits. The hearing drew 750 people from this town of 7,000.
 
'Falling Apart'
 The shuttle, he said, "is falling apart." And in his toughest assertion, he said, "I think when we look back in history at the Challenger disaster, we know what NASA is like. NASA knew three years before that those rings were leaking." The 1986 Challenger explosion, which killed seven astronauts, was linked to the failure of rings designed to prevent hot exhaust gases from escaping.
When Mr. Esher was finished, the crowd gave him a standing ovation.
The extent of the skepticism in the auditorium was evident when Thomas Sones, 16 years old, the president of the student government at the Hancock County High School, added his voice to the opposition. The school, about two miles from the proposed test complex, would be among the first structures affected if the fumes did not behave as NASA predicts.
"Personally I think there's a lot of hiding," he said.
As the hearing ended, Roy Estess, director of the space center, wearily defended his agency. "We have an expert test team we believe is the best in the free world," he said. "We're proud of what we do. We don't back away from it at all. It's based on the best engineering judgment our country has to offer."
The Advanced Solid Rocket Motor, or ASRM, as the device to be tested is known, is the third version of a motor that has been launching the shuttle since it first flew in 1981, and it resembles the others in many ways.
 
Tests in Utah
 NASA has plans to use the new solid-fuel rocket motor on the shuttle for 30 years. Although the advisory panel report this week suggested that the shuttle program be curtailed in favor of unmanned rockets, the new shuttle motor would likely play a role in whatever launching system might replace the shuttle because developing all-new technology could severely delay the space program.
The two previous versions of the shuttle engine were manufactured and tested in a part of Utah that is mostly desert and is relatively remote. And much of the debate here centers on whether the Mississippi coast is an inherently more dangerous place to conduct such tests.
In addition, some local residents assert that NASA revealed one of its basic flaws by even considering this place for the tests.
When Congress considered plans for the new motor in 1987, Representative Jamie L. Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi, suggested that it be built -- but not necessarily tested -- at an abandoned nuclear power plant in his district about 300 miles northeast of here. NASA saw the wisdom of this recommendation from Mr. Whitten, who is chairman of the House Appropriations Committee and has great influence on the agency's budget.
After the decision was made to build the motors in northeastern Mississippi, NASA considered several testing sites, and eventually chose to test the motors here because of concerns about the cost and difficulty of transporting the huge motors large distances, said Rebecca McCaleb, environmental projects officer at the Stennis Space Center.

HEADLINE: STATES TRY PACTS TO AID ECONOMIES

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
W. Allan Anderson's tiny trade office on Toronto's Richmond Street is still too new to have a permanent nameplate on the door. That will come in about two weeks. But some economists and state political leaders say the lonely little outpost is already a sign of the future.
Mr. Anderson's mission is as straightforward as it is unusual. As the first director of the Canada trade liaison office for the Council of Great Lakes Governors, his job is to promote trade between Canada and the eight-state Great Lakes region. 
 The jostling, often cutthroat trade competition that has marked relations among the states for most of their history has not been eliminated. But state officials say that Mr. Anderson's assignment to increase trade between Canada and the Great Lakes states nonetheless represents new ground.
 
Still a Rarity
 Economists and state development officials say such efforts are still rare, especially in politically delicate areas like jobs and trade. But the officials say the states are under more pressure to cooperate in ways that were unthinkable only a few years ago.
Many states face budget constraints and cannot support initiatives to promote themselves or their products, even though development officials see the importance of foreign trade and the threat of growing competition from abroad. Changes in the world economy, especially in western Europe, also favor such collaborations, some economists say, and a result could be that go-it-alone states might become less competitive over time.
Still, most of the steps toward greater cooperation have been tentative. When development officials from Mississippi, Arkansas and Louisiana combined in 1988 to jointly seek Japanese investment in the lower Mississippi River valley, they jointly paid for the trip to Japan, made a joint presentation for the region, but then retired to privately bend their hosts' ears about each state's individual virtues.
The Mid-South Trade Council, a six-state consortium founded in 1983 by Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Tennessee, Louisiana and Kentucky, has been unable to even establish a permanent office or hire any staff because of fears in the state capitols that sharing information will mean the loss of some individual competitive edge.
"The states have different political mandates, and a lot of them change every four years," said Leigh A. Wieland, director of the export office for the Tennessee Department of Economic and Community Development.
 
Economic Health a Factor
 The economic downturn in many states is also acting to dampen broad initiatives. An economic panel created by the New England Governors' Conference recently urged that the states offer a regional tax credit to encourage new investment, as well as a research and development tax credit to encourage innovation. But with almost every state in the conference facing the prospect of falling revenue, even the most enthusiastic proponents saw little likelihood of any action that would further reduce revenue.
Even Mr. Anderson's efforts in Toronto, while hailed as a major symbolic landmark, do not reflect as much cooperation as it would appear. Each of his Great Lakes clients -- Michigan, Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania and New York -- gets an equal crack at competing for any new business referred through the Toronto office.
"I think there is a trend, but it's still at the very early stages," said Carol Conway, deputy director of the Southern Growth Policies Board, a private research group that tracks state economic policies. "It's going to take some time to change the view that you can't cooperate without losing out."
But among the truly converted, including many economists and some elected officials, the future direction is clear: Those states that do not grasp cooperation now will be left behind by the century's close.
 
Economics Is 'Driving Force'
 "Political boundary lines are becoming substantially less important," said State Senator Alan Bluechel of Washington, who is one of the main proponents in an effort to form a confederation of Pacific Northwest states and Canadian provinces. "The driving force in the world today is economics."
Mr. Bluechel, co-founder of a group called the Pacific Northwest Legislative Leadership Forum, said he believes that in the evolving world economy, as it is being redefined by changes in Europe, at least 12 million people are needed to build industries big enough to compete with other export-driven economies. With linked economies, the states of Washington, Oregon, Montana, Alaska and the provinces of Alberta and British Columbia, pass that threshold, with 15 million people, Mr. Bluechel said. Operating as a single economy, the region would have the 10th-highest gross national product in the world.
Organized a year ago, the group's members are at the point of hammering out the wording of the articles of incorporation for the confederation. The group will create a permanent economic steering committee that will be jointly financed by the members.
At the Great Lakes Toronto office, by contrast, the goals are a bit more modest and immediate. Mr. Anderson said the first business link made through his office was made this month between a small Milwaukee-based maker of pollution-control equipment and a Canadian agent who agreed to represent the company across the border. So far there have been no sales.

HEADLINE: Recession's Pinch Fuels Fears About the Future

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
A Wisconsin businessman whose client list has shriveled asks his children for understanding this Christmas. A Boston cab driver, getting fewer riders and smaller tips, works an extra four hours a day to make ends meet. A Seattle art dealer whose customers have grown wary cancels her plans for a vacation abroad.
In varying degrees, Americans are feeling the pinch of the emerging recession. For some, it has meant leaner times; for others, anxiety about the future. In some instances, clearly the minority, it has even helped business. 
 "The rent's overdue, gas is overdue, electric's overdue," said Cheryl Shamus, 30 years old, who was shopping for a maternity dress at the Goodwill Industries store in St. Charles, Mo. Her husband, a factory worker, can no longer depend on regular paychecks because of the slowdown. "There's not going to be a Christmas, let's put it that way," she said.
Although the majority of Americans have not lost jobs or income in the downturn, many have grown anxious about what the next year may bring. They are spending less, trying to save more and making contingency plans.
To many people interviewed at random around the country last week, there was a parallel between the economy and the situation in the Persian Gulf: a worried sense that disaster might be looming, but no direct effect, not yet anyway.
Indeed, roughly the same number of people have been sent or mobilized for Persian Gulf duty, 400,000, as have lost jobs since August.
 
No Major Purchases
 "My job is secure, my company is solid, but there's still a bit of anxiety," said Richard Whittow, a banking executive in Milwaukee. "I wouldn't want to make any major purchases right now. If we spend money we've got, fine. But I wouldn't want to lock into anything."
That caution appears to be widely shared, as many retailers complain that stores are uncrowded, just a week before Christmas. A New York Times/ CBS News poll, conducted Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, found that more than 4 of 10 respondents are spending less on Christmas than in past years. A similar poll conducted in November 1987, a month after the stock market crash, found that 3 of 10 people planned to spend less on Christmas than in previous years.
Around the country, it is hard to find anyone who believes that times will get better before they get worse. The national economic picture is somewhat uneven. The regions that boomed in the 1980's, like the Northeast and Southern California, appear to have been hit the hardest.
David Jameison, 48, a hotel concierge in Boston, said the Christmas gifts would be smaller this year. "The economy is forcing us to cut back on the gifts," he said. "With m wife, when times were good, I used to give her jewelry and furs. This year, it is going to be a lot less."
He said his brother-in-law, who owned a small construction business, filed for bankruptcy six months ago. "It's difficult for him to even hold on to his house, not to mention Christmas gifts," he said.
 
Busy Calendar, Now Nothing
 For most of the year, business was great for Antonio Jebian, the owner of a construction company in Coral Gables, Fla. His calendar was filled with major home-remodeling projects. Then came autumn.
"Everything was going fine," he said. "I was very busy, and I didn't even advertise, just an ad in the Yellow Pages. But things started slowing down in the beginning of November. Now, people are calling, but only for estimates."
For those who were already struggling, the downturn has sometimes pushed them beyond the brink. At some charities, the number of recipients has soared. A food pantry in Watertown, Mass., for example, has seen its client list double in a year.
"If it keeps up at this pace," said Barbara Neel, coordinator at the Watertown Food Pantry, "I don't know if we'll have enough food."
Even businesses serving the affluent are hurting. Lori Kinnear, who runs a private children's dance studio in Seattle, said five students dropped out in the last month.
"Dance lessons are the first thing people cut back on," Ms. Kinnear said.
Nina Ventura, an art dealer in Seattle, said she would be putting off plans to travel abroad. "Instead of going to Hong Kong this year, I'm going to San Francisco."
With cutbacks in corporate expense accounts, employees are spending less and fewer people are doing business over lunch. In Washington, the stretch limousines that come and go from embassy parties and Capitol Hill are still part of the daily scenery, but fewer companies are paying for their managers to ride in such luxury.
"The corporations have trimmed their expense accounts and don't rent as many luxury cars," said Chip Prescott, president of Dominion Limousine Service in McLean, Va. He added that people are not tipping as much these days.
"The $200 tip has been replaced by the $20 bill," he said.
In a few fields, like bankruptcy law, the hard times have helped business. The same is true for temporary employment.
"A company may be laying people off, but they still need to get the payroll out," said Pat Southerland, president of Robert Haft, a Washington company that specializes in placing accountants. And with so many qualified people looking for work, he said, it has been easier than ever to find workers.
Charles D. Miles, a fire safety director at the Grand Hyatt hotel in New York, said he would cut back on vacations to pay off his credit card bills.
 
'Don't Live Extravagantly'
 "I don't live extravagantly," he said, "but I'm cutting out some of the fun things, like vacations."
In general, however, travel bookings have not dropped, agencies say. In fact, reservations on cruise lines have increased.
In Florida, the tourist industry remains strong, bolstered by a flood of foreign visitors who have taken advantage of the weak dollar. Figures from the Florida Division of Tourism show that for the first nine months of the year, 32 million people visited the state, a 6.5 percent increase over the same period last year.
Vacancies in hotels have increased, but industry analysts say that reflects new construction rather than recessionary forces.
As companies cut back, the businesses that cater to them are also feeling the pinch. Randy Clevers, 36, who runs a small business cleaning offices in Sheboygan, Wis., said he and his wife are planning a more modest Christmas. "We've talked to the children about it," he said. "We're going to try to make things, rather than buy them."
He went on: "You start wondering where the next dollar will come from. At my wife's factory, they've been laying people off, and she's worried she'll be next."
Even for workers whose jobs seem secure, there is a fear that a recession will stifle chances for promotion.
Jeff Sloan, who manages a convenience store in St. Louis, worries that a slowdown will keep him from advancing in the store chain.
"What does concern me is the more skilled people getting into the job market and affecting my advancement," he said, adding that the store chain has been receiving applications from people 10 years his senior with midlevel management experience in corporate offices.
 
'Don't Even Ask'
 Few segments of the economy seen untouched by the slowdown.
Tony K. Grubbs, who manages a Red Wing Shoes store near St. Louis, said his customers are thinking twice about buying expensive work boots.
"In the past, people were willing to pay extra for top quality," he said, noting that work boots range in price from $80 to $200. "Now people are coming in saying, 'I don't have the money, so I'm going to a discount store.' I'm hearing that more and more."
Perry Karakostas, a Boston cab driver, has had to extend his work day from 10 hours to 14 hours, just to keep up.
"Last year, I made $38,000," he said. "This year, don't even ask. I don't think I am going to make $18,000.
He had been driving his blue cab through the streets of Boston, looking for customers, but finding few.
"It's 11:30, I've been out since 6 this morning, and I've made $38," he said.
"I have a year and a half left to pay for this thing," he said, referring to his car. "I just hope I don't lose it."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Contented With the Time

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
All year long the city seems decorated for Christmas, the white lights draped profligately around its towers, the brake lights of the cars in rush-hour traffic looking like cranberries strung for the tree, snaking their way in loose patterns up and down the exit ramps of the highways.
Elsewhere the holidays transform drab Main Streets into Bavarian villages, but in New York the effect is a little like a woman already wearing a bracelet and earrings who decides to add a brooch. The lighted tree towering above the skaters at Rockefeller Center. The windows of the department stores, where people stand instead of dashing by. And at the florists, the obligatory scarlet amaryllis, forced from a bulb just in time for an end table in December, the poinsettia of the smart set. 
 Twelve months a year New York is a city of contrasts, but never more than now. Little girls in their best velvets and Mary Janes walk to the ballet past men sleeping beneath their coats. At a store near City Hall, a teen-aged girl counts her cash carefully, shopping for a leather jacket for her boyfriend. She knows exactly what she wants: a match for the jacket he was wearing the night he was mugged. "They took it right off of him," she says, looking through the rack. "He loved that jacket."
It has been that kind of year. Someone said not long ago, "The 90's will be the 80's without money." It's a wonderful wisecrack, but it's not true. The 90's are the 80's with chronic fatigue syndrome. There's this essential malaise that everyone is trying to identify, analyze, above all dispel, a flu of the spirit. The great contrasts in New York this year are not only between rich and poor but between what the city is and what it has been.
It tells my age that I remember waiting for after-Christmas sales; now the sales are during, before, anything to get the registers ringing. Corporations are scaling back Christmas parties, or dropping them altogether. Christmas parties! That staple of movie comedies, that legendary location of so many ill-advised marriages of alcohol and lust.
What's the point? None of this. We lost the point the day we decided that you should be able to call an 800 number and order cranberries already strung for the tree. Because the point was the stringing, wasn't it? We lost the point when we decided you should be able to order a tree from a catalogue, to be delivered already decorated. Because decorating the thing is surely the point.
The point is that this is a holiday that has somehow managed to endure through times much worse than these, and that is because it has always stood for not what we are, or what we were, but what we wish we could be. That's what we're chasing when we run ourselves ragged with parties and presents. It is a time for happy families even among families that are not particularly happy. It is a time for friendship even with friends with whom we often feud.
Every story that survives from generation to generation about this time is about a small thing transformed: a nutcracker, a boy with a crutch, a bright-eyed old angel trying to earn his wings. A manger. "They were not a handsome family," Dickens wrote of the Cratchits in "A Christmas Carol." "They were not well dressed; their shoes were far from being water-proof; their clothes were scanty; and Peter might have known, and very likely did, the inside of a pawnbroker's. But they were happy, grateful, pleased with one another, and contented with the time."
We are not contented with the time. The stores are not crowded. Of course, we can contrast that with the holidays in the Soviet Union, where people are hotfooting it home with cabbages to hoard. We can contrast it, too, with a time just past when we bought not what we wanted or needed but anything we could lay our hands on. Now, like Peter, we've seen the pawnbroker. Santa Claus is coming to town with his bag half full. What'll we tell the kids?
Let them string cranberries.
People say we're going to have to learn to do more with less in the near future, and I believe it. But this is the time of year when less was more all along. We just forgot it. The eternal verities, friendship and family and faith, are cheap and filling. And you won't find them on your Amex bill next month like a bad hangover.
New York will still be covered with tinsel every night of its life. But it's nice to know that if the lights went out, it could still be Christmas, inside our houses and apartments and ourselves, where Christmas has always belonged.

HEADLINE: Topics of the Times;
The End Is Near

 BODY:
The formal Federal statistics don't yet spell recession but informal language does. Whatever the G.N.P. figures show, public discourse is already heavy with apocalyptic terms. Observe, for instance, the frequency of draconian.
Connoisseurs of journalistic cliches know the term derives from the Athenian legal code that a fellow named Draco formulated about 621 B.C. It was pretty draconian all right, prescribing the death penalty for almost every offense. Times haven't yet gotten that tough, even in New York real estate, but everywhere, Draco's name is used in pain.
 Writers seem almost daily to refer to "draconian Gramm-Rudman spending cuts," the "draconian" speed with which new regulations have been pressed on financial institutions and "draconian" cuts in New York state spending.
The word from Europe, meanwhile, is even more alarming. Just before the world trade talks collapsed last week in Brussels, John C. Crosbie, Canada's Trade Minister, said grimly, "It's back to ground zero." He was right to be alarmed but things are not that bad. What Mr. Crosbie probably meant was square one, back to the beginning. Ground zero means the surface area directly below or above the point of detonation of a nuclear bomb. Far from denoting a beginning, it suggests something much closer to the end.

HEADLINE: The World: Dial 911;
Gorbachev Turns To the Forces Of Law and Order

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
WHEN it suited him, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been the glasnost President, the democracy President, the peacemaker President, the economic reform President. He has also been at times the law and order President, and never more than right now.
The Soviet leader's drift to the right in recent weeks has been steady enough to revive fears among the more pessimistic of his subjects that Mr. Gorbachev is inching toward dictatorship. 
 Speculation that he might join forces with the popular insurgents has gone with the last autumn leaves. Mr. Gorbachev finds them too inflexible, too impatient and too divided to serve his immediate purpose of stability. Lacking popular authority of his own, Mr. Gorbachev has turned back to the institutions that are conditioned to respect the chain of command -- the military, the police and the Communist Party.
So the clamorous cast of reform economists who were Mr. Gorbachev's most conspicuous company in the fall have now given way to the Defense Minister and the chairman of the K.G.B., sent by the President to prime time television to warn vaguely of tough measures against black marketers, draft dodgers, nationalists and others who threaten public order.
The immediate agenda has changed, too. Mr. Gorbachev's priorities of the moment are arresting the breakup of the union and restoring discipline. When questions of liberty arise these days, Mr. Gorbachev is more often to be found appealing to the conservative instincts of his countrymen than prodding them to open their minds. He opposed the right of Russian peasants to buy and sell farmland, for example, and created a state committee to fight the country's mild epidemic of erotica.
Is this all a prelude to a Gorbachev autocracy, or another tactical move in the long course of reform?
The Western governments that have been pumping food and medicine to Moscow -- including the Bush Administration, which last week waived a 16-year ban and offered up to $1 billion in grain credits -- are betting that Mr. Gorbachev does not intend a serious crackdown on political liberties. Western donors fear a greater danger is that lengthening food lines could turn into food riots, and the hard-liners may exploit the instability to roll back reforms or take power.
The Western assistance is intended to replenish the depleted central food funds under Mr. Gorbachev's control, which he can parcel out to meet local needs and quell political unrest.
The relief is also a demonstration to those who might be tempted to challenge Mr. Gorbachev that Western good will hinges in large part on respect for this one man.
This would not be the first time Mr. Gorbachev had paused to consolidate his position before mounting a new assault on the establishment. A year ago, for example, Mr. Gorbachev was threatening to rein in the Soviet press, and declaring the country unready for a multiparty system or private property. Since then he has sponsored laws abolishing censorship, erasing the Communist Party's monopoly from the Constitution, and legalizing limited private ownership.
One incentive for a bit of conservative repositioning is that on Monday the Congress of Peoples Deputies, the elephantine super-parliament that is supposed to be the supreme legal authority of the country, gathers in the Kremlin Palace of Congresses for its fourth session.
The first three Congresses have been noisy but ultimately obedient to Mr. Gorbachev, who designed the quasi-democratic body to minimize unwelcome surprises. (A third of the 2,250 members hold unelected seats allotted to the Communist Party and other bastions of the old establishment, and many more contrived to win their seats without competition.)
The Congress chose Mr. Gorbachev as President, and has enlarged his powers whenever he asked. A main issue this week is Mr. Gorbachev's latest proposal to restructure the Government in a way that makes his pre-eminence even clearer. It is likely to be approved, clearing the way for a major shake-up in the Government, including the likely replacement of Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov.
But this time Mr. Gorbachev will be playing to a crowd that has grown more conservative, and less predictable. The radical opposition is in disarray -- two of the most radical delegations, from Lithuania and Armenia, plan to boycott the Congress altogether -- and the hard-liners are feeding on popular discontent.
The most aggressive bloc of deputies is now the hard-line Soyuz group, which blames Mr. Gorbachev for letting central discipline grow slack. One Soyuz leader has threatened to raise the question of impeaching Mr. Gorbachev at the Congress if he has not taken the country firmly in hand.
At the Congress -- and afterward -- the Soviet leader's most urgent objective will be to build a backfire against the raging separatism that threatens to dissolve the U.S.S.R. into a collection of warring principalities.
He will ask the Congress to approve in concept a new union treaty that would bind the republics in a looser confederation. So far he has been unable to get a consensus among republican leaders, who insist on stripping the center of more economic and political power than Mr. Gorbachev is yet willing to surrender. This issue, more than anything else, has driven Mr. Gorbachev lately into the arms of the conservatives.
While the high profile of the K.G.B. and the military are the most spine-tingling evidence, there is much more. A K.G.B. veteran has been installed as Minister of Internal Affairs, with the former commander of Soviet forces in Afghanistan as his deputy. Mr. Gorbachev has decreed the creation of worker vigilante committees to reassert central control over food distribution that has been lost in the more liberal climate.
He has been more attentive lately to the Communist Party, which he heads but which he had been keeping at a Presidential distance. Last month he rallied Communists in the parliament of the Russian republic in an attempt to undercut Boris N. Yeltsin's assertion of greater sovereignty. Last week he called in the party's governing Central Committee to consult them on the union treaty. The party's membership is fast eroding, its prestige is nil, and in some cities party leaders seem preoccupied with laundering the party's wealth into new commercial ventures. But the party network still has clout in the provinces, in the military and in some key industrial sectors.
The Soviet leader has also begun an aggressive courtship of the Central Asian republics, where democracy has not yet made much of an impression. Uzbekistan's cotton farmers have been promised a doubling of state prices on their crop. Kazakstan's popular President, Nursultan Nazarbayev, has been floated as a candidate to be Mr. Gorbachev's new Vice President or Prime Minister. The Asian republics showed last week what a useful ally they can be when they teamed up to threaten maverick Moldavia with a trade cutoff if it continues to resist signing the new union treaty.
So far Mr. Gorbachev's flirtation with the hard-liners has consisted of some hardball politics and some ominous warnings. But assuming that he only wants to stabilize things before moving forward again with reform, there is still the question of whether he will get what he wants.
"These are the institutions that control the instruments of violence," observed a veteran Kremlinologist in one Western embassy, surveying Mr. Gorbachev's recent choice of friends. "Gorbachev may not be preparing to use violence, but there is the danger that he could lose the initiative, and it passes into the hands of those more ready to use violence -- either to hold the union together, or to tear it apart."

LENGTH: 1326 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: U.S. Wages;
Not Getting Ahead? Better Get Used to It

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
FOR a brief moment in the mid-1980's, it looked as if Americans would again know how it feels to get ahead. Wages and family incomes seemed to be rising by just enough to promise more prosperous lives. Some economists even warned that inflated wage costs would price American products out of the world market. But whatever the promise of higher incomes in the mid-80's, it is gone now.
Instead of continuing to rise, real incomes -- that is, wages and salaries adjusted for inflation -- have declined over the last three years, with the decline becoming particularly noticeable this fall, as the national economy slowed. The upshot is that most Americans are entering the 1990's worse off than they were in the early 1970's. Only those Americans whose incomes are in the top 20 percent have escaped this stagnation; their incomes have grown significantly. 
 The last time that most Americans could track tangible improvements in their incomes was in the late 1960's and early 1970's. The decade between the 1973 Arab oil embargo and the 1982 recession was one in which incomes did not rise nearly as rapidly as inflation. Then, after 1982, with inflation very low, there seemed to be some gaining ground again. But hopes of more to come were dashed in the last 18 months, so that today the pay of many individuals and the pooled weekly wages of millions of families buy less than in 1973.
"We're talking pennies when we talk of the improvements in the mid-1980's," said Lawrence Mishel, chief economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group. "Wages did not rise very much; inflation fell, giving an illusion of real wage gains."
The early 1990's are likely to be years of no progress, many economists believe. The Persian Gulf crisis is clearly a setback, with its high oil prices driving the inflation rate well above the norm for recent years. But even when the crisis ends and oil prices drop, wage increases are likely to lag behind inflation. The nation is apparently entering a recession, unemployment is rising and, as a result, the wages of most Americans are not rising by enough to overtake even mild inflation.
All told, the United States is approaching 20 years of lost income growth, notes Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist. "That does not make for a very happy society," he said.
The fallout from Mr. Freeman's lost income growth shows up as angry anti-tax protests, and as a drag on the national economy. The tax revolts in many communities lately have been aimed at local governments that tried to raise property taxes. In effect, they asked for ever bigger portions of a homeowner's stagnant income.
"In the 1960's, government also took more in taxes, but then real wages were going up 1 or 2 percent a year, and taxes were taking only one-third of this extra income and it wasn't so noticeable because people still improved their living standards," said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
Similarly, sales of consumer goods are difficult to sustain when the price of a car or a suit rises from one year to the next by a greater amount than the buyer's income. Partly for this reason, Christmas retail sales are taking a beating, helping to push the economy into recession.
Finally, national savings suffer when Americans spend more and more of their incomes to maintain their living standards. Savings, in turn, supply the money that is borrowed to finance new factories, machinery, highways, airports, schools and the other investments that generate a nation's wealth. As a percent of Americans' income, personal savings are only half what they were in the early 1970's. A blip upward in the late 1980's, coinciding with a brief rise in real incomes, is disappearing.
"It is very hard to save in a world in which your income is falling," said Barry Bosworth, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
The fall and rise and fall again of wages and incomes show up clearly in several Government statistics. The real median hourly pay for 93 million workers, for instance, see-sawed from $8.52 in 1973 to $7.66 in 1982, then up to $7.83 in 1988 and down to $7.46 today. The median weekly pay of full-time workers followed a similar pattern.
Families did better, given the increase in the number of households with two or more incomes in the 1980's. But here, too, the down-up-down pattern was the same. Median weekly family earnings from wages and salaries, adjusted for inflation, went from $516 in 1979 down to $471 in 1981, up to $537 in 1988 and then fell precipitously, to $501 today, according to the Labor Department.
Only the 20 percent of American families at the top of the income scale have prospered in recent years. They did so in part because stock dividends and interest from bonds often supplemented salaries. And some jobs -- in medicine, engineering, corporate management, law and on Wall Street, for example -- paid extremely well.
 
Lucky Them
 The real median income of these lucky families rose year after year to $92,663 from $73,764 in 1981. Such gains in the 1980's were two or three times greater than those of less wealthy families, and alone among Americans the top 20 percent finished the decade with real incomes well above their earnings in 1973.
Economists offer many explanations for the income stagnation that has plagued the nation. The decline in union power is high on the list. As factories have been modernized and jobs lost, millions of assembly line workers have taken lower-paying jobs in the service sector. Many companies, in addition, have chosen to shift production overseas rather than raise wages at home. And the pressure on employers to raise wages is disappearing as a recession develops and unemployment rises. For many workers, keeping a job has priority over getting a raise.
Perhaps more important, the once widely accepted concept of raising wages to offset inflation is fading. Instead, workers' wages are tied increasingly to their employers' fortunes. Instead of cost-of-living raises, thousands of companies now give their workers a share of profits or bonuses tied to profits. Under this system, when profits shrink in hard times, like now, income can stagnate or decline, regardless of inflation.
 
Productivity Problems
 Beyond these trends in labor-management relations, a more ingrained problem holds down pay, many economists argue. Neither wages nor profits can rise very much if productivity fails to go up; that is, if workers fail to produce more goods or turn out more work in a given day or week, thus failing to generate the extra revenue to pay for wage increases and also to fatten profits.
Overall productivity is indeed rising much more slowly than in the 1960's, helping to explain wage stagnation. But the huge manufacturing sector is a glaring exception. Largely through automation and new production practices, productivity in manufacturing rose by 4 percent or more a year through most of the 1980's. At the same time, median wages declined in real terms for millions of factory workers, falling to $8 an hour from $8.65 in 1985.
What happened to the extra money that, in theory, should have resulted from the much higher productivity? Very little wound up in the profit column, suggesting to Mr. Bosworth at Brookings that the productivity gains never fully materialized. The ever more efficient production of small computers, he says, accounts for most of the productivity improvement in manufacturing. But when companies try to use the computers to increase the efficiency of car manufacturing or operating an office, they make little headway.
Whatever the merits of this argument, wages and incomes are not growing. The liveliest economic expansion since the 1920's failed to step up Americans' income. As Mr. Bosworth puts it, "We are wiping out the income gains of the mid-80's at virtually all levels of society, except the very top."

HEADLINE: The World;
Adding Up the World Trade Talks: Fail Now, Pay Later

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
AFTER four years of debate over how many dairy cows can dance on the head of a subsidy, the 107-nation negotiation aimed at lowering trade barriers has broken down.
But the resulting crisis is an abstraction: Ships bearing all those cars and computers and soybeans will still be able to unload in Seattle, Rotterdam and Yokahama for the foreseeable future. The most visible result appeared to be relief on the part of world leaders, who will no longer be pressed to exact concessions from potent domestic interests in the name of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, also known as the General Agreement to Talk and Talk. 
 The lack of an immediate bang, however, does not mean that the whimper will not eventually be felt around the globe. The talks -- which may resume eventually -- broke down over agriculture, but that was only part of what was at stake in Brussels. Gary Hufbauer, an economist at Georgetown University, reckons that at very least the failure represents a lost opportunity to expand world trade by about $300 billion annually. Of that total, roughly 20 percent represents pure productivity gain -- an increase in output requiring no extra input of labor or capital or natural resources.
And to Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University, that is only the tip of the iceberg. The failure at Brussels, he argues, is an invitation to tiptoe away from the liberal trading system that made the West rich and offers the best hope for smashing poverty in the world's have-not nations.
The current round of negotiations was born of fear and opportunism in 1985. Reagan Administration free traders, increasingly on the defensive against a protectionist-minded Congress, sought to build a coalition of business interests with a big stake in expanding world markets.
Europe was asked to abandon farm subsidies to its 10 million toytown farmers -- subsidies that have transformed the largely infertile, highly urbanized continent into a price-busting food exporter and cost American agriculture billions in exports. Third world countries were asked to respect foreign patents, trademarks and copyrights. And everyone was asked to open the door to trade in services, the fastest growing export sector for affluent countries. Japan, a surprisingly small player in the GATT talks in light of its strong trade position, was insistent that its ban on rice imports remain, but appeared open to other concessions.
 
Give and Take
 For its part, Washington offered to slaughter a few of its own sacred cows. Sugar growers and dairy farmers would be forced to compete with their far more productive counterparts in other countries. Textile and apparel makers would gradually lose the protection of the Multi-Fiber Agreement, a "temporary" restraint on imports from poor countries first imposed in 1974.
With a few exceptions, notes Jeffrey Schott, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, third world countries bought into the deal. And the Bush Administration seemed ready to fight the good fight with Congress, provided it was armed with enough concessions for grain farmers, bankers, insurers, telecommunications companies, software designers and drug firms.
But most nations in the European Community -- France and Italy in particular -- were never enthusiastic about tackling their potent farm lobbies. Unable to reach agreement on farm policies, the talks collapsed, stranding the more forward-looking questions of trade in services and protection of trademarks.
 
At What Cost?
 Figuring out the direct costs of the Brussels fiasco is a messy business, in part because no one expected a successful conclusion to the negotiations to remove every remaining barrier to trade overnight. But a few numbers are suggestive.
William Cline, another economist at the Institute for International Economics, estimates that Americans pay an extra $20 billion a year for clothes because of the quotas on imports from the third world. Protection of America's handful of sugar beet and cane growers, by contrast, costs consumers a mere $1 billion. But the resulting collapse of the sugar industry in some of the poorest countries in the world is nothing short of a disaster. "Losses in sugar," Mr. Hufbauer said, "have totally canceled the benefits of the Caribbean Basin Initiative."
Potential gains from tight enforcement of "intellectual property rights," everything from spreadsheet software royalties to kung fu movie licensing fees, are still harder to pin down. But the Pfizer Corporation, for one, is not shy about publicizing its own accounting. The big pharmaceutical house estimates that it is losing $250 million a year in sales of a single drug, the anti-arthritic agent Feldene. In Brazil, for example, copycat drugs share half the market with Feldene.
These direct losses may pale by comparison with the dynamic losses associated with restraints on global competition. Relatively open access to world markets, dictated by the victorious Americans in the 1940's, was critical to the postwar growth in the industrialized democracies. Those who doubt its current relevance, says Mr. Bhagwati, need only compare the record of export-oriented Asian countries with inward-looking, tightly protectionist India.
Thailand and South Korea, to take two examples, were no better off in the early 1960's than India. Nor is it obvious that they were riper for development -- both were (and are) burdened by enormous military expenditures. But by the late 1980's, Thailand's per capita income was triple that of India's; South Korea was so much richer that the comparison is no longer meaningful.
Failure to eliminate trade barriers in apparel and agriculture, industries where cheap labor is a huge advantage, is bad news for poor countries on the edge of an export-led breakout -- Indonesia, Pakistan, Argentina and Poland come to mind. But to Mr. Bhagwati, the failure to put a stake through the heart of "managed trade" in developed countries is every bit as ominous.
If heavy manufacturing was the engine of growth in the 1950's and 1960's, services and high technology will have to play the role for the next few decades. But without a comprehensive trade deal, it will be very hard to counter the inclination to put protectionist fences around productivity-enhancing competition.
For example, attempts to protect America's machine tool industry from Japanese competitors were barely beaten back in the early 1980's. Those lower-cost computerized imports ended up helping to spruce up Rust Belt industries. And only in the last year have electronics manufacturers given up the fight to subsidize development of a uniquely American system for high-definition television -- protection that the author George Gilder believes would have locked the industry into instantly obsolete technology.
 
Protectionism Grows
 Stopping similar protectionist initiatives has grown more difficult since 1988, notes Ronald Cass, dean of the Boston University Law School and the former vice-chairman of the United States International Trade Commission. Before the 1988 trade law, the White House had great discretion in deciding what amounted to unfair trade practices and designing a remedy. Now the President is required to retaliate, giving foreign producers strong incentives to strike their own market-sharing deals with the American rivals.
Those inclined to minimize the brouhaha in Brussels point to the success of regional free trade agreements -- everything from the European Community to the Canada-United States free trade pact. Indeed, Bush Administration spinmasters are already putting new emphasis on the idea of a free trade zone for all the Americas as an alternative to global liberalization.
As the world's largest exporter and the world's largest importer, the United States would make a very solid anchor for a trade zone. But for all the immediate attractions of taking our football and going home, the risks of allowing the globe to break into trading blocks are enormous. Prosperity is built on productivity growth. And the competitive pressure for change where it really counts is coming from Europe and Asia -- not Mexico, Canada or Brazil. Consumers could pay the price for a retreat to the cocoon.
 
WINNERS AND LOSERS IN THE STALLED TALKS
 The collapse of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks is of benefit mostly to politically powerful trade sectors that have required Government support to remain competitive. Analysts believe the losses from the collapse will outweigh the gains, and will result in higher prices and lower productivity in both the developed and developing worlds. As things now stand, these would be among the consequences:
 
Some of the winners:
 
French, German and Italian farmers, who could not compete in open markets for meat, grains, sugar and dairy products, will continue to receive government subsidies.
 
Japanese rice farmers, the most heavily protected farmers in the world, will benefit from subsidies and a ban on rice imports.
 
American dairy farmers and sugar growers will continue to receive subsidies.
 
American apparel manufacturers, who cannot automate sufficiently to offset the lower labor costs of Asian and Latin American countries, will benefit from continued quotas on imported clothing.
 
European telephone and airline monopolies, which are far less efficient than potential American competitors.
 
Some of the losers:
 
European and American drug and computer-software companies, whose patents are not protected in the third world.
 
American music and movie companies, which lose royalties to copyright pirates in Asia and Latin America and are threatened by restrictions on European television.
 
Canadian, Australian, Argentine, American and New Zealand grain, oilseed and meat growers, whose export markets are depressed by subsidized European exports.
 
Sugar cane farmers in Central America, the Caribbean and the Philippines, victims of American protectionism and European dumping.
 
American banks, securities brokers and insurance companies, which now face myriad restrictions in most markets.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 6; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Moscow Faces Apocalyptic Times in the Spring;
Economic Gridlock

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The exchange of views (Op-Ed, Oct. 19, and letter, Nov. 28) between George Soros, a Wall Street financier, and Boris Milner, a Soviet economist, points up the struggle between the old guard and a new guard for control of Soviet economic opportunity. Also important is the viability of economic plans, whoever carries them out.
To build marketing institutions is important, but creates a hollow shell without the purchasing power and production from full employment. Both writers seem to miss the fundamental problem of putting the unemployed and the underused to work in the advanced industrial and agricultural machine needed to maintain a market economy.
There is no magic incantation that will put people to work, just because marketing links are built and capital is made available for tooling up factories and farms. The instinct of entrepreneurs is not to hire workers until sales show them they should do so. They don't get the sales until the workers are well employed throughout the economy. Such gridlock must be broken.
Employment must be required by government fiat. The Soviet Union can do this by tying capital grants for machines to mandatory hiring of the numbers of workers needed to bring volumes of goods produced and consumer purchasing into proper balance.
 
PURNELL H. BENSON
Madison, N.J., Dec. 1, 1990
 
The writer is a professor emeritus of management at the Rutgers Graduate School.

HEADLINE: Moscow Faces Apocalyptic Times in the Spring;
Their Own Fates

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New 'S' and old 'U' in U.S.S.R" (editorial, Nov. 28) demonstrates, to use Soviet language, "old thinking," in that it does not take into account changes taking place. The Soviet Union is an empire composed of nations that were forcibly incorporated. Your implicit comparison to American states is highly questionable.
Furthermore, it is not only the Baltic states that never chose to be associated with Moscow. This applies as well to the other republics, as the Soviets themselves are increasingly admitting. Even the Communist-controlled Georgian Supreme Soviet, before the recent elections in which the nationalists won, condemned the forcible Bolshevik takeover of that republic, which enjoyed independence between 1918 and 1921.
It is up to the nations composing the Soviet Union -- Russia, the Ukraine, Armenia, Lithuania and others -- to determine their own fate. The Bush Administration should neither encourage nor yet discourage "many separate Soviet states," but support democratic and peaceful processes. If these processes lead to separate states (that is, if this is a reflection of the will of the people), then so be it!
 
OREST S. DEYCHAKIWSKY
Beltsville, Md., Dec. 3, 1990

HEADLINE: What's a Deb to Do in Hard Times? Go to the Ball? Burn Her Dance Card?

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
In yet another sign of hard times in gilded circles, the New York debutante quotient is down this season. Some young women whose older sisters were once presented to society at a series of back-to-back balls are curtailing their own curtsies and settling for just one. Other young women are not even coming out but are staying in for the foreseeable future.
"It's not a reflection on whether or not girls want to come out," said Margaret Joyce Hedberg, the director of the 36th annual International Debutante Ball, which will be held at the Plaza on Dec. 29. "It's the economy. All the parties are feeling it this year, although nobody wants to talk about it." 
 Indeed, they do not. Powers behind the 55-year-old New York Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball cite a dwindling demographic pool of women of debutante age, generally 18 or 19 years, in explaining why their gathering in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom on Saturday will be "more intimate" than in the recent past.
In any case, the tradition of coming out, which flourished in the 1980's when it became fashionable to display the trappings of wealth and class, seems on the decline. At least this is true in New York, where organizers of balls attended by debutantes from other states love to pick up the telephone and hear a Texas twang.
"You can have a flat economy or even a depression, and you'll still have Texas girls," said Nancy Stith-Williams, who runs another Plaza party, the Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball, which was started by her mother in 1921. "Texas girls are party girls."
Besides that, the Texas debs are noted for their nose-to-the-floor court bows, unlike New York women, some of whom will be bowing out this year.
The cotillion, which draws its members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, presented 56 debs last year. This year the number of young women who will be doing dreamy waltzes in long white dresses has dropped to 30. Contrast this with the 80's, when the leaders of this party boasted of waiting lists and presentations of 75 or more women. Now they and others are reluctant to talk about what it takes to launch a daughter into society.
Presentation fees at parties range generally between $1,200 and $2,000. Tickets for family and friends cost about $225 each. Add dresses for the deb and her mother, beauty salon visits, cars, wine at dinner, perhaps a page in the party's journal, raffles and auctions and, parents say, coming-out parties can cost $10,000 or more. This is without the round of lunches and brunches, teas and dinners that go with the territory.
Even parents who would not miss the money shrink from spending it in public this year. "It's tasteless in these times," said a Park Avenue mother who asked not to be identified. It is, of course, more graceful to bow at a charity party like the International, as it is known, which raises money for several causes. Or the cotillion, popularly called the Infirmary ball, which benefits New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital.
"If a girl is reluctant to come out, she's at least benefiting the hospital by doing so," said Christina Hoyt Vanderlip, the chairwoman of the cotillion, which was founded by her husband's grandmother, Narcissa Cox Vanderlip.
Mrs. Vanderlip, who came of age in the early 70's, declined to make her debut. "At the time it just wasn't considered cool by a lot of people," she said. "Back then, traditionally the parties were the only way for young women to meet young men. But now they are an opportunity for a wonderful family party."
Despite changing times, tradition endures at the balls, which run from Thanksgiving through New Year's Day. Debs at the International have one military and one civilian escort, and those from other countries often have titles as well, and puzzled expressions. Debs at the Junior League Thanksgiving Eve Ball are presented with green ostrich fans, a symbol of their provisional membership in the group and commitment to do volunteer work after college graduation.
And then there is the intricacy of the cotillion dance. "It's done with garlands and fans and bouquets," said Margot McAnaney, a Harvard freshman who is a chairwoman of the debutante committee. "I'm counting on my long white dress to hide my feet, but don't tell my mom. "
Miss McAnaney, whose parents live in Manhattan, is making her debut at three parties this season. "This type of exercise appears very upper class and old-fashioned and definitely has bad connotations," she said. "But it is not a marriage market. If it was, neither I nor my parents would be connected with it in any way."
What it is, she said, is a chance to dress up, see old friends and meet new ones. "Two generations ago everybody had to do it, and one generation ago nobody wanted to it," Miss McAnaney said, adding that her mother dropped out of the debutante pool. "But now it's very much the girl's decision, and you're not looked down upon either way. "

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
Atrocities by Iraqis in Kuwait: Numbers Are Hard to Verify

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 15

 BODY:
More than four months after Iraq's invasion, Kuwaitis are being subjected to looting, rape, torture and executions, human rights groups, Kuwaiti exiles and other witnesses say. But estimates of the frequency and extent of the abuses are so sharply disputed that the human rights groups, and even some Kuwaitis, say that given the lack of access to Kuwait, they cannot evaluate the remaining population's plight with any certainty.
Kuwait and its supporters say at least 7,000 Kuwaitis have been killed and 25,000 arrested or detained since Iraqi troops invaded the country on Aug. 2. By contrast, Middle East Watch, an independent human rights group based in New York, puts the death toll at about 1,000, and arrests and detentions at 5,000, some 3,000 of whom are still being held. 
 Amnesty International, the London-based human rights monitors, confirmed deaths "in the scores" and arrests and detentions "in the hundreds" in its last report on Kuwait in early October. And while the group is issuing a new report on Wednesday, Amnesty representatives say their estimates are slightly higher than but roughly similar to those of Middle East Watch.
 
Exaggeration Suspected
 The vast discrepancies in the estimates have given rise to suspicions among some human rights monitors that abuses are being exaggerated, consciously or not, for political purposes. Several human rights monitors said in interviews that they believed that the Bush Administration and Kuwait and its supporters are relying on reports of atrocities to help counter lawmakers, former government officials and foreign policy analysts who favor waiting for economic sanctions to force Iraqi soldiers out of Kuwait.
"My country is being savaged and destroyed, our women subjected to mass acts of rape, our men and even children are being murdered while these armchair analysts advocate waiting a year or up to 18 months for sanctions to force him out," Sheik Saud Nasir al-Sabah, Kuwait's Ambassador to the United States, said in an unusually emotional outburst during a recent interview. "Those who favor letting us suffer might at very least consider calling upon Iraq to permit a human rights observer force to enter Kuwait -- which they have refused to do -- to protect our people there."
Human rights groups agree that atrocities are being committed under Iraqi occupation. And they second Sheik Saud's call for greater access to Kuwait. But they add that given Iraq's refusal to permit on-site inspections in Kuwait by humanitarian groups, they cannot confirm many of reports of "mass acts" of rape, torture and execution coming from Kuwaiti sources.
"As a human rights organization, we deplore and would never want to minimize the grave human rights abuses taking place in Kuwait," said Andrew Whitley, director of Middle East Watch. "But neither do we wish to see them overstated or exaggerated in an exercise to whip up war fever."
Iraq has repeatedly denied committing atrocities in Kuwait. But it has also refused to permit journalists or human rights monitors to visit Kuwait to conduct unsupervised interviews and assessments. Moreover, Baghdad has argued that because Kuwait is part of Iraq, it is not bound by the 1949 Geneva Conventions governing rules of war and treatment of prisoners and civilian populations.
 
Propaganda Value Cited
 What is not disputed is the propaganda value of Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait, where 400,000 people, 200,000 of them Kuwaiti, are struggling to survive under rapidly deteriorating conditions, including scarcity of food and virtually no medicine. The Kuwaiti Government in exile has sent missions across the United States and Europe to highlight these conditions and atrocities.
The day before the Security Council voted to authorize the use of force to evict Iraq from Kuwait after Jan. 15, Kuwait made an unusual and moving presentation to the Council on human rights abuses committed by the Iraqi authorities. Using videotaped testimony and giant blowups of photos of torture victims, exiled Kuwaitis told a stunned and silent Security Council about the horrors they said Iraqi soldiers were inflicting on the Kuwaiti people.
President Bush, who has likened Saddam Hussein to Hitler, has said Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait are partly responsible for his unwillingness to rely on sanctions to force Iraq out.
 
Rape Case Is Described
 Iraq's sensitivity to reports of atrocities -- and its ideas about how best to counter such accounts -- were reflected in a recent cablegram filed by an American diplomat in the region.
According to an unidentified woman who recently left Saudi Arabia, the cablegram recounts, Iraqi soldiers recently raped a Kuwaiti woman from a prominent family and her two daughters in their fashionable home in a Kuwaiti suburb. Iraqi troops subsequently returned with one of the rapists and announced that a Kuwaiti male member of the family "would be given a gun to execute the rapist in front of television cameras," the cablegram says.
Residents of the area believed that the rape was "staged deliberately in order to arrive at this end point -- a film that can be used to counter the tales of atrocities coming out of Kuwait by showing that the occupation authorities are taking decisive action."
In its last report, Amnesty International said that based on scores of interviews with refugees, it had found a "horrifying picture of widespread arrests, torture under interrogation, summary executions, and mass extrajudicial killings."
Few informed observers disagree. What is at issue, however, is the number of victims.
 
250 Executions Confirmed
 "Yes, what's happening in Kuwait is terrible and completely unacceptable," said Aziz Abu Hamad, a Saudi who conducted many of the more than 600 interviews used in compiling Middle East Watch's detailed 18-page report, issued in November. "But we simply cannot find persuasive evidence of the thousands of deaths and mass rapes and many of the other abuses on a scale that have been reported in the press."
For instance, he said, he could confirm only about 250 of what Kuwait says were thousands of summary executions.
Kuwaiti officials have said Iraq is trying to re-populate their country with Iraqi citizens. But Mr. Aziz and Mr. Whitley said they could not find evidence to support this.
While there were some Iraqis who had moved down to join husbands who were soldiers, the Government did not seem to be encouraging a substantial migration, they said. On Nov. 26, they noted, Iraq's Interior Ministry ordered all Iraqi families living in Kuwait to return to Iraq and barred Iraqis from moving to Kuwait.
 
'Generalized' Rape Unconfirmed
 A far more sensitive area of disagreement is the issue of rape. Administration and Kuwaiti officials have deplored what one senior American official recently called "the culture of rape" under Iraqi occupation. But Mr. Whitley said that although there is no doubt that many women and even girls have been raped, his group could not confirm "rape as a generalized phenomenon."
A Kuwaiti obstetrician who was brought to the United States by Citizens for a Free Kuwait, a lobbying group, said she had treated four cases of rape in three and a half months of work at Maternity Hospital in Kuwait City. "It appears to be frequent, but not that frequent," she said.
What particularly disturbed her, she added, was the difference in the rapes she had treated soon after the invasion and then last month. She treated the first two women in August, she said. Both were married women who were not Kuwaiti, and both had been picked up on the street by Iraqi soldiers. But in early November, she treated two Kuwaiti girls, both unmarried, who had been raped by soldiers who had entered their home at 5 A.M.
"The male members of the family were taken to the first floor of the house and subjected to mock executions, while the girls were raped below them," she said, asking that her name be withheld to protect relatives still in Kuwait. "Their parents could hear their screams but not help them."
Anita Tiessen a spokeswoman for Amnesty International in London, said that though rape reports were increasing recently, they were particularly difficult to document in a country like Kuwait, in which women were expected to be virgins when they married. "The shame of the event means there is likely to be a lot of underreporting," she said.
 
'Lower Estimates Often Correct'
 Human rights groups are the first to acknowledge that their estimates are conservative. "It makes a better headline to use the larger numbers," said Kenneth Roth, deputy director of Human Rights Watch, of which Middle East Watch is an affiliate. "But we find that the lower estimates often prove correct, so to maintain credibility, we report only what we can confirm."
"The situation in Kuwait makes 'Rashomon' look like a clear story," he concluded. "Without direct access to the country, it is very hard to be sure."
What seems sure, however, is that hundreds of people have been executed -- more by the security police and military intelligence than by soldiers -- in detention centers, in public, or in front of their families.
An Administration official said human rights monitors in the Government tended to believe the human rights groups' estimates rather than those of the Kuwaiti Government.
"We can't accuse them of lying," the official said. "But this is a highly emotional situation, and it's very hard to be cool and objective."
Atrocity reports inolving occupied territories have frequently been incorrect. In 1914, for example, the Germans were falsely accused by the Allies of murdering Belgian babies at the outset of World War I; in World War II many diplomats said reports of German atrocities against the Jews were exaggerated.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 30, 1990, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Dec. 16 discussed reports of Iraqi atrocities in occupied Kuwait. The article noted that reports of atrocities in occupied territories have frequently proved incorrect.
It concluded: "In 1914, for example, the Germans were falsely accused by the Allies of murdering Belgian babies at the outset of World War I; in World War II many diplomats said reports of German atrocities against the Jews were exaggerated."
The passage was ambiguous; it should have made clear that it was the diplomats who were wrong in understating the magnitude of the Nazi genocide, in which six million Jews were killed.
