PUB-DATE: December 16, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5380 words

HEADLINE: Divided Loyalties

BYLINE: By Joel Brinkley; Joel Brinkley is Jerusalem bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:
AS CROWN PRINCE HASSAN LOOKS ON, hands in his pockets, 200 college students wearing the distinctive brown uniforms of the Jordanian Popular Army are marching through their drills on the Jordan University soccer field. The sun is low, and the long afternoon shadows sharpen the sense of theater as the exuberant young men and women writhe on their bellies across the Astroturf, pretending to crawl through enemy gunfire. Others thrust their AK-47 assault rifles at imaginary Israeli paratroopers, screaming war cries with every jab.
The Prince watches, distracted, and doesn't react when the boys shout their guttural chant: "God, land, country, King! Jordan, Jordan, Jordan!"
For Hassan -- the 43-year-old brother of King Hussein and heir to the throne -- this brief afternoon visit to the campus in Amman is not just another in a long day of princely duties. No, for the Prince and the 55-year-old King, the Popular Army is a potent, painful symbol of the yawning chasm splitting Jordanian society. It threatens to engulf the state.
After watching silently for a moment, the Prince glances around and then idly asks a university official, "Do you have squash courts here?" 
 The Prince and the King agreed to mobilize a civilian militia a few weeks ago, even though the Jordanian Government has too few weapons to arm the recruits, not enough cash to pay for their training and no clear military mission for them once trained.
It was the rulers' compromise answer to the angry, threatening cry from Palestinian citizens, about half of Jordan's 3.2 million people. After the Israeli police killed at least 17 Arabs at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem in October, Jordan's Palestinians wanted the Jordanian Government to hand out firearms so they could "face the Zionist enemy."
"We are ready to fight anyone, kill anyone -- Israelis, Americans," says 20-year-old Selwa Farhan, green eyes burning, as she steps off the practice field.
The request for weapons was refused. With profound understatement, King Hussein said that "it will take a bit of time" before the Government can arm the Palestinians, who once tried to kill him and take over the country. Instead, the militiamen train with weapons but aren't allowed to take them home. So, in essence, the royal brothers mobilized all male and many female Jordanians between the ages of 15 and 55 just to calm down the Palestinians.
"It was just sort of an emotional thing," says Gen. Abdul Hadi Majali, former Chief of Staff of the regular Jordanian Army. "Of course, these people don't really have any understanding of the military balance."
This was one more costly concession to the people who have presented King Hussein with his most consistent and dangerous challenge since the moment he took the throne of the Hashemite kingdom 37 years ago. Now, with the gulf crisis, the Palestinians seem intent on dragging Jordan into political and economic ruin, if not into war. Though these refugees from Palestine are full citizens of Jordan, most of them hold allegiance to only one thing: the drive to regain their homeland, now the nation of Israel. Without pause, they say they would sacrifice the kingdom in the process.
Since August, the Palestinians -- "the street," as Prince Hassan and others often refer to them -- have become loud promoters of Saddam Hussein because of his bellicose support for their cause. Not even the bitter stories from the Palestinian workers who have been forced to flee Kuwait, stripped of their life's savings, have done much to alter the prevailing view.
At the same time, native Jordanians, while sympathetic, are despairing that the Palestinians have been allowed to set the nation's tone -- destroying its reputation, and with it the economy. Watching this, the royal brothers have seemed unwilling, or unable, to stop the process.
"I suppose we could have done more," Prince Hassan reluctantly acknowledges.
This November afternoon, as the women's corps marches to the staccato cadence of a drillmaster, a young woman approaches the Prince with a question. Her worried tone belies her polite smile.
"If Israel is handing out arms to all of its citizens," she asks, voicing a popular but inaccurate Palestinian belief, "why aren't Jordanians being given weapons, too?"
Prince Hassan frowns with frustration.
"This isn't a practical question," he snaps back. And in an interview later, he explains that the whole issue of the growing Palestinian militancy had him and his brother deeply concerned.
"The street agenda is totally different from what you and I look at," he says. "It is this Lebanonization of Jordan that I find so worrying. I don't know where it might lead."

EVEN WITH THEIR INSURGENT VIEWS, THE Palestinians are important members of Jordanian society. Large numbers of them have been in Jordan since the nation was founded more than 40 years ago. Today they are the merchants, businessmen and professionals. As a group they are highly educated. And though thousands still live in sprawling but relatively orderly refugee camps largely concentrated outside Amman, most live in the cities; some 70 percent of Amman's residents are of Palestinian origin.
Though Palestinians possess much of the nation's wealth, the native Jordanians hold most of the political control. The true natives are descendants of Bedouin tribesmen. But others who were born in Jordan are considered natives, too, though their parents or grandparents immigrated from other Arab nations. Now this group is dominant in government and the military.
The Jordanians, by and large, want a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. Though many of them, including the royal brothers, admire Saddam Hussein and have little love for the exiled Kuwaiti rulers, they also say Iraq should pull out of Kuwait and the American forces should leave Saudi Arabia. That fence-straddling position is out of concert with the Western view, but still not overtly hostile, American officials say. Though the United States occasionally expresses irritation with King Hussein, relations remain "decent," as one American official put it. Among Jordanians, in fact, the King is often regarded as the most pro-American Arab leader, particularly since his wife, Queen Noor, is American.
At the same time, however, many of Jordan's Palestinians are not only openly hostile to the United States, they also want a war.
The Iraqi President should not only keep Kuwait, they say, but roll his tanks into Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries, and retake the land they still call Palestine. At countless demonstrations, the Palestinians have called for the overthrow, or death, of American, Egyptian and Saudi leaders.
On the day Prince Hassan watched the Popular Army drill, he also addressed a faculty and student group. A single exchange defined the clash of views.
"Our stand against the occupation and annexation of Kuwait is clear," the Prince said. "Since the beginning, Jordan has called for an Arab settlement. This is important because without it we might have only a few days, a few weeks before disastrous war." The audience listened quietly. Then the Prince took questions. Ibrahim Zaid Al Kilani, dean of the religious faculty, stood up and lectured the Prince. The dean's family comes from the West Bank city of Nablus.
"We need to prepare all the people for a jihad and turn Jordan into one big battlefield," he said. His eyes bore down on the Prince. "A great man once said, 'Now is the time to die.' And now is the best time to die."
A deadpan "thank you" was the Prince's only reply.
Al Kilani is not only of Palestinian origin, he is also an Islamic fundamentalist. For the last several years Jordanians have worried about the rapid spread of fundamentalism, and that concern seemed to overshadow the anxiety about the nation's Palestinians.
But as the last few months have shown, Jordan's Islamic fundamentalists are, for the most part, Palestinian. They find that the Islamic call for a jihad to retake Jerusalem and the holy land fits neatly into their pre-existing world view. So secular and fundamentalist Palestinians have joined together in a loud cry for war.
"The brotherhood of Islam, they're all Palestinians," says Abdallah Abdel Fatah Turky, an egg merchant in Baka, a bustling Palestinian refugee camp outside Amman. "The thing we all want the most is a war -- a war against Israel, a war against America."
From the first moment in August, King Hussein and Prince Hassan have tried to convince the world that their position -- they've enforced the sanctions against Iraq, while calling for a diplomatic, not military, solution -- is Jordan's. They have given more speeches and interviews in the last four months than in the previous four years.
Still, the Palestinians have been louder. Their bellicose rhetoric drowned out the official line, and it didn't take long before much of the world came to believe that the Palestinian position was Jordan's.
That perception alienated nearly all of Jordan's friends, allies and trading partners. The country had already lost one-quarter of its export markets by supporting the international sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait.
But a few weeks later, most of the rest of Jordan's exports, along with tourism, foreign aid and expatriate labor markets, were cut off as well. Jordan's neighbors, led by Saudi Arabia, ended almost all trade and commerce, so angered were they by what they saw as Jordan's pro-Iraq tilt. That eliminated almost every source of foreign income. So now Jordan is teetering on the edge of political and economic ruin.
"The reality is that we are in a very serious predicament," the King said in an interview in his office at the Royal Palace. "More serious than we ever faced until now."

IN A LAW OFFICE A few miles away from the Royal Palace, Yousef Hamden, a prosperous 38-year-old Palestinian lawyer who grew up near Nablus, agrees with that assessment. But he doesn't seem concerned.
Hamden holds Jordanian citizenship, voted in the elections last year and has lived in Amman with his family for the last eight years. Dressed in a white shirt and gray silk necktie, hair carefully coiffed, he leans forward in a high-back leather chair behind a rosewood desk. But Palestinian rage burns just below his proper establishment surface. "I have never felt Jordanian -- never," he says. "You wouldn't find even a small percentage of Palestinians in Jordan who wouldn't prefer to live in their own land. We have been humiliated for too long."
Hamden has left work several times to march in Palestinian demonstrations of support for Saddam Hussein. He particularly remembers the day that 15,000 people gathered in Mafraq.
"We sacrifice our blood for you, Saddam!" a Palestinian member of Parliament told the cheering throngs. "Let's hit the Americans, let's hit the Saudis! The time for war has arrived."
If Palestinian support for Iraq drags Jordan into ruin, Hamden says, "Well then the people will live as we lived in Palestine. Let them go back to the old life. Life will be hard, but our dignity will be intact."
In Aqaba, a resort town on the Red Sea, a hotelier, a native Jordanian, is not so sure he agrees.
William Sawalha and Jill Balchin, the assistant manager, are sitting beside the swimming pool of his hotel, the Alcazar, all by themselves at the height of the tourist season. The hotel's lobby is empty. So is the restaurant and the bar and the discotheque.
"We have 152 rooms," Balchin says. After a pause, she adds, "We have three guests just now."
"No," Sawalha corrects her, "they checked out." The gulf crisis, he goes on, is "a complete disaster for us, for the whole industry, for Jordan." Soon, he says, he will have to close his hotel.
How does he think Jordan got into this predicament? The Palestinians, he says, "put the King in a situation where he is forced to take a position."
Sawalha considers for a moment. "Look, we sympathize," he says. "The Palestinians are our relatives, our friends. But you can't close your eyes to the other things that are happening, too."

IF HE STOPPED TO THINK about it, King Hussein might agree that his grandfather, King Abdullah, is largely to blame for his current troubles. Abdullah saddled Jordan with the Palestinian problem.
As a leader of the Arab revolt against the Turks in World War I, Abdullah had hoped the British would reward him with a new kingdom -- Iraq, perhaps, or Syria. It turned out that both were already taken. But the British had another idea: why didn't Abdullah become King of Trans-Jordan, then just a desert wasteland, home to warring nomads. Abdullah was not particularly keen on the idea. For centuries, his Hashemite family had ruled the Hejaz, an area of what is now Saudi Arabia that includes Mecca and Medina. But when the British backed the Saud family's claim to the region, the Hashemites had to find a new kingdom. In the end, Abdullah accepted the British offer, apparently embracing the wisdom of his brother Feisal, the new King of Iraq, who wrote that "the wisest course is to take everything we can take and wait for tomorrow, because the nights are pregnant and might give birth to miracles."
Sitting in the scruffy little desert village of Amman in the 1920's, Abdullah yearned for a miracle that would give him control of Jerusalem, then part of British Mandate Palestine. Abdullah bided his time, and when the British pulled out in 1948, Jordan joined the war against the new Jewish state. When it was over, Abdullah held half of Jerusalem and the area now known as the West Bank -- all that was left of what the United Nations had designated as the new Palestinian state that was supposed to be born alongside Israel.
Abdullah annexed the region, quashing the Palestinians' dream of a land of their own, and Palestinian resentment grew. On June 21, 1951, a Palestinian assassinated the King as he entered Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem. His grandson, Hussein, stood beside him.
Hussein's father, Talal, a schizophrenic, took the throne but was forced to abdicate only a year later. Hussein was crowned at age 17, already wary of the bitter Palestinian refugees who populated his country. To avert more trouble, the young King quickly adopted a light-handed style of rule. He was the consensus King, the leader of all his people.

IN 1967, HUSSEIN MADE what may have been the worst decision of his life. He entered the Arabs' war against Israel -- tricked by Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt into believing victory was near, when in fact the Arabs were already defeated.
The Jordanian Army fought credibly but was overwhelmed by the far superior Israeli force. And with defeat, Hussein lost Jerusalem and the West Bank. As if that were not humiliation enough, he also gained tens of thousands of additional Palestinians. So many West Bank refugees poured across the cease-fire line that now half of Jordan's people were Palestinian. Out of both conviction and political necessity, the consensus King quickly adopted the Palestinians' cause as his own and argued their case at every opportunity.
Months later, Hussein gave his tacit assent as Palestine Liberation Organization militias, many led by the radical leaders George Habash and Nayef Hawatmeh, began using Jordan as a base for guerrilla and terrorist operations. Gradually Hussein lost control. Then on Sept. 1, 1970, the Palestinians tried to assassinate him. They were trying to take over the state.
Historians and others still wonder why Hussein waited so long to face up to the Palestinian militias. Most attribute it to his longstanding distaste for confrontation. Some call it timidity. But eventually he ordered the army to act. In September 1970, after fierce fighting and dozens of deaths during what came to be known as Black September, Habash, Hawatmeh and the other Palestinian guerrillas were routed and expelled.

GEORGE HABASH'S stubby brush of hair is grayer today, and he walks with a pronounced limp, the result of a stroke. But as he makes his way down the carpeted aisle of Amman's Royal Cultural Center with Nayef Hawatmeh at his side -- 20 years to the month after Black September -- the packed hall of several thousand Palestinian followers erupts with cheers andchants. "With our blood, with our souls, we will fight for you."
Neither man had set foot in Jordan since he was expelled. And in that time Amman had grown into a bright, clean and wealthy city of wide boulevards, expansive suburbs and fashionable homes. Most of it was built with Palestinian money, earned working in Kuwait, Saudi Arabia or the other gulf states.
On the streets, the Palestinian bankers and lawyers are hardly distinguishable from the Jordanian civil servants and Government officials. They all wear dark European-cut suits and drive Mercedes-Benzes, if they can, or other late-model cars. The Palestinian women, many wearing veils and long, simple dresses, stand out more often, a reflection of the growing Islamic fundamentalism that has taken hold in Jordan, mostly among the Palestinians.
The country is also partly democratic now. The press is freer, and public expression is rarely limited. And at the end of last year the royal brothers allowed parliamentary elections. The Parliament is free to pass any bill it likes dealing with domestic policy. But the King maintains veto power and also exercises complete control over foreign and military affairs.
For many Palestinians, the natural next step in the democratic evolution was to ask the royal brothers if Habash and Hawatmeh could return. The occasion arose when Arab nationalists, chiefly Palestinians, decided to hold a conference in Amman to show their support for Iraq. When the request came in, several factors weighed on the King's mind.

SIX WEEKS INTO THE gulf crisis, in mid-September, Hussein had never been more popular with his people. His refusal to join the alliance against Iraq raised his standing even among the once-hostile Palestinians. On most every available wall space, they had hung new posters showing the King and Saddam Hussein standing confidently before the Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem -- a montage suggesting that the two would soon take the city back.
"It's amazing," an experienced diplomat said of the King. "The number of people willing to go out there and fall on a hand grenade for him now is legion."
Jordan's international standing was weakened, but the King's fence-straddling had limited the damage. In fact, in the late days of August Saudi Arabia suddenly agreed to supply Jordan with one million barrels of oil a month, to compensate for the declining supply from Iraq.
Then came the matter of Habash and Hawatmeh. The two had a long history of hijackings and other assorted terrorist operations. And there was talk that one or the other might agree to carry out attacks for Saddam Hussein. Would the royal brothers let them in? The issue was seen as a clear measure of where Jordan stood.
The King says he did not equivocate. "I decided they were quite welcome," he said, "in the same spirit that I have approached similar problems earlier on." Over the years he has allowed several former enemies to return.
But Prince Hassan recalls deeper thinking. "It was within the rights of the authorities to say they can't come back," he said. "But look at our population. We have a very high percentage of young people. There was a feeling that keeping them out would just add to their mystique."
General Majali, the former Chief of Staff, remembered his alarm. "We shouldn't have been letting them come back as heroes," he said. "We should have let them come back to stand trial."
The September day before the conference began, the organizers announced that King Hussein had agreed to give the opening address, apparently to welcome the two guerrilla leaders. When word of that was made public, the American Embassy warned the King that he'd better not. Instead, he sent the Speaker of the House.
As soon as the conference opened, it turned into a hatefest.
"Our people feel deep and justified hatred against the United States," the first speaker said. The angry oratory grew darker as the day proceeded.
The next morning, a Monday, King Hussein agreed to meet with Habash and Hawatmeh at the Royal Palace.
"They asked for an audience, and I agreed," he said with a shrug. The two Palestinians later described the session as "warm and cordial."
That afternoon, the conference released a statement appealing to Egyptian, Saudi and Syrian troops to "rebel against their leaderships."
On Tuesday, the State Department said it was "surprised and dismayed" that King Hussein had allowed the conference to go on.
Then on Wednesday, the word came from Saudi Arabia: King Fahd was cutting off Jordan's oil. Within days, the Saudis had also expelled a group of Jordanian diplomats, sent thousands of Jordanian workers home and ordered a trade embargo. Saudi Arabia had been Jordan's largest industrial and agricultural trading partner, and now the nation's difficult situation had suddenly become "a very, very serious problem," as Finance Minister Basil Jardeneh put it.
Back at the conference, the chief organizer, Mamdouh Abbadi, was not apologetic. "When you believe in what you are doing," he said, "you don't think about the consequences."

THE TRUCKERS' YARD AT the Saudi crossing is only half full of tractor-trailers, and it's easy to pick out the few Jordanian rigs. They are the ones whose drivers are spitting mad as they walk around their trucks, trying to repair damage done by official vandals on the other side of the border.
"Look at this! Look at this!" Issa Okla howls, pointing to several rough gashes torn in the side of his trailer. "When the Saudis see my Jordanian plates, they get down and spit on them!" the 29-year-old driver says, gesticulating wildly. "They tear holes in the roof, and then when it rains, the vegetables rot. Look at this. Just look!"
Nearby, 30-year-old Mohammed Mahmoud is calmer, but sullen, as he points out the repairs he has just made in his rig:
"When I pass through, the Saudis say: 'You Jordanian dog. You dog. Your father's a dog!' Then they make me unload everything so they can search. By the time they finish, it's been three days. The vegetables are rotten."
Other drivers walk past the Jordanians without remark. They are Syrians or Turks, and for every Jordanian here, 20 of these foreigners are just passing through the country on their way to Saudi Arabia. They are busy taking over the markets the Jordanians have been forced to abandon.
The few Jordanian truckers are trying to make their way to Bahrain or the other tiny gulf states -- barely significant customers, but the only ones left. Even then, the Saudi authorities are giving them so much trouble that only about half the trucks get through.
"They tell us it's because Jordan is not taking the same stand as they are," Achmed Said says as he leans against his radiator, arms crossed. "But I tell them I'm with Saddam because he is taking a straight line for the Arabs. I'm willing to sacrifice anything for Saddam. Even my children." He points back over his shoulder. "Even my truck."
Several other Jordanian truckers -- all Palestinian -- gather around. A Jordanian customs official and a security officer drift up, too.
"We'd rather die with dignity than give in," Okla says. "I'd sacrifice anything for Saddam, anything. Even Jordan."
The customs official bristles at that.
"Ignorant, ignorant," he spits. "What do you know? You have no honor!"
Shaking his head, the Jordanian security officer, Khalil Nahan, walks back to his office.
"Did you hear that dog a while ago?" Nahan complains to a colleague. "He's willing to sacrifice Jordan for Saddam." Nahan heads back toward the door. "I'm going to go get his passport. Hassle him some." But then he changes his mind and sits back down.
"Those Palestinians," Nahan mutters, "they never appreciate anything." He shakes his head. "You can't really blame the Saudis, considering what the Palestinians are doing."

IT'S EARLY ON A Thursday in November, and five Palestinians have just sneaked across the Israeli border from Jordan. In the darkness, they start hiking toward Jerusalem. Each carries a knife, a pistol and a copy of the Koran.
A short time later, a jeep load of Israeli soldiers is on patrol along the wide sand strip that runs the entire length of the border's fence. They study the dirt track ahead. Behind them, the jeep drags a wide rack, smoothing the sand again. Suddenly they stop. Several sets of footprints are visible in the dirt just ahead. One soldier makes a hurried radio call.
Helicopters and troops start the urgent search. Soon the Palestinians are spotted on the edge of a banana grove, walking west. Troops arrive. There's a gun battle. An Israeli soldier is killed. So is a Palestinian. The others are captured, and it turns out that they were on their way to Al Aksa Mosque, intent on revenge. The Israeli Government reacts angrily. It's the 10th guerrilla infiltration from Jordan this year.
Across the Jordan River the next morning, in a mosque just outside Amman, Sheik Abdul Minem Abu Zant, a Palestinian refugee from Nablus and an elected member of the Jordanian Parliament, is delivering his sermon to several hundred members of his congregation, all Palestinians.
"The five who crossed over to Palestine yesterday are the blessed youths of the Islamic battlefield," he says. "This is a miracle." His voice swells. "They are now the dearest ones to the Prophet. What a blessed and pure mission. They carried the Koran with them."
Other fundamentalists offer similar messages in other mosques. The following Tuesday morning, a 17-year-old Palestinian sneaks across the Israeli border and crawls up to an army post. He draws his pistol, shoots and kills an Israeli soldier. Other soldiers capture him. They find that he's carrying the Koran.
Now angry Israelis are talking about using greater force on the border, possibly even retaliation, though King Hussein claims that "we've always tried to keep our border under control."
And with this, still another of Jordan's neighbors is fed up.
It used to be that Sheik Abu Zant would carry a blanket with him to the mosque each Friday. Inflammatory sermons are illegal in Jordan, and so as soon as he stepped down from the pulpit he'd pick up the blanket to take with him when the police carted him away to jail. It was the routine.
But for the last year, since democratization began, no one has bothered him. Fridays, he can say whatever he wants. This is democracy, the royal brothers say.
The Israelis have their own view. In a secure office at the Defense Ministry in Tel Aviv, an Israeli general gestures to the colonel sitting beside him.
"The colonel will brief you," he tells a half-dozen foreign journalists summoned for a briefing. A large photograph of Jerusalem's Old City hangs like a trophy on the wall.
"Jordan is in a very shaky position," the colonel is saying. "There's a big question about the King's future."
The general takes over a moment later.
"It's true that the Islamic groups are getting stronger," he says, glancing at his notes. "It's a very powerful influence on the regime. Within the walls of the palace, I think they realize that so long as they and the street see things the same way, there will be no real threat to the future of the regime."
The general looks up as he says: "But there is no way, in my opinion, for the long run that they can continue to see eye to eye. There are questions about the future."

SOME JORDANIANS are beginning to ask questions about the present. They wonder why the King allowed things to slide so far.
"The Government had a reasonable position," a former Prime Minister says. "But what happened, unfortunately, is that this reasonable position was swamped, drowned by groups that don't have any allegiance to the King or the regime."
Angrily, he adds, "The regime has allowed itself to be swallowed by the other camp because it didn't have the backbone to stop them."
In response, Government officials say it would be hypocritical to boast that Jordan is growing more democratic -- and then to quash freedom of expression.
"In a democracy, don't these people on the street have the right to say what they think?" Trade Minister Ziad Fariz asks.
In the end, many Jordanians acknowledge that their rulers don't yet fully understand democracy, don't know how to counter dissident voices without actually suppressing them.
Leila Sharaf, who is on a commission to draft a constitutional revision, says: "We instituted democracy too fast. We haven't even passed the laws in Parliament yet to regulate democratic life."
In fact, a year after the national elections last November, political parties are still illegal, probably because the royal brothers fear that someone might form a King's party. What if it lost? That danger was dramatized last month when an Islamic fundamentalist defeated King Hussein's own candidate for speaker of the house.
Political parties may be legalized soon, the King says. But by refusing to legalize them until now, the royal brothers crippled their own supporters. The only people who could organize during the tumult of the last few months were those who had pre-existing issues like Palestinian nationalism or Islamic fundamentalism to unite them. The native Jordanians whose principal affiliations are to country and King had no organized way to promote their beliefs.
"If there had been political parties, there would have been a way to separate between the Palestinian view and the East Bank view," Sharaf contends. But as it stands, General Majali complains, the native Jordanians remain "a silent majority."
The King blames his people for this, at least in part.
"It's up to these people who call themselves the silent majority to wake up to their responsibilities to represent their stands," he said with stiff-lipped certainty. "Many don't take part in the process. When things go wrong, they say the King will resolve it. This has not been the right approach, and I hope they have learned a lesson from it."
What about the King's own duties?
"Well, sir," he said, "I think the responsibility of the Government and the leadership is to articulate itself clearly, and I have done so." After a moment, he also acknowledged that, when this proved insufficient, he called the nation's newspaper editors and columnists in for a private talk.
"I told them, 'Please do not go down to the level that others have reached in addressing this crisis in terms of individuals' -- like King Fahd and President Bush -- 'and in terms of positions that are not helpful to Jordan.' And I think their stand has been on a higher plane than some."
Did he ever consider speaking to some Palestinian leaders, too?
"I could not do more," the King said, "nor would I."
Was it lack of "backbone," as the former Prime Minister put it? Was it timidity born of long and difficult experience with the Palestinians that deterred the royal brothers from doing more?
Prince Hassan, without referring to himself or his brother directly, does acknowledge that the loud Palestinian voices "have made the people become a little timid."
And King Hussein also argues that if he had quieted the Palestinians, or even argued with them in public, "I believe there would have been an eruption. We would have had a very difficult time. The fact that they were able to express themselves that way was the reason Jordan survived this period without violence."
So the King chose domestic tranquillity over international standing and financial solvency. As one diplomat put it, "He will be the popular King of a broken country."
In the meantime, democracy could be running away from him. His country may be teetering on the edge of political and economic collapse. But the King remains steadfast, monarchic.
"Under the circumstances," he says, eyes unblinking as he sits bolt upright in his chair, "looking back at whatever happened, the way we acted, or reacted, we couldn't have done it any other way."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 26; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1097 words

HEADLINE: SOUND;
The Name Is Forgotten, But the Legacy Is Enduring

BYLINE: By Hans Fantel

 BODY:
More perhaps than anyone else, Edwin Howard Armstrong made electronics the meeting place of art and science. His inventions are the main vehicle for music and the dramatic arts in our age; and the methods of wireless communication he devised now span the earth and reach into the depths of space.
Armstrong has been called America's foremost inventor, and historians of science point out that in imaginative scope and technical finesse he far exceeds Edison. Yet while Edison's name is an emblem, Armstrong's is nearly forgotten -- the more reason for marking his 100th birthday Tuesday. 
 There are other contrasts between Armstrong and Edison. Edison's method might be described as inspired tinkering, relying on trial and error to yield successful results -- a traditionally American style of invention throughout the 19th century. Armstrong, by contrast, was one of the first to let theoretical speculation based on mathematical analysis precede the actual construction of his devices. In this, he anticipated modern methods of research.
In other respects, however, Armstrong was old-fashioned for his era -- a strong-willed lone wolf who could not fit himself into the new pattern of corporate team research. It was this trait that led to his downfall and his death in 1954. Yet for most of his career, Armstrong was so securely armored by success as to seem impervious to tragedy.
Fame came to him early. In 1912, barely beyond his teens, he made the first of his seminal inventions -- the feedback circuit. This device raised the sensitivity of radio receivers hundreds of times over what it had been before and opened the way to reliable long-distance reception. Shortly afterward, his continuous-wave oscillator made it practical to transmit sound as well as Morse code via radio. Later, as television developed, Armstrong's circuits also facilitated the transmission of images, and today's satellite communications rest on his inventions. By implementing the instant transmission of information in all its forms, he created the nerve fibers of modern life.
As a student at Columbia University, Armstrong was already more famous than his professors, and his patents made him rich before he was 25. The superheterodyne circuit he devised in 1917 remains the basis of all radio communications to this day and gave the Allied armies in World War I a distinct edge in field communications. At the war's end, both the French and American Governments showered Armstrong with honors.
During the infancy of modern electronics, when many scientists still struggled to comprehend the fundamentals, Armstrong possessed an intuitive grasp of the flow of currents in complex circuits. To him, the happenings in those tubes, coils and condensers were an unfolding drama that he could plot and shape, much as an author fashions a play. It was this rare sense of circuitry as a kind of theater -- electronics as a stage for spectacular events, with electrons as the actors -- that gave Armstrong a creative vividness far beyond the domain of ordinary engineering.
By the late 1920's, radio had become a major factor in the dissemination of music. But Armstrong -- a passionate music lover -- was dissatisfied with the sound. From that time on, the musical fidelity of radio became his enduring concern.
He realized that AM radio, then the only kind, was mainly useful for covering long distances but limited in its sonic capabilities. By 1933 he had devised a new method of transmission that could accommodate the full spectrum of musical sound and eliminated the static that plagued conventional broadcasts. To achieve this, the audio signal representing the music was used to modulate the frequency of the transmitter, and this frequency modulation eventually became known by its initials as FM.
To demonstrate his new broadcasting method, Armstrong rigged a transmitter atop the newly completed Empire State Building and, in 1934, conclusively proved the merits of FM. At the same time, he also introduced another of his inventions -- multiplex transmission, the technical basis of stereo broadcasting. But not until a generation later was the public to benefit from these advances. By the very success of his experiment, Armstrong had set himself a trap.
The newly formed national radio networks immediately realized that FM, with its suitability for independent local broadcasting, posed a threat to their manner of operation. The networks mobilized both their economic and political influence to hinder the development of the new medium.
Lacking the support of the radio industry, Armstrong spent much of his fortune to build his own station, whose tower still stands above the Palisades of the Hudson River at Alpine, N.J. But before these efforts could create much public interest in the new broadcasting method, World War II diverted Armstrong's talents again to military matters.
After the war, the radio industry, like other American enterprises, reshaped itself into new structures that left little room for an individualist like Armstrong. His flair and his flamboyant personal style seemed discordant in the gray-flannel world of the postwar era. Besides, Armstrong's persistent efforts to set up FM under independent auspices riled the networks.
Eventually they found a way to divert Armstrong's energies. RCA, the parent company of NBC, involved Armstrong in a ruinous lawsuit over his most crucial patents. The man who virtually created broadcasting was now hounded by former friends who had gained financial control of his creation.
RCA kept Armstrong in court for nearly a year, confronted day after day by fresh brigades of corporate lawyers until his strength and fortune were spent. Armstrong fought the case all the way to the Supreme Court. Some of the legal examiners were simply not competent to follow the technical arguments on which he based his case, and the Court ultimately decided against him.
Soon after, the Institute of Radio Engineers, the foremost professional group in electronics, officially protested the verdict and passed a formal resolution recognizing Armstrong's claims in direct contradiction of the Supreme Court.
But that no longer mattered to him. Feeling that his work had been stolen from him, his mood darkened. On a winter day in 1954, he dressed as if to go out: coat, hat, gloves and a scarf neatly tucked in. Everything had to be orderly. From his skycraper apartment his eyes swept once more over Manhattan in the dusk. He pulled up a chair. Then he stepped out the window.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Urban Epidemic: Addicts and AIDS -- A special report.;
In Newark, A Spiral of Drugs and AIDS

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Joseph Michael Donlon had an air of ironic detachment as he toted up the damages so far in December: an eviction from his hotel, a gash on his head from a cocaine dealer swinging a cinder block, a badly infected foot, a prescription of AIDS medication that got lost somewhere along the way.
 "After a while you get hard and calloused," Mr. Donlon, an addict for almost half of his 48 years, said placidly the other afternoon in the windowless room of his latest motel. Five hours earlier he had drunk methadone at a clinic here, and now he held a syringe filled with cocaine. He studied his forearm. 
I don't know where my veins have gone," he muttered. "South with the birds, I guess. Dear God, let me have one good hit." He inserted the needle, and then, briefly, there was disgust in his voice. "What a thing to ask God for."
 There are always moments like this for Newark's addicts, moments when things seem horribly strange. But at other times life almost settles into a routine. By now they have had plenty of experience adapting to the malignancies known on the street here by two generic names: the product and the virus.
 The product is drugs, the virus is AIDS and nowhere is the combination felt more acutely than in Newark, which has more AIDS cases per capita than New York City. Forty-three percent of the clients tested at drug-treatment clinics in the Newark area carry the virus, the highest rate in the country. At Newark's largest clinic, the rate is above 60 percent.
 The epidemic in Newark has always been what New York's only recently became: a disease that strikes intravenous drug users more than any other group. Of the 10,000 AIDS cases reported in New Jersey so far, most of them in Newark and other North Jersey cities like Jersey City and Paterson, 53 percent have occurred among drug users; in Newark, the figure is 69 percent.
 
Supply and Demand
 A subculture with its own economy has evolved. Fear of AIDS has spurred a market in new syringes, often supplied by diabetics, that sell for $3 apiece, though many addicts still buy used ones for half price. A "take home" -- a bottle of methadone that clinics provide addicts for the weekend -- goes for $35, or two bags of heroin.
 A $5 vial of cocaine can be bought with a case of Sustacal, a nutrient drink prescribed to prevent weight loss. The 12-can case, which costs about $30 in pharmacies, used to fetch $15 on the street, but the price has dropped as more AIDS patients sell the cans they get free through Medicaid. Some local groceries buy cans from addicts and resell them for less than the manufacturer's wholesale price.
 The price of sex has also dropped because of increased supply. As more women have become addicted to crack, they have turned to prostitution, often with infected drug users as clients, and the number of women with AIDS has risen
 rapidly.
 "A few years ago a woman would charge you at least $40, but you can find one for $5," said Linzy Richardson, 33, one of the many welfare recipients living at the Lincoln Motel in downtown Newark. "You see a woman with 20 men a day, and you know she got to get the virus. But people around here, they'll sell their mama to get the product. Especially cocaine -- they got to be smoking it or poking it."
 
'I Couldn't Wait'
 Mr. Richardson was speaking from experience as a user of both intravenous cocaine and a kind of heroin of unusually high purity called P-Funk or P-Dope. He told of sleeping on the floor of his last apartment for two months after selling off all his furniture and household possessions to buy drugs.
 "It was new stuff that cost $4,000, but I sold it to a guy for $500," he said. "I knew I could have gotten $1,000 just by taking it back to the store, but I couldn't wait until the next morning."
 This focus on the short term is one reason the epidemic keeps spreading. The prospect of AIDS and the need for a clean needle are often distant priorities compared to finding drugs, food and shelter.
 Another reason is the drug subculture itself: the people who know one another from welfare hotels, crack houses, methadone clinics, corner drug markets, prisons and hospital wards. Few other groups in the world -- gay men in some American cities, prostitutes at African truck stops -- include such a high concentration of infected people able to spread the disease.
 Why don't people escape the product and the virus? Scientists speculate about genetic predispositions to chemical dependency. Public-health officials blame a lack of money for drug-treatment programs and governments' refusal to let addicts obtain clean syringes legally.
 Social workers talk about the breakdown of families, governmental indifference to the poor and societal prejudice. Surveys across the country show that half of intravenous drug users are black and a quarter are Hispanic.
 Addicts on the street blame society and government for some of their problems, but tend to do more complaining about the other addicts around them. They also tend to blame themselves. Here are two of their stories: one about the product in its new smokable form, and one about the traditional variety.
 
A Prostitute's Story

 'The Devil's Always Knocking'
 It was a Sunday morning, and a 25-year-old woman known professionally as Kim Williams was in the lobby of the Carlton Hotel canceling an appointment for what is called a freak show. She had been hired to have sex with another woman while a group of men watched or joined in. They had promised her cash and crack, which would be smoked throughout the event.
 "I can't go with you," she said to one of the men who had come to pick her up. "I couldn't get a baby sitter."
 Later that day she found a baby sitter for her 5-year-old son, who lives with her in the hotel, and went out for a walk along East Park Street to explain how she had ended up in these circumstances, and why she was not afraid of getting AIDS.
 "First you use a drug, and then it uses you," she said. "I never used as a teen-ager. I used to be a snitch and tell my mother when I caught my sister.
 "But a few years ago my boyfriend got locked up, and I got so depressed because nobody was there for me. A friend offered me some coke, and I got hooked."
 
'I Must Be Crazy, Too'
 At one point, she said, she was shocked into quitting. "I was sleeping while some friends were getting high in the room, and when I woke up I saw them crawling on the floor, picking up little white specks, taking lint off a sweatshirt -- they were so desperate for coke. My sister was walking around looking like a zombie.
 "I started crying. I thought, 'I must be like this when I'm high. I must be crazy, too.' I got so scared I went into rehab and stayed off coke for eight months.
 "But around here the Devil's always knocking on the door. A friend sees you trying to do positive, so they be negative and offer you drugs. Misery loves company, you know."
 She had lost her last jobs, in a laundry and a bar, she said, and now was collecting a $322 welfare check and $192 in food stamps each month. She said it was barely enough to get by, even with the government paying for her room at the hotel, and the only way she could get money for drugs was through prostitution.
 It was an especially risky form of prostitution, both because of the drug-using clientele -- one of the men for the freak show that morning, for instance, was rumored to have AIDS -- and because of the crack use that accompanied it.
 
Lowered Inhibitions
 Cocaine often leaves men sexually aroused but unable to reach orgasm for a long time, which leads to prolonged sessions that increase the risk of genital abrasions through which the HIV virus can enter. Crack can also lower inhibitions, making women less likely to insist on condoms and more likely to have multiple partners to keep getting the drug. It helps make freak shows possible.
 For all these reasons, prostitution by crack addicts is believed to be an important factor in spreading AIDS. Of the women with AIDS in New Jersey, most are classified as intraveous drug users, but the sharpest recent increase has occurred among other women, who typically get the disease from a partner who is an addict. The number of new AIDS cases among those not using intravenous drugs last year was nearly three times higher than in 1986.
 "We've had reports of girls 11 or 12 years old actively soliciting to support their crack habits," said Barbara Ford, the AIDS coordinator for Newark. "When that's going on, it's not surprising that there's been such an influx of women being infected."
 So far a fifth of New Jersey's 10,000 cases have been women. For women, like men, the toll has been heaviest in the inner cities. More than half of the state's AIDS cases have been among blacks. At University Hospital in Newark, which serves a mainly black and Hispanic community, a survey two years ago found that one in 23 women giving birth carried the AIDS virus.
 Miss Williams, who had not been tested for AIDS, insisted that she was safe because she always used a condom and limited men on crack to three minutes. But she said other women did not take precautions.
 "A lot of the whores I see on the corner don't care," she said. "They're nasty and they'll do anything for crack. A lot of girls have disappeared, and you hear that they got AIDS. But I'm careful. I don't trust nobody."
 She said she was planning to go back to drug rehabilitation someday, and took pains to stress one point:
 "I may get high, but I never let my son see me smoke. I know what I'm doing is wrong, and it depresses me when I think of him doing it. You know the song, 'Losers are users, users are losers, so don't use drugs'? I sing it to him all the time. Slowly but surely he's learning about drugs."
 
A Dealer's Discovery

 'I Don't Feel Sorry for Myself'
 In 1986 Ceford M. used his full name when he appeared on a national television news program. He was introduced as a man who after seven years in prison for heroin dealing and murder had "found a better way." He had kicked his heroin habit, enrolled in a job-training program and won two promotions as a computer data processor.
 This year he insists on anonymity, in deference partly to his family and partly to the police. He lost his computer job in January as a result of a renewed drug habit, and has been supporting himself since by selling cocaine on the streets of Newark. He said he can make $1,500 in the first week of each month, when welfare checks come out.
 "It's really hard to come up with a reason I went back," said Ceford, 39, who had been introduced to heroin as a freshman in college. "I tried to stay off -- for five years I tried -- but something was always missing. I just loved the streets so much. For some reason I like the danger, the excitement."
 He does not necessarily like the people, though. Sitting in a coffee shop across Broad Street from the Lincoln Motel, neatly dressed in a corduroy sports jacket and a tweed cap, he waved disdainfully at the addicts in dirty sweatshirts milling in the motel parking lot. 'I Hate to Be Around Them'
 "Look at the way they're dressed," he said. "Just because you have a weakness, you can't let the rest of your life go. I know how to carry myself and speak correctly. I've got two years of college. I can be a stand-up John when I have to be, and I can be a street nigger. These people only know one way to act, and that's ignorant. I hate to be around them because they're always trying to get slick on you.",
 At this point, shortly before Thanksgiving, Ceford was still living with his wife and his 7-year-old daughter in the suburbs, but he was thinking of leaving. "I've been such a burden to her, I think maybe I should get out of her life," he said of his wife. "She's completely straight -- never touched drugs, very refined, college graduate, good job -- and it tears her apart to see what I'm doing."
 For some reason, he said, his wife had not seemed too concerned about whether he would acquire the AIDS virus. But he had recently gone in for a blood test and was waiting to hear the results.
 "You have to worry about the virus," he said. "A couple of friends of mine that I shared needles with a long time ago died of AIDS. But I'm still feeling good, so maybe I'll be all right." He had fresh track marks on his left hand from shooting cocaine -- the methadone he was getting at a clinic kept him off heroin -- but he said he had not shared a needle since finding out about the AIDS risk in 1983.
 This would put him in the minority of drug users, according to a study published this year by the National Institute on Drug Abuse of nearly 17,000 drug users surveyed in 45 cities, including Newark. Seventy-eight percent of the users reported sometimes sharing a needle. Of those, only 14 percent said they always cleaned the needle with bleach to kill the virus, as is recommended.
 
Finding New Approaches
 "It's disturbing that our public-health efforts haven't been more successful," said Stanley H. Weiss, director of the division of infectious disease epidemiology at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark. Since 1984 Dr. Weiss has been tracking about 1,000 drug users in Newark and five other New Jersey cities, and finds that each year another 5 percent of them become infected with the AIDS virus.
 "The average drug user knows that AIDS can be spread by sharing needles," Dr. Weiss said. "Users are very smart -- they have to be street smart to survive. But AIDS is a relatively remote problem, especially when someone needs a fix at 2 in the morning. Its impact pales compared to the daily pressure to survive, and we have to find some new ways to reach them."
 One way, which was pioneered in New Jersey and is now part of a nationwide project conducted by the drug abuse institute, is to send former addicts into the streets. In Newark former addicts have recruited 1,800 addicts for counseling, an AIDS test and an interview by offering them $15 apiece and a voucher that would admit them to a drug-treatment program.
 "About half of the people end up using the vouchers for treatment,"said Bob Baxter, one of researchers directing the Newark portion of the project. "Obviously it would be preferable to get the rest in treatment, too, but at least we're reaching them with some information about safer sex and drug use."
 Only a quarter of the addicts who have taken the AIDS test have returned to get the results. One of those who did was Ceford, a week after the interview in the coffee shop, and the results sent him on a cocaine binge. On its fifth day he sat tensely in a friend's apartment. 'I Brought It On Myself'
 "They told me I got the virus," he said, "and I've been shooting ever since. There's nothing to live for. I'm going to shoot, shoot, shoot. Maybe I'll get lucky and get a heart attack. I watched my best friend die of AIDS, and it was awful -- he got so small at the end.
"I'm not going to let it come to that. I'll go out first."
 His wife cried at the news, he said, and accused him of getting the virus recently from women on the streets, because it had been so long since he shared a needle. But many people remain symptomless for a decade after being infected, so he could have gotten it from the needles he shared in the early 1980's.
 "I brought it on myself," he said. "You tell a baby a stove is hot, it still wants to touch it. I'd advise anyone thinking about drugs: Stay away from the product, because you're going to like it. Next to sex, ain't nothing like it.
 
'The Hurt in Her Eye'
 "I don't feel sorry for myself. A tear didn't cross my eye when they told me, and I think that's strange. But the only thing I felt was compassion for my wife. And then when I went to tell her, to see the hurt in her eye, that just devastated me."
 His wife now refuses to speak to him, he said, but he hopes she will tell him the result of her blood test when it came back. Either way, he said, he would not be moving back home.
 "I'll stay with friends or go in the city shelter until I get on welfare," he said. "I'm not going back to be a burden on my wife. But I would like to sit down and talk to her.
 "I would say I'm sorry, my life is numbered, but I don't want her to be sick. I want her to raise my daughter and do all the things she never got a chance to do. I'll tell you, I would give up my life this instant for her result to come back negative."

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1424 words

HEADLINE: Hard Times Strain the Spirit of Giving

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
TRADITIONALLY, the middle of December is the peak season of giving. But this year charitable organizations find themselves rich in volunteers but poor in dollars. And the need for funds has never been greater, say the directors of Westchester agencies, as they cite a rise in the number of people seeking help.
"On one Saturday in November, at the emergency food bank in Cortlandt, as many people came in for food parcels as were seen during the entire month last year," said Susan Winters, director of the Westchester Coalition of Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens in Hawthorne, headquarters for 84 emergency community food programs. 
 Ms. Winters said she expected a record turnout for Christmas dinners, judging from the attendance at Thanksgiving.
 
A Doubling of Diners
 "One New Rochelle church, which was pretty much representative of others, reported serving 170 dinners, almost double last year's number," she said. "Students at Hastings High School cooked and served 250 Thanksgiving dinners in the school cafeteria. It was a project they initiated. We arranged to pick up people in vans and deliver them home again. It was not only the homeless who attended. We noticed that more of the elderly came, and an increase in those who are out of work, like some people from the G.M. plant in Tarrytown."
There were also entire families, who brought their children. "Those are the children," she said, "who when asked on a kindergarten test to finish the sentence, 'When I'm hungry I . . .,' answer, 'I go to bed,' instead of the standard answer, 'I eat.' "
Despite the economic downturn, or maybe because of it, Ms. Winters said, individual donations to the coalition were running at about the same level as last year.
 
A Pressing Drive for Funds
 "I think it's because people identify with what we are doing," she said. "We have some loyal contributors who are committed to sending us small amounts of money every month, and that includes a man who has been out of work for a year, who still managed to send us $5 recently."
The drive for funds becomes even more pressing this year because the coalition was cut out of the budget proposed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, she said, adding, "We received $50,000 from the county last year." The 1991 spending plan is now being reviewed and adjusted by the County Board of Legislators.
Another grass-roots organization, the Coalition for the Homeless of Westchester, based in Yonkers, has also lost financing.
"We lost our New York State legislative grant of $11,000," said Anthony Wynne, the group's executive director. "We're now in a crisis situation. We're halfway through our prime fund-raising months of November, December and January, and it appears we are certainly going to fall short."
He said his group was getting "fewer individual donations this year," and added: "People appear to be apprehensive, worried about the economy. They are more willing to give us time than money. We have more volunteers than ever this year, but fewer dollars."
Emphasizing that the Salvation Army has to raise more money because there are more needy people, Roger Rischway, director of volunteer services for the Salvation Army in Westchester and the Hudson Valley, said:
"We're hoping for a big last-minute surge in public generosity this year because contributions in the greater New York area are now 20 percent below last year's. Our kettle collections are down. In Westchester, our people are stationed in the main shopping areas and malls, so retail activity has a big impact on our collections. When retail activity is slow, it has a negative effect on donations."
 
More Volunteers Come In
 But the Salvation Army has also been able to increase its corps of volunteers this season.
"People from all walks of life are out of work," Mr. Rischway observed. "A lot of them prefer to work as volunteers rather than sit around doing nothing. We're grateful to have them because our caseload has increased with every layoff in the county. There are more people with more problems. There's a lot of misery around today, more than I've seen in a long time."
Barbara Rose, deputy general manager of the American Red Cross office in White Plains, said donations to the Red Cross had been running at last year's levels.
"But although contributions have remained generally the same, the demand for our services has become much greater this year," Ms. Rose said. "This year, we're supplying services to the military because of the situation in the Persian Gulf."
The Red Cross, she said, began supplying support groups for service families in September.
"Currently, we're counseling 52 families who have someone in the services, which has increased the caseload for our social workers," Ms. Rose said. "When people need more services, we feel we have to supply them. For example, when support checks don't come through to families, we bridge the gap by making them a loan."
Another Red Cross project, Images From Home, has been videotaping Christmas messages from families of service personnel at Red Cross offices in White Plains and Yonkers.
"Fuji Photo Film in Elmsford donated the equipment, and we'll keep taking and sending messages right through Christmas and afterward, as long as our troops are there," Ms. Rose said.
The Red Cross has also received more calls from people who want to volunteer their services this year, she said. "A lot of them are from families who have someone overseas."
 
Pen Pal Project Created
 The Red Cross is also sponsoring a "While You're Away" pen pal program at 250 Westchester schools. "Twelve thousand students have already sent letters to service people in the Gulf," Ms. Rose said.
The demand for services in Westchester also rises in the winter. "Winter means fire," Ms. Rose explained. "A few weeks ago, a terrible apartment fire in Mount Vernon made 23 families homeless. We were on the scene from 2:30 A.M. to 6:30 A.M., finding lodging for those families."
Ralph A. Gregory, president and chief professional officer of United Way of Westchester, said 30 percent of United Way's contributions came from corporations, 50 percent from employee payroll deduction plans and 20 percent from individuals. "Although ours is a year-round fund-raising effort," Mr. Gregory said, "there's always a strong year-end surge. This year, company downsizing and fewer employee groups have cut down the number of givers. In order to make up for the loss, we've made a two-pronged effort to increase the level of participation."
By broadening and deepening the base, which means trying to encourage more people to give and convincing those who give to give more, Mr. Gregory said, United Way has been able to raise more money from several companies that have fewer employees than they did last year.
"It's an important phenomenon," Mr. Gregory said. "It seems to me that what it signifies, is that people who have jobs are glad of their good luck and willing to dig a little deeper to help."
 
More Requests for Financing
 United Way finances 17 Westchester agencies, but the number of agencies asking the United Way for money this year has tripled, Mr. Gregory said. "It's a sign of the times. A couple of months ago, when the talk about state and county cutbacks first started, we started getting inquiries. Now, requests for financing are flooding in every day."
The requests come from agencies that are "a very important part of the health and human resource systems in the county," he said. "They all need money. Yet it's too early to tell how our campaign will go this year. Although we're encouraged by many of the results, overall fund-raising is not going as well as we would like it."
But a year's-end increase in contributions from individuals who want to take advantage of this year's tax structure is a possibility, Mr. Gregory said. "It's a minor thing, but it would be very nice to have that money up front."
Mr. Wynne said he was also hoping for a last-minute bonanza. The $19,000 his Coalition for the Homeless had in financing last year was used for its eviction-protection program, and saved 30 families from eviction. "If the county had to house those 30 families, it would cost them $1.4 million to do it," he said. "It makes no sense."
The future of the Coalition of Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens is also in jeopardy, Ms. Winters said, adding: "I spend a lot of time these days writing applications for grants. If we can't raise money somehow to keep going, we'll sink."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Salvation Army worker outside a store in Yonkers. "Our kettle collections are down," the agency reports. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)
