HEADLINE: In the Ravaged South Bronx, a Camelot Is Envisioned

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Over a vast, half-desolate swath of the South Bronx, a place of lonely businesses, empty lots and storefront evangelists, planners are drawing the core of a new city.
Their proposal seeks to transform the appearance and economic potential of one of the country's most resilient symbols of urban blight by creating a synergy among a wide range of development projects, some already under construction, others merely proposed. 
 A new police academy, for instance, would provide security for an expanded civic center, while a new nursing school would join a hospital and a growing community college in an area high on unemployment and low on nurses.
Little more than a decade after some cityofficials and planners were declaring the South Bronx to be beyond renewal, the huge plan's ambition is itself a powerful sign of progress in the borough.
After years in which big, publicly financed development projects seemed to land in every borough except the Bronx, the plan's main parts also appeared until recently to have considerable support from Mayor David N. Dinkins.
 
Financial Hurdles Loom
 Yet as New York's financial outlook has darkened, the questions that the plan faces have sharpened and its support at City Hall has waned.
"From a planning point of view, I know we believe it is an appropriate and suitable plan," said Barbara Fife, the Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development. "It's a good,positive planning decision for the future of the Bronx. The questions are the trade-offs."
Called the Bronx Center Plan, it was outlined last month in the long-term Strategic Policy Statement required of each borough under the new City Charter. And while it builds on some ideas that planning officials set forth at least five years ago, it has been greeted with an enthusiasm that is significant precisely for its realism -- the recognition that fiscal constraints could delay the plan for years.
 
Preparing for Progress
 "When the economy slows down, we can do one of two things," said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the New York City Public Development Corporation, a nonprofit city agency that has monitored the Bronx plan's evolution. "We can wring our hands, or we can take advantage of this time to do thoughtful, longer-range planning so that we can have structures in place when the next wave comes. And that's what we're doing in the Bronx."
Yet if the Bronx plan has cornerstones, they are two projects that the city's Office of Management and Budget has fought to strike from the 10-year capital plan scheduled for release Friday.
One is a new Police Academy, which the Koch administration and then the Dinkins administration initially agreed to build on three square blocks east of the Grand Concourse and south of the courthouse on 161st Street.
Because the complex would draw hundreds of police officers each day, it has been viewed as a singular source of security for a burgeoning civic center that is still fringed by areas of high crime. But after being scaled back from a $200 million job to one that might cost $160 million, one senior city official estimated its chances for inclusion in the ever more austere 10-year plan at "50-50."
 
Housing Prospects Wane
 The other critical project is Melrose Commons, a development of about 4,000 moderate-income apartments that also won approval from the Koch administration and early favor from Mayor Dinkins. The city's Housing Commissioner, Felice Michetti, acknowledged that the development's prospects had waned with the city's fiscal health.
In lobbying for the plan, Bronx leaders have stressed their borough's habitual last place on the big-project lists of city agencies. But they also insist that its importance reaches beyond the Bronx.
"The issue is not building pretty buildings," said the Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. "This would create wealth for the borough and the city. It will create jobs. It would increase the tax base. The point is to create a new economic engine."
The key to that goal is the way in which the plan's different elements would complement one another: a parking lot that by day would serve a new housing court could at night be used for events at the expanded arts museum next door; in another area, housing and shopping areas would be expanded side by side.
Despite the "center" in its name, a new Bronx with the plan fully realized could well leave the area resembling the Oakland of Gertrude Stein -- there would not necessarily be a "there" there.
During the 1980's, city and borough officials concentrated efforts for the South Bronx along the Grand Concourse. From 161st Street, planners argued, they could push the recovery further south.
By contrast, the new plan envisions building four separate sub-centers or "nodes," in which different projects would be grouped to complement one another and from which stability could spread.
 
Civic Center Planned
 The most central would be a civic center surrounding the county building that houses Mr. Ferrer's offices and the State Supreme Court. Along with restoration of the building and three surrounding parks, the plan envisions a major expansion of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, a new Housing Court next door and at least two new courthouses and a 40,000-square-foot office building.
Across from the courthouse, private builders have almost finished the first phase of what was to be a $120 million shopping, entertainment and office complex, Concourse Plaza. But despite commitments for more than half the space, construction of the office building has been delayed by loan difficulties, borough officials said.
Further down the Grand Concourse, the plan would anchor a second, "institutional center" with the new Police Academy. Along with Lincoln Hospital, several public schools and a landmark post office, the cluster includes Hostos Community College, which is in the midst of a $200 million expansion.
East on 149th Street, the plan calls for a makeover of the Hub, the area around Third and Westchester Avenues that is the borough's second busiest commercial district after Fordham Road.
 
Cloud Over Housing Project
 While perhaps not the most costly, the part of Bronx Center that poses the greatest challenge is its fourth sub-center, Melrose Commons, a huge moderate-income housing development north of the Hub.
To build an entire neigborhood where there are now mostly vacant lots and abandoned buildings would cost more than $400 million over 12 years. City housing subsidies alone are estimated at $100 million, and some officials are skeptical about developers' chances of drawing better-off home buyers into an area ringed by housing projects.
The plan faces other questions as well, especially about the borough's poor public transportation links and the difficulty of drawing investment to an area that counts its high concentration of empty, city-owned land and the underemployment of its labor force as chief attractions.
Mr. Ferrer and his aides do not deny the drawbacks. Their plan, they argue, is merely the best option to integrate some of the city's youngest, poorest and least-employed residents into the economic mainstream, while wresting the South Bronx from the grip of poverty.
 
Preparing the Prelude
 Having gathered wide support for their ideas within the borough during a months-long consultation that produced a report -- "New Directions for the Bronx" -- last April, borough officials are pressing ahead.
They are beginning talks with the American Institute of Architects to set up a special workshop in which architects, urban planners and landscape designers would draft proposals for specific parts of the plan. A conference of investors would follow, planning officials said.
"It's a very good example of what comprehensive planning is all about," said Sylvia Deutsch, the City Planning Commission's former chairwoman. "It may take some time and an upturn in business and a freeing up of the capital budget to get done, but the necessary prelude is there."

HEADLINE: $5 BILLION '91 LOSS SEEN FOR U.S. FUND INSURING DEPOSITS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, said today that the Government's fund that protects bank deposits, already at its lowest level in history, would probably lose $5 billion next year, moving it perilously closer to insolvency.
That is the most dire portrait yet drawn by the Government of the fund's problems. The fund has incurred increasing losses, paying out more than it has received in premiums from banks, as the Government has had to compensate depositors at banks that have failed in recent years. 
 Such a loss next year, on top of expected losses this year of at least $4 billion, would leave the fund with about $4 billion. And much of that money might not be readily available in cash.
Mr. Seidman also predicted that 170 to 200 banks would fail next year, comparable to the number of failures expected this year.
 
'Inside Information'
 His remarks, made on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" and in an interview later, went considerably beyond recent glum forecasts about the fund by the General Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office. His projections, the first official estimates for 1991, are based on "inside information from our examiners in the field," he said.
"It's a fund that's so weak that it needs to be recapitalized," Mr. Seidman said in the interview. "Nineteen ninety-one is not going to be a good year."
Mr. Seidman and the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, who also appeared on "Meet the Press," said that the cost of shoring up the declining fund would be borne by banks and not by taxpayers. The Government is already deeply involved in a bailout of the savings and loan industry that the Administration currently estimates could cost taxpayers as much as $130 billion, excluding interest payments.
 
New Regulations Urged
 The banking industry is currently suffering a serious decline in earnings, and many economists suggest that the Government must change how it regulates banks. [Page D1.]
The Administration is preparing a package of proposals scheduled to be released next month for overhauling the banking system. Among them will be recommendations on fixing the insurance fund, largely by increasing the contributions from banks.
In June, the insurance fund had 60 cents for every $100 in deposits covered. Today's prediction means that the fund could be down to about 18 cents for every $100 in deposits by the end of next year. Experts have generally agreed that the minimum safe level for the fund is $1.25 for every $100 in deposits, based on actuarial calculations of the problems the fund could encounter.
Five days ago, Mr. Seidman had increased his estimates of losses for 1990 to at least $4 billion, from $3 billion. He said today that 80 percent of the losses reflected anticipated bank failures in the coming months.
On Monday, a House banking subcommittee will release a report that paints an even bleaker picture of the deposit insurance fund. That report is based on economic projections for the next three years. Mr. Seidman said his estimate is "not based on an economic model or anything like that."
If Mr. Seidman's forecast is correct, 1991 would be the fourth consecutive year of losses and the worst year in the history of the deposit insurance fund, even though premiums will be increased by 62.5 percent on Jan. 1. In September, regulators decided to increase bank premiums in January to 19.5 cents for each $100 in deposits, from 12 cents. The F.D.I.C. has said that it will consider raising the rates again early next year and that it is studying the impact a further increase would have on weaker institutions that could collapse if the rates were too steep.
Mr. Seidman said the aim of the proposals under consideration would be to achieve a payment from each bank equivalent to 1 percent of its deposits. That would add $20 billion to $25 billion to the fund.
 
Stock Plan Considered

The Bush Administration is also considering a number of proposals to reorganize the fund without causing still more institutions to fail. One idea under study would have all of the more than 12,000 banks with insured deposits buy stock in the fund. The stock could then be used to satisfy Government requirements that banks keep a certain amount of money aside as a cushion against losses.
Some regulators and bankers find this approach appealing because it would add to the fund without appearing to hurt banks' balance sheets. But the plan has been criticized by some accountants and by the nation's Comptroller General, Charles A. Bowsher, as an accounting gimmick.
"The insurance fund needs to be recapitalized, but not by creating fictitious investments on the books of banks that overstate their true capital position," Mr. Bowsher said in a recent letter to Mr. Brady.
Mr. Bowsher and other critics have said that it would be difficult to value such stock, particularly because there would be no market for it and the price would have to be adjusted downward for any future difficulties of the fund.
 
Extended Recapitalization
 Mr. Seidman said another idea that he believed bankers would favor would begin recapitalization of the fund this year and extend it through next year to reduce the immediate impact of a premium increase.
The Administration is also formulating a plan to charge higher premiums to weaker banks. The theory is that premiums based on the riskiness of investments made by the banks would more closely approximate private insurance and would discourage speculative investments.
But several leading banking experts have questioned such a dramatic shift in policy and have said that a reliable method of assessing the riskiness of investments would be difficult to develop.
To achieve accurate pricing, the Administration is exploring the idea of using insurance companies as co-insurers.
 
Forcing Insolvencies?
 Another concern of both regulators and outside experts is that a change in the system to a risk-based program would be counterproductive. Charging weaker banks more could force still more institutions into insolvency, they say.
It is too soon to determine how much of the bank insurance fund next year will be in readily available cash. Mr. Seidman has said that only $7 billion now in the fund is immediately available, with the rest consisting of assets from failed institutions that cannot be easily sold and money that the F.D.I.C. is required to hold in reserve.
As a result, Mr. Seidman said that next year the fund may be facing a "problem of liquidity" that would require it to begin using some of a $5 billion line of credit that the F.D.I.C. has with the Treasury Department in order to continue to close and sell troubled banks.

HEADLINE: 2 Convicted of Killing Amazon Environmentalist

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 16

 BODY:
A rancher and his son have been convicted in the murder of a celebrated Amazon environmental leader, breaking a long tradition of impunity for pro-development forces in Brazil.
The rancher, 54-year-old Darly Alves da Silva, was convicted of planning the Dec. 22, 1988, murder of the Francisco (Chico) Mendes, leader of a rubber-tappers' union who became internationally known as a defender of the rain forest. The rancher's son, 23-year-old Darci Alves Pereira, was convicted of firing the shotgun blast that killed Mr.Mendes. Both were found guilty and received 19-year sentences late Saturday. The prosecution had sought 30-year sentences. Brazil has no death penalty. 
 The ranchers had sought to expand their pastures by cutting down rainforest. In opposition, Mr. Mendes led the rubber tappers, men who gather latex from wild trees in the forest.
Human rights defenders hope that the explosion of cheers that greeted the verdicts in the small wooden courthouse in Xapuri, in Acre state, about 2,600 miles northwest of here, will now be heard across this huge land of 150 million people. The Pastoral Land Commission, a Roman Catholic group, estimates the more than 1,000 Brazilians have been killed since 1980 in land disputes, virtually all of the victims members of rural unions representing tenants, landless peasants, laborers. Of these murders, the Catholic group says, convictions were only achieved in two cases.
In a typical case, a lawyer for a sugar cane workers union was shot to death Thursday in the Atlantic coastal state of Pernamubuco.
The unionist, Jose Helio da Silva, had ignored several written death threats, including one that said: "Chico Mendes sleeps because he talked too much."
The murder of Mr. Mendes, a mild-mannered, mustachioed man who would have turned 46 last Saturday, became an international cause celebre as concern grew in Brazil, Europe and the United States over unchecked cutting and burning of the Amazon rainforest.
Partly as a result of this outcry, the Brazilian Government has abolished tax benefits that had made it profitable to cut the forest for pastureland. A public awareness campaign appears to be slowing the burning of the 2-million-square-mile Amazon, the world's largest tropical forest.
In one of many tributes to Mr. Mendes, the Government has established in Acre a 2.4 million acre Chico Mendes Extractive Reserve, which is to allow 3,000 families to make a living gathering wild rubber and nuts without fear that ranchers will burn the forestdown.
In Brazil and overseas, Mr. Mendes has become an international symbol of the fight to preserve the Amazon. This year, three books have been published on Mr. Mendes's struggle.
Next year, David Puttnam, the British director, is to start filming a Hollywood movie of the Mendes story.
 
Viability of Rubber-Tapping
 But even as outsiders extol Mr. Mendes and the rubber tappers' environmentally safe way of life, debate has erupted over the long-term viability of the tappers' way of life.
Indeed, the tapping of wild Amazonian rubber only continues because of high tariffs on rubber imported from Malaysian plantations. In a move that may soon affect the Acre rubber tappers, growers recently planted 9 million rubber trees in Sao Paulo state.
While the economic threat may be impending, the physical threat often seems more immmediate to the rubber tappers.
Last week, taking advantage of the presence of a large number of Brazilian and foreign reporters at the Mendes trial, Osmarino Amancio Rodrigues, the slain unionist's political successor, announced that he recently received a series of death threats.
"For now, the general level of violence in Acre is down, no doubt due to the glare of international publicity surrounding the trial of Chico Mendes' murderers," read a report last week by Americas Watch, the New York-based human rights group. "The real test will be what happens in Acre when the spotlight of world attention is turned off."

HEADLINE: Brazil Reportedly Plans Debt Payments

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Brazil will announce on Monday the end of its undeclared moratorium on interest payments on its foreign debt to commercial banks, the O Estado de Sao Paulo newspaper reported today.
Brazil's Government has said previously, most recently earlier this month, that it would make some payment against its arrears, which totals more than $8.5 billion. 
 O Estado said Brazil foreign debt negotiators would tell the banks' advisory committee in New York on Monday that Brazil will resume paying interest on its bank debt in January.
Telephone calls to the Economy Ministry seeking comment were not returned on Sunday.
The third world's largest debtor nation began skipping most interest payments on its medium- and long-term bank debt of $60 billion in July 1989.
Brazil has come under increasing pressure from its creditor banks, which seem to have persuaded the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Nakasone Fund, a Japanese foreign aid program, to tie disbursement of $5 billion in loans to Brazil's progress in negotiations with the banks.
As a result of this pressure, Brazil agreed earlier this month to allow the payment of $940 million by the end of the year. With the banks asking for $2.5 billion, talks again bogged down.
Quoting an unnamed member of the Government's economic team, the newspaper said the announcement Monday is intended "to not leave any doubt about the good faith of the Government in its negotations."
The administration of former President Jose Sarney said it suspended the interest payments to leave adequate foreign exchange reserves to the new Government.
The administration of President Fernando Collor de Mello, which took office last March, has continued the suspension. The Government has maintained that it will not pay the arrears until an overall new debt agreement is reached.
Brazil has total debts of $119 billion, and its proposals in October for repaying the $60 billion of bank debt over a 45-year period were quickly rejected by the institutions as being unrealistic.

HEADLINE: Stability in Yields Is Seen for Now

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For the time being, credit market analysts say, the breathtaking decline in bond yields is probably over. But the near-term stability may be just a pause in what remains a bull market.
Between now and the end of the year, the temptation will be strong to lock in profits that have been building since mid-October, when long-term interest rates began to slide. Moreover, concerns about the Middle East will probably mount as the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for Iraq's withdrawl from Kuwait nears. 
 "I don't think we have seen the bottom in interest rates," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. "But we may have to wait a few weeks before the rally resumes."
While bond yields will probably not move much below their current levels of 8.18 percent for the time being, unremitting signs of economic weakness will prevent them from rising much, analysts said.
 
Selloffs Called Opportunities
 "I don't think there is a lot of downside to buying bonds between now and the end of the year, because the economy is weak," said Roger A. Craig, director of fixed-income management at the Banc One Asset Management Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. "You have to look to these selloffs as opportunities to add to your positions."
The magnitude of the downturn in the current quarter became clearer on Friday, when the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production fell by 1.7 percent in November, the steepest monthly decline since December 1982, when the nation was beginning to crawl out of a recession.
Given the sharp drop in November employment, analysts had expected that manufacturing output would show a big downturn. And even though the number was bigger than expected, some economists said that the report was good news.
 
Controlling of Inventories Seen
 "It is encouraging that industrial production is dropping so sharply because it suggests that people are controlling their inventories very tightly," said David A. Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI McGraw Hill. "The way this is developing makes it look like we will have a mild recession."
While the fourth quarter may well prove to be the deepest point of the current downturn, economists at Salomon Brothers argued in a recent analysis that peace in the Middle East -- commonly viewed as a salutary development for oil prices and consumer confidence -- would not revive the economy.
"The recession now has a life of its own," Richard B. Berner, wrote in the firm's Comments on Credit weekly. "The economic harm done by proliferating job losses would overwhelm any positive fallout from any peace-related drop in oil prices. And plunging disposable income and mounting unemployment are more real threats to consumption and confidence than prospects of war in the Mideast."
 
Fed Panel Meeting Today
 Consideration of the economy's health will probably be the main topic of discussion at today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee.
Until late last week private economists were fairly uniform in their view that the Fed would use the occasion to endorse another easing in monetary policy and lower the overnight Federal funds rate by another 25 basis points, to 7 percent.
Inflation data released on Friday showing that producer prices rose by half a percentage point in November, a greater increase than had been expected, disrupted the consensus about when the Fed's next move will take place.
The November Producer Price Index report "may very well have impeded what would otherwise have been a further easing," Elliot Platt, chief economist at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, said in a weekly bond market commentary.
"The Fed will cut the funds rate to 7 percent," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "But they might not do it at this meeting."
At the very least, the Fed will probably delay any move to reduce the funds rate until after it sees November's consumer price data, which are expected to be released tomorrow.
Thanks to the first decline in retail energy prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait, most analysts are forecasting that the Consumer Price Index will show a November rise of three-tenths of a percentage point, half the increase recorded in October. Excluding the food and energy components, the analysts said, the index will probably register an increase of about four-tenths of a percentage point.
In addition to the fresh inflation report, some analysts said the Fed would be well advised to pay close attention to what almost certainly will be another negative report on the health of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, to be released to Congress this week.
"The U.S. economy's balance sheet is rapidly deflating," said Robert T. McGee, a senior vice president and economist at the Tokai Bank. "Under these circumstances, the Fed's and the market's focus on G.N.P. and inflation numbers is analogous to a driver concentrating on the road ahead while forces underneath the road are building to earthquake proportions."

HEADLINE: Taco Bell Finds Price of Success (59)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Twice a week, Kendall Williams, a 26-year-old department store clerk, drives to Taco Bell for lunch from his job at a mall here.
"They have fast service, and the price is good," said Mr. Williams, as he handed over $2.66 for a large burrito and a small Pepsi. "I like a change of pace from burgers, and this is a fast way to get Mexican food." 
 Taco Bell is winning the fast-food wars on the strength of such reports from the front. The chain, a subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., is making impressive gains in sales and profits after cutting menu prices. The intent has been to create the perception that Taco Bell is the chain with the best deals on meals.
Under the ebullient leadership of its president, John E. Martin, the Taco Bell Corporation, based in Irvine, Calif., has also spruced up its image in recent years and convinced Americans that tacos and burritos are as American as Big Macs, not to mention less expensive.
Last year, Taco Bell introduced a "value menu" of 59-cent tacos and other items and then expanded it in October. The pricing strategy has worked extremely well. Taco Bell is the best-performing large chain in the fast-food business, posting strong double-digit sales and earnings growth. Taco Bell's performance stands out all the more against the sluggish sales growth in the rest of the industry.
According to Restaurant Trends, a market research firm, Taco Bell is generating same-store sales growth of 10 to 15 percent annually, high above the industry average of about 2 to 4 percent. Same-store sales figures cover outlets open at least a year. Growth at many fast-food chains has suffered as competition has increased and consumers have become more wary about higher prices.
Taco Bell's systemwide sales should reach $2.5 billion this year, according to Pepsico, marking a second straight year of 25 percent increases.
But even Taco Bell, which has about 3,200 outlets, may find it hard to maintain its momentum, particularly if there is a strong recession. The company's pricing strategy is being matched by many competitors, ranging from Wendy's, which offers its own value menu, to Del Taco, a Southern California rival that heavily promotes a 49-cent taco.
Of course the fare at Taco Bell -- American versions of Mexican-style foods like burritos, tostados and tacos -- will never appeal to everyone. The chain and the entire Mexican food segment of the industry account for about 5 percent of the $75 billion spent on hamburgers, chicken and other fast food.
Still, Taco Bell, which says its ingredient costs are comparable to those of other fast-food chains, is making its presence felt. In recognizing that threat, McDonald's has moved aggressively to protect its turf. This summer in Denver, McDonald's slashed prices and then obliquely attacked Taco Bell's food in advertising. A television commercial suggested that Taco Bell had low prices but nothing to eat but beans.
McDonald's will raise the stakes early next year by introducing a new value pricing plan that may include long-term price cuts and other menu changes, a spokesman said.
More common tactics have been short-term discounts like McDonald's selling Big Macs for 99 cents, about 80 cents off the regular price. Fast-food analysts have warned of the dangers of discount pricing, which can cut drastically into earnings.
 
The Discount Leader
 Prices on Taco Bell's offerings have been reduced for the long term, not temporarily. Most of Taco Bell's products are offered on a special menu for one of three prices: 59 cents, 79 cents or 99 cents. So the chain has emerged as the industry's discount leader.
"If you look around in the hospitality industry you see a lack of differentiation and a lot of customer confusion -- 99 cents for this, 59 cents for that," said Simon Crawford-Welch, an industry consultant, who is also an assistant professor of hospitality at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas. "But with Taco Bell, I know what I get."
Kevin K. Moriarty, a former Burger King executive who is now president of the Del Taco chain, credits Taco Bell with returning common sense to the industry. He said that to attract customers many chains had added menu items that cost more and took longer to prepare.
"Taco Bell has structured its menu and operations around speed and volume, and as a result, it's growing at the big guys' expense," Mr. Moriarty said.
Mr. Martin and Pepsico, already a force in the fast-food business with its Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut chains, worked to make Taco Bell more efficient. The value menu was introduced nationally in 1989 and that year the number of customer transactions increased 35 percent. Per-store sales have also jumped considerably to about $780,000.
 
Product Innovations
 Another Pepsico subsidiary, Frito-Lay, developed a taco shell that did not crumble easily. And working with suppliers like IBP, a meat processor, Taco Bell developed a method of cooking and quick-freezing seasoned ground beef for tacos at outside sites to save kitchen space and restaurant salaries.
Taco Bell's systemwide sales for the first three quarters of 1990 are up 14.3 percent, to $1.6 billion. Operating profits from 1,900 company-owned stores and other income increased 26 percent, to $90.6 million, Pepsico said.
Taco Bell's low-priced strategy is linked strongly to efforts by Mr. Martin and other executives of Taco Bell and its parent company to turn around a business that was struggling in the years after Pepsico bought it in 1978 from its founder, Glen Bell. Mr. Bell started the chain in Southern California, and Pepisco has expanded eastward.
Taco Bell said there were several reasons for its past problems.
Many people were hesitant to try Mexican food, thinking it was strange or too spicy. The buildings were small and dour and often lacked a drive-through window. Taco Bell's roof signs reflected well the pace of business: They featured a sleeping man in a sombrero. Even employee uniforms were dull.
Mr. Martin, a former president of the Burger Chef chain, which is now part of Hardee's, joined Taco Bell as president in 1983 and began a remodeling and expansion program. He also began work on a marketing plan to convince Americans that tacos were as appealing as hamburgers.
The timing was right. Carl DeBiase, who runs Restaurant Trends, said that as Taco Bell was regrouping, supermarket shoppers were warming to the idea of cooking Mexican food at home.
"Here's a company that has been basically benefiting from the acceptance of their type of food," Mr. DeBiase said.
The plan started to work. Sales per store jumped from $539,000 in 1984 to about $579,000 by 1987. Fast-food eaters had begun to accept Taco Bell, but there was still a problem. They did not return frequently enough because prices seemed high for the amount of food they received. A taco was 79 cents. Many other items cost $1.65, and specialty items were as much as $2.99.
"So what we really were was a place for a change of pace, a place for a treat, but we wanted to be a place to eat every day," Mr. Martin said.
He said about a third of the fast-food customers account for 70 percent of business. They are the "heavy users," some of whom visit a fast-food restaurant nearly every working day. Taco Bell needed to attract these diners to increase sales and earnings significantly.
Solving the problem of offering better value to retain more customers took time. The company tried stuffing its burritos with more meat but that alienated the customers who liked smaller portions. Some restaurants also tried an all-you-can-eat promotion but that also failed.
The next idea was a 39-cent taco. "Our transactions went through the roof, but profitability went through the floor," Mr. Martin said.
But a taco at 49 cents made economic sense. Customers liked them because they could order three for lunch or take away six in box.
To give diners more variety, the company expanded the discount offering last year to five or six items at one price: 59 cents. To keep things simple -- and make more money -- the taco price was pushed up 10 cents.
 
$30 Billion Sales Goal
 When he became president, Mr. Martin announced ambitious sales goals. He predicted Taco Bell would have 4,000 restaurants and do $4 billion in business by the end of 1991. He now says he will come close to meeting that objective, expecting to have 3,500 to 3,600 restaurants doing an average $1 million a year in revenue. Now he is saying by the end of the year 2001 he will have 10,000 restaurants and other points of distribution such as stands and $30 billion in sales.
"We really think there are some large opportunities," he said. The most intriguing is a computer-driven machine the size of a coffee table that Mr. Martin says can make and seal in a plastic bag a perfect hot taco. The machine, he said, could be set up in airports, manned or unmanned, and other places to sell Taco Bell food.
Considering that possibility, Mr. Martin begins to muse further.
"If the Taco Bell brand is powerful, why could we not be 'Mexican food' period? Why couldn't there be a Taco Bell Grill? Why can't we be in the double drive-through business? How about frozen dinners? Why not? Maybe there are good reasons, but at this point, we're saying, 'Why not?' "

HEADLINE: On a Shoestring, a Catholic School Braces for Cuts

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
There is a room at St. Pius V School in the South Bronx in which everything was donated: the computers, the software, the paper, the chairs, the tables, even the dropped ceiling and the industrial carpet. The children are often supervised by volunteers.
On a walk through the school last week, the principal, Sister Mary Ellen Fuhrman, paused and reflected: "It's wonderful, isn't it? But it also leaves us with the disadvantage of having nothing to cut." 
 Like principals at more than 160 of the 243 Roman Catholic elementary schools in the Archdiocese of New York, Sister Mary Ellen has been scouring her school building for economies to try to meet an anticipated reduction in subsidies. The archdiocese, which covers Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island, Westchester and six other counties to the north, has announced that it will reduce the aid it gives to poor parishes by nearly 50 percent, from $11 million to $6 million.
Today is the deadline for schools like St. Pius to submit plans for the cuts to the education office of the archdiocese. As of late last week, however, Sister Mary Ellen's school had found nothing to cut. "We're already down to bone," said the Rev. Paul LeBlanc, the pastor of the St. Pius V Parish, which includes the school and an adjacent church, rectory and convent. He noted that the school, with 245 pupils in nine grades, has a staff of just 11 -- 9 teachers, a principal and a secretary. "Where do you cut?" he asked.
 
Many Volunteers
 The rest of the workers at the school are volunteers, mostly mothers of pupils and members of the parish church. One mother acts as the security guard, standing at the door of the faded brick school, built in 1913, which is marred by graffiti and worn by age. St. Pius is located at East 144th Street at Willis Avenue, next to a rubble-strewn lot with a sign that promises construction by a date long past.
Another mother serves as an aide in the kindergarten. Other parents volunteer in the lunch room, the computer room and the playground -- a narrow space between the school and the church that does not offer much room for play but provides sanctuary from the stray bullets and drug dealers in the neighborhood. A hand-held bell announces the end of recess. "Not high tech," the pastor said, "but it works."
 
Plumbing and Carpentry
 There is a guidance counselor at the school who serves both parents and children, but her salary does not come from the school's $343,000 annual budget. The guidance office is staffed and paid for by an order of nuns, the Religious Sisters of Mercy.
One father provides free plumbing services, another donates his skills as an electrician. The most unusual volunteer may be Juan Ortiz, 41 years old, who is legally blind and works in the parish virtually full-time as a carpenter. Holding building materials just inches from his eyes, Mr. Ortiz has constructed desks, tables and shelves for books and toys. With the help of an aide, he has installed ceilings and partitioned rooms. Mr. Ortiz said he was grateful for the opportunity to help. "I feel good about it and they feel good about it," he said. "That's the best pay I can get."
Father LeBlanc, the 47-year-old son of a carpenter, is also handy with a hammer and saw. He built computer tables for the school and laid new wooden tiles on a classroom floor.
Alba Torres, who has three children at St. Pius, is one of eight mothers who consistently spend the entire school day there as volunteers. "You can see they need a lot of help," she said. "This is not like a public school where there is lots of money to throw at the problems."
While there are volunteers aplenty, money for materials is scarce. As a result, Father LeBlanc spends a lot of time writing letters to businesses that are moving or remodeling their offices and to stores that are having clearance sales. The letters begin like this: "We are a poor school in the South Bronx and we are in desperate need of . . ."
When St. Pius submits its budget plan to the archdiocese today, there will be no cuts in the school program, Father LeBlanc said. Instead, the school will propose raising tuition $10 a month and embarking on an aggressive fund-raising campaign that will go beyond the traditional candy sales and raffles to reach corporations, foundations and philanthropists.
Tuition at the school is $75 a month, or $750 a year; the price goes to $900 a year for two children from the same family and to $1,000 for three. While the tuition is low compared to the cost of other private schools, it represents a major sacrifice for many. Seventy percent of the families in the parish earn less than $15,000 a year.
The archdiocese has grouped St. Pius with three neighboring Catholic schools -- St. Jerome's, St. Luke's and Immaculate Conception -- to map out financial plans. Since the schools are among the poorest in the city and receive large subsidies from the archdiocese, the cuts are particularly severe, reducing the total annual subsidy for the four schools from $488,000 to $244,000.
The four schools, with a combined pupil population of 1,460, held an emergency meeting last Monday night that drew more than 600 parents. While there was concern, there was little anger expressed toward the archdiocese.
"The prevailing mood is of sadness, not of protest or anger," said Father John O. Grange, the pastor of St. Jerome's. "The archdiocese has poured millions into the area. It is time for us to do more."
While the archdiocese has raised the specter of school closings, the South Bronx pastors and principals said that they were confident that the archbishop, John Cardinal O'Connor, would do everything to keep their schools open.
"We are the anchors in this community," said Father Grange. "I can't image this neighborhood without our schools. If we were to close, the South Bronx would become a howling wasteland."

HEADLINE: Brady's View Of Recession

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the economy was heading toward a significant economic slowdown, but that a recession was "no big deal."
"I don't think it's the end of the world even if we have a recession," Mr. Brady said. "We'll pull back out of it again. No big deal."
Mr. Brady, interviewed on the NBC program "Meet The Press," said the difficulty was in predicting how long the slowdown would last. He predicted the economy would return to "a good strong level some time in 1991."
The Treasury Secretary called on the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, to lower interest rates to help the economy.
"I think there's ample room for further reduction in interest rates," Mr. Brady said. "I hope he will do it."
Mr. Brady said further measures intended to help get the economy out of its downturn would be disclosed in February, but would not include more taxes. "The President is not going to raise taxes in 1991," he said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1721 words

HEADLINE: Banking's Reins: Too Tight and Too Loose

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Stunned and sobered by the savings and loan debacle, Washington is determined to protect taxpayers from a second skinning -- this time at the hands of failing commercial banks. Yesterday, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, reaffirmed that determination, while painting the bleakest portrait yet of the banking industry.
But many private economists, who are a step removed from the political scramble, caution that there is more to successful bank reform than defending the public purse. 
 America's banks, they argue, are economic dinosaurs that are rapidly losing in the Darwinian struggle to make money by lending money. If banks are to serve as reliable caretakers of the nation's money supply, they need greater leeway to cut costs and diversify services while simultaneously being held to far tougher standards of financial accountability.
It is no great mystery how that might be managed. The Treasury is said to be considering a number of proposals that analysts say would make banks more efficient, yet more responsive to safety concerns. These include tying deposit insurance to the riskiness of banks' investments and sharply restricting the sorts of investments banks may make.
But getting from here to there, argues Lawrence White, an economist at New York University, "is bound to be a messy business" as banks are forced to live -- or die -- by the economic logic of markets rather than the political logic of regulation.
Banks are go-betweens, earning most of their daily bread by channeling the nation's savings into bricks, mortar and machines. The more aggressive and efficient they are, the more money they make.
But banks are also public utilities of a sort: repositories of cash, processors of tens of billions of dollars in checks and electronic drafts each day. Dullness, here, is a virtue. And as Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution, contends, it is the tension between these two roles that has brought the banking system and its regulators to such grief.
 
Need for Security
 Economies work more efficiently when the payments system is very secure, when depositors need not worry about whether the money is where they left it and when the amount of money in private hands is not subject to sharp, unexpected fluctuations.
That is why the Federal Reserve stands ready to lend to solvent banks that are short of cash. At least in part, it is also why Washington so long tried to protect banks from competition and guaranteed most depositors against losses. It also explains why some banks -- notably, Continental Illinois in Chicago -- were deemed too large to fail, even after they had badly mismanaged their loans.
The lenders that evolved in this heavily, but spottily, regulated system were inefficient. But the system muddled through, Mr. White says, because banks were assured of both cheap deposits from people with few other options on where to put their money and a steady demand for loans from low-risk borrowers like big corporations in need of working capital and home buyers with hefty down payments.
Since the mid-1970's, however, the conflict in the banks' dual role has become all too apparent. Fierce competition from money market funds forced banks to pay higher interest on deposits and made this cost less predictable from month to month.
In the meantime, blue-chip borrowers discovered they could raise capital more cheaply by selling short-term debt securities to pension and mutual funds. "Nobody needed a bank to certify that General Motors was creditworthy," notes George Benston, an economist at Emory University.
 
Problems in Consumer Loans
 And to make matters even worse, profits were souring on loans to consumers for houses, cars and credit cards. Margins on these loans were shaved razor thin when banks discovered they could be packaged as securities and resold to big institutional investors.
At first glance, the banks' subsequent rush into high-risk bonds, commercial real estate and third world debt looks foolish. But to Mr. Litan it seems a natural response for an industry that has for so long been a creature of regulation.
Once hard times stripped away their thin veneer of capital, banks had nothing more to lose by betting the depositors' money on ever more risky projects. Indeed, Mr. White notes, they had much to gain: Fees from new loans would allow them to pay salaries and dividends while they waited for really big payoffs to restore their institutions' solvency.
Depositors never squawked because Uncle Sam insured their accounts to $100,000, sometimes for far more. And as has become painfully obvious in recent months, Federal and state regulators bred to the somnolent culture of monopoly banking were hardly up to the task of closing the bar at so popular a party.
 
Some Possible Solutions
 Congress and the White House now seem determined to prevent commercial bank depositors from following their savings and loan counterparts to the public trough. But what should be done about it?
Mr. White of New York University says one oft-mentioned fix, a doubling or tripling of deposit insurance premiums, would raise banks' costs and accelerate the decline in their competitive position as lenders. Another, a cutback in the maximum deposit eligible for insurance, would clash directly with the objective of preventing bank panics and stabilizing the nation's money supply. "No other industrialized country," Professor Benston of Emory asserts, "would allow depositors to lose money."
Yet another concept that is enjoying a day in the political sun is the "risk-related" insurance premium, or a variant, the risk-related capital requirement. Insisting that premiums be related to risk "is one way to inject market forces in bank decisions," notes Robert Eisenbeis of the University of North Carolina's business school. If, for example, a fixed-rate home mortgage were five times as risky as a short-term loan to I.B.M., let the bank pay proportionately to insure the source of the funds.
Washington is, in fact, already committed by international treaty to linking minimum capital reserves to crude benchmarks of risk: Treasury securities, for example, would require no backing, while mortgages would require a 4 percent capital cushion. A similar approach in deposit insurance would raise the incentive of banks to think twice before taking a plunge.
 
How to Rate Risks
 But Mr. White points out that the science of rating investment risks is quite primitive. Among other problems, a simple categorization plan would not penalize especially risky investments within broad categories like commercial real estate; nor would it reward diversification that reduced risks. What is more, risk-related premiums would not discourage banks that are already insolvent from continuing to gamble.
Perhaps the most sweeping approach to reform, in vogue a few years ago when banks were keen to expand into other financial fields, is "narrow banking." Banks that wanted Federal deposit insurance would be permitted to invest only in low-risk liquid assets like Government bonds, whose value could be easily tracked by regulators.
That would solve the immediate problems of securing the payments system and keeping the deposit insurance fund in the black. And "it would probably make sense if we were starting from scratch," said Paul Horvitz, an economist at the University of Houston. But today it would lead to wrenching, if temporary, economic dislocations as banks dropped their conventional loan businesses.
Herbert Baer, an assistant vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, talks of a potentially more serious risk: the development of a parallel payments system, one beyond the control of regulators or the protection of deposit insurance.
Money market mutual funds, with hundreds of billions in deposits, already serve many of the functions of checking accounts. If the assets of regulated banks were more tightly controlled, the interest banks could afford to pay on deposits would be reduced and the incentives for placing money elsewhere would be increased.
Such drawbacks have pushed analysts toward common ground, if not true consensus. Most want to dismember costly rules that prevent banks from operating across state lines or offering financial services like securities underwriting. But in return they would insist that banks erect a far sturdier wall of capital between depositors and the Federal deposit insurance fund, and require regulators to close banks long before this buffer is breached.
 
A Special Layer of Debt
 Mr. Baer goes a step further, envisioning a second buffer: a layer of uninsured deposits or private debt that could be repaid only after depositors are made whole. This, he notes, would give one group of bank investors a strong incentive to blow the whistle on incompetent practices before the bank had lost enough money to become a ward of the Federal deposit insurance fund.
Mr. Litan of the Brookings Institution would embellish this solution with an objective market test: If a bank could not issue uninsured debt for a reasonable premium above the interest rate the United States Treasury pays, it would be shut. Using similar logic, Lawrence Wall of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta would insist that banks stand ready to buy back their subordinated debt within a reasonable time or face closure.
It is widely agreed that banks are less than eager to raise tens of billions of dollars of new capital. Some would not be able to find investors and would be driven out of business.
But of all the possible approaches to bank reform, Mr. Benston argues, this one is the least intrusive and the least likely to be corrupted in practice by bankers and members of Congress. And for larger banks it would come with a special sweetener: the ability to cut costs by broadening their reach and diversifying their services.
In any case, notes Mr. Eisenbeis of the University of North Carolina, a principal objective of healthy banks is to shield themselves from the consequences of the next, almost inevitable round of bank failures. With taxpayers sure to resist picking up the tab, the added cost of carrying more capital would be a modest price for such protection.

HEADLINE: Ruling Highlights a Rift Among Blacks

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The announcement that the Government considers scholarships designated exclusively for minority students to be illegal has highlighted a rift between established civil rights groups and a small but growing number of blacks who question whether members of racial minorities should get preferential treatment.
In making the decision on the scholarships, Michael L. Williams, Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights in the Education Department, stunned the education establishment, infuriated civil rights groups and moved Mr. Williams from being a well-regarded but obscure official to a political lightning rod. 
 The decision also surprised President Bush and the White House, and with an eye to already strained relations with black voters, Mr. Bush ordered a review of Mr. Williams's action. Some Administration officials predicted that the President would reverse or water down the policy this week.
In an interview last week after the policy became the center of attention in Washington, Mr. Williams said his decision came about solely by "looking at the law," the Civil Rights Act of 1964. "We should start with the general principle that significant decisions should not be based on race," he said. "There is no grand design in all this. For good or bad, this is me."
 
Debate on Affirmative Action
 But whether or not Mr. Williams intended it, his decision exposed the heated debate among blacks over whether affirmative action policies, aimed at correcting historical segregation, have instead created an unfair racial privilege.
Kay James, a black who is a former Assistant Secretary for the Department of Health and Human Services, said the principles behind Mr. Williams's ruling "resonate very well within the black community because most African Americans don't want race-based preferential treatment."
She added: "We want a level playing field, and once given that we can compete very well given that we have the intellect, the skills, the experience to accomplish anything we want. We would have rather decisions based on that rather than race."
But Janell Byrd, assistant counsel with the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, said that few blacks shared that position.
"Our phones have been ringing off the hooks with protests from everyone from cab drivers to civil rights organizations," she said. "I think that it is fair to say that Mr. Williams doesn't represent the black community."
Mr. Williams, who is black, played down the impact of his policy, pointing out that the ruling does not affect federally backed programs for minority members, private grants directed at minority members or scholarships directed at correcting past inequities.
"I've said on a number of occasions, it is not minority scholarships that are illegal," he said, "but race-exclusive scholarships. If we base financial aid on merit and need, think about who are going to be the neediest applicants on campus. For the most part they're going to be minority students."
 
Way to Preserve Scholarships
 Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp said today that Mr. Bush would find a way to preserve race-based scholarships that are linked to students' financial needs. Speaking on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," he said that Mr. Williams's interpretation of the law did not rule out scholarships based on race and financial need. "I think that is what ultimately is going to be the case," he said.
Mr. Williams said he discussed the policy with low-level staff members and cleared it with Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos and the department's legal office, but did not seek White House approval. Mr. Cavazos resigned last week, but Administration officials said there was no connection between the scholarship decision and Mr. Cavazos's departure.
Mr. Williams said his decision on the scholarships reflected one of several top issues for his office, including discrimination in admissions, discrimination against minority students with limited English, racial harassment on college campuses and sexual discrimination in intercollege athletics.
Mr. Williams's agenda was welcomed earlier this year by civil rights and education groups who viewed his arrival as a fresh wind in a moribund agency. But these groups say his latest action aligns him politically with the conservatives who dominated the Education Department during the tenure of former Secretary William J. Bennett in the Reagan Administration.
Mr. Williams's decision comes on the heels of other actions by the Bush Administration that have upset some black voters. Earlier this year, Mr. Bush vetoed a civil rights bill, contending that it would force businesses to impose racial quotas, an assertion that Democrats denied. The issue of quotas was also prominent in this year's election campaigns in North Carolina, Louisiana and California, as Republican candidates sought to paint Democrats as proponents of employment policies that give unfair advantage to women and minority members.
 
'Help Us Disarm Racists'
 Some black conservatives argue that racially based scholarships must be re-examined or they will become the focal point for resentment by white voters during an economic downturn.
"It's a good thing in a sense that there's an attack on quotas," said Walter E. Williams, a black economist at George Mason University, "because it will help us disarm racists around the country who use these things for their means. A lot of whites couldn't get a scholarship under any circumstances, but a racist will be able to exploit the present situation by saying, 'You weren't able to get one because they're giving them away to blacks.' "
He also suggested that the debate over racial quotas and preferences diverts attention from other issues. "If the black civil rights establishment cares anything about black kids being on campus, they would better focus their attention on the grossly fraudulent education going on in school." said Dr. Williams, who is not related to the assistant secretary.
"The paucity of black kids on college campuses has less to do with racial discrimination than it has to do with them being ill-prepared by the public schools," Dr. Williams said.
 
Gains Are Tainted, Some Say
 Others, like Shelby Steele, a black scholar whose criticism of affirmative action has received wide attention in the past year, say racial preferences diminish the achievements of blacks, whose gains are tainted by the appearance of favoritism.
Robert L. Woodson Sr., the founder of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, a nonprofit organization in Washington that helps low-income people take over public housing, lamented that Republicans and conservative whites with dismal civil rights records are the ones raising the issue of civil rights and affirmative action. He argued that that stifles legitimate debate among blacks on civil rights strategies.
"If we are disappointed that Williams and a Republican Administration is raising these kind of challenges, then we ought to raise these challenges ourselves," Mr. Woodson said.
Mr. Woodson said civil rights groups should look again at whom their policies help. "To say we've got 15 slots for blacks and then not have any other definitions doesn't pit white against black, it pits upper-class blacks against low-income blacks," he said.
But Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, a moderate politician seen by many as representing a new black pragmatism, said the scholarship programs had "accomplished much toward providing increased access for minority students who seek to pursue higher education."
In a letter to Mr. Bush on Thursday, Mr. Wilder said Mr. Williams's ruling would have "a chilling effect on all minority-targeted programs," and he urged the President to reverse the policy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We should start with the general principle that significant decisions should not be based on race," said Michael L. Williams, Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights in the Education Deparment. Last week the Government ruled that scholarships based solely on race were illegal. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: San Francisco's Chinatown Seeks to Save Its Soul

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Here on the streets where tens of thousands of Chinese immigrants gained a first foothold in America, their descendants are faced with a wrenching and divisive prospect: the demise of Chinatown.
Until now, Chinatown has simultaneously been a poor ghetto of elderly and newly arrived immigrants, a center of the garment industry, a tourist mecca in a city whose main industry is tourism and the economic, social and religious heart for the estimated 200,000 San Franciscans of Chinese descent. 
 The United States' most densely populated area outside Manhattan, it is honored throughout the Pacific Rim as a landmark in Asian history, having served as a haven from racist persecution and a base where Sun Yat-sen plotted the overthrow of the Manchu dynasty.
 
Fighting Sameness
 But along the main tourist thoroughfare, Grant Avenue, stores selling Chinese products from fine jade to cheap curios have given way to camera and video equipment shops. Boarded-up storefronts alternate with stores selling the same inexpensive T-shirts sold all over town. There are outlets of hamburger and cookie chain stores and even two shops selling Wild West gear.
Judge Harry W. Low of the California State Court of Appeal and national President of the Chinese American Citizens Alliance, said, "The question is, 'Is Chinatown going to remain a unique area with a special history, food and other attractions said or just another place full of camera and T-shirt shops?' "
Judge Low's question is particularly pertinent. In 1991, 300 buildings housing 700 small businesses and thousands of low-cost apartments face state deadlines requiring the installation of special earthquake bracing. The work, intended to anchor floors to walls and prevent roofs from collapsing, will require dislocations and some temporary closures that could force many people out of Chinatown permanently. What will replace them is unknown.
The debate is so heated and confused that even community stalwarts are expressing doubts about whether the nation's first Chinatown can be saved as both a vital Asian community and a lucrative tourist attraction.
"I break out in a cold sweat every time I think about it," said Rose Pak, a consultant with the Chinese Chamber of Commerce and a longtime advocate for Chinatown. "We are at a crossroads. I've never been so concerned and apprehensive. I'm thinking for the first time, maybe it's time to move on."
 
Collapse of a Lifeline
 Change is coming from many directions, from skyrocketing rents that drive out small family businesses to an exodus of middle-class Chinese to the suburbs. But the most obvious blow to the area's economic health was last year's earthquake. Not only did it damage some buildings beyond repair and necessitate expensive changes in others, but it also closed a community lifeline: the Embarcadero Freeway, which brought streams of shoppers from the suburbs every day.
The freeway remains closed, and intense disagreement over its future has driven a wedge deep into the community.
"We had a big fight," said May Louie, an owner of several import shops and president of the new Chinatown Merchants Association, which formed in a protest of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. The break came when the Chamber stopped supporting immediate repair of the freeway, considered by many Chinatown merchants vital to economic survival, and agreed to support the Mayor's long-term plan to tear it down and create a surface roadway.
"I call them all wimps," Mrs. Louie said.
Others argue that the estimated 20 percent downturn in business after the earthquake merely revealed a set of deeper, more complex problems that the community had been avoiding.
 
Moving On and Out
 "It's a superficially simple question to ask whether fixing the freeway is the solution," said James Ho, a Chinatown restaurateur who is San Francisco's Deputy Mayor for economic development. "The earthquake simply brought a lot of changes to the surface."
Mr. Ho cited "unconscionable" rents, garbage, crime and immigration of poor, rural Chinese lacking business skills as some of Chinatown's problems.
Equally important, he said, has been the flight of the middle class to the suburbs and to San Francisco's Richmond district, known in recent years as "New Chinatown," where the children of immigrants have bought homes and opened shops catering to their needs.
"Chinatown is the mother who has created a lot of kids," Mr. Ho said. "Its demise is because of how successful it has been as the beachhead for those who move on."
 
Cleanliness vs. Sterility
 New Chinese restaurants popular with tourists and suburbanites have opened outside Chinatown, where floor space and parking are abundant. Their owners not only enjoy lower rents, but also avoid Chinatown's garbage and traffic problems.
"Caucasians have become more sophisticated about Chinese food," said Henry Chan, president of the Yank Sing company, which operates a popular dim sum restaurant in the city's financial district. "They demand high quality and cleanliness. We really need to clean up Chinatown."
Mr. Chan said he had proposed a task force to insure compliance with city sanitation codes.
But some worry that such efforts may go too far, transforming the community into a sort of Oriental theme park.
"The danger is that everyone wants to fix it up and it becomes a Disneyland where people can't afford to live," Mr. Ho said.
Ms. Pak agreed. "We don't want it to become a shopping mall," she said. "This is a living community with markets selling live fish and poultry and fresh produce on the sidewalks. Where else can you get that? We want to protect the integrity of the community and also serve the tourists."
 
Crime Grows and Changes
 Concern over the rising number of robberies, pickpocketings and other petty thefts has also kept tourists away. Last spring, open warfare between Asian gangs broke out for the first time in over a decade with street shootings that left two dead and nine wounded. The authorities believe that the killings, which remain unsolved, are part of a power struggle to control illegal gambling parlors and drug trade.
Chinatown elders negotiated a truce, arguing that the gangs were hurting their own community, Judge Low said. But changes in immigration have brought in young toughs from the refugee populations of Vietnam. These young men, who have no ties to Chinatown or its leaders, joust with others in enforcing collections and other extortion activities.
Judge Low said he recently met with leaders of New York City's Chinese-American community, who reported that despite gang activities, Manhattan's Chinatown had not experienced a similar economic decline.
"It was jam packed with activity at 10 P.M. on a weeknight," Judge Low said. "It was quite a contrast to San Francisco."
 
Nervous Hong Kong Investors
 Paul Yee, the president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association in New York, said the community was being infused with money from more affluent Hong Kong immigrants who are concerned about investing in San Francisco's Chinatown. "They say they are afraid of the earthquakes and are settling here instead," he said.
In San Francisco's Chinatown, power has rested in the hands of the 140-year-old Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, an all-male hierarchy of Chinatown's dozens of fraternal, district, family, business, and charity organizations that is informally known as the Six Companies. Its strength comes from the family associations, which own about 35 percent of the property in Chinatown.
Women have been excluded from the boards of the family and district associations and in some cases are confined to women's auxiliaries. No woman has ever held a position on the board of the Six Companies. "There is a lot of talent out there that is not being utilized," said Judge Low. If women are not allowed on the boards, he said, "new organizations will come forward and challenge them."
For now, the question has become whether the community can pull together to save itself.
"There's going to be more and more restaurants and businesses closed because they need the outside people," said Dennis Wong, a pharmacist who has owned a small drug-store in Chinatown for 20 years and who sits on the board of directors of both the Six Companies and the new Chinatown Merchants Association. "They can't get by on Chinatown residents alone. There's going to be some survival of the fittest going on."

(Photographs by Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: American Airlines Agrees to Buy London-U.S. Routes From T.W.A.

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines agreed yesterday to sell its six routes between the United States and London to American Airlines for $445 million -- the latest sign that the country's strongest airlines are taking advantage of the troubles of their weaker rivals to acquire lucrative international routes.
T.W.A.'s chairman, Carl C. Icahn, quickly made clear his plans for that money, immediately renewing his attempt to acquire Pan American World Airways. 
 Last month Pan Am agreed to sell its London routes to United Airlines for $400 million. After the announcement of that deal, which is subject to regulatory approval, American said it too was interested in buying Pan Am's London routes, and Mr. Icahn made an offer for Pan Am that its board virtually ignored.
Mr. Icahn's latest offer to buy Pan Am was not contingent on an end to the Pan Am-United deal, as he had stipulated in his earlier offer. He said yesterday that by combining Pan Am and T.W.A., cash could be raised by selling overlapping routes. "What we want is a critical mass," he added.
United States Government approval can take many months. If the deals are approved, United and American, the strongest United States carriers, will now compete head-to-head for business between London and the United States. Pan Am and T.W.A., the two American airlines that built their reputations through overseas travel but are now financially struggling, will no longer fly the most popular route.
"It is a continuation of the strong-getting-stronger trend," said John V. Pincavage, a partner with Transportation Group Ltd., an investment banking firm that specializes in airlines.
The gap has been growing between the strongest airlines and the weaker ones. Last year, Eastern Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection. Earlier this month, Continental Airlines did the same. Both airlines are owned by Continental Holdings Inc., the former Texas Air Corporation.
As the historical American "flag" carriers sell overseas routes, the buyers have been those carriers serving mostly domestic route networks. Such carriers have thrived since the deregulation of the American airline industry, which began in October 1978. United, American, Delta Air Lines Inc. and USAir Group Inc. have all established frequent service among many American cities and have each developed several "hub" airports, at which many passengers arriving from many different cities change planes for flights to their final destinations.
 
Direct Service by Rivals
 At the same time, partial deregulation of international air travel in the late 1970's has allowed more of T.W.A.'s and Pan Am's domestic competitors to offer direct service to foreign cities. American Airlines now offers, for example, nonstop service from Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina to Paris.
Two decades ago, a traveler from North Carolina would have been obliged to change planes, most likely in New York, and would probably have ended up flying Pan Am or T.W.A. across the Atlantic.
Yesterday's announcements were the latest round in a dramatic reshuffling of properties in recent months. With the sharp increase in fuel prices after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, weaker airlines were in distress even as a lagging economy led to a drop in traffic. "The assets that are the most valuable are the ones that go first," Mr. Pincavage said.
T.W.A.'s deal with American also calls for the sale of all its operations in Chicago, as well as those at Heathrow and Gatwick Airports in London, for $70 million. T.W.A., which dominates the St. Louis market, has relatively modest operations in Chicago.
 
Access Sought for Eight Years
 Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of the AMR Corporaton, which owns American Airlines, said the airline had been seeking access to Heathrow, where landing rights are at a premium, for eight years.
American said it would use existing lines of credit and would sell some common stock in the first quarter of next year to pay for the T.W.A. deal.
American's acquisition of T.W.A.'s routes into London and United's deal with Pan Am may well cause the British Government to scrutinize the impact of the changes of ownsership of the routes. "What is going to be the most interesting in all of this is to see what the British Government is going to do," Mr. Pincavage said.
Under a treaty between Britain and the United States, only British Airways, Pan Am, T.W.A. and their "corporate successors" can fly trans-Atlantic routes out of Heathrow Airport.
 
Letter to Pan Am Chairman
 Mr. Icahn, in a letter sent yesterday to the chairman of the Pan Am Corporation, which owns the airline, Thomas G. Plaskett, appeared to be increasing the pressure. "Tom, given the current state of the airline industry in general and the state of Pan Am in particular," he wrote, "it is incumbent on you and your board of directors to allow shareholders of Pan Am, to whom you and your board have a fiduciary responsiblity, to choose for themselves whether or not they wish to avail themselves of the opportunity I have offered."
Mr. Icahn said he was increasing the cash portion of his bid for Pan Am to $1.50 a share, with $1 in notes. The notes would trade at a large discount from their face value. In November, T.W.A. offered $1 in cash and $2 in notes.
Pan Am's stock closed Friday at $1.25 a share, down 12.5 cents. The stock of UAL, which owns United, dropped $2.375, to $106.50, while AMR's stock fell $1.75 to $50. T.W.A. is privately owned, by Icahn & Company, which is based in Mount Kisco, N.Y., where Mr. Icahn lives.
Mr. Icahn would not say if he was prepared to make a tender offer for Pan Am's stock if the parent company's board reacts as it did to his earlier offer -- that is, basically to ignore it.
 
Analysts See Sense in Merger
 Analysts said a T.W.A.-Pan Am merger would make some sense. "You might be able to make a stronger 'one' out of the weaker two," Mr. Pincavage said. "You could have some excess assets to sell off," he said, but added that it would be nice if one of the airlines possessed a London route.
Both the Pan Am-United deal and the T.W.A.-American deals include joint marketing agreements, in which the airlines coordinate schedules to feed each other's flights and honor each other's frequent-flier arrangements. Some routes even overlap: both include flights to Heathrow from Los Angeles and from Kennedy and Newark International Airports in the New York area.
United is also acquiring the rights to fly from Washington, San Francisco and Seattle to London. American is also acquiring the rights to fly to Heathrow from Boston and Philadelphia. Last December, American had agreed to acquire T.W.A.'s Chicago-London route for $110 million. The expiration date for that agreement, which is still awaiting Government approval, was extended by today's agreement.
 
Concern Expressed by Skinner
 A flurry of deal-making in the airline industry last year prompted Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner to send a letter to the presidents of 28 commercial airlines, expressing concern about the buying and selling of Government-granted international air route authorizations.
Lawrence M. Nagin, UAL's senior vice president and general counsel, said yesterday that he doubted that the completion of a second big international route sale agreement in two months would affect his company's plans. "United's Pan Am agreement stands on its own, and United is optimistic that Department of Transportation approval will be quickly forthcoming," he added.
Mr. Nagin declined to comment on how American's move might affect United's marketing. International routes are particularly valuable because the overseas markets are growing faster than domestic ones, and analysts said American would be able to take far better advantage of the London routes than would T.W.A., which is losing millions of dollars a month.
American has one of the strongest frequent-flier programs and computerized reservation systems in the country. "They have a better ability to fill up planes going to London than T.W.A.," Mr. Pincavage said.
 
Icahn Cites Drop in Earnings
 The London routes were probably one of the few areas in which T.W.A. was making significant profits, analysts said. Yet, Mr. Icahn, in a statement, said the earnings from these routes had deteriorated in the last two years and that, with new competition from United, the earnings would almost certainly continue to erode.
T.W.A. is currently one of the weakest airlines in the country, with a fleet of aging planes and debts estimated at more than $2 billion.
For the first nine months of the year, T.W.A. lost $54.3 million on revenues of $3.58 billion. Pan Am, another very weak airline, lost $268 million on revenues of $3 billion for the first nine months of the year.
AMR, on the other hand, earned $175.5 million on revenues of $8.7 billion for the first nine months of 1990. UAL earned $217.9 million, mostly through the sale of property, on revenues of $8.2 billion for the first nine months.
 
A Long History
 T.W.A. was one of the early success stories of American aviation. Founded on July 13, 1925, as Western Air Express, it grew during the 1920's and 1930's as a major carrier of air mail as well as passengers. Howard Hughes became T.W.A.'s principal shareholder in April 1939, and in the years immediately after World War II built a globe-girdling set of international routes. Mr. Icahn gained control of the company in late 1985 and became its chairman the following year.
A spokesman for British Airways P.L.C., the largest carrier between the United States and Britain with 37 percent of the market, declined to comment last night on the American-T.W.A. deal, other than to say, "We will remain competitive."
British Airways has a joint marketing agreement with United that the two companies have said they will retain after United buys Pan Am's routes to London.
