HEADLINE: WEST BLOOMFIELD JOURNAL;
Jews and Ethnic Iraqis: A Neighborhood's Story

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST BLOOMFIELD, Mich., Dec. 16

 BODY:
A more unlikely picture could hardly be imgined than one in which Jewish American supporters of Israel and American descendants of Iraqi Christians socialize over coffee and danish at a Jewish temple, expressing their worries about the Persian Gulf crisis with neighborly warmth.
How that came to be is a story of how two groups are learning to live together in a neighborhood, not a story about politics. 
 If any ethnic group in the Detroit area is as prosperous, upwardly mobile and communal as the Jews of Detroit's northwestern suburbs, it must surely be the Chaldeans, Christians whose ancestors came from Iraq.
The ancestors of both groups arrived in Detroit decades ago and opened small shops and grocery stores. As the families prospered, they began to migrate, first to Southfield and Oak Park, and then farther northwest to Bloomfield Hills, Birmingham, Farmington Hills and West Bloomfield.
Today, about 50,000 to 60,000 Chaldeans live in the Detroit area. The Jewish population is a little larger.
Despite striking similarities in their histories and economic progress, the two groups socialized mainly among themselves. But, increasingly in this affluent suburban area, members of the two groups are finding themselves to be neighbors, classmates and colleagues.
A year ago, a little more of the distance between the two groups began to close when the Chaldean-Iraqi Association of Michigan bought the Shenandoah Golf and Country Club, which is directly across the street from Temple Israel, a Reform Jewish synagogue.
A minor contretemps ensued. Some homeowners objected to the purchase, saying it could bring further development. It was never clear whether those objecting were Jewish, but some Chaldeans sensed prejudice.
Saad Marouf, who immigrated to this country from Iraq in 1973, said there was much discussion among Chaldeans at the time about the homeowners' motives. "When you feel you are being rejected, you feel many things," he said.
But the opposition wasn't vigorous or long-lasting, and the Chaldeans spent about $1 million renovating the clubhouse and the golf course.
During the dispute, Temple Israel leaders recalled that 11 years earlier they had had to fight a legal battle for permission to build the temple.
"They told us the neighbors didn't want noise and traffic," said Harold Orbach, Temple Israel's cantor. "But I think there were ethnic considerations."
So to welcome the Chaldeans, Temple Israel organized a program of Jewish and Chaldean songs and dances, followed by interfaith noshing in the social hall. About 1,000 people, evenly divided between the two groups, attended.
Over coffee and pastry, many temple members asked how their Chaldean neighbors viewed the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. In several such conversations, Chaldeans said that Mr. Hussein had contributed money to their churches here and that, although they had misgivings about his actions in Kuwait, they would not discuss their views openly for fear of reprisals against relatives in Iraq.
But there also was talk of possible future cooperation, like care for the elderly. As Charles Tobias, the temple's president, said, "We will have missed an opportunity to reach the full potential of this relationship if we don't pursue programs together for social action, for our youth and other areas."
And while the Jews and Chaldeans of West Bloomfield spoke of working to solve their differences, there were the inevitable thoughts of their common roots in the Middle East.
Mr. Marouf and many other Chaldeans are descended from families in and around the village of Talkaif. The village is less than 20 miles from Ur, where Abraham is said to have grown up and embraced monotheism.
"This is why we call the Jews our cousins," Mr. Marouf said.

HEADLINE: Recession Darkens Christmas Shopping Spirit

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
There is the spirit of Christmas, and in a recession, its corollary: the often dispiriting act of Christmas shopping.
"It seems a little grimmer this year," said Lilian Benesevich, 34 years old, an insurance company executive from Hartford, who has made a tradition of shopping in Manhattan with her college roommate every Christmas. 
 They sat together Saturday on a near-empty charter bus that ferried American Express card holders down Fifth Avenue free of charge. The bus paused briefly before the opulent windows of Saks Fifth Avenue, as well as those of an out-of-business B. Altman's, blackened windows that looked like a tableau of Scrooge's Christmas Yet to Come. "There used to be more lights, more decorations," Ms. Benesevich noted. "Now, it's all clearance sales. It feels like January already."
 
'This Is the Worst Christmas'
 As the number of shopping days left before Christmas dwindle, shoppers and vendors in New York and across the nation talk of spending less, hunting for bargains, cutting frills and holding back on the holidays. Retailers are projecting what salespeople, Salvation Army volunteers and shoppers already know: Money, this year, is tight.
"This is the worst Christmas we've ever had in here," said Brunie Ciuz, a saleswoman who stood idly in John Gerald Jewelers in the Queens Central Mall in Elmhurst.
The stores that are crowded are packed with people who are there mostly to look. A long line formed early outside F.A.O. Schwarz, and inside, the aisles were jammed with shoppers, most of whom wore the dazed looks of museumgoers at a crowded art exhibit. Michael Spinelli, a house painter from Cleveland, picked up a stuffed bear, examined the $110 price tag and threw it back on the shelf as if it were radioactive. "The prices are mind boggling," he said. "I just don't see that many people buying."
Impulse buying, along with what retailers call "additional suggestive selling," coaxing customers to spend more, were figments of Christmas Past. "This year we're spending our money on necessities," said Robyn Cash, a fifth-grade teacher in District 9 in the Bronx, who went to Macy's to pick out her Christmas gift with her fiance, Joe Ragins. She chose a "good pair of shoes" and a shoe tree, "to keep them in shape and make them last."
Mr. Ragins, a sixth-grade teacher, also with District 9, said, "This is the 90's, and it seems it's going to be different."
 
Helpful Clerks, Nasty Customers
 Stores are less crowded, the price of most merchandise has been reduced, and shop assistants are downright helpful. "All the salespeople were really nice; I was shocked," said Randy Banner, a 37-year-old writer from Yonkers, who had gone to Neiman Marcus in White Plains on Saturday braced for rudeness. She had found her silver lining. "In the boom market of the 80's," she noted, "essentially you gave them money, and they told you, 'Drop dead.' "
But store employees reported that their customers' tempers seemed mainly nasty, brutish and short. "People are in bad moods, really rude," said a saleswoman in the appliances department of Bloomingdale's. On a distinctly unbusy Friday night, she stood with a fellow sales clerk, and they huddled like two police officers on a slow beat. "Customers seem to be bringing their problems and all the tension over the economy into the stores."
Salvation Army officers who were camped outside, as well as the growing armies of volunteers seeking donations for the homeless, reported scant success. "It's noticeable," said one Santa Claus, a homeless man who would identify himself only as Lorenzo, as he rang his bell for donations outside Bloomingdale's. "Fewer people stop. I see a lot of people walking by, worried."
Discount shops like Conway's and moderately priced stores like Abraham & Straus were filled, often with first-time customers seeking lower prices. "This is my first time in here," said one woman inspecting baby clothes marked under $10 in a Conway's on Broadway. She would not give her name, but noted, grimly, that her company was laying off workers.
 
Bloomingdale's? Saks? No Way
 "I'm spending a lot less this year," said Norma Gorycki, a bookkeeper from Medford, L.I., whose husband, a salesman, had been out of work for six months earlier this year. She was shopping at A.&S. and said she would not even enter Bloomingdale's or Saks. "I wouldn't go there any more than I would go into Tiffany's," she said indignantly. "It's far too expensive."
Even those who looked unassailably rich said they were exercising caution. "I'm planning on spending a lot less this year," said Bill Butler, an elegantly dressed 27-year-old insurance broker, as he carefully examined $19 Christmas novelty ties at Brooks Brothers. He noted that he was planning to use only cash. "I still owe on my credit cards, and it's one way of curtailing spending." He added with a self-conscious laugh, "I am still paying off the credit cards I built up in the 1980's."
Todd Lipscom, a sidewalk vendor who had customers crowding three-deep around his table outside of Macy's, reported that his business was up, despite Saturday's rain. "It's a quick pickup," he said of the piles of $10 "Gucci," "Hard Rock Cafe" and "I Love New York" sweatshirts. "The department stores can't beat these prices."
 
$700 Worth of Swatch Watches
 There were exceptions to the general rule of moody scrimping shoppers. Roger Cyr's flushed face and his overflowing jumbo-sized shopping bags stood out at Macy's. "I've spent $500 and I haven't even hit the expensive stuff yet," he announced happily. Mr. Cyr, who works for an insurance company in Stamford, Conn., said, "I know there is a recession, but it just hasn't hit home yet."
Foreign tourists, taking advantage of the weakened dollar, shopped with abandon. "I just had a gentleman buy $700 worth of Swatch watches," George Taylor, a floor supervisor at Bloomingdale's, noted with awe. "He was from Europe. He shook my hand and thanked me."
There were also those who spoke anxiously of the Persian Gulf. One middle-aged couple from Stuyvesant Town in lower Manhattan had gone to Bloomingdale's Friday night after a movie, "just for fun." But the ornaments, carols and yards of tinsel and twinkling lights failed to lift their spirits: They were in no mood to give their names. "Things are a little drearier, aren't they?" The husband said, hesitatingly. His wife explained, "We have an 18-year-old son. If we get into a war, then nobody will have a Christmas."
Even Santa Claus was subject to mood swings. Jean-Darcel Michel, 32, who is from Haiti, vigorously chanted "Ho, ho ho," as he ice-skated in the rain at Rockefeller Center on Saturday. Off the ice, water dripping from his plush velvet suit and cotton beard, he grew more sober. "I'm very much worried," he said. "I just switched jobs, I didn't make the union and I am watching what happens next."
His three children would not get the presents they wanted, he explained, nor would he be able to afford a Christmas tree. Then he rallied, unwilling to disgrace his red-and-white uniform. "We have no tree," he said, "but we'll have a good time anyway."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
When Just Saying No Won't Do the Trick

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Narco-Terrorism
By Rachel Ehrenfeld
225 pages. Basic Books. $19.95.
Narco-terrorism, writes Rachel Ehrenfeld in this sobering if somewhat sketchy report, "is the use of drug trafficking to advance the objectives of certain governments and terrorist organizations."
In her paradigmatic case, a drug-producing subculture is offered protection by a politically radical organization. The organization sells the drugs to raise money for weapons and uses the weapons to promote revolution and to provide further protection for the drug producer. 
 "The major target for this deadly and illicit activity is and always has been the United States, as a natural consequence of economic and political factors," Ms. Ehrenfeld continues. "For the trafficker, the United States is the wealthiest and biggest consumer of illegal drugs in the world. The United States remains the 'main enemy' for the Marxist ideologue and other anti-democratic and anti-Western forces for whom drugs serve a threefold purpose. First, they destabilize American society; second, they undermine non-Marxist democratic governments in this hemisphere and elsewhere; and best of all, the results come at no cost to these regimes and their terrorist allies, since the whole enterprise in effect is paid for by the American and other Western drug consumers."
"As is always the case in these matters," she writes, "the proof for narco-terrorism is found in bits and pieces scattered across the globe. Some elements are missing. Some only can be surmised. And since I am not putting anyone on trial, the body of evidence is not airtight."
All the same, what she has assembled is "a mosaic in which the patterns are distinct enough to form substantial conclusions." This mosaic comprises countries like Bulgaria, Cuba, Lebanon, Syria, Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. Typical of her survey is the Palestine Liberation Organization, which, she asserts, earns $300 million from the narcotics trade yearly, "approximately three times what it earned from supportive Arab regimes." In Peru, she writes, the Maoist guerrilla organization called the Shining Path exploits one of the world's richest sources of raw coca to finance its war against so-called Yankee imperialism and to win over the Indian population that harvests Peru's crop and constitutes the country's majority.
But almost equally to blame is the United States itself, whose rising demand for drugs continues to make narco-terrorism work. In her long polemical concluding chapter, "The Other America: From Grass to Crack," Ms. Ehrenfeld points an accusing finger at everything from the counterculture of the 1960's to Presidents like Jimmy Carter whom she considers drug-permissive to the sort of flabby thinking, as she sees it, that promotes the legalization of drugs.
Because America lacks the will to fight back, she argues, drugs have worked their way into every crevice of the country's life, and addiction will continue to rise, she says, until we acknowledge our true enemies.
Ms. Ehrenfeld, who has an advanced degree in criminology and is a research scholar at New York University's Law School, makes a powerful case on the whole, though there are certainly gaps in her logic. She tortures her argument somewhat to explain why President Fidel Castro's execution of General Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez for narcotics trafficking, among other sins, was done in part to cover up Mr. Castro's own involvement with narco-terrorism, and she goes to considerable lengths to explain why Colombia's drug trade isn't simply built on monumental greed and corruption.
In describing the cycle of drug use in the United States from the late 19th century to the 1930's, she neglects to mention the Harrison Narcotic Act of 1914, so that one cannot tell from her text that drug consumption was legal at the start of the cycle and illegal at the end of it, or that the revival of drug use beginning in the 1960's occurred despite prohibition being in effect. Similarly, in describing what she calls the failure of Britain's experiment with legalization, she neglects to mention that in at least some people's judgment addiction and drug-related crime have continued to rise since prohibition was reinstated in 1971.
Her case against legalization in America is based on extremely limited source material, and her fanciful projection of what would happen if drugs were legalized can be refuted by an equally plausible scenario that would prove just the opposite. In fact, no one knows whether consumption would rise or fall if drugs were decriminalized, nor can one even guess what drugs would prove most popular.
Nonetheless, by calling attention to what drugs have done to societies other than to the United States's, "Narco-Terrorism" serves powerfully to raise one's consciousness of their danger. If things seem bad now, just imagine what it would be like if the country were "Colombianized," which Ms. Ehrenfeld contends is not far from remote, what with drug enforcement agents becoming more accessible to corruption, at least in her view, and prosecutors finding it increasingly difficult to find witnesses willing to give evidence to drug crimes.
In her opinion, it is not enough just to say no. "Narco-terrorism should become a major issue in bilateral discussions in the international community, including the Soviets and their explicit and implicit allies," she concludes. "Terrorist organizations and other subversive groups have witnessed the success of the drug business and the failure of democratic governments to deal with the problem; in all probability, this will embolden them to continue business as usual."

HEADLINE: GOLF NOTEBOOK;
Trevino Tops List in Earnings

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

 BODY:
Lee Trevino finished in a tie for second place in the New York Life Champions tournament in Dorado, Puerto Rico, yesterday, earning $95,000 and pushing his earnings for the season to $1,190,518. That gave him more money for 1990 than the PGA Tour's leading money winner, Greg Norman, who earned $1,165,477.
Trevino thus became the first player in the 11-year history of the Senior Tour to exceed the money-winning total of the leader on the regular tour. 
 Trevino entered the tournament with $983,018 and had locked up $112,500 more in bonus money as the leading money winner on the Senior Tour. That put him $69,959 behind Norman, who received a $175,000 bonus as the leading money winner on the regular tour.
 
Herbert Wind Moves On
 Herbert Warren Wind, the distinguished golf and tennis writer for The New Yorker magazine for about 40 years, has announced his retirement from the weekly effective Jan. 1, 1991.
Wind, who is 74 years old, will continue to serve as the editor of the "Classics of Golf," an ongoing reprint series of significant books about the game.
Over the years, Wind's finely crafted 15,000 word pieces for The New Yorker were consistently the most comprehensive reports of the golf's annual major championships.
Wind is also the author of more than a dozen books, including, "The Story of American Golf," and the co-author of the instruction classic, "Ben Hogan's Five Lessons: The Modern Fundamentals of Golf," as well as Jack Nicklaus's autobiography, "The Greatest Game of All."
Wind, educated at Yale and Cambridge, was hired by The New Yorker as a full-time writer in 1947. He left the magazine for six years to work for the then-fledgling Sports Illustrated, but rejoined The New Yorker in 1962. Besides golf and tennis, Wind also wrote about football, hockey, basketball and other racquet sports for the magazine.
"I think I've just grown older, and I'm not as capable as I used to be," said Wind from his home in Weston, Mass. "But I think I will stay in golf for the rest of my life."
Robert Gottlieb, editor of The New Yorker, said no decision has been made as to whether the magazine will continue to cover golf in Wind's absence.
"We do not feel obliged to write about golf or any other particular subject, but, of course, if a wonderful writer comes along who wants to write about golf, we may very well take it up again," Gottlieb said.
 
Feeling the Pinch
 The downturn in the nation's economy is apparently beginning to have an impact on professional golf. The ailing Bank of Boston has pulled out as a sponsor on the PGA Tour, and the Bank of Boston Classic, scheduled for July 11-14 of 1991, will be known as the New England Classic.
On the L.P.G.A. tour, the Boston Five Classic is without a sponsor after the withdrawl of the Boston Five Cents Savings Bank. The event, tentatively scheduled for late July, is also searching for a site to play on.
In 1992, two major corporations, U.S.F. & G. and Shearson Lehman, will withdraw as sponsors of PGA Tour events in New Orleans and San Diego. Both companies announced that changes in top management caused the expenditures of golf sponsorship to be re-evaluated.
 
Eyes on the Masters
 The most watched golf telecast of the year belonged to the Masters, which earned a 10.5 rating on CBS. Next was the Doral Ryder Open (CBS), with a 6.0 rating, the Los Angeles Open (CBS) and the Skins Game (NBC), tied with a 5.9 rating, and the United States Open (ABC), with a 5.8 rating. The highest rated senior event was the United States Senior Open (ABC), with a 5.2 rating, while the highest-rated women's telecast was Nabisco Dinah Shore (NBC), which earned a 3.0 rating, the 31st highest among all golf telecasts. The lowest rated telecast was the Walt Disney World/Oldsmobile Classic (NBC), which received a 1.5 rating.

HEADLINE: Sanity or Suicide on Trade?

 BODY:
The Uruguay Round of international trade negotiations collapsed 10 days ago in Brussels when the European Community refused to cut back its protectionist food policy. Denied access to European markets, negotiators from third world food-exporting nations were left with no option other than to pack their bags.
The fallout from Brussels could turn ugly, and fast. Without rules to govern trade in agriculture, services and investment, countries will be free to accuse each other of unfair trade practices, and to unilaterally impose sanctions. Sanctions, in turn, invite retaliation. 
 The threat of escalating trade wars is no mere speculation: within days of the suspended talks in Brussels, the U.S. and several of its trading partners began saber rattling.
The U.S. is reportedly preparing to raise duties on European exports of food and beverages by 200 percent -- in part to retaliate against a European ban on pork and beef imports from the U.S. The Administration is also drawing up plans to retaliate against countries deemed to discriminate against U.S. companies selling financial services; Japan, South Korea and Brazil are the likely targets.
And without international trade rules for intellectual property, Washington will be pressured to impose sanctions on countries like Thailand that tolerate massive pirating of copyrighted and patented materials.
The United States won't be the only country to engage in unilateral sanctions. That's why international rules are important, and why the trade talks must be salvaged.
All sides must give. But the Europeans must give the most. The European Community could break the logjam by agreeing to phase out export subsidies. These allow European farmers to dump surplus food at subsidized prices on international markets, devastating third world farmers. The E.C. could insulate the rest of the world from its internal food policies in another important way: helping its farmers with direct income payments rather than with production subsidies.
For their part, the U.S. and other food-exporting countries could back off from demands that would require the Europeans to cut food supports by 75 percent or more. The E.C. agriculture policy is deeply ingrained, politically and economically. It needs to be phased down over time, not dismantled all at once.
The White House could also emphasize to the Europeans that it, too, is prepared to take a political beating by pushing through Congress a trade agreement that would undo an elaborate U.S. system of quotas on peanuts, sugar and textiles.
In Brussels, the E.C. -- at the insistence of President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany -- made an understandable but hardly noble political decision to protect its own farmers rather than protect world trade. If world trade is to flourish, the E.C. will have to find ways to do both.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Major Change

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
France and Germany have decided that the best way to create a regional European superpower is to launch an undeclared trade war on the United States.
That puts in plain, stark and understandable terms the meaning of a git-GATT-gittle that glazes the eyes when called "the collapse of the Uraguay Round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade." 
 Here's how the war broke out. At last July's economic summit in Houston, France's Francois Mitterrand and Germany's Helmut Kohl assured President Bush that the talks to ease restrictions on world trade, going on for four years, would succeed. That meant a phase-out of the protection of French farmers that raised food prices and walled off our exports.
Ever the good schnook in dealing with our supposed allies, Mr. Bush embraced German unification and spoke glowingly of the new Europe as a trading partner. But France's farm lobby leaned on Mr. Mitterrand, who promptly caved; Mr. Kohl, his own election secure, put proximity over principle and rallied to the French side against the Americans. When our negotiator, Carla Hills, refused to sell out America's interests to the Euro-protectionists, the free-trade talks fell apart.
This break coincided, not by coincidence, with the ouster of the foremost holdout against a political-economic Festung Europa, "Fortress Europe" -- Britain's Margaret Thatcher. The Iron Lady's fierce stand against a common European currency, with her country's economic fate to be determined by German bankers, led to the resignation of her Finance Minister and the revolt of the Conservative "wets."
Why did this Thatcher-Tory rape delight Mr. Kohl and Mr. Mitterrand? Because "Europe" is Germany and France -- "Kohlerrand" -- followed by nine other guys, and by the English-speaking islands across the Channel that form a bridge to the United States. To the extent this Franco-German alliance needs a bridge across the Atlantic, Britain is that bridge.
The new Prime Minister of the U.K., John Major, 47, presents himself as Thatcherism with a human face. At the latest Kohlerrand conference in Rome, the new P.M. acted like Mr. Bush espousing Reaganism -- mostly hanging tough in a kinder, gentler way. Mr. Major proposed a voluntary common European currency first, essentially living together before marriage, which Kohlerrand will consider.
But on the new man's way out, France's European supercrat, Jacques Delors, hit him in the back of the neck with a brick, warning "If we need to provoke a political crisis, we will do so." The arrogance was galling: any of this British sovereignty stuff, and we'll get you thrown out as we did Thatcher.
This week, Prime Minister Major will travel to Washington to meet President Bush. He will gain deservedly admiring headlines by being the firm ally in the Persian Gulf (even British Labor, mindful of the political disaster that followed its soppiness on the Falklands, has turned hawkish). But out of sound-bite range, the engaging Briton will do his bridge duty for Der Entente, persuading the Americans to save GATT by offering help to subsidized French farmers.
Mr. Bush is expected to accommodate him, to undercut the hard-line Mrs. Hills, and to dispatch a Cabinet deal-cutter to "save GATT" before a March 1 deadline brings on the dreaded U.S. Congressional oversight. The American President is too preoccupied with his eyeball-to-eyeball confrontation with Saddam Hussein and his mouth-to-mouth resuscitation of Mikhail Gorbachev at a Moscow summit to entertain a trade war at this time.
But we have been brought to that brink by the Kohlerrand regional isolationism. The cement that has held Europe together for the past generation has been fear of an expansionist Soviet Union; the cement binding it now is envy of a prosperous America and Japan.
Not every war is hell; we need not respond to Europe's shortsighted economic regionhood by wringing our hands and predicting dire consequences in a world given over to the tariff-mongering Helmut Smoot and Francois Hawley.
Instead, realistic Americans should counterbalance Europe's penchant for protection by promoting free trade and food production within the Western Hemisphere, and by offering the incipient third grouping, the Asians, the choice of open intercourse or risky retaliation.
Europe's threatened goodbye to GATT need not mean a farewell to free trade. We can make it mean that the new world marketing order will find an efficient competitor in what used to be called the New World.

HEADLINE: War in the Gulf: Counsel of Ignorance

BYLINE: By Arthur Schlesinger Jr.; Arthur Schlesinger Jr. is professor in the humanities at the City University of New York.

 BODY:
Many factors shape foreign policy -- interest, information, judgment, vision, prejudice, fatigue, fear, panic, stupidity -- but there is one we tend to forget. That factor is ignorance -- ignorance of the challenge, of the context, of how ignorant we may be.
Take the Persian Gulf crisis. Do we really know enough about the Mideast to act with confidence? The U.S. has not had serious historic experience in this region. A few missionaries went there in the 19th century, a few oilmen in the 20th and that is about it. We have no strong tradition of Arabist studies in our universities. Most of the time we don't know what we are doing in the Mideast. 
 Recall our policy toward Saddam Hussein: support when he committed "naked aggression" against Iran; unconcern when he gassed Iranians, massacred Kurds and murdered his own opposition; agricultural credits amounting to a billion dollars; opposition to economic sanctions against Iraq until the very eve of more "naked aggression," against Kuwait.
One year, Saddam Hussein is our pal; the next, he is Hitler. One year, Hafez al-Assad of Syria is the king of terrorists; the next, he is our pal: we will repent that, too. When we got so much wrong about the Mideast yesterday, the day before yesterday and the day before that, why do we suppose we have suddenly got it right today? Right enough to send thousands of Americans to their deaths?
Years after the Vietnam War, I asked a high official of the Johnson Administration why they had ever supposed, as they said at the time, that North Vietnam was the spearhead of planned Chinese expansion into South Asia. Historians, I noted, could have told them that the Chinese and Vietnamese had hated each other for a thousand years.
My friend replied: When it came to Soviet questions, policymakers could turn to Government experts like Charles Bohlen, George Kennan and Llewellyn Thompson for informed counsel. In the case of China, John Foster Dulles had purged the State Department of the old China hands in the 50's. Our Far Eastern policy in the 60's thus plunged blindly ahead without benefit of expertise on China. So we got things wrong.
Alas, no Middle Eastern Bohlens and Kennans advise the Government at high levels today. In consequence, we are used, exploited and manipulated by wily locals in flowing robes who live in air-conditioned hotels and expect us to do their fighting for them.
If our ignorance of today's Middle East is considerable, our ignorance of the future there is total. Yet the case for war is increasingly based on the conviction that we have divine foreknowledge and know the shape of things to come. Those who claim the gift of prophecy say that unless we destroy Iraq's nuclear program, 5, 10 or 15 years from now Saddam Hussein, armed with the bomb, will terrorize the world. We have heard such prophecies before. It is the old -- I thought discredited -- argument for preventive war.
It requires particular presumption in 1990 to claim accurate foreknowledge of the future. Over the last four years, the world -- from the Soviet Union to Eastern Europe to South Africa to China to the Middle East -- has undergone extraordinary changes. What is equally extraordinary is that no one foresaw them: All the statesmen, sages, experts, all those bearded chaps on "Nightline" were caught unaware.
Some Americans were once so sure they could foretell the future that they called for preventive war against the Soviet Union and China. Does anyone regret that our Government declined to drop the bomb? And if great powers like the Soviet Union and China did not rate preventive war, why should we contemplate it against a third-rate power like Iraq?
Let us not sacrifice lives today because of a guess about what Iraq may be up to 10 or 15 years from now. Don't forget the warning of the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr about "the depth of evil to which individuals and communities may sink . . . when they try to play the role of God to history." Ignorance of the present, ignorance of the future -- these are pardonable. No statesman, no nation, can expect to know everything. But ignorance of how ignorant we are is unpardonable.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 660 words

HEADLINE: We Needn't Beggar the Old to Aid the Young

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Again, Age Beats Youth" (Op-Ed, Dec. 2), Richard Lamm uses the wrong comparisons and then gets his facts wrong.
He lambastes Congress for spending more on the elderly than the young. But a proper comparison of public expenditures shows that (in 1986) combined Federal, state and local outlays totaled $278.9 billion for the young, but $263.4 billion for the elderly. The Federal Government spends more on income maintenance and medical care, focusing on the elderly (through Social Security and Medicare), while the states and localities (with substantial Federal aid) spend more on income maintenance for the young, through the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, and on education. 
 Mr. Lamm incorrectly asserts that "the elderly have the highest disposable income and the lowest rates of poverty of any group in America." The first allegation comes from a flawed study that defined "disposable income" as amounts above 30 percent of the average for "similar families." The same study showed families 65 and older to have the second lowest median income ($13,324), while other fully adult groups had income between $25,085 (25-34) and $33,223 (45-54). Only the group with family heads 15-24 years old had lower income, as one would expect of people in school or beginning work.
The study declared that the elderly had the largest pool of "disposable income" because more of the elderly had 30 percent above $13,324 than other age groups had above their higher average income. It counted all 17.7 million people in the 65-plus group and compared that with 10-year groups (25-34, etc.), consisting of 6.1 million to 9.1 million people.
A person or couple 65 or older must be poorer than younger comparable family units to count as poor under Census standards. In 1987, to be counted as poor, an individual younger than 65 could have income of no more than $5,909; but for a person 65 or older, the figure was $5,447. For a couple younger than 65, no more than $7,641, but for those 65 and older, no more than $6,872.
In "Drawing the Line" (1990), Patricia Ruggles, a Congressional economist, argues that these different standards are unjustifiable. If the same thresholds were used for everyone, she observes, the poverty rate for the elderly would be almost 3 points higher, and 1 1/2 points above that for the nonelderly. Without Social Security, about half of the elderly would fall below their poverty line; with it only about 13 percent do.
Mr. Lamm demands we curtail Medicare for those who can afford health insurance. But Congress enacted Medicare because private insurers could not provide the elderly an affordable product; the needs-tested Medical Assistance for the Aged program (1960 to 1965) did not do the job. And those with higher earnings pay more in payroll taxes for the same hospital insurance package than those with lower earnings. Also, a serious illness often ends or curtails work income, dropping Medicare recipients down the income scale.
Yes, as Mr. Lamm asserts, millionaires could afford to pay their own way without Medicare or Social Security. However, this group is so small statistically that it makes no sense to dismantle a successful system and throw millions of the elderly into financial and emotional distress to eliminate the rich.
Mr. Lamm is correct that we shortchange the health and education of the young. But he proceeds from false premises to his conclusion that "we have to spend more money on the next generation and less money on the last one." Beating up on the elderly, as Richard Lamm and Peter G. Peterson habitually do, is an unjustifiable and fruitless diversion.
We should enlarge our human investments in food, housing, education and health care for the young. We need not beggar the elderly to do so.
 
MERTON C. BERNSTEIN
JOAN B. BERNSTEIN
St. Louis, Dec. 3, 1990
 
The writers are authors of "Social Security: The System That Works."

HEADLINE: How to Put Iraq Out of the Oil Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You are correct in "How to Choke Iraq" (editorial, Dec. 7): economic sanctions are working, to the embarrassment of the Bush Administration. Iraq will pull its troops out of Kuwait, but the sanctions are not the reason. They require time, which the Administration does not want to spend, since it has turned an erroneous defensive strategy and rationale into an erroneous and inappropriate offensive one. 
 The Administration now claims the sanctions will still permit Iraq to develop nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. If the Iraqi threat to the Persian Gulf is to be permanently reduced, put Iraq out of the oil business. This is the only message Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d need carry to Baghdad.
Iraq's Saddam Hussein lacks revenues for an indeterminate period, and the goods halt while his social and military infrastructure disintegrates. He has had zero oil sales and revenue since Aug. 3. Saudi Arabia, Iran, the United Arab Emirates and others have seized his embargoed oil market share. Production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is higher than Aug. 1.
Iraq has to do what it did in 1985: give huge price discounts and exceed any quota OPEC assigns it, to win back lost market share.
To put Iraq out of the oil business, OPEC need merely price its entire oil production at $15 a barrel or half any price Iraq asks. Potential buyers will lack incentive to restore Iraq's market share. This should be done for at least three years, preferably until 2001; it will destroy Iraq's ability to develop nuclear, biological and chemical weapons immediately and eliminate its ability to use those it has.
Washington should tell those whom American lives are defending: Implement this strategy, or we pull our troops and ships out beginning Feb. 2. If those in the gulf will not effectively and nonmilitarily eliminate a threat to their future, why should Americans die to impose an inefficient means?
 
NORMAN HIGBY
Menlo Park, Calif., Dec. 7, 1990
 
The writer publishes an oil industry news letter.

HEADLINE: Broken Contracts

BYLINE: By Irving R. Kaufman; Irving R. Kaufman is judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, where he was Chief Judge.

 BODY:
Mass dismissals of young associates at important New York City law firms are reported almost daily in the news media. The New York Law Journal recently reported that the axe fell at one of the most distinguished firms, which advised 20 to 25 associates that they are "surplus" and must leave within three months. Other news accounts speak of decisions to discharge partners.
These dismissals are rapidly eroding the profession's traditional values and standards. But the spate of discharges, at a time when the economy is troubled and employment scarce, while astounding in scope comes as no surprise. 
 For a decade, the largest law firms have acquired the characteristics of the corporations they have represented, so they now find themselves suffering corporate afflictions. Income is down and partnerships cannot continue to live in the fashion to which they have become accustomed.
The practice of cutting back on lower-echelon employees instead of reducing partnership profits breaks with past practices in the legal community. At one time, law firms took care of their own, standing behind their partners and associates through hard times. Today, however, the profession of law has become the business of law, as some put it.
Although lawyers have long acted as experts called in for particular aspects of corporate work, they once largely remained on the periphery of the matters they negotiated. But with the dramatic increase in high-priced deal-making, firms could not resist the opportunity to share in the enormous profits they helped generate.
No longer outsiders to deals they facilitated, law firms essentially became extensions of investment banks, and corporate lawyers became members of investment teams. Some lawyers abandoned their accustomed role as underwriters of fair dealing and merged their financial interests with those of their clients. The tremendous number of hours billed accounted for much of the increase in revenues.
The National Law Journal said in 1988 that in the RJR Nabisco leveraged buyout law firms reportedly earned upward of $60 million in legal fees. It said the $25 billion transaction, which took two months to complete, involved the services of about 200 lawyers from at least 10 firms.
As corporate deals abounded in the 80's, each requiring significant legal supervision, firms hired associates in record numbers. Targeting students at top law schools, firms spent untold sums courting summer and permanent associates.
Many leading legal lights reportedly receive more than a million dollars a year for their individual share of the profits. A survey in The American Lawyer's July-August issue estimated that partners at the six top-grossing firms earned from $1.015 million to $1.765 million in their most recent fiscal years.
Not long ago, these and other prestigious firms practiced a different kind of law. Their services included drafting contracts, preparing wills, supervising a wide range of problems and settling disputes. The training of associates was a more prominent item on the firms' agendas, as well. Young lawyers were carefully introduced to the profession's traditional methods and values, and partners, committed to younger members of the firm, invested a great deal of time and energy as mentors. The expectation of a long, fruitful relationship was taken for granted.
Perhaps some trimming of staff is unavoidable, but dismissals should be a last resort. Firms may be truly unable to afford the young lawyers they hired when profits from premium billings flooded their coffers. But alternatives exist: Partners could agree to compensate for shrinking profits by receiving smaller distributions, reducing administrative costs and offering associates salary cuts rather than pink slips.
While the practice of law has gone through many changes over the years, it has always held itself above the economic fray, insulated from the vagaries of the marketplace. At a time when the nation is beset by fiscal uncertainty, the legal profession should be the first to admit that perhaps it has been living beyond its means. It must set its house in order, but in a just way.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CONGRESS AND THE GULF;
Hard Question May Need an Answer Soon: Should It Give Bush a Go-Ahead on Force?

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
After months of ducking a serious debate on American policy in the Persian Gulf, Congress is preparing to face its moment of truth.
 Unless a diplomatic breakthrough persuades President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw his troops from Kuwait before Jan. 15, lawmakers expect that they will have to decide whether to give President Bush the go-ahead to remove them by force. 
 Mr. Bush has offered no guarantee that he will seek such approval, saying only that he is "considering" it. And the Democrats who control Congress have shown no interest in pressing the point with resolutions specifically ruling out force. Instead, Democratic leaders have made plans for the new Congress that convenes on Jan. 3 to remain on call instead of recessing until Jan. 23 as originally scheduled.
"The Senate should and will debate this issue," the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, told reporters as he and seven Democratic colleagues left Washington on Thursday for a weeklong trip to the gulf that they described as an information-gathering mission. It includes visits with American troops in Saudi Arabia and meetings with Saudi, Egyptian and Israeli leaders.
But much as Congress wants to play a part in shaping Persian Gulf policy, the fact is that by tradition and inclination it is a reactive institution, especially in foreign affairs.
Its role in the current crisis is defined by sometimes contradictory objectives -- exercising the war-making powers conferred on it by the Constitution, raising legitimate questions about the conduct of foreign policy, supporting the President when American lives and vital interests are at stake and getting the President to make the first move.
 
The Vietnam Experience
 Representative Dante B. Fascell, the Florida Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, describes the Congressional posture as "staying as quiet as you can while gnashing your teeth and growling."
The first objective, shared by Republicans and Democrats, hawks and doves, is a genuine desire to see the constitutional prerogative to declare war protected and observed. The Vietnam experience weighs heavily on lawmakers, even though only 23 current House members and 5 current Senators were in office when the Gulf of Tonkin resolution was adopted in 1964.
Institutionally and emotionally, Congress has never quite forgiven itself for giving President Johnson what amounted to a blank check to conduct that war. Lawmakers who were prepared to wink at the Constitution when American forces were called to action in Libya, Grenada and Panama without prior Congressional approval see the gulf as a very different matter.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's assertion on Dec. 3 that the President has all the authority he needs right now to order offensive military action is taken very seriously on Capitol Hill.
"There is no question that the President, as Commander in Chief, can order the forces to engage in offensive action, and they will properly obey his command," the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, acknowledged in an interview on the CNN program "One on One."
"But to do that from a standing start," Mr. Foley said, "in my judgment, in constitutional terms, requires an authorization -- not necessarily a formal declaration of war, but an authorization."
 
More Than a Legal Nicety
 House Democrats were sufficiently exercised by Mr. Cheney's comment to adopt overwhelmingly a policy statement stipulating that the President should not order American troops into offensive combat without the explicit approval of Congress. Although Republicans have been less vocal on the subject, influential figures like Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, and Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, a senior member of the Foreign Relations Committee, have told the President that it would be folly to proceed with a military offensive unless Congress is behind him.
The worry over consititutional requirements is more than a legal nicety. House and Senate leaders and the rank and file recognize that once American troops are engaged in combat, Congress will have little stomach to exercise its other constitutional prerogative: cutting off money to fight a war. That means that if a resolution authorizing force is adopted, any reservations, limitations or redefinitions of policy goals that lawmakers want to express on Persian Gulf policy will have to be built into it.
Those mechanics will be tricky if Congress is to meet another of its objectives: making sure that it is seen as supporting, or at least not obstructing, the President in the first major foreign policy crisis of the post-cold-war world. For Democrats this is also a matter of partisan political concern. Party leaders would like to dispel the image that Democrats are unwilling to use American military might under any circumstance.
That explains why Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Foley went along with President Bush's decision to order additional American troops to the gulf last month.
 
Support for Bush's Goals
 Party politics were also a major factor in the move by moderate and conservative House Democrats to modify the language in the House Democratic policy statment. At their behest, and with the full backing of the House leadership, the statement was amended to include a reiteration of support for the President's goals in the gulf and the initial deployment of troops to defend Saudi Arabia against an Iraqi attack.
"I've believed all along that there is something here worth standing up for and even dying for," said the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. Like other top Democrats in the House and Senate, Mr. Gephardt has argued that economic sanctions against Iraq should be given more time to work before miltiary action is taken. But that view, he said, has never been advanced to preclude the use of force, but rather to insure that it is a last resort.
In the last week, the Democratic Party's sensitivity to its image on questions of war and peace was underscored by the appearance of several prominent liberals in a new bipartisan coalition advocating the use of force to dismantle President Hussein's chemical and biological arsenal and potential nuclear weapons.
Congressional leaders are struggling with yet another difficult objective: making sure that once Congress speaks, it does so with something approaching coherence and unity.
 
Special Session Ruled Out
 This month, Mr. Foley, Mr. Mitchell and the House Republican leadership judged that convening a special session of the lame-duck Congress to debate gulf policy would be the worst way to accomplish that.
Although Mr. Bush was persuaded, there were dissenting voices from both political parties. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said the Bush Administration should have faced the question of authorization for use of force back in September, but he also blamed Congress for not pressing the point. "I think it was our responsibility," he said. "If they didn't, we should have."
Nonetheless, Congressional leaders fear that Congress does not deal well with hypothetical questions. Their fourth objective is to have the President ask Congress for something specific.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 19, 1990, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Careers;
Help Exists For Dealing With Job Cuts

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
WITH the bad news of rising unemployment, bankruptcies of companies like Continental Airlines, more corporate downsizings and efforts by companies like Citicorp to cut costs by reducing staffs, good news is hard to pinpoint. But it exists: there will be a holiday hot line offering advice for the unemployed, a hopeful statement that almost everyone who persists can find a job eventually, and a book of suggestions for those with jobs, temporarily without jobs and those in retirement.
Manpower Inc., the big Milwaukee-based supplier of temporary help, recently predicted that hiring plans of American companies "will suffer a sharp decline in the first quarter of the new year." 
 Based on its quarterly survey of 15,000 employers, Manpower said there would be a net hiring drop of 1 percent; 16 percent of the companies will hire fewer people and 15 percent plan to increase hiring. The figures indicate "recession depths" of hiring everywhere except in the Midwest with the bad news most evident in the Northeast, Mitchell S. Fromstein, Manpower's president, said.
Many financial service companies have cut traditional year-end bonuses, and other companies are not paying bonuses or have been considering a revamping of salary levels. Some have begun so-called gain-sharing plans to provide financial flexibility. Workers receive a relatively low base salary, with profit-sharing based on changes in productivity or profitability.
More and more management consulting and law firms are holding seminars to advise management on how best to dismiss people without being sued and how to modify pensions, health or salary levels. For example, the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler held one last week for human resource managers titled "Reductions in Force, Executive Terminations and Early Retirements."
On the other side, outplacement firms help the dismissed employees, but outplacement firms receive their fees from companies doing the dismissing. Basic outplacement advice to the discharged employee is not to be bitter and not to sue but to concentrate on an immediate job search. Outplacement firms provide counseling, telephone answering, resume writing, job data banks, and other aids.
One piece of good news: Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., an outplacement firm with headquarters in Chicago, said that for the fifth year it would offer free job-hunting advice by telephone to anyone calling (312) 332-5790, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M, Chicago time, on Dec. 26 and Dec. 27.
"We will provide the call-in service for two days instead of one because of higher unemployment," James E. Challenger, the firm's president, said last week. Thirteen counselors will handle the calls. The firm expects more than twice the 1,100 calls it received last year.
Always an optimist, he says that most middle managers and others can find jobs in an average of 3.3 months if they conduct serious searches, not much changed from the typical 3.2-month search in recent years. "They might have to work for smaller companies," he added, "but jobs are out there."
George E. L. Barbee, executive director, personal financial services, at Price Waterhouse, the big accounting firm, stressed the need for middle managers and clerical workers, both young and old, to begin retirement and job-loss planning early in their careers. "Immediately," he suggested. He agrees with other experts that jobs will be less secure in the future, and few workers will spend 30 and 40 years with one company.
Employees should not count on severance pay, like the typical two weeks for each year worked, he said, or on weekly unemployment compensation, which varies from state to state, to take care of them.
Mr. Barbee's operation provides corporations with advice on how to encourage workers to prepare for their future when company benefits are being cut. Savings methods include payroll deductions for savings, stock purchase plans, 401(k) plans that permit workers to set aside taxfree money for retirement and Individual Retirement Accounts.
His organization has issued a paperback book titled "Retirement Planning Adviser, 1990-1991 edition," published by Pocket Books. It emphasizes some facts that make the case for hefty savings:
*Retirees will live an average of 20 years or so.
*Inflation eats big chunks of retirement money, at least 5.4 percent in 1990.
*Employees will change jobs or careers five or more times during a working life, which means less chance to accumulate pension money.
*Rising health-care costs mean "a person should watch health more carefully and set aside a reserve."
*Housing values have stopped growing and "retirees can no longer count on homes as a ready source of cash when they need it."

HEADLINE: MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Bracing for the Year Ahead: Tighter Belts, Playing It Safe

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
"A CURTAIN of gloom has descended" on Madison Avenue, Edward Meyer, the chairman and president of Grey Advertising, said recently, assessing the current state of the advertising business. "As the industry continues to slowly shrink, there are going to be a lot of unhappy people."
Like many agency executives, Mr. Meyer predicts that 1991 will be a tough year as the industry bottoms out. Agency forecasters, like McCann-Erickson's Robert Coen, recently predicted that advertising spending will increase by only 4.6 percent next year, the lowest rate of growth in nearly two decades. 
 Even executives at agencies that have had banner years in 1990 are pessimistic.
"The best strategy is to plan on zero growth," said John M. Connors Jr., the president and chief executive of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, a Boston-based agency that saw its billings grow by more than 15 percent this year, to $400 million.
Many industry executives do not expect a turnaround to begin until late next year or early in 1992, when advertising spending should increase because of the Olympic Games and the elections.
As a result, many agencies are cinching their belts more tightly than ever. "Advertisers have become extremely cautious," said Carl Spielvogel, the chairman and chief executive of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide. "They've gone from making yearly budget commitments to quarterly commitments, and that has made it rough on agencies."
Mr. Spielvogel said his agency was watching expenses more closely than ever, mandating cost-saving practices like limiting executives to tourist class for business flights.
Burt Manning, the chairman and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson, said he was also looking for ways to trim costs. Thompson recently laid off about 40 employees each in its London and Los Angeles offices, and Mr. Manning said there were likely to be more staff reductions.
In the last few months, there has been a wave of layoffs at agencies, leaving hundreds of jobless in the industry. Some excutives say the biggest cuts are yet to come, with many expecting the new year to begin with several thousand layoffs. Some executives forecast that at least 10 percent of those working in advertising, primarily at big New York agencies, will eventually lose their jobs.
In some ways, smaller agencies may be hit even harder. Although many will manage to struggle through the tough times ahead, many executives predict a rash of closings for small and even some mid-sized agencies.
"The boom during the last decade simply created too many small agencies," said Mr. Connors of Hill, Holliday, Connors. "A lot of these agencies are now living on borrowed time."
Many industry executives say small agencies in particular will be hurt as nervous clients switch from smaller, more creative agencies to bigger agencies that have track records for developing marketing strategies that sell products. That may prove to be a boon of sorts for some of Madison Avenue's more famous names. Mr. Manning of J. Walter Thompson said that more clients than ever were looking for new agencies. "When times get tough, advertisers gravitate to the most successful agencies," he said.
They also tend to play it safe, emphasizing a concrete selling strategy over creative flair. But some industry executives said the conservative approach could backfire. "Advertising usually becomes more mundane during a tough economic period," said Jay Chiat, the chairman and worldwide chief executive of Chiat/Day/ Mojo. "But just being competent is riskier than going out on a creative limb."

HEADLINE: Albania Discusses Abolishing One-Party System

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The Communist Government of Albania has begun discussions with members of a fledgling opposition party on allowing independent political organizations in what has been a one-party country for the last 46 years.
Among the issues is how soon the current election law can be overturned. Only last month, Parliament made Communist Party entities eligible to take part in elections but proscribed any others. Parliament also set national elections for Feb. 10. 
It is not clear whether the Government can decree the legitimacy of new parties or whether Parliament must change the law.
Leaders of the five-day-old Democratic Party said in interviews by telephone that they were also requesting that the election date be postponed until spring, so that they and other opposition groups would have time to organize themselves to go against the Communist candidates.
According to another caller from Tirana, a group of Albanians meeting secretly three weeks ago formed an Albanian ecological party. The caller said they intended to make their organization public this week in the capital. Thepostwar industrialization of Albania has created pockets of severe air pollution around factories erected by Soviet and Chinese concerns in places like Elbasan, Shkoder, Lesh and the capital itself.
The discussions between the Democratic Party leaders and Prime Minister Adil Carcani began on Sunday night after a week of political unrest that climaxed in outbreaks of violence in four cities from Wednesday to early Saturday. Mr. Carcani, who became head of Government in 1982 under Enver Hoxha, then the Communist leader, told them the country's political future depended on dialogue.Mr. Carcani, who is 68 years old, said the Government would publish a decree authorizing the creation of independent parties, but his spokesman later said any changes would have to be ratified by Parliament.
 
Party Claims 300 Members
 Most of the members of the Democratic Party who have appeared in public are relatively young men. A spokesman, Genc Polo, said the party had 300 founding members, virtually all of them in Tirana.
In the last official count in 1986, the Communist Party had 147,000 members in the country.
In the Sunday discussion, Mr. Carcani and the leaders of the new party went over the outbreaks of violence that had caused destruction in Elbasan, Shkoder, Kavaje and Durres.Chemal Ljama, Albania's new chief prosecutor, said 157 Albanians faced trial on charges that they had committed acts of violence in these cities.
Gramoz Pashko, an economist who is a founder of the new party, said he and another founder, Sali Berisha, had deplored the violence in their meeting with Mr. Carcani but urged that those charged be given fair trials. Following a practice new in Albania this year, the defendants will have their own lawyers.
In a separate interview, Neshat Tozaj, a popular Albanian novelist, said he felt that the Democratic Party should have a role in framing the revised election law, even though it is not represented in Parliament.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Post Gains On New Fears of Gulf War

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened slightly against most leading foreign currencies yesterday, buoyed by heightened concern over the potential for war in the Persian Gulf.
Gold prices rose slightly in New York, up 80 cents an ounce, to $377.50, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $376.50 an ounce, up 75 cents. 
 Currency trading was sparse as participants wrapped up their positions for the end of the year in anticipation of the Christmas holiday.
But the traders said new war talk by President Bush supported the dollar, generally considered a safe investment in times of turmoil.
Since Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, traders have focused on heightened war tensions there, often to the exclusion of economic factors that ordinarily might sway the market's direction.
In yesterday's comments, Mr. Bush demanded again that the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, completely withdraw his forces from Kuwait by Jan. 15, the deadline imposed by the United Nations.
There will be "no concession, no negotiation for one inch of territory," Mr. Bush said. "He has got to leave without condition."
Mr. Bush said he was still willing to meet with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, on the gulf crisis if mutually acceptable dates could be arranged for the meeting, as well as for a reciprocal meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Mr. Hussein in Baghdad.
"The dollar is definitely being propped up by the impression that maybe the situation in the Persian Gulf is deteriorating slightly," said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank.
The dollar strengthened slightly against the British pound, with sterling closing at $1.9305 an ounce in New York, down from late Friday's $1.9370. In London, the pound fell to $1.9290, from $1.9390 late Friday.
The dollar was also slightly stronger against the yen, closing at 133.10 yen in New York, from late Friday's 132.85. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 133.10 yen, up from 131.87 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 133.15 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Friday, included: 1.4870 German marks, up from 1.4825; 1.2745 Swiss francs, up from 1.2735; 5.0620 French francs, up from 5.0405; 1.1579 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1583, and 1,122.75 Italian lire, up from 1,119.75.

HEADLINE: In Time of Crisis, Help From Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
Doris B. prefers mopping floors, doing the laundry and operating a cash register to waiting in long lines at the welfare office. But despite her willingness to work a 40-hour week, she is one of thousands of New Yorkers who are having a hard time making ends meet.
For the last two years, she has been struggling to keep up with bills that keep growing and to keep a roof over her head. 
 Yesterday, her one-bedroom apartment in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn smelled of ammonia and soap from its daily mopping. She said that she cleans it every morning after she returns from working the graveyard shift at a group home for the retarded.
"I like to keep this place spotless," said the 50-year-old woman who spoke only on the condition of anonymity . "I've lived here since 1978, and I would die and go to hell before I lost this place."
 
Her Savings Ran Out
 But earlier this year, it looked as if she might have to give up the apartment. She had lost her job of 18 years when Ohrbach's flagship department store in Manhattan closed, and she had not been able to find another full-time position that paid $20,000 a year. Her savings ran out, and she could not pay the rent. When her landlord served her with an eviction notice at the end of 1989, she was desperately looking for help to pay part of her back rent.
Doris received little help from the welfare office. She became a part-time cook for $90 a week at the Salvation Army, but this was just enough to buy food and pay part of her phone and utility bills.
Through emergency relief from the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Doris was able to receive immediate assistance -- $336.15 for one month's rent -- in January. She then persuaded her landlord to wait a few more months until her lawyer had won enough back benefits from welfare to pay her debt.
The money that helped Doris keep her apartment came from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. For the last 79 years, the fund has been raising money for the sick and the needy of New York.
 
Washing, Dressing and Feeding
 The proceeds from this year's Neediest Cases appeal, which began last month, will go directly to seven charities, including the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. The New York Times pays the entire overhead cost for the campaign.
Money from the fund gives people a helping hand in times of dire need, but it is often only a brief respite in their struggle to pay the bills.
Doris now has a full-time job but she is making $8,000 less than she did at Ohrbach's. She does not complain about the strain of her new job at the group home. Instead, she said yesterday, she likes the hugs the clients give her, and she shrugged off the unpleasant tasks -- taking them to the bathroom and washing, dressing and feeding them.
But Doris said she was tired of having to work so hard for such limited results. Financially, she is barely keeping her head above water.
 
Always Behind in the Bills
 There are three bowling trophies in her living room, but she has not been able to play for more than a year.
More than a third of her $12,000 yearly salary must go to rent. She is still behind on her utility and phone bills from her years of unemployment. She owes money for a loan she received to go to a vocational school. She completed the six-month nurse's aide program and has applied at a half-dozen hospitals, but that has not led to a job. She has no health insurance and must pay for the medicine her unemployed husband needs for his arthritis.
"I'm behind all the time," she said. "I'm having a hard time now, but I'm the only one I can turn to."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Says Cultural Agency Will Be Spared in Reorganization

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Reacting to the first tremors created by his administration's plans for a major reorganization of New York City's government, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the Department of Cultural Affairs would not be eliminated as part of an effort to trim administrative fat.
With the city facing huge budget cuts, officials said last week that they were examining the functions of all 60-odd city agencies. The reorganization could meld a number of smaller agencies into larger ones, eliminate some departments and consolidate the functions of others. 
 While the process holds the promise of savings, it is fraught with political peril: Every agency has its own constituency and can be expected to fight for survival.
As word spread last weekend that the major function of the Department of Cultural Affairs -- awarding grants to cultural groups -- could be shifted to another agency, alarms sounded in the arts community that such a move would send a negative signal about the importance of the arts in the city.
 
Arts, Not Alps
 Yesterday, at a breakfast forum for businesses sponsored by The New York Post, Mr. Dinkins said the Department of Cultural Affairs would be spared changes but that his administration was still committed to a reorganization. The measures would be among the first to help bridge a $1.3 billion budget gap for the fiscal year that begins July 1.
"I think it is appropriate that we examine our structure to see whether or not we might think differently and in a more effective fashion by some consolidations and downsizing," Mr. Dinkins said. "If we have several administrations that could be condensed into one, we ought to consider it."
But the Mayor added, "When one looks at the budget of Cultural Affairs, I do not think it would be wise to fold that into the Mayor's office, as has been the suggestion of some.
"I am mindful, as one person put it, that people don't come to New York to ski and look at the Alps," Mr. Dinkins said. "Among the reasons they come to New York is the great cultural center that we have here -- museums and theater and on and on and on."
Tourism is worth between $7 billion and $10 billion a year to the city's economy, he said.
 
Arts Officials Relieved
 Linda Blumberg, an assistant commissioner of cultural affairs, said yesterday that the department was relieved by the Mayor's statements. Organizations like the Cultural Institution Group and the Theater Development Fund had noted that only about $2 million of the department's $90 million budget goes to administration.
"I am aware of the difficulties the Mayor faces in meeting budget gaps," she said. "He is also aware of the role that culture plays in the city."
Ray Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private government watchdog group, said the outcry over the Department of Cultural Affairs illustrates how extraordinarily sensitive the reorganization will be.
"This is going to be a real good test of how serious people are about political reform," he said. "Unless a lot of people get on the bandwagon, narrow political interests may carry the day.
"The simple fact of the matter is that the present structure of New York City government is no longer sustainable," Mr. Horton said. "Logically, rationally, you can see a lot of overlap. You can even see some agencies that don't do anything of high social utility, but you have people who don't want to be out of work."
 
Union Concerns
 Stanley Hill, president of the 140,000-member District 37 of the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees, said yesterday that he was awaiting a meeting with city officials to express his concern about possible layoffs resulting from the reorganization.
Complaining that the union had been left in the dark on the issue, Mr. Hill said: "It's a bad way to run a government. It has an impact on our contract; it has an impact on workers."
In all, the future of about 15 smaller city agencies, like the Board of Standards and Appeals and the Department of Records and Information Services, is being scrutinized. More broadly, city officials say they are looking at administrative functions like grant applications, press operations, legal and accounting services and intergovernmental affairs to determine the amount of overlap between agencies.

HEADLINE: Stocks Ease in Slow Trading; Dow Off 0.49

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices weakened yesterday in the slowest day in almost a month, with 1,054 issues ending lower, although the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chips fell only 0.49 point, to 2,593.32.
Activity slid to 118.6 million shares, the quietest since Nov. 23, the day after Thanksgiving Day, when trading dropped to 63.4 million shares. On Friday, volume totaled 150.9 million shares. 
 Heavy buying in the final half hour helped lift the Dow from a slump that had pushed it down nearly 19 points early in the day.
Analysts blamed the market drop on uncertainty over both the Middle East and interest rates.
Crude oil prices, the continuing barometer of the Gulf crisis, rose 50 cents, to end at $27.05 a barrel.
"The market's marking time," said David B. Bostian Jr., chief economist and strategist of Jesup, Josephthal & Company, "until we see what policy initiatives come from the Fed's Open Market Committee meeting" today.
He noted that there has been some speculation that the Fed might cut the discount rate, the rate the Fed charges banks for loans. He argued that even if the Fed did not cut the discount rate, it might cut the Federal funds rate, the rate that banks charge one another for overnight loans.
Also weighing on the market, he said, was the uncertainty created by the impasse between the United States and Iraq on a meeting date to discuss the Gulf crisis.
Kenneth Spence, director of technical analysis for Salomon Brothers, noted that "the broad market was a lot weaker than the blue chips, and the ratio of downside to upside volume was two-to-one on the downside."
"It suggests that the broad market was under selling pressure throughout the session," he said, "while the blue chips rallied at the close."
 
The Triple Witching Hour
 He said that with the triple witching hour coming Friday, when stock options, index options and index futures expire simultaneously, the rally seemed to have come from buying programs.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity, said two selling programs much earlier in the day lopped fewer than four points off the Dow, while the sole buy program, lifting the market barely 3 points, came at noon.
Mr. Spence said he did not see much institutional buying and thought that if the rally did not originate with program buying, it might have come from asset allocators, advisers or institutions that move money quickly from one market to another on the basis of their view of market valuations.
He said he thought the market would be "choppy" for the rest of the year and "finish the year higher -- somewhere near 2,685."
Chrysler topped the Big Board's most active list, rising 5/8, to 12 7/8 in heavy trading after news that Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast investor who sold MGM/UA last month for $1.3 billion, now owns 9.8 percent of the auto producer.
Bank stocks fell broadly amid continued market nervousness, with Citibank off 3/8, to 13 3/8; First Interstate 1 1/8, to 24 1/8; Manufacturers Hanover 1 1/4, to 19; Comerica 1 1/4, to 41 1/2, and Crestar 1 3/4, to 14 1/2.
