HEADLINE: USE FORCE IN GULF, 14 EX-AIDES URGE

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Fourteen former senior Government officials, most of whom worked on national security affairs, urged today that the Administration use military force shortly after the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
The form of their message was a letter to Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, that was made public today with the intent of countering recent testimony by two former Chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. William J. Crowe and Gen. David Jones. In comments before a Congressional committee the two men and others pressed the Administration to postpone military action against Iraq and give economic sanctions a year or more to work. 
 The former officials who signed the letter to the Iraqi Foreign Minister included two former White House national security advisers, Richard V. Allen and Robert C. McFarlane, and a former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Thomas H. Moorer.
 
View Directed to Baghdad
 The view in which they concurred was directed to Mr. Aziz to make clear to Baghdad that several former American policy makers favored a quick, decisive military strike if Iraq did not leave Kuwait by the deadline.
Robert F. Ellsworth, who was a Deputy Defense Secretary in the Ford Administration, said in an interview that he had organized the letter-signing effort in the last week to balance "the effects of some testimony over the last couple of weeks to let sanctions carry the full burden."
In their letter, the officials urged Mr. Aziz "to advise President Saddam Hussein that such misguided views should not stand in the way of the use of all necessary means to enforce the U.N. Security Council's resolutions."
Mr. Ellsworth, a former Republican Representative from Kansas and United States Ambassador to NATO, said: "Letting sanctions carry the whole burden is very, very damaging to the President's effort to get Saddam out of Kuwait without a war. It sends the wrong signals that he can just sit there and not worry about a credible threat of military attack."
Delaying military action indefinitely after Jan. 15 would erode the credibility of the United States-led coalition against Iraq and wear thin the patience of the American people, the officials said in interviews.
 
Growing National Debate
 They added their voices to the national debate that began growing on Nov. 8 when President Bush announced a wave of reinforcements that would swell the size of American forces in the Persian Gulf to 400,000 by late January.
Some experts, like former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, warn that there is no guarantee that sanctions will succeed. Others, including former Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger and former national security adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski, argue that sanctions should be given a chance to work before waging a costly war.
Administration officials like Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, have testified that sanctions are working but carry no assurance that they will force Iraq to withdraw.
In addition to Mr. McFarlane and Mr. Allen, who served as national security advisers to President Reagan, and Admiral Moorer and Mr. Ellsworth, the letter was signed by former Air Force Secretary Thomas C. Reed, former Navy Secretary John F. Lehman and a former commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. P. X. Kelly.
The officials also included Vice Adm. John J. Shanahan, former commander of the Navy's Second Fleet; Brig. Gen. James D. Hittle, a former Assistant Secretary of the Navy; Brig. Gen. Hugh S. Aitken, a former Marine officer; Robert H. Knight, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York; Robert D. Blackwill, former special assistant to President Bush for national security; Roland A. Paul, former counsel to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and William J. Taylor, former director for national security studies at the United States Military Academy.

HEADLINE: F.D.I.C.'S CHAIRMAN SUGGESTS NEW FEES TO INSURE DEPOSITS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The day after he predicted that 1990 and 1991 would be the worst years ever for the program that protects deposits at failed banks, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, told Congress today that one way to strengthen the ailing insurance fund would be a $25 billion assessment on the industry and an 18 percent increase in the contributions banks make to the program.
Although Mr. Seidman stopped short of endorsing such a plan outright, he offered no other alternatives in an appearance before a House banking subcommittee, saying only that a proposal to reorganize the fund would be presented next month. 
 He outlined a plan calling for a one-time assessment of $1 for every $100 in deposits insured by the fund early next year and an increase within the next two years on bank premiums to 23 cents for every $100 in deposits insured. Premiums are scheduled to rise next month to 19.5 cents for every $100 in deposits, from 12 cents.
 
More Failures Feared
 Although the industry earned only about 60 cents per $100 of deposits in the first nine months of this year, Mr. Seidman predicted that the assessment "would add only marginally to bank failures andfailure-resolution costs." Economists, however, told the subcommittee that it could be quite damaging and might lead to more failures, and hence to losses to the fund of $3 billion to $8 billion.
How such an assessment would actually affect banks' financial statements is uncertain, because the Government has not yet decided how banks would account for it. The Treasury and banking regulators are considering whether to let banks count some of the assessment on their books as capital by giving them stock in the insurance fund or to let them recognize the cost of the assessment over a long period of time.
Because the plan does not directly involve taxpayer money, lawmakers are likely to regard it favorably. But the burden would probably be borne by banks' depositors and customers. who could be expected to earn less interest on deposits and pay higher fees and interest charges for borrowing as banks pass along their higher costs.
To make the assessment more palatable to the industry, Mr. Seidman held out a political carrot: a promise that he and the Bush Administration would offer support for rolling back Federal laws written during the Great Depression that limit commercial banks' ability to trade and underwrite corporate securities and to conduct business across interstate lines.
Mr. Seidman also said that regulators were preparing a policy to restrict the ability of troubled banks to declare dividends as a way of limiting bank failures and losses for the fund.
 
Payments Based on Health
 Another likely aspect of the overhaul of the bank insurance fund would be to charge banks premiums based on their financial health. On Tuesday, the board of the F.D.I.C. is expected to consider asking Congress to grant it the authority to change the premiums from the current flat-fee structure.
Mr. Seidman conceded that the plan he had outlined, which would raise $44 billion through the end of 1993, still might not be enough to protect the insurance program if a deep recession struck.
"There are scenarios under which the fund could become insolvent," he said.
On Sunday, Mr. Seidman said that 1990 and 1991 would see a drain of at least $9 billion from the insurance fund caused by collapsing institutions, leaving it with about $4 billion by the end of next year, much of which might not be readily available in cash.
He foresaw about 180 bank failures in 1991 involving assets of $70 billion. Those estimates are based on information provided by bank examiners and represent the worst institutions among about 1,000 troubled banks, he said.
 
Big and Small Banks
 Regulators calculated what those bank failures would mean for the fund based largely on historical patterns at comparable banks, Roger Watson, director of research and statistics at the F.D.I.C., said. Generally, smaller institutions cost the Government about 25 percent of their asset base to rescue, while larger banks, which have value in their franchises beyond their asset bases, cost 10 percent to 17 percent.
Most of the failures would probably be smaller institutions, Mr. Watson said.
The F.D.I.C. has estimated that reimbursing depositors of the 180 banks expected to fail would cost the fund $10 billion, and that it would receive premiums of $5 billion at the same time, creating a loss for 1991 of $5 billion.
The fund would be left with a balance of $4 billion, but because not all those assets are immediately marketable and because it is required to keep some in reserve, the fund would actually have considerably less than $4 billion in cash.
In addition, Mr. Seidman said the fund was facing possible additional liabilities of $6 billion to $7 billion because it had agreed to buy back certain assets from failed banks that their acquirers may not want to hold. These contingent liabilities have not been reflected on the fund's current balance sheet.
 
Congressional Study
 Much of Mr. Seidman's testimony was in response to a study commissioned by the banking subcommittee and produced by three economists who formerly worked for the Government: James R. Barth of Auburn University; R. Dan Brumbaugh Jr., a California consultant, and Robert E. Litan of the Brookings Institution.
The three economists predicted that "by conservative estimates," the bank insurance fund would face costs of $31 billion to $43 billion from collapsed banks through 1993. At the upper limit, the study found that the costs of bailing out the banking industry in a severe recession could be $63 billion.
During the same period, the economists estimated, new money added to the fund would be $28 billion to $31 billion if the premiums did not rise above 23 cents for each $100 in deposits.
The economists did not have access to the examination reports used by the F.D.I.C. Instead, they looked at publicly filed information about the banks. They compared the historic relationship between capital levels at banks and their failure rates over the last three years and extrapolated from that information a probability of failure that they then applied to the industry.
Mr. Brumbaugh said that many banks "would not be able to survive" a 1 percent assessment. He said he opposed the assessment and instead favored a financing of the fund through a borrowing of the Treasury Department of up to $50 billion.
Mr. Litan, who favors either a Treasury borrowing or a one-time assessment, estimated that the assessment could generate $3 billion to $8 billion in additional losses to the fund by forcing more marginal institutions into insolvency.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: NAICS524128 OTHER DIRECT INSURANCE (EXCEPT LIFE, HEALTH & MEDICAL) CARRIERS (94%); SIC6399 INSURANCE CARRIERS, NEC (94%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: Regan Sees New Shortfall In the Budget

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Just three days after New York State lawmakers grudgingly approved $1 billion worth of budget cuts, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said today that the state was facing a new budget shortfall of up to $500 million.
The prediction publicly confirmed what many officials in Albany were saying privately last week: Despite the budget cuts, the state is likely to run short of cash by the end of the fiscal year on March 31. 
 Based on tax collections through November, Mr. Regan estimated today that state revenues for the year would be $200 million to $500 million less than state lawmakers assumed last week when they approved the largest package of mid-year spending cuts in New York's history.
 
Three Revenue Sources Decline
 Continuing their steady decline, the state's three major sources of revenue -- sales, corporate and income taxes -- all fell short of projections in November, even though the projections had been revised at the beginning of the month to reflect the onset of a recession.
"The prospect that the economy is going to revive to alter this erosion is very dim," said a spokesman for the Comptroller, Marvin G. Nailor. "We're saying that if things continue the way they're going, we're going to be short another $200 million to $500 million."
Mr. Regan also said today that the state was confronting a budget gap for the coming fiscal year of $4 billion, or $1 billion more than he predicted two months ago. This gap represents the difference between the amount the state expects to collect from existing taxes and the amount it expects to spend to maintain existing programs.
"The continuing erosion of the three major taxes and anticipated further decline in revenues would cause me to believe that my October estimate of a $2 billion to $3 billion shortfall is now closer to a range of $3 billion to $4 billion," Mr. Regan said. A $4 billion shortfall represents 8 percent of the state's $49 billion budget.
In Albany, where a new budget gap seems to be announced with every change of season, the news from the Comptroller's office was treated as no more surprising than the weekend's snowstorm. Many officials, adopting an I-told-you-so stance, said they had expected the bad news all along.
 
Leaders Not Surprised
 "Last month I said that our own fiscal analysts believed that the deficit for this year would probably be more than $1 billion," said the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "I see nothing in the Comptroller's report that leads me to believe anything different."
Anne Crowley, a spokeswoman for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, said, "We said all along that it could get worse."
Indeed, implicit in the budget-cutting plan proposed by the Governor last month and finally approved by the Legislature last week was the assumption that the state's financial condition would continue to erode as the year wore on. By the Governor's most recent estimate, the state's budget shortfall amounted to $900 million; the budget cuts, in contrast, amounted to $1 billion.
But even as they were congratulating themselves on facing up to the state's grim fiscal realities last week, many lawmakers acknowledged that the budget cuts they were imposing on programs ranging from education to road repairs would not be sufficient to avert a deficit. Rather than contemplate additional cuts, however, they made a concerted effort to recess for the holidays before the Comptroller could release his report.
 
Full Picture Awaited
 Despite Mr. Regan's projections, budget analysts in both the Governor's office and the State Legislature cautioned today that the full extent of the state's fiscal problems would not be known for at least six weeks.
Both December and January are important tax collection months, with the state expecting to collect almost one-quarter of its total revenues for the year, and until the receipts are in, officials can only speculate about the size of the deficit.
Cuomo adminstration officials said today that the Governor would wait for more financial data before taking steps to close the growing budget gap. They said Mr. Cuomo had already ordered his budget office to prepare plans for cuts, some of which he could impose administratively, while others would require legislative action.
One financial analyst was critical of this approach, saying the Governor should take action now to stave off a deficit.
 
Immediate Cuts Urged
 "This isn't the last time we're going to talk about deficits this year," said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group sponsored by businesses. "The Governor should adopt the highest number and make the necessary cuts immediately."
Even a shortfall of $200 million, at the low end of the Comptroller's projection, would present Mr. Cuomo with a vexing set of choices in a fiscal year like this one, when the state has already cut spending and announced plans to lay off 2,000 workers. A shortfall of $500 million could force the Governor to borrow money to make it through the end of the year, something he has done in each of the last two years but has pledged not to do again.

HEADLINE: In National Speech, Cuomo Says He Is a Budget-Cutter

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo used a major speech here today to position himself as a Washington outsider whose experience as a born-again budget-cutter contrasts with President Bush's stewardship of the ailing national economy.
In a speech at the National Press Club, Mr. Cuomo accused Mr. Bush of ignoring the country's economic downturn while being preoccupied with the Persian Gulf crisis. He urged a shift in national focus toward domestic policy, which would necessarily form the rationale for any Cuomo Presidential bid. 
 "There is a long-term national economic crisis as dangerous to this country as Saddam Hussein," he said. "But so far, there is little evidence that Washington is prepared to deal with it."
Although he asserted that Mr. Bush should change course on the economy, he provided few details about the alternate path he might favor.
 
A National Platform
 The address was Mr. Cuomo's first on national economic policy since he was re-elected to a third term on Nov. 6. Many political analysts say they believe that if Mr. Cuomo is to run for President, he must decide by this summer to build a credible organization.
Whenever asked, Mr. Cuomo maintaines that he has no plans to enter the 1992 race. He has sent no signals otherwise, at least when his actions are measured against those of four years ago, when he chose not to run.
But he came here knowing that a speech to the press club, which often provides a platform for candidates-in-waiting, would do little to muffle speculation about a potential Cuomo candidacy. And his speech, after disappointing re-election results -- he was expected to get more than 53 percent of the vote -- allowed him to reassert his position as a national Democratic spokesman.
Mr. Cuomo said that voters' anger at the polls last month represented cries of middle-class anguish about the recession. Average Americans, he said, have figured out that the promises of supply-side economics were false.
 
Importance of Deficit Cutting
 He called for new recognition in Washington that economic growth depends not only on creating wealth, but also on improving the quality of the country's work force, schools, housing and transportation.
He criticized the White House, Democratic leaders and Congress for not doing enough in this year's budget negotiations to reduce the deficit, and complained that the country's borrowing spree had done little to strengthen its long-term economic prospects.
"That's the part that gets me and most governors," he said. "Two hundred billion dollars a year in interest that doesn't put a single computer into the hands of a single student, fund a single hour of research or provide a single meal to one hungry person."
Mr. Cuomo conceded that there was little Washington could do to forestall a recession next year, but said deficit reduction will be the key to stimulating the economy.
 
States' Budget-Cutting Example
 On that subject, he suggested repeatedly that the recent experience of cuting budgets in New York and other states could provide an example.
Mr. Cuomo and the New York State Legislature last week closed a $1 billion budget gap largely through spending cuts. The cuts were made in a budget that included a record tax increase for the second year.
The State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, announced today that new revenue forecasts suggest the gap could grow by another $500 million by the end of the fiscal year, in March.
"Don't tell me it's hard," Mr. Cuomo said. "I know it is. But that's why you're there. It is not a lack of options. It is not a lack of ideas. It is simply unwillingness so far to make the hard decisions."

HEADLINE: Tax Exemptions of Nonprofit Hospitals Scrutinized

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Congressional investigators have found that many private nonprofit hospitals provide charity care worth less than the financial benefits they get from their tax-exempt status.
Federal and state tax officials have begun systematically auditing nonprofit hospitals, prodding them to provide more charity care in return for their tax exemptions. The Internal Revenue Service has formed teams of experts to examine nonprofit hospitals, in a program coordinated from the agency's headquarters in Washington. 
 In Congress, several lawmakers have introduced bills to establish strict standards for the amount of charity care that must be provided by nonprofit hospitals.
The Attorney General of Texas has just sued the 1,527-bed Methodist Hospital of Houston, one of the nation's biggest private nonprofit hospitals, charging that it did not provide enough charity care to justify its exemption from local property taxes.
In Erie, Pa., Hamot Medical Center recently lost its exemption from local property taxes, and a state judge said its parent corporation used the hospital as a "money tree" to generate profits for investment in real estate, including a marina near Lake Erie. In Utah, county officials are trying to tax at least eight nonprofit hospitals.
Federal law does not say exactly how much charity care tax-exempt hospitals must provide. They qualify for an exemption only if they are organized and operated exclusively for charitable purposes. I.R.S. rulings say tax-exempt hospitals must be able to show that they are operated for the benefit of the community as a whole. And charity care is one aspect of such service to the community, the rulings say.
 
'One Way to Provide Benefit'
 "We are encouraging hospitals to provide greater benefit to the community," said Marcus S. Owens, a senior I.R.S. official responsible for tax-exempt organizations. "And charity care is one way to provide benefit to the community. We want to make sure these hospitals operate as they said they would when they got their exemptions."
Health-care economists and Federal officials say it is often hard to distinguish between tax-exempt nonprofit hospitals and investor-owned profit-seeking hospitals. In a fiercely competitive environment, many nonprofit institutions now engage in commercial activities, establish profit-seeking subsidiaries, form joint ventures with private physician groups and try to expand their share of the local health-care market.
Timothy J. Sullivan, a lawyer at the I.R.S., said Federal tax auditors wanted to know if nonprofit hospitals provide emergency room care to all "regardless of ability to pay," if they turn away uninsured patients and if they exclude "any segment of the community." He said the Government had received information that some nonprofit hospitals discriminate against Medicaid patients.
Public health and tax officials say there is a big need for charity care because more than 31 million Americans have no private or public health insurance.
James J. McGovern, assistant chief counsel of the I.R.S., said many people mistakenly assumed that the need for free inpatient care would wither away after Medicaid and Medicare were created in 1965. But, he said, the need for charity care remains substantial and has been heightened by the cost-control efforts of Federal agencies and private insurers, which have given all hospitals strong incentives to economize in the last five years.
 
$4.5 Billion in Lost Revenue
 Nonprofit hospitals are big business. The 3,200 private nonprofit hospitals constitute less than 1 percent of all charitable organizations in the United States, but they account for 43 percent of all the revenues of such organizations ($115 billion of $268 billion) and 32 percent of the total assets ($135 billion of $423 billion), Mr. McGovern said.
The private nonprofit hospitals account for 56 percent of the nation's hospitals. Nonprofit hospitals, which are not barred from taking paying patients, can and do make profits, defined as a surplus of revenues over expenses. But the surplus is supposed to be reinvested to further the hospital's charitable purpose and cannot be distributed to shareholders or others who have "a personal and private interest" in the hospital. The I.R.S. has said the surplus may be used for "improving facilities, equipment, patient care and medical training, education and research."
About 720 hospitals in the nation, accounting for 13 percent of the total, are owned by investors. An additional 1,789 hospitals, or 31 percent, are public, operated by Federal, state or local government agencies; they are generally not operated for a profit.
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, estimated that the Federal Government loses $4.5 billion a year in revenue as a result of the tax exemption for nonprofit hospitals. State and local governments together lose perhaps $3.5 billion.
Until this year, the I.R.S. rarely investigated nonprofit hospitals. But Steven D. Kohlert, senior vice president of Intermountain Health Care, said a team of I.R.S. agents had conducted "a top-to-bottom audit" of his company over the last nine months, reviewing books and records, examining scores of physician contracts, visiting emergency rooms and measuring the volume of indigent care. Intermountain is a Salt Lake City holding company with 24 nonprofit hospitals in Utah, Idaho and Wyoming.
A recent study by the General Accounting Office found there was "little difference in overall rates of uncompensated care" provided by nonprofit hospitals and by those that seek to make a profit. Forty-three percent of private nonprofit hospitals in New York, and 71 percent in California, provided charity care worth less than they would have paid in Federal and state taxes if they were not exempt, it said.
"For many nonprofit hospitals, the link between tax-exempt status and charitable activities for the poor or underserved is weak," said Mark V. Nadel, who supervised the accounting office study. "If Congress wishes to encourage nonprofit hospitals to provide charity care and other community services, it should consider revising the criteria for tax exemption."
 
Push in Congress
 Representative Edward R. Roybal, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging, has introduced legislation to establish stringent criteria for the tax-exempt status of private nonprofit hospitals, including numerical standards for charity care.
Representative Brian Donnelly, Democrat of Massachusetts, has introduced a bill that would require nonprofit hospitals to provide certain amounts of charity care as a condition of being allowed to issue tax-exempt bonds, a major source of financing for nonprofit hospitals.
Profit-seeking hospitals look enviously at their tax-exempt rivals. James D. Baker, executive director of the Biloxi Regional Medical Center, a 153-bed privately owned for-profit hospital in Mississippi, said: "Some private nonprofit hospitals are making unbelievable amounts of money, not paying any taxes and not using the money for research, education or charity care. They have an unfair advantage."
Hospitals compete aggressively for patients, and the I.R.S. says some offer cash bonuses, loans and other financial incentives to attract doctors who will admit patients to the hospital. But tax officials say such arrangements by private nonprofit hospitals may violate Federal law, which says that no part of the net earnings of a tax-exempt corporation may "inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual."
"Driven by their need for access to patients, hospitals are scrambling to attract and retain doctors, who control over 70 percent of health-care expenditures today," said Mr. Sullivan of the I.R.S.
 
Action in 12 States
 New guidelines for I.R.S. auditors tell them to "scrutinize any business arrangements under which hospitals finance the construction of medical buildings owned by staff doctors," because such arrangements may improperly siphon off charitable assets for the doctors' benefit.
Local officials have tried to revoke tax exemptions from nonprofit hospitals in at least 12 states.
Methodist Hospital of Houston disputes the charges made by the Texas Attorney General, Jim Mattox. "We are a nonprofit hospital, but not a charity hospital," said Larry L. Mathis, the hospital's president. "We do not set out specifically to extend our services to the poor. We were founded 71 years ago as a teaching and research center, and we believe those activities are charitable because they benefit everyone."
Mr. Mattox acknowledged that Methodist Hospital was providing some benefits to the community, but he insisted that it was not providing nearly enough charity care.
Bonnie S. Brier, general counsel of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, the nation's oldest children's hospital, said the Government's scrutiny of nonprofit hospitals was overdue.
"The perception of abuse without enforcement is creating a political climate that may result in overreaction by Congress and state legislatures," she said in an interview. "It is in the interest of charities to have the law fairly and evenhandedly enforced, or else Congress and state legislatures will try to enact more severe measures that impede our ability to carry out good works."
Sister Bernice Coreil, chairwoman of the 302-bed Hotel Dieu Hospital in New Orleans, said Roman Catholic hospitals opposed the idea of a uniform national numerical standard for charity care. The need for such care varies from state to state, she said, depending on local economic conditions, Medicaid eligibility criteria and the generosity of Medicaid payments to doctors and hospitals.
"We have a call to respond to the needs of the indigent," said Sister Bernice, a spokeswoman for the Catholic Health Association of the United States. "It has nothing to do with numbers or percentages. We are willing to carry part of the burden of caring for the uninsured, but it's really the obligation of society as a whole."

HEADLINE: Exemption to Rise $100

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The personal tax exemption will increase by $100 next year, to $2,150, the Internal Revenue Service announced on Friday. The exemption is adjusted each year to account for inflation, as are the standard deductions. The standard deduction for couples filing joint returns, which is $5,450 this year, will go to $5,700. The deduction for single people, now $3,250, will rise to $3,400.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of U.S. Issues Rise Modestly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly and interest rates slipped a bit yesterday, as dealers bought notes and bonds on the apparent expectation that policy makers will decide to ease monetary policy at a meeting in Washington today of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee.
"Participants are watching the Fed, and there is a possibility they might do something," one government bond trader said. "If they don't ease, then the market will give back some of the gains." 
 Analysts said the Fed's open market operations yesterday provided no clues as to its intentions on lowering the overnight Federal funds rate to 7 percent, from its current target of 7.25 percent.
 
New Reports Awaited
 Before a Government report on Friday showed that producer prices rose by an uncomfortable five-tenths of a percentage point in November, analysts were almost unanimous in their view that the Fed would move to lower rates at the meeting. Now, even though the economy is in a steep slide, private analysts said the Fed might delay its next move until after it has seen reports on how the economy fared this month. Those will not be available until early in January.
"It's only a matter of when they will ease, not if," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "And when they do, they will also have to consider what to do with the discount rate."
The discount rate, the rate the Fed charges banks for loans at its discount window, is currently at 7 percent, unchanged for almost two years. Although the Fed has said it is studying the possibility of allowing the Federal funds rate to fall below the discount rate, traditionally the discount rate is set below the funds rate.
Analysts at MMS International, an economic information and service company, said in a market commentary that "given the weakness in the economy, as strongly reflected in recent economic and money numbers, rising inflation is highly unlikely. The inflation hawks at the Fed have very little to support their case."
The analysts said they expected the Fed to signal an easing tomorrow.
Speculation about a possible Fed move was the focal point in an otherwise slow session. But traders said they were encouraged with the day's developments. "This was a good day," one bond trader said. "Prices fell for two straight days and were down again early today. But then it turned around. I think the correction everybody was looking for has taken place, and that we are heading for lower rates."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 106 13/32 late yesterday, up 1/8 point, to yield 8.17 percent, down from 8.18 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 3/8, up 6/32, to yield 7.99 percent. The 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 22/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.70 percent. And the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 5/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.28 percent.
 
Three-Month Rates Down
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 6.78 percent, down from an average rate of 6.86 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 6.77 percent, up from the average rate of 6.74 percent a week ago.
Activity in the new-issue market for corporate debt slowed significantly yesterday, as only one new issue was priced. Indeed, investment bankers said that after an extremely hectic few weeks, the corporate appetite for floating new debt in 1990 had probably been satisfied. "That could be it for the year," one investment banker said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues slipped by about 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: New York Giving Up 5-Year Drive to Build Middle-Income Units

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration has decided to shelve a proposal made nearly five years ago by some of New York City's leading developers to build 3,000 apartments for middle-income New Yorkers at no profit, the developers and city officials said yesterday.
The decision ends a prolonged saga for the ambitious and highly promoted program, one that included political and community opposition, financing difficulties, a drastically weakened real-estate market and, now, the city's fiscal woes. 
 The developers' plan was conceived as a demonstration of how inexpensive housing could be built privately if government barriers were removed. Instead, it has provided a graphic example of the long, arduous, sometimes tortured path between an idea and a building. It has demonstrated the kind of bureaucratic, political and legal obstacles inhibiting development.
The developers made their offer in March 1986 after the city said it would streamline the regulatory process and change some building regulations in a major effort to spur new housing construction for the middle class.
The first phase of the plan was to be a large condominium complex called Tibbett Gardens, to be built in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. It was originally to include 1,000 apartments. An average two-bedroom apartment was to sell for about $112,000, with the city providing a direct subsidy of as much as $25,000 an apartment and other incentives.
But the complex became mired in a host of problems, including strident opposition from the neighborhood. It was delayed for nearly two years by a lawsuit filed by some of its neighbors. And, once that was resolved, the developers confronted the sharp downturn in New York's real-estate market and a tightening credit market.
Tibbett Gardens finally expired because of the city's fiscal problems, which require huge cuts in the capital budget. The Dinkins administration told the developers last week that it had canceled the proposal, said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, the trade group that represents the city's developers and real-estate brokers and was the plan's overall sponsor.
 
A Decisive Vote
 Felice Michetti, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, confirmed yesterday that Tibbett Gardens would not be included in the capital plan that Mayor David N. Dinkins is to make public on Friday. When the complex was approved by the city's Board of Estimate in November 1987, Mr. Dinkins, then Manhattan Borough President, cast one of the decisive votes in its favor.
Ms. Michetti said the current fiscal crisis, combined with the competing needs of other housing programs, spelled the end of Tibbett Gardens. "I think Tibbetts really reflects a long, complicated history," she said.
Mr. Spinola said he believed that the canceling of Tibbett Gardens also meant the end of all other components in the developers' plan, including a similar condominium project in Astoria, Queens, which would also require city subsidies.
"I guess I feel sad that so many people who tried to do something good failed because of circumstances that I think were beyond our control," Mr. Spinola said in an interview. He said no single factor had caused the project's demise, but that it had fallen victim to a host of causes.
Opponents of the Bronx complex were jubiliant yesterday when they were informed of its cancellation. Some objected to the site chosen; others objected to the use of city subsidies for middle-income, rather than low-income housing.
The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said the project was doomed because the city's subsidy -- originally estimated at $25,000 an apartment -- had grown to double that amount or higher. The developers disputed the higher estimates.
Mr. Ferrer contended that the site for Tibbett Gardens, eight acres at 230th Street and Tibbett Avenue, was inappropriate for a large housing complex because it is at a busy intersection and much of the site is landfill.
"It's a dopey housing site," he said. Mr. Ferrer said he would like for the city money to be used instead on other housing proposals for the Bronx.
The complex had faced strong opposition from people in Kingsbridge and neighboring Riverdale, who contended that it would tie up traffic, overburden local schools and pose environmental hazards. Mr. Spinola said he believed that some opponents were motivated by racial bias and that they feared black and Hispanic New Yorkers would buy apartments at Tibbett Gardens.
Mr. Ferrer said he, too, believed some of the local opposition was based on race. "I am not naive," he said. "Some of the most vocal opponents had in their hearts, I am certain, a motive that was racially biased. But I opposed it for the reasons I laid out, which had nothing to do with race and ethnicity."
 
'Completely Unjustifiable'
 In addition to the local opposition, Tibbett Gardens and the developers' overall plan were opposed by some citywide housing groups.
Bonnie Brower, executive director of the Association of Neighborhood and Housing Development, a coalition of community groups, hailed the decision to shelve Tibbett Gardens. "It was a project that was completely unjustifiable, unnecessary and mistargeted, and its passing will not be mourned," Ms. Brower said.
But the program's proponents saw its passing as a lost opportunity.
"I think it's really bad for the city," said Paul A. Crotty, a city housing commissioner under Mayor Edward I. Koch who designed the city's ambitious 10-year housing program. "The people for whom this project was targeted are decent, hard-working people, people who need some help to stay here, and now they won't get that help."
Among the program's problems, several supporters said, was an inability to rally political support for it. The opponents were highly vocal, proponents said, while the middle-class people who would have benefited from the housing did not speak out for it. The city defines middle-income households as those with incomes between $32,000 and $53,000 a year.
"There was no constituency, other than the quiet people who wrote to us and said they needed an apartment," said Mr. Spinola of the Real Estate Board. Although the developers never solicited potential buyers for the Bronx condominiums, more than 1,000 people had written to inquire about them after reading news articles about the project, he said.
Politics was only one of the reasons the developers' effort foundered, Mr. Spinola said. The suit by local opponents tied up the project for almost two years. The developers prevailed in court, but during that time banks began to tighten up on loans and the city's real-estate market shifted significantly.
Some critics had argued for several years that the fate of Tibbett Gardens would hinge on an odd technicality: no developer was willing to take on the liability of paying off the loan for construction costs. "They were donating their time, their effort, but they were not going to make a profit from this and so they did not want to take a risk," Mr. Spinola said.
 
An Escrow Fund
 In 1988, he said, a bank might have granted the loan anyway. But in the current real-estate market, that became extremely difficult. For the project to proceed, the banks wanted the city to set aside $50,000 to $60,000 an apartment in an escrow fund to cover costs if it took years to sell all the apartments, Mr. Spinola said.
Critics argued that such a subsidy was much too high. But Mr. Spinola maintained that the real cost to the city would have been much lower, perhaps $35,000 an apartment in the worst case, because revenues from the initial apartment sales would have offset the cost of paying off the construction loan.
The Dinkins administration decided early this year that the escalating costs endangered the project. So Tibbett Gardens, which had already been reduced from 1,000 to 750 apartments to obtain the Board of Estimate's approval in 1987, was scaled down again.
This time, the plan was for only low-rise town houses, with a maximum of 400 apartments, not the mid- and high-rise structures envisioned originally.
But the city's budget crunch caused the end of this more modest version, the developers and city officials said.
"It's grim," Mr. Spinola said, "because it's tied to the downturn of the city's economy and the nation's economy. I think this would have happened otherwise."

HEADLINE: Route Shifts Challenge British Air

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
From the way Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, talks about the New York Giants and their chances of making it to the Super Bowl, it is obvious that he is still attached to America, where he spent 11 years.
But not all of his thoughts of the United States are so pleasant these days. He is very much concerned about the pending deals by American Airlines to buy seven routes between the United States and London from ailing Trans World Airlines and by United Airlines to buy five others from teetering Pan American World Airways. 
 Five of the T.W.A. routes, including a Chicago route that American bought earlier but has yet to start flying, and all five Pan Am routes have operated out of Heathrow, the London airport preferred by most international passengers and the one where British Airways is king.
The other two T.W.A. routes go to London's Gatwick Airport, to which American already flies from Miami and Dallas-Fort Worth. American also flies between Chicago and two other British cities: Glasgow and Manchester.
The United States Government is putting pressure on the British Government to allow the Heathrow rights to be transferred from Pan Am and T.W.A. to United and American, and there could be months of thorny negotiations. [Page D6.]
If the British Government does allow the transfer -- and many analysts and industry executives, including Sir Colin, are betting it will -- British Airways will face the biggest challenge to its dominance of the Britain-United States market. British Airways holds 39 percent of the market, which is its most important business.
"United and American are going to be greater competitive threats than Pan Am and T.W.A.," said Daniel M. Kasper, an airline consultant at Boston-based Harbridge House.
British Airways is Western Europe's largest carrier and No. 7 in the world, based on the number of miles it flew passengers last year. In the year ended March 31, the routes to the Americas accounted for 252 million ($415.2 million), or 62.7 percent of British Airways' airline operating profits of 402 million. The routes represented 1.59 billion, or 33.8 percent, of the airline's revenues of 4.72 billion. Of its profits and revenues from the Americas, the vast majority came from the United States.
American, the largest United States carrier, is already in the midst of putting in place a plan to become a big trans-Atlantic carrier. It now serves 11 cities in seven European countries from the United States. Even before the T.W.A. pact, American had plans to add two more routes to its existing 18 in 1991.
United, the No. 2 carrier in the United States, is following a similar strategy. This year it began flying to Frankfurt from Chicago and Washington and to Paris from Chicago.
 
Sought Deal With United
 United's interest in the European market must be an especially bitter pill for Sir Colin and Lord King, chairman of British Airways, because they had been counting on an alliance with United to help expand British Airways' presence in the North Atlantic market.
British Airways flies to 19 cities in the United States. About the only big American city it does not serve is Denver. But Sir Colin and Lord King have been hoping that United would feed their airline lots of Europe-bound passengers from smaller American cities.
Although Sir Colin is not saying the marketing alliance with United is dead, he said, in reference to the United-Pan Am agreement, "It is incumbent upon us to review our options in the light of that deal, assuming that the deal finally occurs." United has said it will call off the Pan Am deal if it is forced to fly to Gatwick.
A treaty between the United States and Britain gives the rights to fly to Heathrow specifically to Pan Am and T.W.A. Under British law, the rights are not transferable: There is a long waiting list to get into Heathrow and newcomers have to fly to Gatwick, London's No. 2 airport, or Stansted, a new airport.
The American and British Governments are renegotiating the treaty. The Bush Administration, which is concerned about Pan Am's dire financial condition, wants Britain to allow the Heathrow rights to be transferred and the British Government is reviewing the law, though a decision is not expected before mid-January.
If the British Government makes the Heathrow rights transferable, Sir Colin wants Britain to demand concessions from Washington. First, he wants the 25 percent limit on foreign ownership of United States carriers to be raised significantly if not altogether eliminated -- something Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner is considering.
In addition, Sir Colin is seeking changes in Federal rules and industry practices that he contends discriminate against foreign carriers in computerized reservation systems that handle most passenger bookings in the United States.
 
Seeking U.S. Stake
 Clearly, British Airways has not lost its desire to buy a sizable stake in a big United States carrier. Last year, British Airways joined with United's management in an attempted buyout of the American carrier. British Airways was prepared to invest $750 million in return for 15 percent of United.
But the deal fell through when United's management could not get financing. United's stock price then plunged far below the offer price. And with United preoccupied until October with a series of unsuccessful takeover bids from its unions, British Airways deferred its ambitions.
But British Airways still has the money it raised for the original deal. It is one of the world's strongest airlines financially and could probably come up with $1 billion to $1.5 billion to buy a stake in a United States carrier.
Given the toll being taken on balance sheets throughout the airline industry by the high fuel prices caused by the Middle East crisis, several American carriers could undoubtedly use an injection of capital.
United would seem a less likely candidate given its decision to invade British Airways' turf. The marketing alliance between the two, which was signed in 1987, has also not been very productive, though Sir Colin blames United management's preoccupation with the attempted takeovers. "The actual business we have received has continued to be less than 2 percent of our North Atlantic traffic," or about 6,000 passengers a month, he said.
Stephen F. Wheatcroft, a London-based consultant and former British Airways executive, said one possible target is the USAir Group. British Airways already has a small tie with USAir: Passengers on its Britain-United States flights can acquire USAir frequent-flier points. British Airways is in United's and American's frequent-flier programs, too.
Delta Air Lines and British Airways coordinate their Britain-Dallas-Fort Worth flights. But Delta has much more extensive marketing agreements with Swissair and Singapore Airlines.
Greater ties with a United States carrier seem crucial now that United and American are poised to replace Pan Am and T.W.A. on the United States-London routes.
Pan Am and T.W.A.'s reputations for indifferent service forced them to resort to discounting to attract customers, analysts said. As a result, they have not posed much of a threat to British Airways, which has been making money by attracting business travelers who are willing to pay high fares for top service.
 
Tougher Rivals

American and United promise to be much tougher rivals. Not only do they have the domestic routes to feed passengers into their international system, they also have a reputation for superior service.
Sir Colin said he was not quaking at the prospect of a head-to-head battle for business travelers with United and American. "We're certainly not taking this frivolously," he said. "But if it does become a battle over who can provide the best service, that's fine by us."
After all, he noted, "we've already been worrying about all the others" -- including American, Delta, Northwest, USAir, Continental and Virgin -- that fly out of Gatwick.
His confidence -- and British Airways' profits -- underline how much the carrier has changed since the early 1980's, when it was still state-owned and passengers said B.A. stood for "bloody awful" service.
John King, an industrialist, was appointed in 1980 by the former Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, to transform the bloated, loss-ridden company into a profitable, competitive airline that investors would want to own.
In 1983, Lord King recruited Colin Marshall. A marketing specialist, Sir Colin had worked at Hertz, headed Avis and been a senior executive at Norton Simon, the American conglomerate that had bought Avis, before returning to Britain in 1981 to be the No. 2 at Sears P.L.C., the British retailer.
Under Sir Colin's leadership, British Airways has been systematically improving its service. He had made enough progress to enable the company to be sold to shareholders in February 1987. But he has not eased up and is considered to have helped to create a revolution in the airline industry by treating passenger categories as brands.
In the nearly three years since British Airway overhauled its business, or Club, class, the number of Club passengers has risen by about 27 percent. Since a new first-class service was introduced in March 1989, the number of passengers has risen by about 5 percent.
 
Improving Economy Fare
 Given that a first-class one-way ticket from Heathrow to Kennedy Airport in New York costs $3,024, a Club class costs $1,802 and the least expensive full-fare economy is $508, it is obvious why British Airways is one of the most profitable airlines in the world.
The next category to be improved and branded is economy. That will happen on a worldwide basis on Jan. 15, when the World Traveller and Euro Traveller classes will include more comfortable seating, improved catering and a new range of in-flight entertainment.
"We decided that it was very opportune to do it in this recessionary climate," when many business travelers and consumers are trading down, Sir Colin said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways. The airline holds 39 percent of the lucrative Britain-United States market. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times) (pg. 1)

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN THE GULF;
A PARTIAL PULLOUT BY IRAQ IS FEARED AS DEADLINE 'PLOY'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told America's NATO allies today that he expected President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to take a dramatic step, like a partial withdrawal from Kuwait, just before a United Nations resolution authorizing force to evict Iraq goes into effect in mid-January.
Addressing foreign ministers at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's annual winter meeting, Mr. Baker urged his colleagues to stand united against any such "ploy."
"We should anticipate," Mr. Baker said in his remarks to the ministers, "that as we draw close to Resolution 678's Jan. 15 deadline, and as the choices are presented starkly, Saddam Hussein is likely to try to undercut the collective will of the international community to use force. Just as I believe he chose to release hostages for this purpose, I think he may take a dramatic step on or around Jan. 15. He could withdraw partially."
 
'We Need to Anticipate'
 Mr. Baker added: "We have all agreed that partial solutions or outcomes that are conditioned or linked to other issues are unacceptable. We need to anticipate Saddam's possible moves, be prepared for a partial withdrawal ploy and coordinate closely our responses." 
 The American assessment appeared to have met with widespread approval from the 15 other NATO ministers, who issued a statement on the Persian Gulf crisis at the end of their discussions today, declaring that "there can be no partial solutions."
Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy, which is currently serving as the rotating president of the European Community, said the community's foreign ministers would decide at a meeting on Tuesday whether to go ahead with a planned meeting in Rome this week with Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz.
 
Considerations Behind Meeting
 That visit had been scheduled when it was assumed that Mr. Aziz would be meeting with President Bush today in Washington and then go to Rome for talks with the community.
Iraq has asked the community to go ahead with the meeting. [Page A8.] But with the Iraqi-American dialogue now on hold in a dispute over dates for Mr. Baker's proposed meeting with President Hussein, Administration officials said it appeared unlikely that the community would agree to see the Iraqi minister now for fear that he would try to use the opportunity to drive a wedge between them and the Americans.
Mr. Baker's remarks were the first public expression of a concern shared by Administration officials ever since Nov. 29, when the Security Council approved Resolution 678, authorizing the use of force against Iraq after Jan. 15.
 
Worried About Partial Pullout
 Their worry is that on or about Jan. 15, President Hussein will announce a partial withdrawal from Kuwait in an effort to split the international coalition between those who would still insist on a total pullout and those who would accept a partial withdrawal as sufficient to avert war.
 
Move Considered Logical
 Administration officials said that they have no particular intelligence that the Iraqi leader planned such a partial withdrawal but that such a move would be logical for him to first try to see if a partial withdrawal might divide and weaken his opponents before considering a total pullout.
Reports from Kuwait that Iraq has fenced off the northern part of the country, or only integrated part of it into neighboring Basra province, have fueled speculation that Mr. Hussein might be planning to keep just the northern half of Kuwait. That would leave him in full control of the disputed Rumaila oilfield, most of which is already inside Iraqi territory, as well as Warba and Bubiyan islands, which control Iraq's access to the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Baker apparently chose to raise this issue now -- even before there is an agreement between the United States and Iraq on the timing of talks between the two Governments -- because officials anticipate that in the talks, the Iraqis are likely to at least hint at such an alternative.
 
Concern Over Hussein's Stature
 Asked what would be so bad about a partial Iraqi pullout, a senior State Department official argued that if the Iraqi leader is in any way rewarded for his invasion of Kuwait, he will be seen in the Middle East has having won against both the United States and the United Nations. As a result, his stature would grow and he would be able to dominate the region politically the same way Egypt's President, Gamal Abdel Nasser, did after his political victory over Britain, France and Israel in the 1956 Suez crisis.
The Administration's concerns about an Iraqi offer of a partial pullout are also exacerbated by a sense of the fragility of the anti-Iraq alliance, as well as the fact that such an Iraqi offer would provide strong ammunition for domestic critics of the Administration's strategy of threatening Iraq with war. The critics would be able to argue that if four months of sanctions produced a partial Iraqi withdrawal, then maybe four more months could produce a total withdrawal and therefore military action should be delayed.
"Making clear that there will be no reward and no linkage to other issues is essential to convincing Saddam, one, that he cannot drive wedges between us and, two, that time is running out," Mr. Baker said in his speech at NATO's Brussels headquarters. "A peaceful outcome depends on his seeing that he has only two choices. Any meeting with the Iraqis should reinforce the starkness of the choices, lest any miscommunication lead them to miscalculate once again, thereby actually increasing the risk of war."
 
Issue of Meeting With Aziz
 On the issue of the meeting with Mr. Aziz, Mr. De Michelis said the community's initial objective in scheduling the session had been to "strengthen, not weaken the international cohesion" against Iraq. But the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said Britain opposed a European Community meeting with Mr. Aziz until after the Iraqi Foreign Minister met with the Americans. He added that Britain would not be alone in that position.
The NATO gulf statement also gave a general endorsement in principle to the American and community diplomatic contacts with Iraq.
"We are confident," the NATO statement said, "that a contact between the presidency of the European Community and the Foreign Minister of Iraq, among other initiatives, can make a contribution. We also encourage action by the U.N. Secretary General to this end. In particular, we support efforts for a dialogue, such as those made by President Bush, to provide Iraq through direct, high-level contacts with the clearest possible understanding of the consequences of further postponing of the fulfillment of its obligations."
In addition to calling on his colleagues for unity, Mr. Baker also put them on notice that he would soon be calling on them for more money.
 
Allies' Share of the Burden
 "When I last spoke to you on this subject, we had not yet augmented our forces in the gulf to provide a credible offensive capability," said Mr. Baker, referring to the Administration's decision on Nov. 8 to double American troop strength in the gulf. "That was a very big decision for us. It meant calling up reserves and dividing tens of thousands of families. It meant significant new economic burdens for us. And it means real risks and real sacrifices for the American people. It is in this context that we will be coming to you again to discuss how we might responsibly share these additional costs and risks."
Congress has become increasingly agitated over the fact that so many allies have pledged so little and those who have pledged more have not all delivered their payments.
The House majority leader, Richard Gephardt of Missouri, warned President Bush on Saturday that he must be more aggressive in securing financial backing from America's key allies if he wanted Congress to approve the $20 billion in supplemental funds that the Administration plans to seek in early 1991 to help pay for the gulf operation during the coming year.
Mr. Gephardt and a fellow Democrat, Rep. Charles Schumer of Brooklyn, estimated that the gulf operation would cost the United States $36.85 billion in the 1991 fiscal year. They said America's wealthy partners in the anti-Baghdad coalition -- Japan, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Germany and Korea -- had up to now pledged $10.62 billion, or 29 percent, with Washington having to cover the other 71 percent of the operational costs.
 
Not One Inch, Bush Declares
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Bush said today that Iraq had until midnight on Jan. 15 to withdraw from Kuwait and vowed he would not negotiate for "one inch of territory" with President Hussein.
"None of us wants war, but none of us is prepared to accept a partial solution," Mr. Bush said after meeting in the White House with representatives of 28 countries that have sent troops or money to aid the Persian Gulf military operation.
Mr. Bush said he was still willing to meet with the Iraqi Foreign Minister, but only if Mr. Hussein agreed to receive Secretary of State Baker before Jan. 12, the date proposed by Iraq.
"I'm not going to shove these meetings right up against the United Nations deadline and thus have the adverse effect of undermining the total fulfillment of the resolutions," Mr. Bush said.
Referring to the United Nations resolution setting Jan. 15 as the date after which force may be used to end the Iraqi occupation, Mr. Bush said, "I think at midnight, if he's not totally out of Kuwait, the U.N. sanctions must be fulfilled."

HEADLINE: White House Retreats on Ruling That Curbs Minority Scholarships

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The White House chief of staff today ordered the Education Department to reverse its ruling on scholarships for minority students, acting on President Bush's instructions to retreat from the decision, Administration officials said.
The action today came within hours of Mr. Bush's selection of Lamar Alexander, the former two-term Governor of Tennessee, as the new Secretary of Education. He would replace Lauro F. Cavazos, who was forced to resign last week by the White House. The selection of Mr. Alexander, one of the first governors to champion education reform more than a decade ago, was seen as an effort to revive the department and make good Mr. Bush's pledge to be the "education President." [Man in the News, page B14.]
 
Debate at Meeting
 In a contentious meeting in his office this afternoon, Mr. Bush's chief of staff, John H. Sununu disagreed with officials from the White House, the Justice Department and the Education Department over how far the Administration should retreat from the ruling that scholarships designated solely for minority students were illegal. 
 Some officials suggested that the Education Department ruling should simply be suspended while a lengthy review was conducted. Others urged language that would let the ruling stand but add restrictions that, in the words of one official, "would take all the legal teeth and political problems out of it."
Instead, Mr. Sununu said the Administration should go further and reject the foundation of the ruling. Where the Education Department said private donations should be treated in the same way as public money, Mr. Sununu ordered Federal lawyers to come up with language that would draw a legal distinction between private and public scholarship money. Mr. Sununu argued that this could be presented as something less than an outright reversal, but officials who were unhappy with his decision said it would be seen that way.
Those officials argued that accepting any form of race-exclusive spending would undermine the principles on which the Bush Administration's civil rights policies rest: that there can be no discrimination of any kind, even if that would adversely affect minority groups.
As of this evening, an Administration official said Mr. Bush had not given his approval to Mr. Sununu's approach, but the chief of staff wanted to announce a decision on Tuesday in hopes of getting Mr. Bush out of this latest political bind on civil rights as quickly as possible.
Michael L. Williams, the head of the Education Department's civil rights division, who issued the original scholarship ruling without the knowledge of the White House, scheduled a news conference for Tuesday morning.
Mr. Williams decided that it was illegal for colleges and universities supported by Federal money to give scholarships that are designated solely for minority students.
Mr. Williams argued that even if the money came from private donations once it was in the possession of a university, it was, in effect, public money. Lawyers from the Education and Justice Departments, led by the White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, agreed with that assessment.
 
Embarrassment to Bush
 Although the Administration has strongly opposed quotas or race-specific programs like the ones rejected by Mr. Williams, the ruling deeply embarrassed Mr. Bush, who learned of it only after it was reported in the press and disapproved of it. The announcement stunned the education establishment, infuriated civil rights groups and complicated Mr. Bush's already strained relationship with black voters.
Still smarting from criticism of his veto of civil rights legislation earlier this year, the President made it clear he wanted his staff to find a way to reverse the scholarship policy, while saving as much face as possible in the process, officials said.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, indicated Mr. Bush's position today when he said the President, who has long been a supporter of the United Negro College Fund and other efforts for minority students, was "very disturbed" by Mr. Williams's decision.
"He does believe that minority scholarships have been important for economic growth and development, for educational opportunity," Mr. Fitzwater said.
Some officials argued that the Administration could not simply reverse Mr. Williams's ruling without embarrassment and without appearing to reject Mr. Bush's stand against quotas. The President vetoed the civil rights bill largely because he believed it would lead to racial quotas in employment.
In discussions over the weekend and in Mr. Sununu's office today, one official said, some officials suggested that the White House could suspend the ruling and order a "thorough review."
"Of course, a review can go on forever, and meanwhile the old policy would be in place," the official said.
Another suggestion was that the ruling be "redefined" to say that it applied strictly to scholarships that were distributed according to an applicant's race but that scholarships intended to redress economic imbalances or past patterns of discrimination would be legal, he said.
"Bush's instincts were to be pro-minority access and supportive of Willams at the same time," a senior official said, noting that Mr. Bush telephoned Mr. Williams today to express his personal support for him.
"One way would be to issue a statement that would offer to give technical assistance to universities to make those scholarships need-based and diversity-based in a way that would make sure there was no reduction of minority access," the senior official said.
Mr. Sununu decided it was possible to draw a legal distinction between money that came from private sources and money from public sources, the official said, and ordered the lawyers to do so. The chief of staff argued that private money could be spent any way the donor saw fit, the official said.
"At one point, someone said, 'Well, what if person X gave money to a university and said it could be used only for white students?' " the official said. "The ruling was that that was O.K. because it would be private money."
The official said the latest draft of the Administration's new ruling on the issue stipulated that the law "would allow universities, including public universities, to administer scholarships where the donor restricts eligibility."
 
'Fairly Progressive Governor'
 This debate was the backdrop to Mr. Alexander's selection as Education Secretary. But the former Governor skirted questions about the issue today at a White House news conference.
A longtime associate of Mr. Alexander said: "I would rate Lamar as having been a fairly progressive Republican governor, and you can read between the lines on what he says about this question. But he's political enough to know that he's got to move the President's agenda in a way that's got some political sensitivity to it. And there is no way he's going to get himself staked out on a position until he knows the political landscape."
Mr. Alexander, now the president of the University of Tennessee, was considered as a Vice Presidential candidate in 1988. He was seen as a likely choice for Mr. Bush's Cabinet in 1989, but was passed over.
Many conservatives, including Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip who has been feuding with the White House, applauded the selection of Mr. Alexander.
Some conservatives were disappointed that their candidate for Education Secretary, Lynn Cheney, the head of the National Endowment for the Humanities, was not chosen.
"What's to be enthusiastic about?" asked Thomas S. Winter, editor of the weekly Human Events, a conservative magazine. "It's a boring choice. No imagination there."
