HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Late Activity After Cut in Discount Rate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell moderately against most foreign currencies yesterday after a flurry of late-afternoon trading prompted by a move by the Federal Reserve Board to lower its key bank lending rate.
Gold fell slightly in New York, down $1 an ounce, to $376.50, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. 
 Traders said that although the dollar fell, its decline was cushioned by the continued potential for a war in the Persian Gulf to disrupt foreign economies heavily dependent on imported oil.
Walter Simon, vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company, said the drop would have been bigger in a "normal market."
The central bank lowered the discount rate to 6 1/2 percent, from 7 percent. The rate is what the Fed charges member banks for loans. It also provides a guide to interest rates, since banks set loan rates above the discount rate.
The Fed move, which takes effect today, had been expected for some time. But traders took it as a further indication of the slumping American economy, which generally erodes the dollar's value against foreign currencies.
"This is displaying to the market the lack of confidence in the economy the Fed has," Mr. Simon said.
Traders said the dollar displayed its greatest weakness against the German mark amid rising interest rates in that country.
They speculated that some European economies might move to firm their interest rates to stabilize their currencies against the mark. This could further weaken the dollar.
The dollar closed at 1.4780 German marks in New York, down from 1.4870 late on Monday.
The dollar's decline on the Fed move came after an earlier report on the worst United States monthly trade deficit numbers in nearly three years. The trade deficit climbed to $11.61 billion in October, the biggest imbalance since February 1988.
It cost $1.9305 in New York to buy one British pound yesterday, unchanged from late on Monday.
Also in New York, the dollar weakened to close at 132.72 Japanese yen, down from 133.10 late on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Monday, included: 1.2667 Swiss francs, down from 1.2745; 5.0375 French francs, down from 5.0620; 1,118.00 Italian lire, down from 1,122.75, and 1.1554 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1579.
On the Comex, gold fell slightly, by $1 an ounce, to $376.50. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $375.75 an ounce, down 75 cents from late on Monday.

HEADLINE: Dow Jumps 33.41 After Cut in Discount Rate

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks rose sharply late yesterday in heavy trading, responding only seconds after the Federal Reserve Board slashed its interest rate on loans to banks, or the discount rate, to 6 1/2 from 7 percent.
"For about three minutes, buying exploded," said Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading for Shearson Lehman Brothers. "Then profit taking came in, because the news didn't exactly come as a big surprise. If we hadn't talked about it so much, the market would have gone up 100 points." 
 H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist for Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said the move was an indication that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, "belatedly recognized that the economy is in a serious recession and he better do something about it."
Although it was the first cut in the rate in more than four years, its expectation had been widely credited with fueling the stock rally in the last three weeks. But until it came, at 3:25 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average had been marking time, rising barely 9 points in sluggish trading. Then the Dow jumped 28 more, falling back only slightly as many traders cashed in their chips to end the day at 2,626.73, up 33.41.
 
Volume Surges
 Trading volume surged to 176.5 million shares, from an anemic 118.6 million the day before, with 969 stocks ahead and 23 rising to 52-week highs, while 577 fell and 52 dropped to lows. The advance also extended across the Standard & Poor's 500 index, the Nasdaq composite average of over-the-counter stocks and to a lesser extent to the smaller stocks on the American Stock Exchange.
Despite nervousness over the Persian Gulf crisis and a rise in oil prices to $27.86, up 81 cents, transportation stocks showed strong gains. Bank stocks and other interest-sensitive stocks, including insurers and utilities, rose sharply on the rate cut in spite of new concerns over bank dividend payments. Drug stocks, chemicals and high-tech stocks also advanced broadly. Retailing and telephone stocks also rose.
Mr. Heinemann noted that since little lending was actually done at the discount rate, its importance was symbolic. But, he argued, "the move will trigger a cut in the prime rate, probably at once, and it will also signal that the Fed presumably will get around to putting some money into the banking system in the weeks ahead."
The cut in the discount rate, he predicted, will be accompanied in the next four to five months by further reductions in the Federal funds rate to "well under 6 percent." The rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, stood at 8 1/4 percent in January and has been gradually cut to about 7 1/2 percent.
 
Ending on a Selloff
 Explaining the slight selloff in the closing minutes, Mr. Grennan said, "December is one of the wackiest months because it's very choppy and investment managers make lots of adjustments as we come into the end of the year. They want their performance as of Dec. 31 to look as good as possible because they're going to live with it for the next 12 months."
Laszlo Birinyi, president of the research firm of Birinyi Associates, said: "Many of these stocks were strong before the Fed news -- like I.B.M., Compaq Computer, General Motors and UAL.
"The news basically broadened the rally and brought in some of the secondary and over-the-counter stocks."
Heavy program buying, including one wave beginning moments after the rate cut, lifted the Dow 31 points, the Birinyi firm computed.
In a strong high-tech group, I.B.M rose 2, to 113 1/2, on 1.6 million shares. Compaq rose 2 1/8, to 56 1/2; Digital Equipment 2 1/8, to 59 1/4, and on Nasdaq, Apple Computer 2 1/8, to 42 1/4. After saying it expected a sharp rise in profits for the fiscal quarter ended Dec. 28, AST Research jumped 5 1/2, to 32, in heavy trading.
 
High-Tech Stocks
 In other Nasdaq high-tech stocks, Sun Microsystems rose 1 5/8, to 22 5/8; Stratus Computer 1 1/8, to 21 7/8; Microsoft 1 1/4, to 75 1/4, and Novell 1 1/4, to 32 3/4.
G.M., a market leader, rose 1 1/4, to 35 1/8. UAL, with a proposed deal to buy Pan Am's routes to London, rose 2 7/8, to 108 1/4.
Manufacturers Hanover, which had been expected to cut its dividend, rose 1 7/8, to 20 7/8, after its quarterly payout remained unchanged at 82 cents.
Topping the Big Board's active list, Citicorp rose 3/4, to 14 1/8, after it slashed its dividend and said it would have a big fourth-quarter loss.
Bankers Trust New York rose 2 7/8, to 44 1/8, after it raised its dividend.
Among other interest-sensitive stocks, J. P. Morgan rose 2 7/8, to 44 5/8; Wells Fargo 2 5/8, to 57 3/4; Lincoln National 2 1/4, to 42; Cigna 2 1/8, to 41 1/2; General Electric 1 1/2, to 56 7/8, and Fannie Mae 1 1/2, to 35 1/8.

HEADLINE: Punjabis, Caught Between Sikh Rebels and New Delhi, Fear a Showdown

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHANDIGARH, India, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Over the last few days, on narrow roads that run between fields of golden mustard and emerald-green rice seedlings, convoys of army trucks, artillery and ambulances have been rumbling through Punjab, India's breadbasket.
To many Punjabis, the message is clear: a military showdown may be coming with militant Sikhs, another aggrieved and alienated minority in a nation already torn by Hindu-Muslim violence. 
 This week, the Government of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar removed the civilian governor of the state, the third this year, and replaced him with a former army chief, Om Prakash Malhotra. With locally elected state government suspended since 1987, the Governor has almost unlimited powers.
"By putting a general in charge here while the army is being deployed makes us think there is some mischief in the minds of the Government," C. S. Sidhu, a leader of a Sikh political party under pressure from New Delhi and armed militants, said.
 
'Fear Psychosis' in Punjab
 But despite what Punjabis call "police raj" or armed rule in this state, where about 60 percent of the population is Sikh, thousands of people have died this year. A militant campaign of intimidation of state-government employees and the press is daily more audacious, officials are assassinated, criminal gangs flourish and, most wrenching to the hard-working Sikh community, Sikhs have begun killing each other as divisions among them deepen.
Up to 95 percent of the dead are Sikhs: militants, policemen, suspected informers and ordinary men, women and children.
"A fear psychosis has gripped the state in the last 10 days," said Jagjit Singh Aurora, a retired lieutenant general and critic of Government handling of Punjab. General Aurora, who heads a civil-rights group, the Sikh Forum, blames government officials and the militants, symbolized if not led by an underground organization called the Panthic Committtee.
"The villager doesn't want to get robbed and killed by militants or criminals," he said in an interview in his home in New Delhi on Friday. "But the villager is also getting robbed and killed by the police."
Further militarization of the state, he said, will only create "an actively hostile population."
 
Arms Cross Pakistan Border
 Sikh leaders say many families have already been alienated by offically sanctioned death squads and extortion by policemen who abduct young people and threaten to book them as terrorists if ransoms are not paid. Reports of torture and death in police custody are common.
The Indian Army is also fighting separatists in Kashmir, where there is a Muslim majority, and in the northeastern state of Assam, where there are cultural and ethnic grievances. Use of military force seems to have hardened rather that weakened resistance in rebellious states, yet succeeding Indian Governments have said that political issues can be addressed only when violent opposition has been put down.
In Punjab -- where in addition to religious differences, there are complaints that the state is denied its share of development revenues, power and water supplies -- the economic and political roots of the crisis will not be eliminated by force, say Sikh leaders here, in Amritsar, the holy city of the Sikhs, and in New Delhi, where many Sikh families from what is now Pakistan settled after the division of British India in 1947.
Those leaders question the Government's assertions that Pakistan, plotting to destabilize India, is to blame for militancy in the northwestern states. They do not deny that weapons are crossing the border, or that militants are going to Pakistan. But Sikhs say that those activities would be curtailed if demands for some autonomy were met and free elections were held to restore the democratic process.
 
Guns Trained on Shoppers
 The present worsening situation is encouraging Pakistani involvement, General Aurora said.
Indian officials say the army is being deployed in Punjab this week only for routine exercises along the Pakistani border, where troops will also block infiltration of arms and guerrillas. But a reporter saw army troops in jeeps, guns trained on shoppers and other pedestrians, patrolling the streets of the border city of Amritsar this weekend.
Hindus have been fleeing to the city from frontier villages, saying that they are being killed by militant Sikhs. In New Delhi, officials say orders to kill Hindus are emanating from Pakistan.
Sikh leaders dispute that. They say the attacks on Hindus may be politically motivated provocations intended to malign Sikhs and inflame Hindus elsewhere in India.
 
State That Once Was Quiet
 Reacting to Sikh doubts about the effects of a military response, Prime Minister Shekhar, a critic of an army attack on the Sikhs' Golden Temple in 1984, is trying to bring Sikh leaders into talks with the central Government.
Today, New Delhi announced that the head of the Punjab state police, K. P. S. Gill, was being removed. Simranjit Singh Mann, a former police official who now heads the largest faction of the Sikhs' traditional party, the Akali Dal, had made the removal of Mr. Gill a condition of negotiations.
But Mr. Gill will become director general of a national paramilitary organization called the Central Reserve Police Force, accused throughout India of brutality and corruption.
A decade ago, Punjab, a leader of India's agricultural and industrial revolutions, was largely a quiet, prosperous state. The Nihangs, a temple guardian sect, were the most warlike of the Sikhs, who follow a religion with Hindu and Muslim roots founded in the 16th century.
 
'84 Golden Temple Attack
 Proponents of Khalistan, an independent Sikh nation, were very few.
Then in June 1984, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ordered a tank assault on the center of the Sikh religion, the 400-year-old Golden Temple in Amritsar, to dislodge an armed, radical Sikh faction led by a preacher, Sant Bhindranwale, whom she had earlier supported to weaken the Akali Dal, a mainstream political rival in Punjab to her Congress Party.
 
Taj Mahal Open Despite Curfew
 AGRA, India, Dec. 18 (AP) -- More than half the city that is home to the Taj Mahal was under curfew today after three days of riots by Hindus and Muslims, but the 17th-century architectural masterpiece reopened to tourists.
At least 11 people were killed and 49 wounded in Agra in riots that were the latest in a wave of clashes between to have swept several cities across India.
Residents stood watch on rooftops and alleys near the Taj Mahal, ready to sound alarms at the first sign of trouble. A curfew was in force in eight of Agra's 15 districts, the police said.

(Barbara Crossette/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit of U.S. Worst in 2 1/2 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The United States suffered the worst monthly trade deficit in two and a half years in October, an $11.6 billion imbalance that analysts said would make the early months of the recession worse than expected.
The Commerce Department attributed much of the 24 percent jump in the trade deficit to higher foreign oil prices stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis. But there was also a big rise in car imports. 
 The increase in car imports helped total imports jump to an all-time high and swamped a smaller rise in United States exports sales, which also hit a record high.
 
Bleak Forecasts Lowered
 The bad trade news prompted some economists to lower their already bleak forecasts for overall economic performance in the current October-December quarter.
Export growth and a narrowing trade deficit had been one of the few bright spots in an otherwise lackluster economy. Analysts said a rising trade deficit meant that even this source of strength would be removed in the final three months of the year, the period most forecasters pinpoint as the start of the recession.
"This is a bad number," David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said of the October trade deficit. "It suggests that we are not going to get as much help from net exports as we had hoped and it suggests there is more inventory out there than we had thought."
 
Decline Put at 3 1/2 Percent
 Mr. Wyss added that he had subtracted another half a percentage point from overall economic activity in the fourth quarter based on October's trade number, putting his forecast of a decline in the gross national product at a sharp 3 1/2 percent.
Analysts said the rise in imports at a time when consumer demand was falling suggested that retailers would be stuck with a lot of unwanted inventories, forcing production cutbacks in the months ahead. "That will tend to deepen the economic recession and add to layoffs," said Robert Brusca, chief economist of the Nikko Securities Company of New York.
Economists took more encouragement from today's report on consumer prices, which showed that inflation at the retail level rose at an annual rate of 3.7 percent in December after three months of much sharper increases. Energy prices, which had soared after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, posted only a small increase.
 
Maneuvering Room for Fed
 Economists said the reassuring inflation report gave the Federal Reserve the maneuvering room it needed to fight the economic slump with lower interest rates. The Fed this afternoon reduced the discount rate, the rate it charges banks for loans, to 6 1/2 percent, from 7 percent, the first change in that rate since February 1989.
About one-fifth of the deterioration in the trade deficit came from a 17 percent jump in America's oil bill in October, which climbed to $7.23 billion, the highest monthly total since April 1981. The volume of imports was little changed at 8.03 million barrels daily, but the average price for a barrel shot up by $4.73, to $29.04.
For October, imports rose by 12.2 percent, to an all-time high of $46.38 billion, while exports rose a smaller 8.6 percent, to a record $34.77 billion.
The trade gap, the difference between imports and exports, was at its highest level since a $12.56 billion deficit in February 1988.
 
Rebound From Low Car Imports
 Adding to the deficit in October was a 39 percent rise in imported cars, which climbed to $4.51 billion. Analysts said that represented a bounce back from unusually low car imports in previous months.
Through the first 10 months of 1990, the trade deficit was running at an annual rate of $103 billion, putting the country on track for its seventh consecutive year of deficits above $100 billion.
The big jump in car exports, many of them from Japan, lifted America's deficit with that country to $4.9 billion, the highest imbalance with Japan in the last 12 months.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aide Says Sudan Famine and Ban on Help Will Kill Thousands

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 18

 BODY:
An imminent famine in the Sudan and the Islamic Government's opposition to Western help have made it "all but certain" that hundreds of thousands of people will die of starvation in the Sudan next year, a senior United States official in that country has told Washington in a confidential cable.
It is too late to prevent many deaths, the official, Dr. Frederick E. Machmer Jr., director of the United States Agency for International Development in Khartoum, wrote in the message sent earlier this month. 
 The United States and the United Nations have suggested that the combination of drought, civil war and a Government that is bankrupt and ideologically driven indicate hard times to come in the Sudan. But the assessment by Dr. Machmer in his cable, was the most cataclysmic and specific so far.
"It is no longer a question of preventing deaths by starvation in the Sudan in 1991," Dr. Machmer told the State Department. "It is now a question of whether those deaths will number in the thousands, the tens of thousands, the hundreds of thousands, or even in the millions. I am willing to risk the point of view that, as of this date, it is all but certain that hundreds of thousands of innocent people in the Sudan are going to die of starvation in 1991."
 
Anti-Western Government
 The director said the hundreds of thousands would die "even if, repeat, even if the Government of the Sudan and all donors were to begin today working together with a maximum effort to address the situation."
Such predictions were almost unknown before the big famines in Ethiopia and the Sudan in 1984-85. There was less prior knowledge about crop patterns and harvests then, information that is now gathered from weather satellites and United Nations crop assessments.
Adding gloom to Dr. Machmer's analysis is the anti-Western nature of the Sudanese military Government, which has sided with Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. While the Sudanese and Ethiopian Governments in 1984-85 were not cooperative toward Western efforts to overcome the needs of the hungry, officials say they were not as obstructionist as the Islamic Government now in power in Khartoum.
Dr. Machmer, the A.I.D. director in Khartoum since the beginning of the year, held the post in Ethiopia during the 1984-85 famine there.
 
'Rather Alarmist' Analysis
 But the director of Africa operations for the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva, Pierre Gasman, described Dr. Machmer's analysis as "rather alarmist." The Khartoum Government has stopped Mr. Gasman's organization from continuing its relief efforts in the Sudan.
"Deep down, from experience as old Africa hands, we are not as alarmist," Mr. Gasman said. "But we don't have the information -- either the hard information or the software that these guys have."
At a news conference in Nairobi Friday, Dr. Machmer said the food needs in the Sudan for next year were greater than the needs in Ethiopia in 1984-85, when according to estimates 250,000 to one million people died of hunger.
Dr. Machmer said he agreed with the estimate of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations that the Sudan needed 1.2 million tons of food for next year, all of which would have to be imported. About one-third of the Sudan's 24 million people will be in need of food rations in 1991, he said.
 
Food Transport Problems
 But, he said, given poor road conditions, lack of truck spare parts, disorganization and obstruction, that much food could not be moved into Port Sudan, unloaded, and trucked to areas in need.
American officials insisted that the Sudanese junta's sympathy to Iraq in the gulf crisis has not affected Washington's willingness to help civilians. But the anti-Western sentiments of the Government made it hard to get food in, the officials said.
The Government has long sought to keep aid from reaching the south, where support is strong for the rebels who are challenging the Government based in Khartoum. The People's Liberation Army rebels from the African and animist and Christian south have fought a long and draining civil war against the Government, based in the Arab and Muslim north. While famine was previously harsh in the south, the new threat is worse because the rains have also failed in the north.
American and other Western officials say the Government of Lieut. Gen. Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir has confiscated food intended for southerners and bombed towns in the south while Red Cross and relief efforts were in progress.
 
Fear of Terrorist Attacks
 As another example of the inadequacy of relying on the Government to deliver Western food aid, American officials pointed to 19,000 tons of food that has disappeared since the World Food Program delivered it to Port Sudan last month. The officials said they believed some of it, but not much, had gone to civilians in the northern province of Kordofan, one of the hardest hit by drought.
Dr. Machmer recommended in his cable that the United States rely solely on nongovernmental Western humanitarian agencies to distribute the food, thus boycotting the Sudanese Government agencies. But American officials said that with the gulf crisis and the instability of the Sudanese Government, such agencies were having difficulty hiring people willing to work in the Sudan. Because of worry about terrorist attacks, United States Government officials may be evacuated from the Sudan in the coming weeks, several American officials said.
Washington has pledged 100,000 tons of food for next year, but stated that it expected the Khartoum Government to meet certain conditions. Those include a halt to bombings of civilian targets in the rebellious south, where Western donors are trying to deliver food through the United Nations. Washington has told the Government that it expects donated food to be delivered to people in the south as well as the north.

HEADLINE: SOCIAL SECURITY IS SHORT OF MONEY

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Commissioner of Social Security said today that she would ask the White House and Congress for additional funds because the money provided in the recent budget agreement was not enough to operate the agency through the remaining nine months of the current fiscal year.
The Commissioner, Gwendolyn S. King, said she would ask the White House to release a "contingency reserve" of $146.4 million and was preparing a separate request to Congress for supplemental appropriations. 
 Her plans came to light as the Federal budget director, Richard G. Darman, notified more than 100 Government agencies of his preliminary decisions on their budget requests for the next fiscal year. In most cases, he allowed less than had been requested.
Cabinet officers and other agency administrators have until the end of this week to challenge those decisions. President Bush will send his 1992 budget to Congress in early February, eight months before the start of the fiscal year 1992.
 
Benefits Are Not Jeopardized
 Congress earmarked $4.2 billion to cover the administrative costs of Social Security in the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. But Mrs. King and other Social Security officials said the amount was not enough.
The shortage could adversely affect services to Social Security beneficiaries, but does not in any way jeopardize the benefits of people who are legally entitled to them. Benefit payments are not subject to the statutory limit on administrative expenses.
In a memorandum analyzing the problem, Janice L. Warden, Acting Deputy Commissioner of Social Security, said the spending limits set by Congress "will cause severe cutbacks to public service" provided by Social Security field offices.
"We project that field offices, teleservice centers and program service centers will run out of supplies by the middle of the fiscal year," she wrote.
 
Effect on Training Cited
 Ms. Warden warned the agency's central records office, which makes a permanent record of earnings for millions of American workers, "will run out of both office and computer supplies during the second quarter" of the fiscal year, from January through March 1991.
In addition, she said that as a result of budget constraints, "we will not be able to provide sufficient training to the technicians we will hire this year."
Even low-paid Social Security employees are now expected to work with computers, Ms. Warden said, adding, "We gain little advantage in hiring new staff if we cannot give them adequate training."
Peter C. Toland, manager of the Boston office of the Social Security Administration, said he shared Ms. Warden's concerns.
"From October through early December of this year we have not been able to order supplies like computer paper and forms for the filing of claims, except in real emergencies," said Mr. Toland, who is president of a national group representing Social Security field office managers.
 
Agency's Staff Cut by 21%
 The problems are exacerbated by the fact that the staff of the Social Security Administration has been cut by 21 percent, or 17,000 people, over the last six years, even as the number of beneficiaries was increasing.
Officials in the Bush Administration contend that Social Security employees, working with new computers, are more productive. But Mr. Toland said the personnel cuts "have resulted in reduced service to the public."
Mrs. King said the Administration would ask Congress for extra money to review claims filed by hundreds of thousands of poor children with severe physical and mental disabilities. The Supreme Court ruled in February that the Government had improperly denied benefits to such children, using eligibility criteria far stricter than those established by law.
"Readjudication of the children's disability cases will require a tremendous amount of additional resources," Mrs. King said. She did not specify the cost.
 
Claims for Jobless Benefits
 The Labor Department is also drafting plans for a supplemental budget request to cover administrative costs of the unemployment insurance program. Those costs have soared with the increase in claims for jobless benefits across the country.
Congress provided nearly $2 billion to operate unemployment insurance offices in the current fiscal year. Cheryl A. Templeman, a spokeswoman for the Interstate Conference of Employment Security Agencies, said at least $150 million more was needed to keep up with the increase in claims. The conference is composed of state officials who administer unemployment insurance laws.
Other Federal agencies are also considering supplemental budget requests. For example, Medicare officials said they did not have enough money to pay contractors who review claims filed by Medicare beneficiaries, doctors and hospitals.
Donald R. Cohodes, administrator of Federal programs at the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said the 1991 budget for contractors was inadequate, in part because Medicare officials had underestimated the number of claims.
Without additional funds, he said, those who provide health care "will not be paid promptly for their Medicaid services" and "improper payments will inadvertently be made" from Medicare trust funds.

HEADLINE: In the U.S., Haitians Take Their Joy to the Streets

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
In the cramped Soleil Restaurant in Manhattan, behind steaming dishes of conch and red snapper and piles of rice and red beans, emotions soared yesterday as Haitians celebrated the victory of a man some called Haiti's Mandela or Martin Luther King Jr.
Taxi drivers, engineers, students, they pounded the tables of the restaurant at 10th Avenue and 57th Street, the din of their French and Creole drowning out the orders of some frustrated clients. 
 It was but a small slice of the fevered exultation among New York City's estimated 350,000 Haitians over the victory of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the priest who was elected President of Haiti on Sunday in the country's first democratic elections.
"He is defending the poor like Christ defended the poor," said Frantz Fequiere, 36 years old, a taxi driver who received a law degree in Haiti before coming to New York 10 years ago. "This is a day for jubilation. We finally have hope and we have shown that democracy can exist in Haiti."
 
'Pure Democracy at Work'
 At the next table, Joseph Saint-Hilaire, a Transit Authority engineer, described the election as proof that Haitians were capable of creating democracy on their own. "For us it is like a second independence," he said. "We have finally been able to see pure democracy at work."
Celebrations started on Sunday night along Eastern Parkway, a mostly Haitian area in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, which was cloaked with red and blue Haitian flags as people gathered to dance, drink and sing. In other Haitian neighborhoods on the East Coast the mood was also euphoric. In Little Haiti in Miami, thousands of cheering revelers improvised a vast street party.
Father Aristide, a 37-year-old Roman Catholic priest, is an advocate of liberation theology, a Latin American-based movement that holds that priests have a moral obligation to help the poor politically. This has won him wide support among the young and impoverished in Haiti.
In New York, whose Haitian population represents a cross-section of Haitian society, there was overwhelming support for Father Aristide, too.
"Haiti has reached a point where the country cannot be in any worse state," said Ricot Dupuy, program director of Radio Tropical, a 24-hour Haitian radio station that closely reported the elections. "Something has to be done that goes beyond the realm of traditional politics. The key to Aristide and his power is that he can talk to the people and they will listen."
 
Heavily Favored by Callers
 During the campaign, Radio Tropical, which did not back any candidate, dedicated its talk shows entirely to Haitian politics. Callers said they favored Father Aristide by a margin of 10 to 1, Mr. Dupuy said.
The greatest worry among Haitian expatriates is that the army may not remain on the sidelines until February, when Father Aristide will officially take over.
"Whenever there is a radical change, it will always scare people," said Joseph Etienne, director of the Haitian Centers Council in New York. "But we have a Consitution. This is not a revolution. Aristide has to abide by it."
The election campaign appears to have created some divisions among Haitian New Yorkers. One weekly newspaper, Haiti Progres, backed Father Aristide while another, Haiti Observateur, backed his closest rival, Marc L. Bazin, a former World Bank economist. Both papers have a circulation of more than 60,000.
 
Publisher Reports Threats
 Leo Joseph, publisher of Haiti Observateur, said that the election aroused strong emotions and that his newspaper had received threats.
"This is the first time I have seen the community so aggressive," Mr. Joseph said. "No doubt Aristide is a popular man. But we feel Aristide has a very violent language and he is a divisive influence in Haitian society. Promoting justice in his own camp may mean resorting to violence to settle certain scores."
Haiti Progres predicted the Aristide victory last Tuesday, George Honorat, a spokesman for the paper said.
He also said his circulation had significantly increased over the last few weeks. One of the paper's criticisms of Mr. Bazin was that he was linked too closely to other countries, in particular the United States. Many in the community agreed.
"Aristide is a very lucid politician," Mr. Dupuy said. "He won because he understood his candidacy was not challenged by the U.S. and he understood that the world is not what it used to be."
At Le Soleil Restaurant, Haitians recounted the history of their country and heatedly argued over what might happen after February. "We are at the crossraods of history," Franklin Pierre told Mr. Saint-Hilaire, jabbing him playfully in the arm. "But let's be realists. Haiti has many problems. We will contribute to change but it may not happen tomorrow."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Cut in Discount Rate Lifts Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Although widely anticipated, the Federal Reserve Board's decision to cut its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 6 1/2 percent, was enthusiastically received in the credit markets yesterday. Treasury note and bond prices posted strong gains, and interest rates fell.
For the past few weeks analysts had been saying that the Fed would have to lower the discount rate, if only because the overnight Federal funds rate, the market rate the Fed most directly controls, was being moved steadily down toward 7 percent. Generally the funds rate trades at a higher level than the discount rate. 
 Indeed, in announcing the change the Fed said that one of the reasons for the cut was to realign the discount rate with other market rates.
But traders and analysts said the Fed's admission that the cut was being made against a background of "weakness in the economy, constraints on credit and slow growth in the monetary aggregates" was the real reason the market reacted so positively to the move.
The timing of the step -- as members of the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee were meeting in Washington -- was also seen as highly significant. Under Alan Greenspan, its chairman, the Fed has tended to move in a more deliberate fashion.
"The Fed is not panicking, but they have stepped on the accelerator," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "It means that another cut in the funds rate is a given, and that a move to 6.75 percent very soon is highly probable. The market got the message real fast."
 
Decline in Fed Funds Rate
 Indeed, shortly after the Fed's announcement the Fed funds rate fell to 7 percent, where it stayed much of the rest of the day. Analysts said they expected to see confirmation today from the Fed that it has endorsed a further quarter-point cut in the funds rate, which since early December has been trading around a target level of 7 1/4 percent.
If the Fed validates a drop to 7 percent, it will mean it has lowered the closely monitored rate by a full percentage point in less than two months.
Analysts said the cut in the discount rate sent a clear message to commercial banks that it was time to lower their prime lending rate. A few institutions lowered the prime to 9 3/4 percent earlier this month, and Norwest Bank in Minneapolis announced late yesterday that it would cut its prime to that level, effective today. But virtually all other banks have kept the prime at 10 percent for nearly a year.
"A cut in the discount rate is purely symbolic," said Darwin L. Beck, a money market economist at the First Boston Corporation. "But it is one that may get the banks' attention."
Analysts noted with satisfaction that bond yields, which had fallen during early trading, moved even lower on the discount rate news.
Bond traders often do not like the inflationary implications of a drop in the discount rate, and respond by selling long-term securities.
"The Fed took a risk, and the market has given the Fed this round," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. "There is no hint of an inflation revolt in the bond market."
 
30-Year Bond Offering
 By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 107 14/32, up more than a point, or more than $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.07 percent.
A report that showed the Consumer Price Index rose by a modest three-tenths of a percentage point in November helped send up bond prices early in the session. So too did an unidentified buyer, believed to be Japanese, who openly purchased more than $1 billion worth of bonds.
Treasury note prices posted strong gains, and short-term bill rates fell sharply.
By late in the day, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 5/ 32, up 7/8 point, to yield 7.88 percent. And the 7 3/8 percent two-year notes rose by 10/32, to a price of 100 15/32, to yield 7.11 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 6.59 percent, down 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 6.57 percent.
Response to the Fed's move in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities was more muted than in the Treasury market.
Traders said that prices of most corporate bonds rose by about 1/2 point. Activity in Citicorp securities was very light, with little change in prices, the traders added. Citicorp announced yesterday that it would have losses of $300 million to $400 million in the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Hospital, Family Doctor and Benefactor

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
The procedure was a spinal tap, and Eldris Green stared intently as the doctors behind the glass window at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center plunged a needle into the spine of a tiny baby. Other students wriggled uncomfortably, but Eldris did not flinch. She was born at the hospital, lives a few blocks away and will have a summer job there this year. She may well work there full time when she grows up.
Eldris, 15 years old, was one of 50 ninth graders from the nearby Taft High School who visit the hospital once a week to learn -- early -- about health care careers. In today's bureaucratic jargon, that kind of recruiting of inner-city youth is called "mentoring," but it harks back to old-fashioned patronage.
 
$200 Million Renovation
 If that insular, seven-square-mile section of the South Bronx can be viewed as a small town, then it is a company town, and Bronx-Lebanon is the company. Its two towering complexes, one on the Grand Concourse, the other a mile away on Fulton Avenue, straddle the nation's poorest Congressional district -- an area of the South Bronx where the median income is well below the poverty line and there are more abandoned buildings than trees, more storefront churches than stores or churches. The hospital is the largest private employer in the South Bronx. Almost by default, it also provides its community with drug-addiction treatment, half-way houses, social welfare services, housing, job training, counseling and health education. 
 At dusk, the streets empty and the hospital waiting rooms fill with people who have no family doctor or insurance or, more simply, no other place to go. It's the kind of community where only crack houses and the hospital's emergency room operate 24 hours a day.
More than 70 percent of the hospital's 3,200 employees live in the immediate area, just about everyone except the doctors. "We're not just a hospital," said Miguel A. Fuentes, the president of the hospital. "We are an economic anchor in the South Bronx."
Bronx-Lebanon is a private nonprofit hospital that accepts patients regardless of their ability to pay and that almost went bankrupt in the early 1980's treating its increasingly indigent clientele. Rescued by an influx of special funds earmarked for "financially distressed hospitals," Bronx-Lebanon is now solvent and undergoing a state-financed $200 millionrenovation and expansion that will increase its bed capacity from 574 to 677 -- government money given with the understanding that the hospital provides more to the community than just medical services.
Health care, Borough President Fernando Ferrer said, is "the Bronx's single largest industry," and Bronx-Lebanon, in particular, illustrates the grim paradox that rules many inner cities: illness is the community's greatest blight, and it is also its chief economic linchpin.
"Here, health care will always need employees," said Margaret Hutton, 38, who has worked as an emergency room nurse for the last 10 years and watched the patient population grow -- and grow ever younger and sicker. Her husband also works there, as a lab technician. "The hospital," she said, "is the only place where jobs are secure." She said she hoped and expected her that her 12-year-old daughter would work in pediatrics there some day.
 
'Accepted the Responsibility'
 "The only good thing that has come out of our AIDS epidemic is that it has channeled money into this community," said Dr. Jerome Ernst, an AIDS researcher and clinician who says 20 percent of the hospital's patients under 40 are HIV infected. "The hospital has given us the money; it's not afraid of being branded as an AIDS hospital. They have accepted the responsibility -- that's why I am still here."
Bronx-Lebanon employs 200 attending physicians and 120 full-time social workers -- more than 40 of those work exclusively with HIV-infected patients who even after they leave need help filling Medicaid claims, finding child care, housing, clothing or even a meal. Last month the hospital distributed 100,000 pounds of food.
The hospital, which is a partner with three local community groups and coalitions in an effort to build new housing in the area, is simultaneously spilling out onto the surrounding streets and drawing outsiders within its walls: the office of Community Board 4 is in one of the Grand Concourse buildings, and in January Community Board 3 plans to move into an office in the Fulton division. Bronx-Lebanon, which employs 114 guards, recently set up its own 24-hour security station a block away from the hospital -- in a sense, helping to police its own neighborhood.
 
Urban Enterprise Zone
 Particularly in the Fulton division, the part of the hospital that fills two blocks on Fulton Avenue, an area far from the epicenter of Bronx "revitalization," the main signs of vitality are hospital construction sites: there, across the street from the pre-World War I building is a new pink and white granite almost-completed 240-bed nursing home. Half of the new building will be reserved for AIDS patients, and it will be the city's first free-standing AIDS nursing home. In the neighborhood, it is viewed as a kind of urban enterprise zone.
The ill worry more about services than jobs."They fixed it up real nice," said Carmen Gearhart, 25, of the renovated waiting area of the emergency room, "but the service is still so slow."
 
No Other Doctor
 Mrs. Gearhart, who had carried her feverish 9-month-old boy into the Grand Concourse emergency room at 9 A.M., was still there, waiting for blood test results, at 6 P.M. Overcrowding, a shortage of beds and long waits are endemic at Bronx-Lebanon. "Our patients don't have a family doctor, whatever problem they have," explained Dr. Luis Maceira, an emergency room physician. "They have to come to the hospital instead."
Unlike most of the other doctors, Dr. Maceira, 44, does not commute to Bronx-Lebanon from the suburbs. He was raised in the South Bronx and left high school in the 10th grade to become an Air Force mechanic in Vietnam. When he returned, many of his neighborhood friends worked in the hospital, and he first considered becoming a nurse or an X-ray technician. But he discovered those fields had three-year waiting lists. Almost by default, he became a doctor, starting medical school at the age of 31. He decided to stay in the South Bronx, he says, to "help the community" and also because "all my friends are from the area."
Bronx-Lebanon is not very well known outside the Bronx. As Judy Turnock, a community organizer put it, "This is a community hospital -- the Shah of Iran doesn't come here for heart surgery." But for those who live in the area, it is one constant in a neighborhood that keeps changing and rarely for the better. "Our care can't be that bad," Mrs. Hutton said with a laugh. "We employees all say we would never go there as patients, but as soon as we get sick, we go to Bronx-Lebanon."

HEADLINE: Global Markets Lure 'Baby Bells'

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The regional Bell telephone companies are moving aggressively into foreign countries, eager to enter profitable businesses from which they are barred in the United States and to gain access to markets that have room for growth.
Earlier this month the Government of Mexico announced its intention to sell a controlling interest in Telefonos de Mexico to a consortium that includes the Southwestern Bell Corporation for $1.76 billion. In September, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Ameritech teamed up to buy New Zealand's telephone company for $2.4 billion. 
 At least nine governments are seriously weighing plans to put their state-owned telephone companies up for sale in the months ahead and others may follow. They are Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Malaysia, the Netherlands, Portugal, Puerto Rico, Singapore, Uruguay and Venezuela. Australia plans to sell its satellite company and to license the new owners to compete with the existing telephone company.
Meanwhile, countries including Britain, Czechoslovakia, Israel and Poland are auctioning off franchises for cellular systems, paging services and cable television.
Among the ventures announced so far: Pacific Telesis is part of a consortium building a cellular system in Germany; U S West and Bell Atlantic are building a cellular system in Czechoslovakia; Southwestern Bell has acquired stakes in cable television franchises in Britain and Israel, and BellSouth is weighing a bid to buy Puerto Rico's telephone company.
Because Puerto Rico is a United States commonwealth, a Bell Company would be subject to the same regulatory restrictions that Bell companies face in this country if it buys the state-owned phone company, .
Perhaps most alluring to the Bells, many of these governments are dangling the prospect of regulatory control less restrictive than that imposed on them in the United States. The Bells are barred in this country from providing long-distance service and cable television, as well as from owning information services and manufacturing equipment. As a result, they remain largely confined to the local telephone business, which is stable and profitable but grows only about 4 percent a year.
"The most important driving force for the companies is the total conviction that the internal market in the United States can't grow as fast as the international market," said Andres Bande, president of Ameritech International, the international subsidiary of the American Information Technologies Corporation. "They realize that they need to expand internationally and to diversify."
But the proposed deals vary enormously, and present a host of political and economic uncertainties. Will the host governments remain as friendly as they are today, or will they see the foreign-dominated telephone companies as an easy political target for stiff taxation and even nationalization? Can the Bell companies turn a profit in countries where the telephone system must be overhauled almost entirely? Will governments in countries suffering from periodic bouts of hyperinflation let the telephone companies raise their rates enough to keep pace?
"Investment in a basic industry like telephones is analogous to investment in a basic industry like oil," said Thomas Gage, a management consultant in McLean, Va., with a large practice in telecommunications. He cited American oil companies that invested abroad in the 1970's. "You can see that all kinds of things can happen," he said. "You can be taxed very heavily. You can be restricted in your activities. You can be required to invest in collateral areas that add to the public good but don't add to earnings. And then there is the long-term risk: How do you get out? Is this a perpetual deal?"
The Bell companies are acutely aware of these issues, and are trying to pick their targets carefully. Although the bidding has been intense on the comparatively small deals involving cellular franchises, the few big deals thus far have not attracted a feeding frenzy among buyers. Still, at least some of the Bell companies view the wave of privatizations as the hottest development in their industry.
"People have become aware that they don't have to wait five minutes for a telephone connections," said Raymond W. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Bell Atlantic. "It's this dissatisfaction with service that they now have, and the recognition that it can be much better, that have converged to drive the trend toward privatization."
 
Logic Is Clear
 It is still too early to know whether the Bells' new ventures will turn out to be successful, but the logic and in some cases the perils are already quite clear. Of the recent Mexican and New Zealand deals, each holds an entirely different allure.
Telecom New Zealand has a relatively high household penetration and earned profits of $148 million last year. Bell Atlantic and Ameritech, which will be allowed to provide local, long-distance and international telephone service as well as cellular and paging services, hope to increase earnings by cutting costs and by introducing an array of data-communications and information services.
Under terms of the deal, the company cannot raise rates for residential telephone service by more than the rate of inflation. But, in sharp contrast to the United States, the company faces almost no restrictions on rates for business customers and is free to assemble innovative packages of local, long-distance and even data-base services.
 
The Mexican Deal
 In the Mexican deal, Southwestern Bell and its partners must contend with one of the most antiquated systems in Latin America. Telephone service reaches only one in 17 households, and people who do have phones must often wait several minutes for a dial tone. By the same token, the country constitutes a huge opportunity for expansion and investment in basic telephone service. The new owners of Telmex will be able to provide local and long-distance service, without the restrictions that would be imposed in this country.
Daniel P. Reingold, a telecommunications analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, said that earnings from Telecom New Zealand are expected to climb 15 to 20 percent a year, and add slightly less than 1 percent a year to the earnings growth of both Bell Atlantic and Ameritech. For 1991, he said, that translates into total earnings of $1.3 billion for Ameritch, an increase of 5.5 percent over 1990, and earnings of $1.5 billion for Bell Atlantic, an increase of 6.5 percent.
He said the impact of Southwestern Bell's interest in Telmex is expected to be negligible in 1991 and increase earnings growth by five-tenths of 1 percent in 1992.
 
Nynex Drops Out
 Despite the potential, the bidding for Telmex turned out to be quite subdued. A consortium formed by the Nynex Corporation, Bell Canada Enterprises and Casa de Bolsa Inverlat Associates, a Mexican investment banking firm, dropped out the day the bids were due. A Nynex spokesman would say only that "outstanding issues could not be resolved." Although several other Bell companies looked at the deal, only Southwestern Bell participated.
People who have looked at terms being imposed by the Mexican Government cite troubling concerns for any buyer, including questions about how much management control the new owners will have. Under the deal, the new owners will acquire 51 percent of the voting rights in the company, but only 20.4 percent of the shares.
A different set of worries derailed an attempt to buy part of Argentina's telephone system this year. Argentina had approved a $2.3 billion bid by a consortium organized by Manufacturers Hanover Trust. Under the proposed deal, Bell Atlantic was to manage the system as a hired contractor. Manufacturers Hanover had planned to put up $100 million in cash, and pay for the rest through an exchange of Argentine Government debt.
But the deal unraveled, largely because the bank was unable to persuade institutions holding the Argentine debt to exchange their notes for equity in the telephone company. Bell Atlantic officials attribute part of the impasse to a dispute with Argentine authorities over the ability to raise telephone rates -- a crucial issue in a country where inflation soared in the thousands of percent less than two years ago. According to a Bell Atlantic official, the American group wanted to tie telephone rates both to inflation and the exchange rate of the Argentine peso, but the Argentines insisted on linking it only to the inflation rate. On Oct. 5, the Argentine Government canceled its agreement with the consortium. One month later, it awarded the sale to a rival group headed by Morgan Guaranty Trust, France Telecom and STET S.p.A., the Italian telephone company.
The Argentine deal remains in dispute. Bell Atlantic and Manufacturers Hanover complain that the Argentines may have given the new consortium better terms than they received.

HEADLINE: BIGGEST U.S. BANK RETRENCHES AGAIN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
For banks, the bad news keeps coming. Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, announced yesterday that because of rising problems with bad loans it would cut its stock dividend sharply and lay off 4,400 more workers. It has already cut its work force by 3,600 this year.
The bank's troubles, which Citicorp said would mean a quarterly loss of $300 million to $400 million, are the latest reminder of the increasingly harsh conditions facing banks. Three months ago Chase Manhattan and Chemical, two of Citicorp's New York rivals, also cut dividends, laid off workers, added to their cushions against bad loans and posted quarterly losses. 
 Citicorp did not say where the job cuts would be made or how many would be in the New York area.
"Citicorp certainly survives, but the question is, How will it succeed?" said Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman, the Wall Street firm. "We are not optimistic about the economy, particularly in the Northeast. It is likely Citicorp will need further additions to reserves to reflect future deterioration" in the quality of its loans, he added.
Despite Citicorp's troubles, its stock jumped more than 5 percent yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, rising 75 cents a share, to $14.125, as the Federal Reserve acted to help the economy by cutting the rate it charges on loans to financial institutions, including banks.
Before yesterday's announcement, Citicorp had tried to handle its problems by cutting expenses, especially in its corporate lending offices in Europe and North America.
The company has so far avoided closing or selling significant parts of its highly profitable consumer banking business, which earns more than $1 billion annually, or the highly profitable parts of its global network of corporate lending offices outside of Europe and North America. It continues to have the largest international office network of any bank, though it is only the 10th-largest banking company in the world.
 
Deterioration Admitted
 Yesterday's announcement, which coincided with the end of a regular annual bank examination at Citibank, Citicorp's main subsidiary, was an admission that the company's problems had become worse. "Earlier this year, there was an air of almost defiance at Citicorp that they could cope with the problems by growing their way out of them," said James McDermott, president of the brokerage firm of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
Continued problems with bad loans would be a further blow to Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed. After earning accolades for the development of Citicorp's highly profitable consumer business, Mr. Reed has seen his reputation sullied by the increases in bad loans and higher expenses.
In recent months, the nationwide real estate slump and rise in defaults on bank loans by developers have been augmented by a broad-based slowdown in the economy that is causing increasing problems with loans to consumers and other kinds of businesses. Loan defaults have caused about 800 banks to fail over the last four years, resulting in four consecutive years of losses for the Government-run bank deposit insurance fund, including a record shortfall of about $5 billiion expected this year.
While Federal regulators are trying to devise plans to raise more funds for the deposit insurance fund, the Federal Reserve yesterday took immediate action in cutting the discount rate. Banks borrow little from the Federal Reserve, but its action was another sign that short-term interest rates would continue to fall.
 
Shift by Regulators Cited
 "Regulators' attitudes have shifted from seeming indifference to banks' troubles to support for the industry," said Mr. McDermott of Keefe, Bruyette.
Because Citicorp, like some other large banks, operates with only about $4 of shareholder funds for every $100 of assets, an increase in loan defaults by only a percentage point or two is enough to create serious problems.
To create more of a cushion to absorb future losses and satisfy Federal regulators, Citicorp said it would reduce the shareholder dividend to 25 cents a quarter, down from 44.5 cents. Analysts assume the dividend cut was a result of prompting by regulators who were upset early this year when Citicorp increased its dividend, despite weak earnings.
Earlier this month Mr. Reed said reducing the dividend was an inefficent way of raising capital because the money saved was too little compared with the lower price the company would receive when it next tried to sell stock. The dividend cut could save up to $260 million annually, but the actual savings will be reduced by the amount that investors reinvest in new shares of stock.
In another move to strengthen its financial condition, Citicorp is expected to announce a special $200 million increase in earnings by an accounting change in the way it records gains and losses from interest rate and currency swaps.
A significant increase in Citicorp's capital is expected soon from a sale of about $1 billion of convertible preferred stock to investors in Germany, Hong Kong, Singapore, Greece and Saudi Arabia. "I expect the earnings announcement will help clear the way for the completion of the private placement of convertible preferred stock," said Thomas Hanley, an analyst at Salomon Brothers.
 
Savings of $800 Million
 The fourth-quarter loss at Citicorp results from the $300 million cost of reducing by 8,000 workers a staff that at the end of 1989 stood at 90,500. The company estimated that in 1992 the cut in jobs plus other savings would amount to $800 million. About $300 million of the reduced expenses will come from pulling out of or selling some businesses.
Another part of the loss comes from a $340 million increase, which is subtracted from profits, in the $4.062 billion of reserves Citicorp held for troubled loans at the end of the third quarter. That increase is far smaller than the $2 billion or more some analysts have said is needed to bring Citicorp's reserves into line with its $9.7 billion of delinquent or troubled loans, but much larger than the $95 million the company added to the reserve in the third quarter.
Citicorp did not disclose yesterday how many bad loans it expects to write off as a loss, or how many loans it expects to list in a troubled category where interest and principal payments are counted toward profits only as they are received, not as they accrue. Both items are needed by analysts trying to estimate the severity of Citicorp's loan problems.
Mr. Hanley of Salomon Brothers said that a modest increase in loan charge-offs, such as the $600 million to $650 million that company officials have indicated is likely, "leaves reason to worry that earnings will continue to be hurt" by continued charge-offs at a high level and large additions to funds held in reserve. But if a much larger amount than $600 million of loans are written off, "then Citicorp will have made a significant move toward purging itself of the problems," he added.

HEADLINE: M.I.T. Deal With Japan Stirs Fear on Competition

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has agreed to teach Japanese scientists how to replicate a laboratory in which researchers are developing futuristic entertainment and education products, touching off an intense debate over scholarship and high technology.
Under the agreement, the Japanese are about to begin an effort to duplicate the creative atmosphere of M.I.T.'s Media Laboratory, which computer experts say is probably the world's only lab in which young scientists are being encouraged to pursue their most creative ideas in merging computers, television and films.
Critics say the $10 million contract is a crass sale of expertise in one of the few areas of computer science in which the Japanese say they are lacking: the ability to build a creative environment to generate new ideas. The critics also say the agreement does not require the Japanese to publish all the results of their research, as M.I.T. does.
But others defend the agreement, saying it is dangerous even to think of taking a protectionist view toward science. They say the university and the world can only benefit by having a Japanese counterpart to the university's media laboratory.
 
Race for High-Definition TV
 The research being conducted in the lab offers America what the experts say is its greatest hope in the race with Japan to develop and market high-definition television. Researchers at the lab have also found ways to send movies over telephone lines, instead of over the airwaves or over cable lines, so that instead of going to a video rental store, people will be able to call a number and have a movie transmitted to their television sets.
The researchers have also developed a technique they call interactive television, which allows viewers to use a computer to tailor television shows to their liking, focusing on one item in a news show or selecting a camera angle for a sports event.
Japanese executives speak of products like these when they say they were motivated to buy American movie studios with a goal of merging the technologies of computers, television and films. Last month the Matsushita Electrical Industrial Company bought MCA, owner of Universal Studios, and last year the Sony Corporation bought Columbia Pictures.
Researchers at the media lab say science cannot be restricted by national boundaries. They say that the more media labs, and the more people thinking of such ideas, the better. But critics say the real question is what, besides money, the university and the United States get out of the deal.
 
2 Japanese Interests
 The agreement is between M.I.T. and two Japanese interests: Nihon University and the Japanese industrialist Chiyoji Misawa, a leading builder who is interested in futuristic homes in which computers will control various functions, including regulating temperature, turning lights on and off and opening blinds to let in the sun.
In the debate in the United States, the opposing positions are represented by Pat Choate, an economist who is concerned by Japan's success in acquiring American products, and Andrew Lippman, the associate director of M.I.T.'s media lab.
"Of course it will hurt us," said Dr. Choate. "This kind of knowledge is a major underpinning of our future."
But Dr. Lippman said he believed that the world and American science would be better off if more scientists learned the M.I.T. style. "Right now, it's unfortunate that the media lab is unique in the breadth and scope of what it's doing," he said. "More media labs can only be better."
 
Questions on Competitiveness
 Another critic, Dr. Amar Bose, teaches electrical engineering and computer science at M.I.T. He is also founder and director of the Bose Corporation of Framingham, Mass., which designs and produces high-fidelity equipment. "The Japanese recognize that what they are lacking is in the creative side," he said. "They have been unable to develop that side of their economy and they know their future depends on it. So does ours, by the way. They know exactly what they want and they're prepared to go out and buy it.
"If you ask whether this is going to diminish ultimately the U.S. competitive position, the answer is yes."
Seigi Hinata, a spokesman at the Japanese Consulate in New York, agreed that the Japanese were developing basic research. "Up to now Japan has excelled in applying results of European and U.S. basic research," Mr. Hinata said. "But now we are beginning to put an emphasis on producing world-class research that will break new ground."
While the agreement was actually reached in 1987, it has not been publicized, even within the university. And the Japanese officials involved in the project only recently obtained the building permits needed to start work on the media laboratory in Japan, although a small lab has been in operation so some research techniques could be learned.
 
Details on Contract
 M.I.T. officials say the university will get nothing tangible, other than the $10 million, and they acknowledge that the agreement does not require the Japanese to publish all their results. "I don't know if M.I.T. gets anything out of it other than money," said Dr. Kenneth A. Smith, vice president for research at the university.
But Dr. Smith cautioned that he was not certain that a media lab like M.I.T.'s could be transplanted.
Dr. Nicholas Negroponte, founder and director of the media lab, said that under the terms of the agreement he could not release a copy of the contract without permission from the Japanese. But he agreed in a recent interview to discuss the arrangement.
Dr. Negroponte said the Japanese would pay M.I.T. the $10 million over five years. The money will go into M.I.T.'s $1.6 billion endowment, but in an informal arrangement, the money will be used to support the media lab.
So far, as part of the agreement, three Japanese scientists have spent a year each at M.I.T., learning the culture of the media lab and how to run a lab like it. In addition, Dr. Negroponte said, virtually every one of the 19 professors at the M.I.T. lab has gone to Japan and looked in on what he said was the "small prototype" of the lab that was created while the Japanese waited for permission to build the real thing.
 
Future Help From M.I.T.
 Two graduates of the M.I.T. media lab were hired this year to help start the Japanese laboratory, which is to be built in Chiba prefecture east of Tokyo. Once the new lab opens, M.I.T. researchers and students will regularly spend time there, the agreement said.
M.I.T.'s Media Laboratory is a fairly new venture, having opened in 1985. Timothy Browne, who had worked for the lab and now manages an interactive television project for McCann-Erickson World Wide, an advertising agency, said the media lab is dissimilar to any Japanese lab. "There are a lot of wild kids who are given a lot of responsibility and authority," he said of the researchers. "Stereos are blaring and there is a lot of laughter. Japanese labs are considerably more serious, and the researchers themselves aren't given that kind of responsibility and authority."
Dr. Negroponte said it costs $10 million a year to operate the media lab and that $9 million of this was provided by the Federal Government and private companies. The Government pays about 30 percent, he said. About 15 percent of the corporate money is provided by Japanese firms under previous agreements, Dr. Negroponte said.
The $10 million that the Japanese agreed to pay under the new contract is enormously important as a source of funds, Dr. Negroponte said. Asked what else is in the arrangement for M.I.T., he replied, "You mean the money isn't enough?"
Some experts say they have mixed feelings about the agreement, adding that their reaction would be determined by what the United States got out of the deal.
 
A Two-Way Flow?
 "It's really a hard call," said Dr. Joseph Nye, the director of the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University. "The critical question is whether there is a two-way flow."
But others say that from what they have heard, M.I.T.'s agreement may seriously harm American competitiveness.
"The Japanese are moving toward the year 2000 to have a research and development capacity that is equal to or greater than that of the U.S.," Dr. Choate said. "The Japanese intend to dominate us."
Making their own version of the media lab "is an integral step," he added.
Dr. Choate said that the Japanese arrangement makes him question whether it is wise for industries to invest in M.I.T. "The fact that M.I.T. is peddling off its media lab should be of great concern," he said.
Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategies Institute, a research organization in Washington, said: "I can't imagine Japan doing a similar kind of deal. It seems to me that we typically undervalue what we have."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up by Modest 0.3%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose a modest three-tenths of 1 percent in November, less than half the torrid oil-driven pace set during the three months immediately after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Labor Department figures showed today.
The slowdown reflected both moderation in energy prices, which benefited from diplomatic efforts to solve the crisis instead of threats of force, and a general weakness in the economy. That weakness has tended to put downward pressure on the prices of some items while preventing higher prices for energy.
When food and energy are excluded, the Consumer Price Index rose by the same three-tenths of 1 percent as when these volatile items are included. The rise in so-called core inflation has now been three-tenths of 1 percent for three straight months.
 
Strange Behavior for Housing
 While the November increase was about as expected, many analysts had braced for an unpleasant surprise since the largest element of the price index, housing, has been behaving strangely of late and because last week's report on prices at the producer level was worse than expected. 
 The reassurance provided by the modest rise in the consumer index appeared to extend to the Federal Reserve, whose governors announced this afternoon a half-point cut, to 6 1/2 percent, in the discount rate, the rate charged financial institutions when they borrow at the central bank. This move came as the Fed's Open Market Committee concluded a meeting to establish the course of monetary policy until early February.
Today's cut in interest rates was aimed at arresting the decline of the nation's economy, which seems to face little immediate risk of resurgent inflation and therefore provided the Fed the maneuvering room to lower the discount rate.
"There has been no diffusion of higher energy prices into the structure of prices," said Jeffrey R. Leeds, an economist at Chemical Bank. He added that any inflation threat remained "very latent."
One inflation cloud, however, did loom larger today as the Government reported an increase in the nation's trade deficit for October that included a $5 billion jump in imports, about $1 billion of which was from the jump in the price of oil.
The dollar's extremely weak performance in world currency markets makes the situation even worse since it raises the price of imported goods, which thereby provide an unbrella under which domestic producers can raise their own prices.
 
Trend Called Troubling
 William T. Archey, a vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said the October trade figures might be a fluke but added that "if they represent a trend, it is a troubling one as it would represent a major inflationary problem for the United States economy."
For now, however, the risks lie clearly with the slumping economy, not rising prices. Only one of the seven main consumer price categories, food and beverages, showed inflation quickening last month and this was mostly the result of higher prices for fruits and vegetables.
This 2.7 percent upturn and faster increases in the price of beef more than offset declines for poultry, dairy products and cereal and bakery products. Food prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent after three straight months of rises of three-tenths.
 
Least Rise Since May
 The housing component, which accounts for 42 percent of the consumer index and includes fuel, utilities, furnishings and maintenance, rose by only two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the least since May and far less than the increases of five-tenths between June and October. The narrower shelter component had jumped at an annual rate of 10.5 percent for the three months ended in August but this rate has slipped to 1.4 percent for the latest three months.
Labor Department and other Government officials continue to seek an explanation for the midyear bulge in shelter costs, which has baffled private analysts as well. One theory is that landlords were raising rents to offset declining returns on real estate investments but evidence has not yet been found to support this.
Gasoline rose three-tenths of 1 percent following a 7.7 percent October jump. New cars rose for the second straight month -- 1991 models are higher priced even though they are not selling well -- but used cars again fell. Public transportation rose 2.6 percent last month, mostly because of a 3.6 percent increase in airline fares that have now risen 8.4 percent in the last three months.
Apparel prices posted a second straight drop of two-tenths of 1 percent, with declines widespread during the early Christmas shopping season for everything except men's clothing.
 
Services and Commodities Up
 Services, accounting for 55 percent of the price index, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November while commodities, at 45 percent, rose two-tenths, the report also showed.
For the first 11 months of 1990 consumer inflation has run at a 6.4 percent annual rate, up from 4.6 percent for the similar 1989 period, with energy primarily responsible.
Among the five metropolitan areas for which price figures are published monthly, Chicago's rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent was the only large change. New York posted a one-tenth decline as shelter and clothing costs fell and food was unchanged.
Before rounding, the price index, which covers all urban consumers, rose 0.300750 percent in November, a rate that if maintained for 12 months and compounded would result in an annual inflation rate of 3.7 percent.
With the index now standing at 133.8, this means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-84 now costs $13.38.
The Labor Department also reported today that average weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation and seasonality, rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month after falling 2.2 percent in October.
