HEADLINE: BUSH SAYS BUDGET MAY BAR A TAX CUT FOR CAPITAL GAINS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
President Bush suggested for the first time today that budget constraints would prevent him from proposing a cut in the capital gains tax next year.
"I haven't given up my philosophical commitment to the idea that capital gains would stimulate growth," the President said at a news conference with regional reporters. "But we're faced with this practical problem as to what we can do, not just on capital gains but on other stimulants that cost money." 
 Mr. Bush was badly bruised politically this year in his unsuccessful attempt to win a lower tax rate on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments like stocks, bonds and real estate. Democrats argued that the proposal would have benefited rich people for the most part, and they managed to portray the President as the patron of fat cats.
In an interview Monday evening, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said he was recommending against trying again for such a tax cut next year because he thought it would lead to a fight with Congress that the Administration could not win.
 
No More Discussions
 "Why would you get back into that discussion again?" Mr. Brady asked, asserting that the Democrats would demand "an enormous increase in income taxes" to offset the capital gains cut.
"I don't see any point in doing that," the Secretary said, "because the President won't raise taxes."
A failure by Mr. Bush to offer a capital gains proposal would surely disappoint conservatives who believe lower capital gains taxes are essential for economic recovery. Without the President's total commitment, such a measure has almost no chance of enactment.
Capital gains are now taxed at the same rate as other income like wages, salaries and dividends -- in most cases, 28 percent or 33 percent. The budget law enacted this fall would require the wealthiest taxpayers to pay 28 percent on capital gains but 31 percent on their other income.
Last year, the President proposed that 30 percent of all capital gains be excluded from taxation, the effect of which would have been a top capital gains rate of about 20 percent under either the old or new law.
The most powerful argument the Democrats had against that proposal was a table prepared by Congressional staff tax specialists showing that 66 percent of the benefits would go to taxpayers with incomes above $200,000 and that 83 percent would go to those with incomes above $100,000.
No one disputes that the direct beneficiaries of a lower capital gains tax would be the affluent, since they are mainly the ones who have investments to sell. But Mr. Bush and his top advisers have argued that the entire economy would benefit from a capital gains tax cut because that would encourage more investment and thus more jobs.
Now, the Administration is making a new argument, holding that the way the Democrats in Congress calculate, or in budget jargon "score," the distribution of the benefits among income groups is misguided. If it were calculated the right way, Administration officials argue, the richest taxpayers would appear to pay more taxes.
 
Rarely Discussed in Public
 Mr. Bush alluded to that argument at his news conference today. "What I'd love to think is that we could change the way we score it to a more realistic view," he said.
A dispute between Congress and the Administration over how to calculate the effects of a capital gains tax reduction has been going on behind the scenes since early in the Reagan years. But the facts are so arcane and the explanation is so complicated that it has rarely been discussed in public.
The decision by Administration officials to make a public issue of it now was interpreted by Democratic tax and budget experts on the staff of Congress as an effort to find a way to explain to conservative supporters why the President would be forced to back away from his campaign promise to press for a lower capital gains tax. The real reason, these staff members said, was that Mr. Bush did not want to fight another losing political battle on the issue.
The dispute over the calculations involves two related issues.
The first is the Administration's view, disputed in Congress, that a lower capital gains rate would actually raise revenue for the Government. No capital gains tax is paid until investments are sold. If a lower tax encouraged more people to sell more investments, the Administration's argument goes, the Government would receive more tax payments.
 
A Question With No Answer
 Congressional experts acknowledge that there would be more tax payments at first as people sold investments, but they maintain that in the long run the Government would lose money. This disagreement can never be resolved conclusively, since the decision to sell investments involves much more than the capital gains rate.
The second issue is whether the benefits to various income classes should be based on the amount of taxes paid or on the extent to which those paying the capital gains tax would be better off economically following a cut in its rate. The Administration bases its calculations on the former, while Congress uses the gauge of overall economic betterment. This is essentially a political question that has no right or wrong answer.
Economists disagree over which is the proper way to do it. Paradoxically, one of the foremost academic articles on the question was written almost three years ago by Lawrence B. Lindsey, then a professor at Harvard and now an assistant to President Bush on tax and economic matters.
Mr. Lindsey, who wrote the article with Jane G. Gravelle, the top tax scholar at the Library of Congress, came down on the side of the Congressional methodology. The article stated, "With a lower tax rate, these upper-income taxpayers are less burdened than they were before, even though they pay more taxes."
An economist for the House Ways and Means Committee put the argument this way: "What you're trying to drive at is the economic well-being of a group of people. The fact that they are selling more than they would otherwise tells me they're better off."
On the other hand, Administration experts make a powerful argument that even if rich people are better off with a lower capital gains rate, no one is worse off. Therefore, they say, it is wrong to imply, as the Congressional tables do, that poor and middle-class taxpayers would somehow be disadvantaged by lower capital gains rates.

HEADLINE: Educators See Need for Diversity on Campus, but Debate How to Achieve It

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's struggle to define its stand on awarding scholarships designated exclusively for certain racial or ethnic minorities has prompted a debate in the academic world.
When Michael L. Williams, head of the Education Department's Office of Civil Rights, originally ruled earlier this month that such scholarships were illegal, many educators, social commentators and philosophers were quick to express either delight or dismay. 
 But now that the Bush Administration has retreated from the policy, fewer of them were willing to discuss it directly. Instead, many preferred to move the discussion toward what they called the underlying issues, saying that these are too pervasive to be resolved by a single policy decision.
These issues, they said, include affirmative action, preferential treatment and the demands for racial and cultural diversity on college campuses in the 1990's.
In recent years, American colleges and universities have increased their academic and financial aid to racial and ethnic minorities who have historically lagged far behind whites in entering higher education. And in the 1980's as Federal grants began to be replaced by loans, many colleges eager to recruit more minority students began to compensate by offering scholarships to them, sometimes out of their own budgets.
 
Create 'Model Societies'
 Richard F. Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, said the 815 institutions that belong to the association remain dedicated to finding ways for minority students to enter private colleges because society demands it.
He said that colleges have a larger responsibility than simply educating in the classroom, and that they must create "model societies by bringing together diverse people so that they may reason and learn how to live with each other."
Mr. Williams and many of his supporters have said that scholarships earmarked for minorities should be recast into financial aid based on need and be aimed at students from economically disadvantaged families. Many minority students would still be served by this approach, he suggested.
But a report prepared by the American Council on Education, a Washington-based higher education association, found that even among middle-income blacks and Hispanic Americans, there has been a severe decline in college entrance rates in the last few years.
 
Fewer Seeking Degrees
 By 1986, the report said, "the enrolled-in-college participation rate of middle-income African Americans had fallen to 36 percent, from 53 percent in 1976." Among Hispanic students, the rate was 46 percent in 1988, compared with 53 percent 13 years earlier.
More generally, the number of blacks, American Indians and Hispanic Americans obtaining bachelor's and master's degrees from 1985 to 1987 continued to show large declines, the report said. The report did not come to any conclusions as to why the declines occurred.
Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, said the statistics sketch a distressing vision of the future.
"You have an unhappy participation rate in the first place," he said. "You have a crying need for minorities in the labor force in the 10 years immediately ahead. And we know that that labor force is going to have a lot of jobs that require a post-secondary education."
That, he said, creates a powerful justification to continue to have effective programs to help minority members afford a college education.
The decision on minority scholarships has drawn more than criticism. There has also been passionate support.
On the NBC program "Today" yesterday, John Bunzel, a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution, a conservative research organization in California, argued forcefully with the president of Xavier University, Norman Francis, that scholarships based on an applicant's race undermine the nation's sense of equality.
 
Opened the Subject
 Thomas Sowell, author of "Preferential Policies: An International Perspective," wrote in The Wall Street Journal on Monday that the only people who would have been affected by Mr. Williams's decision would be "those few who are not, in fact, needy, but who are trading on color, surname or other ethnic indicators."
Whatever Mr. Williams's intentions, Mr. Sowell wrote, he has opened the subject of equal opportunity versus preferential treatment.
Shelby Steele, an English professor at San Jose State University who often writes about race and society, said, "In principle, it was a solid decision." But, he added, "it came out into a political atmosphere, which made it almost impossible to really look at the real issue."
In his collection of essays, "The Content of Our Character," Dr. Steele decribes his dilemma as a black college professor who has two sons who will soon be of college age.
"Their society now tells them that if they will only designate themselves as black on their college applications, they will likely do better in the college lottery then if they conceal this fact," he writes. "I think there is something of a Faustian bargain in this."
In an interview from his California office, Dr. Steele said the Education Department's initial decision tried to develop a policy that recognized a "color-blind society."
"In order to achieve a color-blind socity, both whites and blacks have to make sacrifices for fairness," he said. "If something is fair for one group it must be fair for others."
"If preferential treatment is correct, why not a David Duke Scholarship for poor Appalachian whites?" Dr. Steele asked. Mr. Duke, a State Representative in Louisiana, is a former Ku Klux Klan leader who lost a race for the United States Senate earlier this year.
 
What Is Diversity?
 Steven M. Cahn, provost and professor of philosophy at the Graduate School of the City University of New York, urged both sides to be more precise in their debate. He said terms like "diversity" needed to be more clearly defined.
"There are various respects in which students can be diverse," he said, including age, gender, race, religious affilation, economic class, military experience and sexual orientation.
"I think that when college classes are put together, when students are chosen, any or all of these might be what is meant by calling for diversity or pluralism," Dr. Cahn said.
While he said he believed diversity on campus was valuable, Dr. Cahn added: "I don't want to say the most important aspect of any person is that person's race. I think that is a fundamentally mistaken idea."
